Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsection Title: NOTICE TO CERTAIN INVESTORS United States
Subsubsection Text: In making your purchase, you will be deemed to have made certain acknowledgments, representations and agreements. See "Notice to Investors." This Offering Memorandum is being provided to investors (i) in the United States that the Issuer reasonably believes to be QIBs under Rule 144A for informational use solely in connection with their consideration of the purchase of the Notes and the Guarantees (the "Securities") and (ii) outside the United States in offshore transactions in accordance with Regulation S. Its use for any other purpose in the United States is not authorized. It may not be copied or reproduced in whole or in part nor may it be distributed or any of its contents disclosed to anyone other than the prospective investors to whom it is originally submitted. Until 40 days after the commencement of this Offering, an offer or sale of the Securities within the United States by a dealer (whether or not participating in the Offering) may violate the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act if such offer or sale is made otherwise than in accordance with an available exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. This Offering is being made in the United States in reliance upon exemptions from registration under the U.S. Securities Act for offers and sales of securities which do not involve a public offering, including Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act. Prospective investors are hereby notified that sellers of the Securities may be relying on the exemption from the registration requirements of Section 5 of the U.S. Securities Act provided by Rule 144A. The Securities may be offered and sold outside the United States in offshore transactions in reliance on Regulation S. Terms used in this paragraph have the meanings given to them by Regulation S. The Securities have not been registered with, recommended by or approved by the SEC, any state securities commission in the United States or any other securities commission or regulatory authority, nor has the SEC, any state securities commission in the United States or any such securities commission or authority passed upon the accuracy or adequacy of this Offering Memorandum. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense in the United States.

Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a "U.K. **distributor") should take into consideration the U.K. manufacturers' target market assessment; however, a U.K. distributor subject to the FCA Handbook Product Intervention and Product Governance Sourcebook (the "U.K. MiFIR Product Governance Rules") is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the U.K. manufacturers' target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of the Notes in the United Kingdom will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 as amended and as it forms part of the U.K. domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the "U.K. Prospectus Regulation") from a requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Title: MiFID II Product Governance / Professional Investors and ECPs (as defined below) Only Target Market:
Subsubsection Text: Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer's product approval process, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible counterparties ("ECPs") and professional clients only, each as defined in Directive 2014/65/EU, as amended ("MiFID II"); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to ECPs and professional clients are appropriate. The target market and distribution channels may vary in relation to sales outside the EEA in light of local regulatory regimes in force in the relevant jurisdiction. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a "distributor") should take into consideration the manufacturers' target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers' target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels. For the purposes of this paragraph, the term "manufacturers" shall mean such of the Initial Purchasers as are subject to the product governance rules under MiFID II.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Title: PRIIPS Regulation / Prohibition of Sales to EEA Retail Investors: The Notes are not intended to be offered,
Subsubsection Text: sold or otherwise made available to, and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to, any retail investor in the EEA. For these purposes, a "retail investor" means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II or (ii) a customer within the meaning of the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II. Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014, as amended (the "PRIIPs Regulation"), for offering, selling or distributing the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared, and, therefore, offering, selling or distributing the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of the Notes in any member state of the EEA that is subject to the Regulation (EU) 2017/1129, as amended (the "EU Prospectus Regulation") will be made pursuant to an exemption under the EU Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the EU Prospectus Regulation. Accordingly, any person making or intending to make an offer of the Notes in a member state of the EEA may only do so in circumstances in which no obligation arises for the Issuer or any of the Initial Purchasers to publish a prospectus pursuant to Article 3 of the EU Prospectus Regulation, in each case, in relation to such offer. Neither the Issuer nor the Initial Purchasers have authorized, nor do they authorize, the making of any offer of the Notes in circumstances in which an obligation arises for the Issuer or the Initial Purchasers to publish a prospectus for such offer.

Subsubsection Text: Germany. The Notes may not be offered and sold in the Federal Republic of Germany except in accordance with the provisions of the Securities Prospectus Act of the Federal Republic of Germany (Wertpapierprospektgesetz) (as amended, the "German Securities Prospectus Act"), of the EU Prospectus Regulation, and any other laws applicable in Germany. This offering memorandum has not been and will not be submitted to, nor has it been nor will it be approved by, the German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (Bundesanstalt fur Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht) ("BaFin"). BaFin has not obtained and will not obtain a notification from another competent authority of a Member State, with which a securities prospectus may have been filed, pursuant to Article 25 of the EU Prospectus Regulation. The Notes must not be distributed ----- within Germany by way of a public offer, public advertisement or in any similar manner, and this offering memorandum and any other document relating to the Notes, as well as information contained therein, may not be supplied to the public in Germany or used in connection with any offer for subscription of Notes to the public in Germany. Consequently, in Germany the Notes will only be available to, and this offering memorandum and any other offering material in relation to the Notes is directed only at, persons who are qualified investors (qualifizierte Anleger) within the meaning of Section 2 No. 3 of the German Securities Prospectus Act in connection with Article 2 of the EU Prospectus Regulation. Any resale of the Notes in Germany may only be made in accordance with the German Securities Prospectus Act, the EU Prospectus Regulation and other applicable laws. Subsubsection Title: Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum includes the following consolidated financial statements of the Group: - the audited consolidated financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2023 (the "FY 2023 Financial Statements"); - the audited consolidated financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 (the "FY 2022 Financial Statements"); and - the audited consolidated financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 (the "FY 2021 **Financial Statements"). The FY 2023 Financial Statements, the FY 2022 Financial Statements and the FY 2021 Financial Statements are herein collectively referred to as the "Financial Statements." The FY 2023 Financial Statements, the FY 2022 Financial Statements and the FY 2021 Financial Statements have been audited by Deloitte Accountants B.V., who issued unqualified opinions as part of the corresponding audit reports for each year. The FY 2023 Financial Statements and the FY 2022 Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with international financial reporting standards as adopted by the European Union ("IFRS") and in accordance with Title 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The FY 2021 Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with the statutory provisions of Title 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code and the firm pronouncements in the Guidelines for Annual Reporting in the Netherlands as issued by the Dutch Accounting Standards Board ("Dutch GAAP"). Our financial year runs from January 1 to December 31. The Financial Statements are contained in the F-pages to this Offering Memorandum and should be read in conjunction with the relevant notes thereto.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION Historical Financial Data
Subsubsection Title: Presentation of Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: We first prepared annual consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS for the year ended December 31, 2022. Until December 31, 2021, we prepared our consolidated financial statements in accordance with Dutch GAAP. Accordingly, we prepared the FY 2022 Financial Statements in compliance with IFRS as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, together with the comparative period data as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021. In preparing the FY 2022 Financial Statements, our opening statement of financial position was prepared as of January 1, 2021, the date of our transition to IFRS. As Dutch GAAP differs in significant respects from IFRS, the adoption of IFRS greatly reduces the comparability of the FY 2023 Financial Statements and the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared under IFRS with the FY 2021 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. For additional information on our first-time adoption of IFRS, including reconciliations of certain financial information from Dutch GAAP to IFRS for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, see note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements. In order to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a comparable basis in this Offering Memorandum, we present our historical financial condition and results of operations as follows (unless otherwise indicated): - as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, as derived from the FY 2023 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS; ----- - as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, as derived from the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS; and - as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021, as derived from the comparative financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS. As indicated above, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 has been derived from the Group's FY 2022 Financial Statements. In the Group's FY 2023 Financial Statements, the Group presented certain reclassified comparative financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022. Such comparative financial information differs from the Group's FY 2022 Financial Statements and the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum as a result of reclassifications to take account of the following: - a reclassification to reflect the separate reporting of 'Disposal / sale of PPE non-fleet' from the 'Carrying amount of disposal of PPE'; - a reclassification to reflect the split of the category 'Other assets' into two separate categories, namely 'Vehicles' and 'Other tangible assets'; - a reclassification to reflect the separate reporting of 'Other non-current assets' from 'Other receivables'; and - a reclassification to reflect the separate reporting of 'Other non-current liabilities' from 'Other current liabilities – deferred income'. For further details of the effect of this reclassification, see notes 2.5, 6, 11, 13 and 21 to the Group's FY 2023 Financial Statements. Prospective investors are advised to consult their professional advisors for an understanding of: (i) the differences between Dutch GAAP, IFRS and other generally accepted accounting principles and how those differences might affect the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum; and (ii) the impact that future additions to, or amendments of, IFRS may have on the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum, our results of operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability of prior periods. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the sections entitled "Summary—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information," "Risk Factors," "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" and the consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Title: Net Debt
Subsubsection Text: In our FY 2022 Financial Statements and FY 2021 Financial Statements, we defined Net Debt as "Gross debt (representing long- and short-term loans with financial institutions and bonds, lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts) and the nominal amount of other loans) less cash and cash equivalents." For the financial year ending December 31, 2023, we reconsidered our definition of Net Debt and decided to no longer include amortized costs as part of Net Debt. Accordingly, in this Offering Memorandum, we define Net Debt as "Gross debt (representing long- and short-term loans with financial institutions and bonds (both excluding amortized costs), lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts) and the nominal amount of other loans) less cash and cash equivalents." We believe the revised definition of Net Debt provides investors with more useful information and we intend to continue to present Net Debt in accordance with this revised definition going forward. We have applied our revised definition of Net Debt throughout this Offering Memorandum for each of the years presented, and as a result, the amount of Net Debt presented herein does not reconcile to the amounts presented in the FY 2022 Financial Statements and FY 2021 Financial Statements.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum contains certain financial measures and ratios, including Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions), Cash Conversion, Free Cash Flow, Gross Capital Expenditure, Gross Debt, Net Debt, Net Debt/Adjusted EBITDA, Operating Cash Flow, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Reported EBITDA, Reported EBITDA Margin and Reported Free Cash Flow, that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS (the "Non-IFRS Measures"). For reconciliations of the Non-IFRS Measures to the nearest IFRS measures, see "Summary—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information" and "Management's Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures," "—Free Cash Flow," and "—Net Debt."_ The Non-IFRS Measures are used by our management to assess operating performance, and we believe that they and similar measures are widely used in our industry as a means of evaluating a company's operating performance and financing structure, and because we believe they present helpful comparisons of financial performance between periods by excluding the distorting effect of certain non-recurring items. These measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and are not measurements under IFRS standards or other generally accepted accounting principles. The Non-IFRS Measures are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or profit from ordinary operations or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. The Non-IFRS Measures include figures derived from the Financial Statements and accounting records through aggregation, subtraction or division, but the Non-IFRS Measures have neither been audited nor reviewed. We define these Non-IFRS Measures as follows: - **_Adjusted EBITDA_** represents our Reported EBITDA, adjusted for certain one-off items described in "Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As _Adjusted Financial Information";_ - **_Adjusted EBITDA Margin represents Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue, expressed as a percentage; - **_Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions)_** represents purchases of property, plant and equipment plus purchases of intangible assets shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows; - **_Cash Conversion represents Operating Cash Flow divided by Reported EBITDA; - **_Free Cash Flow represents_** our Operating Cash Flow less Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions), the carrying amount of sold property, plant and equipment and disposal/sale of PPE non-fleet; ----- - **_Gross Capital Expenditure represents our Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) plus acquisitions shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows; - **_Gross Debt_** represents our long- and short-term loans with financial institutions and bonds (both excluding amortized costs), lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts) and the nominal amount of other loans, see also "—Net Debt" below; - **_Net Debt represents our Gross Debt less cash and cash equivalents, see also "—Net Debt" below; - **_Net Debt/Adjusted EBITDA represents Net Debt divided by Adjusted EBITDA; - **_Operating Cash Flow represents_** our Reported EBITDA adjusted for changes in net working capital and operating lease payments; - **_Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA represents our Adjusted EBITDA, after giving pro forma effect to the expected EBITDA impact of completed acquisitions in FY 2023, the acquisition of MG Rental AB in January 2024 and the Acquisition of the Target Group, as if such transactions had occurred on January 1, 2023, as described in "Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS _Measures and As Adjusted Financial Information";_ - **_Reported EBITDA represents profit for the year before depreciation and amortization expense, financial income, financial expense, share of profit of joint venture, income tax expense and other operating expenses. Other operating expenses represents the impairment of our investment in Fortrent in the year ended December 31, 2022; - **_Reported EBITDA Margin represents Reported EBITDA divided by revenue, expressed as a percentage; and - **_Reported Free Cash Flow represents_** our Reported EBITDA adjusted for the carrying amount of sold property, plant and equipment and disposal/sale of PPE non-fleet, less Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions). These Non-IFRS Measures may be defined differently from the corresponding terms under the Indenture and have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation. Some of their limitations are the following: - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debt; - they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and the relevant Non-IFRS Measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required to make such replacements; - they do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently from the way we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these limitations, these Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our audited financial information and by using these Non-IFRS Measures only to supplement your evaluation of our performance. -----

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum is a confidential document that the Issuer (together with its subsidiaries, "we," the "Group," the "Boels Group," "us" or "our") is providing only to prospective purchasers of the Notes. You should read this Offering Memorandum before making a decision whether to purchase any Notes. You must not: - use this Offering Memorandum for any other purpose; - make copies of any part of this Offering Memorandum or give a copy of it to any other person; or - disclose any information in this Offering Memorandum to any other person, other than a person retained to advise you in connection with the purchase of the Notes. This Offering Memorandum does not constitute an offer to sell or a solicitation of an offer to buy by anyone in any jurisdiction in which such offer or solicitation is not authorized or to any person to whom it is unlawful to make such offer or solicitation. No action has been, or will be, taken to permit a public offering in any jurisdiction where action would be required for that purpose. Accordingly, the Notes may not be offered or sold, directly or indirectly, and this Offering Memorandum may not be distributed in any jurisdiction except in accordance with the legal requirements applicable in such jurisdiction. You must comply with all laws applicable in any jurisdiction in which you buy, offer or sell the Notes or possess or distribute this Offering Memorandum, and you must obtain all applicable consents and approvals. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers (as defined below) shall have any responsibility for any of the foregoing legal requirements. This Offering is being made in the United States in reliance upon exemptions from registration under the U.S. Securities Act for offers and sales of securities which do not involve a public offering, including Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act. The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the U.S. Securities Act, or the securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction, and therefore may not be offered or sold within the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and applicable securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction. If you purchase the Notes, you will be deemed to have made certain acknowledgments, representations and warranties as detailed under "Notice to Investors." The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale and may not be transferred or resold except as permitted under the U.S. Securities Act and applicable securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction pursuant to registration or exemption therefrom. You may be required to bear the financial risk of an investment in the Notes for an indefinite period. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers are making an offer to sell the Notes in any jurisdiction where the offer and sale of the Notes is prohibited. None of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC"), any U.S. state securities commission, non-U.S. securities authority or other authority has approved or disapproved of the Notes or determined if this Offering Memorandum is truthful or complete. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense. In making an investment decision, prospective purchasers of the Notes must rely on their own examination of the Issuer and the terms of the Offering as described in this Offering Memorandum, including the merits and risks involved. In addition, neither the Issuer nor any Initial Purchaser nor any of their respective representatives is making any representation to you regarding the legality of an investment in the Notes, and you should not construe anything in this Offering Memorandum as investment, legal, business, tax or other advice. In accordance with normal and accepted market practice, neither the Initial Purchasers, the Trustee, the Security Agent, the Paying Agent, the Registrar, nor the Transfer Agent (each as defined below) is responsible for the contents of this Offering Memorandum or expresses any opinion as to the merits of the Notes under this Offering Memorandum. Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: Industry publications, surveys and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that there can be no assurance as to the accuracy and completeness of such information. We believe that these industry publications are reliable, but we have not independently verified any of the data from third-party sources. Forecasts and other forward-looking information obtained from these sources are subject to the same qualifications and uncertainties as the other forward-looking statements in this Offering Memorandum. We cannot assure you that any of the assumptions underlying any statements regarding our industry are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the industry. Market data and statistics are inherently predictive and speculative and are not necessarily reflective of actual market conditions. Such statistics are based on market research, which itself is based on sampling and subjective judgments by both the researchers and the respondents, including judgments about what types of products and transactions should be included in the relevant market. In addition, the value of comparisons of statistics for different markets is limited by many factors, including that (i) the markets are defined differently, (ii) the underlying information was gathered by different methods and (iii) different assumptions were applied in compiling the data. Accordingly, the market statistics included in this Offering Memorandum should be viewed with caution and no representation or warranty is given by any person, including us or the Initial Purchasers, as to their accuracy. Certain statements in this Offering Memorandum regarding our industry and market share and position are not based on published statistical data or information obtained from independent third parties, but are based solely on our own experience, internal studies, investigation and assessment of market conditions at the time of this Offering Memorandum. These statements have not been reviewed or verified externally and may differ from estimates made by our competitors or independent third parties. While we believe that our own market observations are reliable, our estimates and information derived from them and the market data, statistics and other information included in this Offering Memorandum, may prove to be inaccurate because of the methods by which we obtained some of the data for these estimates or because this information cannot always be verified with complete certainty due to limits on the availability of raw data and other factors. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding our own estimates presented herein, such estimates involve risks, assumptions and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under the heading "Risk Factors" in this Offering Memorandum. Accordingly, such estimates should be viewed with caution and no representations or warranty is given by any person, including us or the Initial Purchasers, as to their accuracy or completeness. -----

We are a leading rental equipment specialist in Europe. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2023, with strong market positions across our main markets, including the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden and the second largest market share in each of Germany and Finland, in each case in terms of revenue in 2023. Our family-owned business started out of four garage boxes in the 1970s, and, under five decades later, has expanded into an industry leader with an extensive network of 764 depots in 18 European countries and a fleet of approximately 865,000 rental units as at December 31, 2023. In the year ended December 31, 2023 we generated €1,552.7 million in revenue and €554.5 million in Adjusted EBITDA. We serve customers in a variety of end-markets from civil engineering, industrial, construction and infrastructure to events and warehousing. Our core product offering includes general and specialist rental equipment alongside complementary products and services, enabling us to be a one-stop-shop for our customer base of both corporate clients (business-to-business) and individuals including craftsmen and retail clients (business-to-consumer). Our generalist division is mainly focused on the less cyclical 'fit-out, maintain and operate' market segments which use lighter equipment, while our specialist division is tailored to reach niche markets, such as site preparation, sanitation and access control. With approximately 865,000 rental items and significant bulk rental items in our rental fleet, with a purchase value of €3.0 billion as of December 31, 2023, we offer our customers access to one of the largest, widest, highest quality, and latest ranges of rental equipment and tools in Europe, for use in the fields of civil engineering (such as excavators, landscaping tools and dumpers), transport and handling (such as forklifts, cranes and trailers), climate control (such as heating and cooling systems, mobile boilers and air purifiers), and construction (such as construction site and installation products), among others. In addition to our vast range of tools and equipment available in our general depots, we provide a wide range of specialist products to niche markets primarily outside the construction industry, which we believe differentiates us from our competition and contributes to our strong brand recognition and greater diversification in terms of end-markets and product offering. Our specialist products range from HVAC systems and hoisting and lifting machines to mobile LED screens, temporary housing solutions, portable kitchens and heavy duty pumps. In parallel, we offer "do-ityourself" ("DIY") shop-in-shops across Europe, in partnership with DIY retailers where retail clients get access to primarily smaller equipment rental, which we believe further renders our business less cyclical than the traditional equipment rental business. Our corresponding service lines are geared towards further simplifying our customers' complex projects and include equipment service and maintenance, fuel management, training courses, project management and emergency assistance. In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain information for the following four geographic regions: - **_The Netherlands, which generated €373.0 million in revenue (representing 24.0% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; - **_Central Europe, consisting of Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which generated €554.8 million in revenue (representing 35.7% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; - **_Northern Europe, consisting of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which generated €576.5 million in revenue (representing 37.1% of our revenue, with Finland, Norway and Sweden generating 33% of our total revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; and - **_Other Countries, consisting of Italy and the United Kingdom, which generated € 48.4 million in revenue (representing 3.1% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023. ----- In addition, in the year ended December 31, 2023, we introduced segmental reporting in line with IFRS 8 "Operating Segments" for the first time. For additional information on our operating segments, see "Presentation of _Financial Information—Operating Segments."_ We operate under two main brands: Boels Rental and Cramo. Boels Rental, the original brand of the Boels Group, is active in 12 countries in Central and Western Europe and we believe holds the strongest brand recognition across our portfolio. Cramo is active in the Nordic and the Baltic states, having been an independent leading rental company in Europe since 1953 before we acquired it in 2020. We operate a hub-and-spoke depot network, consisting of 684 general rental product depots and 80 specialist rental product depots as of December 31, 2023. We believe the decentralized structure of our network enables us to provide our products and services to our customers more conveniently and efficiently, while also supplying us with a diversified and local customer reach. In countries where we have an extensive depot network, such as the Netherlands and Germany, each depot is connected to a central hub location. In countries with larger markets, we have several hubs. Our depots generally stock smaller and more commonly used equipment, while the larger and less commonly used equipment is stored at our hubs, from where they can be easily shipped directly to a customer or local depot as needed. We believe this structure allows us to make more efficient use of our fleet and minimize transport movements. Through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions, we have expanded significantly over the past decade, both in terms of geographical reach and product offering. Since Pierre Boels Jr. became the CEO of Boels in 1996, we have executed a growth strategy based on product portfolio diversification and greenfield openings (including through international expansion), as well as through strategic bolt-on acquisitions executed to enter specific geographic areas (such as Germany, the UK and the Nordics) or specialist markets (such as industrial rental and traffic service). In 2020, we acquired Cramo, which positioned us as one of the largest equipment rental companies in Europe and complemented our geographic presence with an expansion into the Nordics and a further extension of our Central European offering. In addition, our 2022 acquisition of Eekels Pompen allowed us to expand our specialist product line by adding a high-quality offering of pump rentals to our customers with niche needs. The sharing economy is at the very heart of our business, and we believe that long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, driven by increased consumer preferences for rental instead of ownership. From our perspective, renting provides our customers with optimal availability, accessibility, and capital deployment, enabling them to reduce the amount of capital required for their operations, and, in turn, increase their capacity to deploy it for other investments. As such, our rental concept aims to help customers and their end-consumers meet their targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality and sustainability. We also believe that rental, compared to ownership, can contribute positively to the environment. Therefore, alongside the benefits that we strive to offer our customers, we also invest in products and solutions that align with our commitment to advancing sustainability in our and our customers' industries.

Subsubsection Title: Leading market positions in a large and growing European market supported by favorable underlying growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We have grown significantly since our founding in 1977 as a local rental company. Since then, we have grown into a multinational company through a combination of organic growth and transformative and bolt-on acquisitions. With the Cramo acquisition in 2020 and with the pending acquisition of the Target signed in March 2024, which allowed us to further expand our operations in the Nordics, Baltics and other European countries in which we were not previously present while strengthening our network in Western and Central Europe, we have created a true pan-European rental equipment player with increased scale and resilience. We believe that our current footprint provides us with beneficial scale in strong and growing geographic and customer end-markets. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental business in Europe by rental revenue in 2023. As of December 31, 2023, we operated a comprehensive depot network of 764 depots, comprising 684 general rental depots and 80 specialist rental depots, and on a combined basis with the Target, we had 829 depots, comprising 684 general rental depots and 145 specialist rental depots. We believe that our scale is particularly important as a provider of rental equipment, because it helps us optimize fleet utilization rates through our ability to easily relocate units to areas with higher demand for specific types of equipment and provides us with additional bargaining power in negotiations with OEMs and equipment suppliers and maintenance partners. We believe that our scale and our market leadership also help to increase our brand recognition and affords us with greater opportunities to attract and retain talented and experienced personnel. Taking into account the Acquisition, in the Netherlands, which is historically our cornerstone market, we believe that we hold a strong leader position with between 25% and 30% of market share based on revenue in 2023, which we ----- believe is significantly ahead of our competitors. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we are also the leader in Belgium with approximately 10% of market share and the second-largest player in Germany with between 5% and 10% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2023. With the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, we expanded our presence into five more European markets (Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia and Lithuania) and significantly strengthened our position in six European countries where Boels and Cramo had a joint presence. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe that we are the leader in Sweden, with between 15% and 20% of market share, and the second largest player in Finland, approximately 15% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2023. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe that we are also the third-largest player in Norway with an estimated market share of between 10 and 15%, based on revenue in 2023. With the Acquisition of the Target, we are combining experience and resources in European regions where our presence overlaps, such as Germany, Sweden, Norway, Netherland or Poland while opening the doors to new markets such as Spain and France as well as international markets such as India or Qatar. We believe that the markets we address are strong and poised for further growth. According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the total market size of the top 16 European rental equipment markets covered in the report (representing Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Finland, France, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK and Portugal, together, the "ERA Europe Countries") is estimated to have increased by 2.7% from €28.9 billion in 2022 to €29.7 billion in 2023 and is forecasted to grow by 2.7% in 2024 and 4.6% in 2025. According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the European market continues to be favorable, driven by an increased rental penetration and a structural shift in customers' preferences towards renting rather than owning equipment. This shift is supported by the attractiveness and flexibility offered by renting, as it optimizes the split between operating costs and capital expenditures by reducing the fixed portion of maintenance and fleet replacement costs and allows customers to avoid investing in expensive equipment that may not be used frequently. Moreover, the transition to achieving net zero CO2 emissions amplifies this effect, as electric equipment is generally more expensive. This structural shift is expected to support continued demand for rental equipment companies' products and services over the medium and long term. We believe that we are well-positioned to benefit from growth and positive trends in the equipment rental industry. The European rental equipment industry is still highly fragmented, consisting of a large number of small companies serving local or regional markets, with a limited number of medium to larger companies serving regional, national and international customers. We believe we are one of only a few companies with a strong pan-European platform, with strong relationships with the key equipment OEMs. We compete with a large number of smaller competitors locally and a few larger international competitors. We believe that we are well-positioned for growth by leveraging our scale and footprint, while relying on our proven approach of customizing our strategy for each local market, while centralizing our key operations.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model supported by robust diversification across geographies, end markets, products and customers, supported by a notable depot network
Subsubsection Text: We strive to minimize the impact of economic cycles through continually maximizing our rental fleet utilization rate, developing specialist activities focused on non-construction related niche markets, diversifying our customer base by investing in a broad product range aimed at non-construction related customers and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction projects. We have a diversified footprint and address several different customer end-markets, helping to mitigate our exposure to macroeconomic uncertainty. In particular, with the acquisition of Cramo, we significantly increased our geographical diversification, bringing our revenue generated in the Netherlands to 24% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to nearly half of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018. Moreover, no single country represented more than 25% of our revenue generation for the year ended December 31, 2023. We believe that our diversified geographical footprint will be reinforced with the Acquisition of the Target, which will not only strengthen our presence in the European markets in which we already operate in but will also expose us to new markets. We believe that this enhanced geographic diversification gives us greater resilience during periods of slow economic growth, as different countries operate within different economic cycles. Based on our revenue and EBITDA growth, we believe we outperformed our largest European competitors during the COVID-19 pandemic, proving the resilience of our business model. ----- The table below provides a breakdown of our revenue by geographic segment for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Northern Europe: Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. (2) Central Europe: Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia. (3) Other: Italy and the UK. We address multiple customer end markets, which also contributes to our resilience in reducing the impact of volatility of external factors such as market conditions and macroeconomic developments. We have positioned ourselves as a leading generalist equipment rental company that is also active in the attractive specialist sub-segment and in DIY, with specialist rental and DIY representing 28.6% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2023, approximately 54.8% of our sales were derived from non-construction end-markets, indicating a relatively modest exposure to the cyclical construction market. Furthermore, our exposure to the construction end market includes a large part of less cyclical phases of construction activities, such as the fit out, maintenance and operational phases. The chart below provides a breakdown of our revenue by end markets for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over time, we have continued to develop our expertise in specialist rental equipment, focusing on nonconstruction related end-markets, such as site preparation, modular space, measurement, testing and safety, sanitation, portable kitchen, hoisting and lifting, access control, and industrial rental and pumps. We believe our specialized knowledge is key to our ability to service different niche markets, providing further resilience and less exposure to the more cyclical construction market. By leveraging our generalist rental equipment business, we also aim to provide the best and most comprehensive rental solutions for our customers with the objective of cross-selling our specialist equipment to fuel future growth. Ultimately, our specialist business represents a key peer differentiator with customers, which we believe provides for higher returns. In parallel, we also operate in the niche market of DIY rental, with more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops as at December 31, 2023, where customers at DIY retail stores have access to primarily smaller equipment rental such as tools. This type of business is less cyclical than traditional equipment rental market and the costs to operate this business are typically lower than other equipment rental businesses due to the strong operational leverage of the existing rental depot network. In the DIY market, we are able to offer convenience as a differentiating factor to our customers, generating higher customer foot traffic in the stores, at a time when e-commerce is putting a strain on retailers and brick-and-mortar stores. We strive to offer a wide range of equipment and tools across all the phases of construction projects, including the build (both heavy construction and fit out), operate and maintain phases. Our business model also hinges on providing a diversified range of products to our customers. Approximately 16% of our rental revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023 was generated from smaller equipment rentals, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators and sanding equipment. These rentals position us within the less-cyclical 'fit out', 'maintain' and 'operate' phases of the asset cycle, as demand for such rentals is typically more resilient and makes us less dependent on lengthy construction ----- projects. For example, smaller equipment rentals tend to be more sought after for renovation and maintenance use, which are inherently less exposed to cyclical demand than other end uses. As of December 31, 2023, with a fleet of approximately 865,000 equipment units, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment, in addition to valueadded services such as logistics, we aim to provide full turnkey solutions to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner. Furthermore, with a comprehensive network of 764 depots (strategically located within a 50-kilometer reach of our key customers and project sites across Europe) and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of December 31, 2023, we are capable of mobilizing our rental fleet even in remote places for any customer or user at the right time, through multiple delivery methods: pick up and return or delivery to desired locations. By constantly adapting our network to changes and fluctuations in the market, we have the strategic ability to open or close access points near our customers. Based on market trends or developments in specific regions in Europe, we can adapt swiftly and embrace changes in our industry. Our hub-and-spoke networking model provides a diversified customer reach and develops efficiency and flexibility in our operations, ensuring that we are close to our customers and their projects, whether for pick-up and return or project delivery. This proximity to our customers results in shorter transport times, lower costs and lower CO2 emissions. Supported by our broad product offering and dense network, we also benefit from a large and diversified customer base, serving numerous customers of different sizes and from different sectors through our various channels (both generalist and specialist rental products) ranging from DIY customers, cash customers and craftsmen to large industrial, services and construction companies, potentially operating in different economic cycles. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our top 10 customers accounted for 7.1% of our revenue and our top three customers accounted for 3.7% of our revenue. No single customer accounted for more than 2% of our revenue in the same period. We benefit from strong customer loyalty, evidenced by the fact that our 10 largest customers by revenue have, on average, an approximately 20-year relationship with us. The chart below provides a breakdown of our customers for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Well-invested fleet focused on smaller equipment with strong unit economics and robust fleet management and digital capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We differentiate our offering from most of our peers by focusing on smaller rental items, such as tools and access equipment, in addition to construction equipment and containers. The chart below shows the breakdown of our rental revenue from our fleet by product category for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Reflects rental revenue of unique fleet only, excluding bulk and re-rent items. ----- Over the last five years, we have invested more than €1.5 billion to renew our rental fleet, with €397.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. We have a young, well-invested rental fleet with a historical purchase value of €3.0 billion as of December 31, 2023. These investments have reduced the weighted average age of our fleet to 52 months as of December 31, 2023, allowing us to offer our customers the latest advanced equipment and sufficient headroom to reduce or delay our capital expenditures during economic downturns. The chart below shows our rental equipment fleet's average useful life and its age (in months), by product category, as of December 31, 2023. Our tools product category, which amounted to 16% of our rental sales for the year ended December 31, 2023, has the lowest spread between average useful life and average fleet age in our fleet, with an average of approximately 4 years of use remaining before ultimately needing to be replaced. The weighted average fleet age of the Target is close to 94 months which is higher than the current average age for the Boels fleet, reflecting the different market dynamics in the regions where the Target operates. Particularly outside Europe, the Target provides equipment rental services in markets where the average age of rental equipment varies, allowing the Target to extend the economic life of its fleet toward close to 180 months. The Target's fleet management strategy involves deploying the equipment in three successive stages: "first life" in Central Europe, "second life" in the Middle East and "third life" in Kazakhstan and India. We will leverage on our existing young fleet and well-established fleet management to support the integration of the Target and an efficient transition towards Boels. Our smaller equipment, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators, sanding equipment, and other small tools, are characterized by superior unit economics compared to our other product categories, as they lead to higher money utilization rates (defined as our twelve-month fleet sales divided by the historical purchase price, based on the weighted average price by number of rental units). For the year ended December 31, 2023, our money utilization rate for the tools and light equipment product category was higher than our larger product categories, such as construction equipment, which we believe results in an increase in our return on fleet investments and an increase in our resilience through business cycles, given our high exposure to the tools and light equipment category. The chart below shows our money utilization rate for our different types of rental equipment for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Money utilization defined as our twelve-month fleet sales divided by the historical purchase price, based on the weighted average price by number of rental units Our focus on tools and access equipment makes us less dependent on lengthy construction projects and more exposed to the less cyclical renovation market, where we have a better pricing power among our smaller customers. On ----- our major long-term projects, we often provide a full range of equipment from small hand-held tools to larger equipment, reflecting our ability to support our clients on their various steps and needs with adequate and available equipment. This ability to provide full range of equipment in due time ultimately fosters relationships with our clients, creating recurring revenue streams and the potential for cross-selling between our generalist and specialist equipment. We have developed a robust asset management strategy for our extensive fleet. Our fleet management strategy covers the entire lifecycle of our equipment units, which includes purchasing, renting, and equipment servicing, as well as reselling the equipment at the end of its financial or economic lifetime. When making purchasing decisions, we seek to provide a true one-stop shop experience for our customers by ensuring a high degree of availability across our entire rental range and equipment that is adapted to their needs. By closely monitoring trends, events and market prices, we can quickly adjust and adapt our offer to customers' needs. For example, the share of Eco-labelled equipment in our fleet is relatively high and growing in line with higher market demand for electrical, hybrid or battery-powered equipment and the highest sustainability standards. Simultaneously, we seek time- and cost-efficiency to maximize our economies of scale and fleet occupancy performance. These initiatives improve our fleet availability and utilization rates while minimizing our maintenance capital expenditures. We have implemented an advanced and integrated infrastructure to drive decision making for our fleet, such as enterprise resource planning and specialized hardware and software. This asset management system allows us to track the complete life cycle of any rental asset in our fleet, providing us with visibility on our any given item (such as depot performance, inventory levels, fleet allocation and pricing) and the ability to adjust our fleet investment and pricing. This enables us able to serve our customers according to their needs, quickly and efficiently. In addition, this system makes it possible to limit downtime and improve utilization rates and pricing. Finally, as a piece of our equipment reaches the end of its lifecycle within the Company, we believe that we are able to optimize the timing of its resale and maximize its resale value through closely following secondary market prices and trends and taking third-party insights into account. Our fleet management strategy also relies on a central procurement strategy. This enables us to benefit from economies of scale and allows us to be close to our OEMs and their product development, positioning us at the forefront for the latest products in terms of efficiency, safety and sustainability. In addition, our relationships with OEMs not only allows us to negotiate better prices, but it also give us insights on the availability issues that may occur due to shortages of materials. In 2022, the equipment markets suffered from supply chain shortages. Due to our excellent relationships with our OEMs, we were able to successfully navigate these shortages, which we believe differentiates us from our competitors. We also foster our relationships with our OEMs by collaborating on technological developments and data analyses, and we aim to deepen our cooperation with them further. In addition, we have invested and continue to invest in the latest technology to help us efficiently process our fleet maintenance and repairs and minimize our related costs and administrative workload. These technological capabilities allow us to be in full control of depreciation and replacement strategies and therefore systematically improve our fleet usage, composition and performance. We monitor and reduce the impact machine repairs and maintenance have on lifetime costs and resale value. Finally, we seek to be a leader in innovation and digital transformation across the entire rental process, which we believe results in higher customer satisfaction and percentage of recurring business, better fleet damage control and substantial emissions savings. We were an early adopter of digital offerings in the European rental market, having anticipated this trend by preparing a detailed mapping of our customer experiences per segment, with the aim to simplify online rental in all our customer's life cycle stages and provide a one-stop-shop solution: from becoming a customer to online renting, logistics, usage, having all relevant information available and invoicing. In parallel, this digital transformation generates operational efficiencies by allowing us to optimize our processes such as transport and logistics.

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial and operational track record supported by counter-cyclical cash generation through capital expenditure flexibility and proven M&A integration capabilities
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance has been driven by a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions, which have expanded our geographical reach and product offering. Since our foundation more than 45 years ago, we have been focused on increasing scale and achieving sales growth. Our business model is based on actively distributing our fleet through our depot network, directly competing with local players and ultimately winning market share by providing newer equipment and better customer service. This model has delivered a proven track record of strong growth over the past decade. Between 2013 and 2023, our revenue grew at a CAGR of approximately 18.9%, significantly exceeding the growth of the economy, the construction market and the equipment rental market over the same period in Europe. While delivering robust sales growth, we have also managed to retain steady and high margins, with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 35.7% in the year ended December 31, 2023. By being highly focused on maintaining a high portion of variable costs, we have managed to retain our profitability during economic downturns. ----- The Acquisition fits well within our overall growth strategy built on both organic growth as well as selective bolton acquisitions. By realizing economies of scale, combining overhead costs, procurement advantages and cross-selling between Boels and the Target, the Acquisition is expected to generate meaningful synergies over the coming years. The following chart shows our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA growth from the year ended December 31, 2012 through the year ended December 31, 2023.
We believe our success is attributable to the following competitive strengths which will drive our future growth:

Subsection Title: Long-term financial track record (€ millions and %)
Subsubsection Text: Notes: Figures between 2012 and 2019 reflect our reported results prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP and are not comparable with subsequent years prepared in accordance with IFRS. Figures provided for 2020 reflect the unaudited management financial information presented using the principles applied by the Company to restate its Dutch GAAP financial statements in accordance with IFRS together with certain pro forma adjustments to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020. Figures provided for the Company for 2021, 2022 and 2023 reflect our results prepared in accordance with IFRS. It should be noted that the pro forma figures presented for 2020 represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and Cramo. Further, figures provided for Riwal and the combined figures, taking into account the Acquisition as if it had been completed January 1, 2023, are unaudited and represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and the Target. Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information and is presented for illustrative purposes only. The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma _Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (1) For comparability purposes, revenue growth between 2019 and 2020 is expressed as 2020 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020, compared to 2019 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2019, each prepared under Dutch GAAP. Revenue for 2019 has been prepared solely for illustrative purposes based on management estimates utilizing a simple aggregation of the revenue of Cramo and our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. (2) Represents the Group’s growth rate on a standalone basis (excluding the Target Group). We have the ability to actively manage our fleet investment based on existing market conditions and the stage of the industry cycle, which has contributed to our counter-cyclical cash generation. In an industry growth cycle, we invest in our rental fleet to enhance our product catalogue and expand into new products and markets. In a downturn, with our newly invested young fleet, we can rapidly reduce our capital expenditures and postpone our investments, streamline our depot network and the size of the fleet, and pay down debt with our strong cash flows resulting from lower capital expenditures. Our business has flexibility to make investment decisions on a regular, short-term basis, and has no long-term expansionary capital expenditures commitments. Therefore, we are generally able to quickly adjust our fleet investments to respond to the changing market environment. For example, recently, we were able to quickly adapt our investments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on maintaining our existing fleet through reduced capital expenditures. After the stabilization of market conditions in 2021, we resumed our investments by increasing our capital expenditures. The countercyclical nature of cash generation and our ability to adjust our capital expenditure while preserving our cash generation through the cycles supports our conservative leverage policy and enables us to deleverage during challenging economic periods, as we did during the global financial crisis between 2008 and 2009, the double dip recession, and more recently, during the COVID-19 pandemic. -----

Subsubsection Title: Strong senior and local management teams with extensive industry experience
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong management team with extensive experience in the equipment rental industry and a track record of operational excellence, led by one of the most recognized and distinguished people in the industry, Pierre Boels Jr., our Chief Executive Officer since 1996 and President of the ERA between 2016 and 2022. The members of our management are further supported by divisional and regional managers in an organizational structure that empowers entrepreneurship spirit and decision making. Jan Piet Valk, our Chief Financial Officer since 2020 and member of our Management Board, has acquired a proven international experience through his previous chief financial officer positions. He is responsible for the overall financial management, M&A strategy, health and safety policy, legal, treasury, sustainability and real estate matters and is involved in all key decisions in the company. Mr. Valk has recently been awarded "CFO of the Year" by Financieel Management, in recognition of his independent role in the leadership of our Group, his management skills and his board position. Mr. Valk is due to step down as Chief Financial Officer on June 1, 2024 to become chair of the Supervisory Board on September 1, 2024. Under Mr. Pierre Boels Jr.'s leadership, we managed to significantly increase our sales and EBITDA, both organically and through acquisitions, having successfully executed and integrated 28 acquisitions since 2012. Our CEO has assembled an experienced management team with significant industry expertise, including: - Reiant Mulder, Chief Operations Officer of Central Europe and member of our Strategic Board with more than 20 years of services experience. - Guy Cremer, Chief Procurement Officer, working with us since 1989 and leading in the Fleet Management department since 2000. Additionally, Mr. Cremer was recognized with the award for "Rental person of the year" by ERA in June 2023 for his influential role in the shift towards lower carbon emission equipment last year; and - Martin Holmgren: Chief Operations Officer of Nordics and a member of our Strategic Board. Mr. Holmgren is also Vice President of ERA and has worked for almost 30 years in the construction and rental industry. - René Olsthoorn, who will be appointed Chief Financial Officer for the Group on June 1, 2024 replacing Mr. Valk. Since May 2009, Mr. Olsthoorn has served as an executive officer of Timber and Building Supplies Holland N.V., first as Chief Financial Officer and, following his appointment in January 2019, as Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Olsthoorn began his career in 1990 as a project leader with Fokker Aircraft and has held management roles ranging from logistics to finance since then. Our highly qualified senior management team is in close contact with our local business directors, since investment decisions strongly benefit from local market knowledge. For example, the choice between opening a greenfield location when expanding into a new region or acquiring an established company in the region is based on local insights about rental company concentration provided by local business leaders: we consider acquisitions when rental concentration is high and greenfield expansion in locations where rental concentration is low. We have an external Advisory Board that meets five times a year and consists of a group of experienced entrepreneurs and leaders. This independent body advises the Management Board on policy matters and the general course of affairs of the Group. In addition, the Advisory Board and its individual members function as a critical sounding board for our Management Board. We are in the process of implementing a two-tier board system and aim to install a Supervisory Board in September 2024, which will replace the Advisory Board. The Supervisory Board will supervise the general course of affairs in the company and the businesses affiliated with the company. It will also supervise the functioning of the Management Board as such and the policy conducted and will provide the Management Board with advice. On March 19, 2024, it was announced that Jan Piet Valk will join the Supervisory Board of the Group as chairman as of September 1, 2024. For further discussion on our management team, see "Management." -----

Subsubsection Title: Ambitious CSR targets to lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry and mitigate environmental impact throughout the value chain
Subsubsection Text: We strive to lead our company with high business ethics and lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry. We have set ambitious CSR targets to position ourselves as a front runner in the development of a safe and environmentally friendly business and a key partner to our customers in meeting their increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. We believe that the core purpose of rental, compared to ownership, is the achievement of the efficient use of equipment and materials, therefore making a positive contribution to the circular economy. According to a research study led by ERA, efficient use of equipment results in a reduction of approximately 30% to 50% of CO2 emissions (depending on specific user practice) and that the rental business model stimulates such efficient use. Our rental concept allows our customers and their end-customers to meet their objectives and targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality, safety and to reduce their carbon footprint. CSR topics are at the heart of our business model. We also chose to apply the Global Reporting Initiative 2021 ("GRI 2021") Standards and Disclosures to report our sustainability-related data, to commit to the guidelines of UN Global Compact and to implement the Sustainable Development Goals relevant to our business. In addition, based on a formal materiality assessment, we have identified four focus areas covering all aspects of corporate and social responsibility, including Employee Care, Social Care, Customer Care and Environmental Care. We have also identified, key performance indicators in relation to each topic and set ambitious targets for 2025. We aim to be the leader in sustainable fleet investments, to enable our customers in executing their projects with the lowest level of emissions, while continuing to deliver profitable growth. Our Green Team, which includes members from our fleet, sales and marketing departments, has jointly set out a strategy to invest in anticipation of customer needs and develop ambitious and innovative solutions (including zero emission equipment) in their field. For our fleet, we invest in energy-efficient products to improve our energy performance. For example, our fleet includes electrical two-ton excavators, fully battery-operated six-meter telehandlers and over two-ton electric-wheeled loaders. We also have a wide availability of battery packs and have created solar panel roofs for site huts and new zero emission welfare units, which were both brought to market in 2022. Additionally, our fleet contains more than 10,000 Stage V engines meeting the EU standard for non-road machines with low emissions of particulate matter. On December 21, 2023, we entered into a €100 million loan agreement with the European Investment Bank to support our further investments in 'green' electric equipment. _See "Summary––Recent Developments––New EIB Facility."_ Our state-of-the-art fleet adheres to strict environmental and safety performance standards and helps increase our customers' productivity while reducing their emissions footprint. Of our total energy powered fleet units (equipment driven by a motor and with all types of power), approximately 82% is electrically-powered as of December 31, 2023 and we aim to increase this percentage to 85% by 2025. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 67% of our fleet value was comprised of electric, hybrid and gas equipment and not motorized equipment (meaning, equipment without an engine or motor). We have steadily reduced the portion of our diesel-powered equipment as a percentage of fleet value over time, reaching 23% as of December 31, 2023 (excluding Stage V diesel powered equipment). A breakdown of our fleet value by type of power as of December 31, 2023, is presented below.

Figures for the company provided for 2021, 2022 and 2023 reflect our results prepared in accordance with IFRS; (1) For comparability purposes, revenue growth between 2019 and 2020 is expressed as 2020 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020, compared to 2019 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2019, each prepared under Dutch GAAP.
