The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. See "Risk Factors— _Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (2) Represents Free Cash Flow. (3) Total net leverage calculated based on Reported EBITDA. (4) Defined as PP&E and intangibles, excluding acquisitions and incl. book value of disposals. Acquisitions are also an integral part of our growth strategy that we pursue either for geographical expansion (filling in gaps in our existing footprint), increase market share, acquire specialist knowledge, improve our competitive position, or acquire certain assets. We have a clear, defined and well-established acquisitions strategy with a dedicated integration team in place. The success of our international expansion and our ability to effectively integrate acquired companies is demonstrated by our track record of 28 successful acquisitions since 2012. In particular, we demonstrated our disciplined M&A strategy and execution with our transformative acquisition of Cramo in 2020. During the 6 months of the initial integration period, our management executed a clear integration plan to minimize execution risk related to the acquisition, while maintaining a high quality service for our customers and efficiently responding to their needs. In countries where Boels and Cramo had geographic overlap, such as in Germany, Austria, Poland, Czech Republic and Slovakia, we focused our efforts on optimizing our depot network, rebranding and refurbishing Cramo's depots in Central Europe (including Germany), enhancing our cross-selling opportunities and optimizing our back-office functions. We also invested substantially in integrating the fleets in Western, Central and Eastern Europe, increasing the availability of fleet and our flexibility, allowing us to optimize our response to market demands. In 2021, 2022 and 2023, we invested in and deployed new equipment categories that meet specific local requirements as a result of our analyses of the local markets, in order to be less dependent on large projects, with the aim to reach small and medium enterprises and retail clients. As a result of such efforts, we were able to successfully integrate our Central European operations in only 10 months and achieved synergies in terms of centralization of our mutual best practices in our key operations: IT, finance, fleet management and human resources through the deployment of our One Boels strategy. As a result of these efforts, we believe we have realized significant synergies, which generate recurring savings in EBITDA and capital expenditures, primarily due to the optimization of our procurement functions, the consolidation of our IT systems and the reduction of our corporate expenses (including as a result of the closing of Cramo's headquarters in Finland). ----- We believe that our acquisition track record, including our ability to integrate companies, positions us for growth while strengthening our local presence. The success of our international expansion supports our financial and operational development and establishes us as a market consolidator in a fragmented equipment rental industry. For further details about certain of our recent acquisitions, "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings."_

Subsection Title: Our fleet value as of December 31, 2023 (in € billion)
Subsubsection Text: ----- Furthermore, during 2023, we have made significant progress in offering resource-efficient and sustainable alternatives to customers, supporting them to minimize climate impact: - We invested more than €50 million in 2023 in the electrification of our rental fleet. - We increased the share of units powered by electricity within our energy-powered fleet. - We increased the share of Eco-labelled fleet. - We invested over 2.5% of our total fleet value in high-tech, zero-emission machines, with a target to reach 4.7% by 2025. We also continuously work to mitigate our own climate impact by reducing energy consumption, increasing the use of renewable energy and increasing circularity of our products and operations. We reduce, reuse or recycle materials, reduce waste and handle hazardous waste properly. For facilities and installations, we invest in energy efficient products, services and design for energy performance improvement. For example, we have been increasing our energy efficiency while reducing our emissions through investments in sustainable technologies and services, LED lighting, solar panels, better insulation or development of energy management systems. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we reduced our energy use relative to sales by 8.6%, compared to 2022. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we reduced our gas usage by 25% compared to 2022, which resulted in a reduction of approximately 5,800 MWh and 720 tCO2 of our emissions. We are also improving logistics planning in order to limit emissions related to equipment deliveries, as well as increasing our purchase of more renewable energy. We also disclose the Group's greenhouse gas emissions for Scope 1 (direct emissions) and Scope 2 (indirect emissions) with clear reduction targets. In 2022, we announced a number of targets with respect to our carbon emissions for 2025, using 2021 as a baseline, including: - reduce our emissions (calculated in tCO2) relative to sales (Scope 1 and 2) by 20%; - reduce our energy use relative to sales (Scope 1 (direct energy use) and Scope 2 (purchased energy)) by 15%; and - increase our share of renewable electricity to above 92% (compared to 56% in 2022 and 49% in 2021). Simultaneously, we are assessing our scope 3 targets with the main initiatives expected to be set as soon as 2024. In 2023, we retained our EcoVadis Platinum status for Sweden and obtained EcoVadis Bronze status in the Netherlands. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental and social governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance." As a leading provider of sustainable AWP rental solutions in its markets, the Target fits well with our CSR strategy. It has a high proportion of electrically powered fleet in Europe, which we plan to increase further by 2030. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 60% of the Target's AWP fleet in Europe was electrically powered.

Subsubsection Title: Achieve a leading position in all our markets and become a leading partner for our customers
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue working to provide a high quality, one-stop-shop experience for both individual consumers and businesses, while ensuring that our entire rental range of products meets our customers' evolving demands, in order to achieve a leading market position in each of the markets we address. We believe that we are well-positioned to become the leading partner of our customers in all the geographies we serve. We believe that our customers already recognize us as a preferred one-stop-shop for their rental needs, primarily due to our diversification across products, end markets, general and specialist rental, and our strong European geographic coverage. Our acquisition of Cramo has demonstrated our ambition to keep strengthening and expanding our geographic coverage and diversifying our service offering. ----- We believe we can achieve a leading position in our markets through our strong, long-term partnerships with our customers. In order to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner, we aim to provide full turn-key solutions, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment (including site huts, site safes, traffic sets and sanitation), in addition to value-added services such as logistics. For example, in 2021, we delivered full service rental solutions for a wind farm project in Lithuania by providing site huts, construction equipment and special tools, in addition to access control, on-site maintenance, and helping with planning, transportation, delivery. Since 2022, we provide full turnkey solutions for an automotive Gigafactory located in Berlin-Brandenburg. We combine our proximity to customers and our understanding of their needs in order to continue providing our customers with valueadded services and products. Finally, we intend to continue pursuing our fleet investment strategy, which aims to maintain a complete range of sustainable and safe rental equipment.

Subsubsection Title: Grow through a combination of organic development and bolt-on acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: We have achieved an impressive track record of both sales and EBITDA growth through a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both our transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions. Through our acquisition strategy in particular, we have expanded to cover new geographic markets and have diversified our catalogue of products and services. We believe we have significant opportunities to continue growing organically due to our comprehensive network of 764 depots and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of December 31, 2023. We intend to increase the density of our network in less concentrated regions which we believe have a strong potential of profitable growth through our clear greenfield expansion strategy. We also intend to continue evaluating strategic acquisition targets to further strengthen and expand our operations and customer base, to selectively enter new markets over time, in particular in geographic areas with low rental company concentration to increase opportunities for upselling and cross-selling our products. In pursuing such acquisitions, we maintain the same disciplined, targeted, and opportunistic acquisition investment criteria that have historically enabled us to successfully identify acquisition targets and profitably acquire and integrate them. In March 2024, we announced the acquisition of the Target, a rental company with expertise in Aerial Work Platforms ("AWP"). This Acquisition will increase our network of depots to 829 depots as of December 31, 2023 (on a combined basis) while strengthening and diversifying our current geographic footprint. See "The Transactions" below. Successful integration of acquisitions is key to our strategy, and we believe we are well-positioned to integrate future acquisitions efficiently and profitably. We have dedicated integration teams supported by local teams with superior knowledge of their local markets to develop synergies in our fleet management, expedite the completion and integration of acquisitions and position us to achieve our long-term success.

Subsubsection Title: Drive digital innovation to increase productivity for our customers and improve our operational efficiency
Subsubsection Text: We have developed and intend to continue to develop digital services in order to improve our customers' experience and boost our operational performance. We believe that we are a leader in the development of new, innovative digital business models in our industry. We have developed and deployed new types of data- and connectivity-based solutions to connect our people, internal processes and fleet to our customers, such as our new smart application for mobile devices, "Equipment Pool", which improves customers' access to equipment and machines, while reducing transportation times to and from customers' construction sites. We believe that we can leverage our digital processes and use of data in a customer-focused manner in order to improve communication between our employees and our customers, better identify customers' needs and facilitate interactions and transactions with customers. Although we already have improved processes and digital tools in place to optimize our customers' experience, we intend to continue enhancing our rental websites, including those of Cramo, Boels Rental and IQ Pass, to add further equipment data and specifications and combine our general and specialist rental fleet in a single platform. We believe that such technological capabilities positions us to achieve the full potential of our one-stop-shop solutions. We also intend to continue leveraging digital tools to streamline and boost efficiency in our internal systems. For example, we have implemented a single group-wide financial system to monitor our cash flows and key performance indicators. We have also implemented our group-wide One Boels strategy in order to continue harmonizing systems and processes based on four pillars: (i) One IT approach, (ii) One financial organization, (iii) One fleet and procurement organization and (iv) One HR approach and organization. We have developed our One Boels strategy as a clear, distinct, and strong organization that focuses not only on our customers' needs, but also boosts our efficiency. We intend to continue enhancing our operational systems and processes to increase our operational and procurement efficiency, improve our ----- strategic relationships with OEMs, strengthen our fleet management and negotiating position for strategic procurement and maintenance of our fleet, and enhance our employee retention.

Subsubsection Title: Maintain top-tier performance as a leading rental company
Subsubsection Text: We aim to maintain our operational performance by systematically improving and optimizing fleet usage, composition and performance. Historically, we have had a more centralized business model where our rental fleet was managed centrally to optimize the allocation of equipment, while local managers organized by countries and depots offered knowledge of local markets. Cramo, on the other side, has historically had a more decentralized business group structure, where operating decisions were made at the country and business-unit level. With the integration of Cramo, we have developed a synergized approach, which aims to combine the best practices of both organizations by centralizing key operations such as procurement or fleet management, while we keep a flexible and locally oriented commercial approach for each market and geography. We believe that this approach, together with our close cooperation with, and monitoring of, our depots, business units and departments, positions us to achieve our strategy, whilst retaining our disciplined and flexible business and financial models.

Subsubsection Title: Reinforce our commitments to the environment, safety, quality and corporate responsibility
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to promoting and maintaining corporate sustainability and responsibility as a core component of our business. We intend to continue being a leading climate- and resource-efficient rental company, paving the way to enhance sustainability in the rental industry and to reduce our environmental footprint throughout our value chain. We believe that our value chain perspective on sustainability helps us identify how we can optimally manage our impact on the environment while efficiently operating our business. We also strive to meet our customers' increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. We are convinced that applying and maintaining an adequate corporate governance policy is a prerequisite to structure the organization efficiently and effectively and achieve our strategic goals. We also believe that our sustainability policy helps us to manage risks and to consider the interests of all our stakeholders, including our shareholders, our employees and our customers. We discuss our material sustainability topics, focus areas and strategic targets twice a year with our Strategic Board and our Operations Board, and periodically with the Sustainability Steering Committee that we have implemented to help us achieve our sustainability goals. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental, social and governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance."

Our business strategy focuses on profitable growth, further enhancing operational efficiency, strengthening our market position in all segments, expanding our service offerings, developing innovative digital solutions to improve customer efficiency and promoting corporate social responsibility.

We expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with cash on balance sheet, to: (i) repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B, (ii) finance the Acquisition on the Acquisition Closing Date, and (iii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The Acquisition is not contingent on the Offering and the proceeds of the Offering will not be held in an escrow account prior to the completion of the Acquisition. If the Acquisition does not complete, the Notes will not be subject to a special mandatory redemption and the proceeds of the Offering will not be returned to holders of the Notes ahead of redemption or maturity. If the Acquisition does not complete, that portion of the proceeds of the Offering earmarked for the Acquisition will instead be used by the Issuer for general corporate purposes, including debt refinancing, capital expenditures and other strategic bolt-on acquisitions. See "Risk Factors—If the Acquisition is not completed, the proceeds _of the Notes may be used for alternative purposes."_ See "—The Transactions" and "Use of Proceeds." For descriptions of our current and anticipated indebtedness following the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, see "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements" and "Capitalization." The Offering, and the application of the proceeds from the Offering, including the repayment and cancellation of a portion of the Existing Term Loan B, the consummation of the Acquisition and related transactions, are collectively referred to in this Offering Memorandum as the "Transactions." See also "Use of Proceeds," "Capitalization," "Description of the Notes" and "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements."

On March 8, 2024, the Issuer as purchaser and ProDelta Investments Partners II B.V. as seller entered into a share purchase agreement (the "Acquisition Agreement") for the acquisition of the entire issued share capital of Riwal Holding Group B.V., a private company with limited liability under the laws of the Netherlands, having its official seat in Dordrecht, ----- the Netherlands, and its registered office address at Galvanistraat 35, 3316 GH Dordrecht, the Netherlands, and registered with the Dutch trade register under number 23062680 (the "Target" and together with its subsidiaries, the "Target

The consideration for the Acquisition is estimated to be €415 million, which includes the base purchase price payable under the Acquisition Agreement of €164.8 million and repayment of certain indebtedness of the Target Group of €234.9 million, subject to adjustments as set out in the Acquisition Agreement, including for certain notified cash leakage items. The Acquisition is currently expected to be consummated in the second quarter of 2024. However, closing of the Acquisition is subject to several conditions, including receipt of antitrust and other regulatory approvals. See "Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition—The Acquisition is subject to uncertainties and risks."_

Subsubsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: The Target is a leading equipment rental company that provides for the sale and rental of Aerial Working Platforms ("AWP"), telehandlers and power equipment. Founded in 1968 and based in the Netherlands, the Target has a global footprint of 14 countries and 1,218 full time equivalents. As of December 31, 2023, the Target's rental fleet comprised approximately 20,000 units with a purchase value of approximately €649 million. On a global scale, the Target has the 18th largest AWP fleet, while Boels is the ninth largest, as of December 31, 2022, in each case based on revenue. The acquisition is expected to enhance Boels' global presence and scale, elevating it to the 6th largest AWP rental operator worldwide. The Target operates in approximately 65 locations across Europe, Asia and the Middle East. In Europe, the Target has a presence overlapping with Boels in the Netherlands, Germany, Poland, Sweden and Norway, and has a presence in Denmark, France, Spain, Slovenia and Croatia, where Boels is not active. Outside Europe, the Target has established operations in India, Kazakhstan, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar. Together with the Target, our combined global footprint spans 27 countries. The chart below provides a geographic overview of the Target and our operations for the year ended December 31, 2023. The table below shows certain information on our combined depot network (including the Target) by country as of December 31, 2023:

For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Target generated approximately €310 million in revenue, of which approximately €190 million related to equipment rental and approximately €120 million related to the sale of goods and other services. During the same period, the Target generated an EBITDA of approximately €64 million based on accounts prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP, (or approximately €77 million based on management estimates to adjust for IFRS, including IFRS 16), representing an EBITDA margin of approximately 25% based on management estimates to adjust for IFRS. We estimate that our combined revenue (including the Target) for the year ended December 31, 2023 would have been approximately €1,863 million, of which 67% related to rental income and 33% related to sales of goods and other services. During the same period, our estimated Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA would have been approximately €650 million (after taking into account certain acquisition synergies amounting to an estimated €13 million expected to be realized in the first two years following the Acquisition, as further described herein), representing a margin of approximately 35% compared to our estimated combined revenue (including the Target). It should be noted that these figures are unaudited and represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and the Target. Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information, is based on information made available to our management through our due diligence review of the Target, has not been reviewed by our independent auditors or the auditors of the Target and is presented for illustrative purposes only. The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. Investors should therefore not unduly rely on this information. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and _other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ The following table sets out our estimated combined revenue (including the Target) by geographic region for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Strong customer diversification
Subsubsection Text: The Target has a diversified customer base, consisting of large, national contractors, regional operators and smallto medium-sized local contractors. No single rental customer accounted for more than 6% of the Target's total revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023, and the top 10 rental customers collectively represented approximately 5-6% of the total revenue in the same year. The Target's sales business, however, has a higher degree of customer concentration, as the top 10 sales customers generated 33.7% of the total sales revenue in 2023. Including the Target's rental revenue only, our combined top 10 clients accounted for 6.4% of our estimated combined revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. Additionally, based on our estimated combined revenue (including the Target) for the year ended December 31, 2023, our sales from specialists segments on a combined basis is estimated to be approximately 40% as of December 31, 2023 compared to 26% as of December 31, 2021 on Boels only basis, further strengthening our diversification.

Subsubsection Title: Products and services
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, the Target operated a rental fleet of approximately 20,000 units. The table below shows a breakdown of the Target's rental fleet as of December 31, 2023:

Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information and is presented for illustrative purposes only. The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_

As of December 31, 2023, the average age of the equipment in the Target's fleet was 7.8 years, which is higher than the standard maintained by Boels (which has an average fleet age of 4.8 years for access equipment as of the same date). However, this reflects the different market conditions and customer preferences in the regions where the Target operates. The Target provides equipment rental services in markets where the average age of rental equipment varies, allowing it to extend the economic life of the fleet. The Target's fleet management strategy involves deploying the equipment in three successive stages: "first life" in Central Europe, "second life" in the Middle East and "third life" in Kazakhstan and India. As an increase in average fleet age is generally correlated with higher maintenance expenses, Boels may decide to increase its capital expenditures to gradually rejuvenate the Target's fleet in the medium term. In addition to the rental of equipment, the Target provides customer trainings on equipment operation and maintenance. The Target also acts as an official dealership for JLG and Magni in certain countries, which involves providing services and spare parts, in addition to equipment sales. ----- The table below provides a breakdown of the Target's estimated revenue by product type for the year ended December 31, 2023. (3) Other sales includes parts, third-party maintenance, training and other revenue streams provided by third-party suppliers The following table sets forth certain information on our combined fleet (including the Target) as of December 31, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Leading provider of sustainable AWP rental solutions
Subsubsection Text: The Target is a leading provider of sustainable AWP rental solutions in its markets. It has a high proportion of electrically powered fleet in Europe, which we plan to increase further by 2030. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 65% of the Target's AWP fleet in Europe was electrically powered. The Target has been recognized for its environmental performance and social responsibility by industry awards and ratings. In 2022, the Target won the 2022 IAPA (International Award for Powered Access) Sustainability Award, during the annual IPAF (International Powered Access Federation) Summit. In addition, the Target currently holds an EcoVadis Gold medal, which is awarded to the top 5% of companies evaluated by EcoVadis, a sustainability rating agency.

Subsubsection Title: Rationale for the Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: With the Acquisition, we intend to strengthen our position in the attractive AWP rental market in Europe. We believe the Acquisition will enable us to improve our footprint and realize economies of scale in the countries where both the Target and Boels have a presence. Furthermore, the Acquisition will expand our footprint into countries where Boels previously did not have any material presence. In countries such as Denmark, France, Spain, Slovenia and Croatia, the Acquisition provides an opportunity for further expansion of both our specialty offering of access equipment and certain other general offerings. With approximately 65% of the Target's fleet already electrified, the acquisition aligns with our commitment to sustainability. The Acquisition fits well within our overall growth strategy built on both organic growth as well as selective bolton acquisitions. By realizing economies of scale, combining overhead costs and cross-selling between Boels and the Target, the Acquisition is expected to generate meaningful synergies over the coming years. Most of these synergies are expected to come from (i) efficiencies from overlapping operating countries and local headquarters, (ii) procurement advantages related to improved pricings and savings on spare parts from using our highly efficient procurement tool, and (iii) cross ----- selling opportunities in overlapping and new jurisdictions. See "Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information— _Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As Adjusted Financial Information—As Adjusted Consolidated Financial Information."_

Subsubsection Title: New EIB Facility
Subsubsection Text: On December 21, 2023, we entered into a €100 million term loan with the European Investment Bank to support our further investments in "green" electric equipment in line with the European Investment Bank's commitment to climate action and environmental sustainability. The financing ranks pari passu in right of payment and security with the Notes offered hereby, the Existing Notes and the Existing Senior Facilities. As of December 31, 2023, the EIB Facility was undrawn. The Issuer may draw amounts under the EIB Facility in the second quarter of 2024 to finance its investment in "green" electric equipment in accordance with its terms. For additional information, see "Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—EIB Facility."_

Subsubsection Title: Management
Subsubsection Text: On March 19, 2024, we announced that Jan Piet Valk will resign as Chief Financial Officer and statutory director of the Group as of June 1, 2024. On September 1, 2024, he will join the Supervisory Board of the Group as chairman. He will be succeeded by René Olsthoorn, who will be appointed as Chief Financial Officer on June 1, 2024. See "Management".

Based on preliminary management accounts, we estimate that our revenue for the quarter ended March 31, 2024 will be slightly above the same quarter in the prior year at €365 million. Despite the estimated increase in our revenue for the first quarter of 2024, we expect our Reported EBITDA to temporarily decrease to €112 million due to inflationary pressures and as a result of a strong first quarter in 2023 rolling off. We have implemented several cost measures since the end of last year to counter these inflationary pressures, although the effect of those will not yet be fully reflected in our results for the first quarter. Taking into account our preliminary results for the first quarter of 2024, we estimate that our revenue for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024 will be in line with the year ended December 31, 2023 at €1,555 million, while our Reported EBITDA for the same period may come slightly down by less than two percent to €536 million. We continue to experience solid growth in sales from our specialist rental activities due to our strategic diversification in this area, partially offset by a slight softening in our general rental business, particularly in the Nordics. We are aware of the political and macro-economic tensions in Europe, but with our installed base, resilient business model and value-added strategy, we continue to navigate well through current market conditions. We remain committed to add value to all our customers and other stakeholders with reliability, drive and energy. We continue to invest in our fleet to remain on top of market developments. Based on our already highly electrical fleet and ECO equipment and machinery, our aim is to play a leading role in the energy transition within the equipment rental sector. A substantial amount of our ongoing investments is planned to be used to further expand our ECO label and zero emission fleet. We note that increasing tension in the labour market in many countries in which we are active creates inflationary pressure. We are wellpositioned to mitigate the effects and we will continue to monitor these developments closely and act accordingly. We have the tools to reduce costs when needed, while allowing for continued investments in fleet, talent and other areas in the year ahead. _The foregoing preliminary financial information is based on preliminary internal unaudited consolidated monthly management accounts as of and for each of the three months ended March 31, 2024, with comparative financial information_ ----- _for each of the three months ended March 31, 2023, respectively, which were prepared by and are the sole responsibility of the Group’s management. This financial information has not been audited, verified or the subject of any procedures by any auditor. The foregoing preliminary financial information is inherently subject to material modification during the preparation of Issuer’s condensed consolidated interim financial statements as of and for the quarter ended March 31, 2024 or consolidated financial statements as of and for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2024. While the Group believes the foregoing financial information to be reasonable, actual results could vary materially and you should therefore not place undue reliance on such financial information. The presented preliminary financial information is not representative of any quarterly or twelve-month period results of operations and should not be regarded as an indication, forecast or representation by the Issuer or any other person regarding the Group’s future financial performance for the quarter ended March 31, 2024 or the fiscal year ending December 31, 2024. See “Forward-looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain factors that could affect the Group’s future performance and results of operations._ -----

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Guarantees ........................ The Guarantee of each Guarantor will:
Subsubsection Text: - be a general senior obligation of such Guarantor; - be secured as set forth under "—Security," on a pari passu basis with the interests granted in favor of the Existing Notes, the EIB Facility and the Existing Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the relevant Guarantor that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee, including such Guarantor's obligations under the Existing Notes, the EIB Facility and the Existing Senior Facilities; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee; - be effectively senior to any existing and future obligations of the applicable Guarantor that are not secured by the Collateral owned by such Guarantor, to the extent of the value of such Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future obligations of such Guarantor that are secured by property or assets that do ----- not secure such Guarantee to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such other obligations; - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future obligations of the subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not provide Guarantees, including obligations owed to trade creditors; and - be subject to the limitations described herein and in "Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure—Each Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability" and "Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations."_ The Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See "Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure— There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee," "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement" and "Description of the Notes—Guarantees—Release of the Guarantees."_

Subsection Title: Security ........................................................ On or about the Issue Date, the Trustee will accede to the Intercreditor
Subsubsection Text: Agreement pursuant to a creditor accession undertaking as a _pari passu debt creditor. Subject to the terms of the security documents, the Agreed Security Principles and applicable perfection requirements, the Notes and the Guarantees will be secured by: (a) on or about the Issue Date and, in any case, within 30 days of the Issue Date, (i) the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and material structural intercompany receivables of the Issuer, (ii) material structural intercompany receivables owed to P.B.K. NV (the "Parent") by the Issuer or any material subsidiary, (iii) the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and certain material structural intercompany receivables of the Guarantors and (iv) substantially all inventory, machinery, plant, trade receivables, vehicles and construction machines of the Guarantor incorporated in Norway (by way of a floating charge) and substantially all movable assets of each Guarantor incorporated in Finland and Sweden (by way of a business mortgage) (collectively, the "Initial **Collateral") and (b) within 120 days following the Completion Date, the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and certain material structural intercompany receivables of each of the Post-Completion Guarantors (the "Post-Completion Collateral", and together with the Initial Collateral, the "Collateral"). The Initial Collateral also secures, and the Post-Completion Collateral, will, substantially concurrently with the Notes, secure the Existing Notes, the EIB Facility and the Existing Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations on a _pari passu_ basis. The Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see "Description of the Notes—Security" and for more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see "Limitations on Validity _and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations" and "Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure."_ References to pari passu security interests include security interests that were created subsequent in time and thus in ranking but are contractually pari passu with prior ranking security and entitled to equal treatment with other prior ranking security and secured creditors pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement. See "Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, ----- _the Guarantees and Our Structure—Holders of the Notes must rely on the effectiveness of the Intercreditor Agreement to implement parity among the secured parties."_ The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See "Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the _Guarantees and Our Structure—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee," "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement" and "Description of the Notes— Security—Release of Security."_

Subsection Title: Additional Amounts ................................... All payments by or on behalf of the Issuer or any Guarantor (or any
Subsubsection Text: surviving entity) under or with respect to the Notes or any Guarantee will be made free and clear of, and without withholding or deduction for taxes, unless required by law. If any withholding or deduction for or on account of any taxes imposed by any relevant taxing jurisdiction is required, the Issuer, the Guarantor or surviving entity, as the case may be, will pay such additional amounts as may be necessary to ensure that the net amount received by each holder of the Notes after such withholding or deduction will be not less than the amount the holder would have received if such taxes had not been required to be withheld or deducted, subject to certain exceptions. See "Description of the Notes—Guarantees—Additional _Amounts."_

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption of Notes .................. Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Notes
Subsubsection Text: at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of such Notes plus the applicable "make-whole" premium set forth in this Offering Memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may during each twelve-month period following the Issue Date redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem on one or more occasions up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to      % of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date; provided that, at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption. On or after     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum under the caption "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption" plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption."

Subsection Title: Redemption for Taxation ........................... In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may
Subsubsection Text: redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption—Redemption _Upon Changes in Withholding Taxes."_ -----

Subsection Title: Change of Control ...................................... Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a "change of control,"
Subsubsection Text: the Issuer is required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash of 101% of the principal amount thereof on the date of purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. See "Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Change of Control."

Subsection Title: Tender Offers .............................................. In connection with any tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less
Subsubsection Text: than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes (excluding any early tender or incentive fee) plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption—General."

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ...................................... The Indenture will contain covenants that, among other things, limit the
Subsubsection Text: ability of the Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries to: - incur additional debt and issue guarantees and preferred stock; - make certain restricted payments, including dividends and other distributions; - make certain investments or loans, including participating in joint ventures; - repay or redeem subordinated debt or share capital; - create or incur certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to the Issuer; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including shares of any of our Restricted Subsidiaries; - guarantee certain types of our other indebtedness without also guaranteeing the Notes; - effect a merger or consolidation of, or sell, all or substantially all of our assets or all of the assets of certain companies within the Group; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as the Notes achieve and maintain investment-grade ratings. See "Description of the _Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status."_ Each of these covenants is subject to a number of important limitations and exceptions as described under "Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants."_ -----

Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions ................................. The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered
Subsubsection Text: under the U.S. Securities Act, or the securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction, and may not be offered or sold within the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and applicable securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction. See "Notice to Investors" for further detail and additional restrictions applicable in the EEA and the United Kingdom.

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds ........................................... We expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with cash on
Subsubsection Text: balance sheet, to: (i) repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B, (ii) finance the Acquisition on the Acquisition Closing Date, and (ii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The Acquisition is not contingent on the Offering and the proceeds of the Offering will not be held in an escrow account prior to the completion of the Acquisition. If the Acquisition does not complete, the Notes will not be subject to a special mandatory redemption and the proceeds of the Offering will not be returned to Holders of the Notes ahead of redemption or maturity. If the Acquisition does not complete, that portion of the proceeds of the Offering earmarked for the Acquisition will instead be used by the Issuer for general corporate purposes, including debt refinancing, capital expenditures and other strategic bolt-on acquisitions. See "Risk _Factors– If the Acquisition is not completed, the proceeds of the Notes may be used for alternative purposes."_

Subsection Title: No Prior Market ......................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is no prior market.
Subsubsection Text: Although certain of the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that a liquid market for the Notes will develop or be maintained.

Subsection Title: Listing .......................................................... Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission
Subsubsection Text: to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange.

Subsection Title: Governing Law ........................................... The Indenture, the Guarantees provided therein and the Notes will be
Subsubsection Text: governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English Law. The Security Documents will (subject to certain exceptions) be governed by the laws applicable to the relevant asset.

Subsection Title: Trustee ......................................................... BNY Mellon Corporate Trustee Services Limited Paying Agent ............................................... The Bank of New York Mellon, London Branch Registrar and Transfer Agent ................... The Bank of New York Mellon SA/NV, Dublin Branch Security Agent ............................................ Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. Risk Factors ................................................ Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should carefully
Subsubsection Text: consider all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the "Risk _Factors" section of this Offering Memorandum before making a decision_ whether to invest in the Notes. -----

Subsubsection Text: (i) Represents the estimated pro forma adjustment to reflect the contribution for the five acquisitions completed in the year ended December 31, 2023 (described in "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results _of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings") as if such acquisition had been completed as of January 1, 2023._ This information does not represent the results we would have achieved had the acquisition occurred as at January 1, 2023. See "Risk Factors— _—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (ii) Represents the estimated pro forma adjustment to reflect the contribution of the acquisition of MG Rental (based on unaudited financial information available for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023) completed on January 4, 2024 (described in "Management's _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings") as if such acquisition had been completed as of January 1, 2023. This information does not_ represent the results we would have achieved had the acquisition occurred as at January 1, 2023. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them." (iii) Represents the estimated pro forma adjustment to reflect the contribution of the Acquisition of the Target Group as if such acquisition had been completed as of January 1, 2023, reflecting the Target Group's EBITDA prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP amounting to €63.8 million, certain management adjustments to present EBITDA on a basis that is substantially consistent with IFRS (including IFRS 16) amounting to €12.8 million and estimated run-rate cost savings synergies that we aim to achieve within two years of completion of the Acquisition amounting to €13.4 million, mainly relating to operational expenditures. In addition to the run-rate cost savings synergies reflected in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, we aim to realize further run-rate synergies from capital expenditure savings and cross-selling opportunities, including beyond the initial two years. Most of these synergies are expected to come from (i) efficiencies from overlapping operating countries ----- and local headquarters, (ii) procurement advantages related to improved pricings and savings on spare parts from using our highly efficient procurement tool, and (iii) cross-selling opportunities in overlapping and new jurisdictions. We estimate that in the two years following the completion of the Acquisition, the one-off transaction, integration and personnel costs associated with realizing these synergies will amount to €14.1 million and will largely be incurred within the first year of completion of the Acquisition. Our synergy and one-off cost estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the information available and our judgments based on such information. The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy benefit estimates. This information does not represent the results we would have achieved had the acquisition occurred as at January 1, 2023. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks— _We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (2) _As adjusted total debt interest expense represents the interest expense on our total debt as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on January 1, 2023, including interest expense in connection with the Notes offered hereby and lease liabilities recognized in accordance with IFRS 16 "Leases." As adjusted interest expense excludes commitment fees payable on the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, does not give effect to hedging arrangements in respect of the Existing Senior Facilities and assumes the Existing Revolving Credit Facility would have been undrawn during the full twelve-month period. (3) _As adjusted senior secured debt interest expense represents the interest expense on our senior secured debt as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on January 1, 2023, including interest expense in connection with the Notes offered hereby but excluding lease liabilities recognized in accordance with IFRS 16 "Leases." As adjusted interest expense excludes commitment fees payable on the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, does not give effect to hedging arrangements in respect of the Existing Senior Facilities and assumes the Existing Revolving Credit Facility would have been undrawn during the full twelve-month period. -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following tables set forth our financial information as of the dates and for the years indicated below. We also present certain unaudited consolidated financial information on an as adjusted basis, to illustrate the effect the Transactions would have had on certain of our financial results for the year ended December 31, 2023, or on our financial position as of December 31, 2023, as applicable. The unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial information is for informational purposes only and is not intended to represent or to be indicative of the consolidated results of operations or financial position we would have reported had the Transactions been completed as of January 1, 2023, in the case of our as adjusted total debt interest expense and as adjusted senior secured debt interest expense, or as of December 31, 2023, in the case of our as adjusted cash and cash equivalents, as adjusted total debt, as adjusted total net debt, as adjusted senior secured debt and as adjusted senior secured net debt. The unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial information should not be taken as indicative of our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. Our historical results may not be indicative of our future results following completion of the Transactions. The unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial information has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards. The following tables also contain Non-IFRS Measures and ratios that are not presented in accordance with IFRS, are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered a substitute for, or superior to, the equivalent measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS or those calculated using financial measures that are prepared in accordance with IFRS. See "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures." You should also read the following information in conjunction with the "Presentation of Financial Information," "Risk Factors," "Capitalization" and "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations."_ -----

Subsubsection Title: We are vulnerable to fluctuations and deteriorations in the economic conditions in the industries and markets in which we and our customers operate.
Subsubsection Text: We may be negatively impacted by economic downturns and uncertainty in any of the countries in which we operate or the global markets generally, as adverse economic conditions may reduce commercial activity, cause disruption and volatility and increase rates of default and bankruptcy. The demand for our products and services is dependent on, among other factors, the industries in which our customers operate, the general economy and the stability of the global credit markets. During economic downturns, certain of our customers may, for example, suspend or delay projects and events or become more likely to go out of business or default on their payment obligations towards us. We serve a large number of customers, with a significant portion of our business being derived from construction, infrastructure, civil engineering and industrial activities. Many of the industries we serve are cyclical and seasonal by nature, with activity levels that tend to increase during periods of economic growth, decline during economic downturns and vary from quarter to quarter. Consequently, a downturn in construction, infrastructure, civil engineering or industrial activities, or the economy as a whole, generally leads to decreased demand for our equipment. Downturns also intensify price competition as equipment rental providers seek to increase utilization of idle equipment, and inflation can result in increased operating expenses that we may not be able to fully pass onto our customers. For example, for the year ended December 31, 2023, our employee benefits expenses outstripped our revenue growth, in part because we were unable to fully pass along the cost increases to our customers at the same rate as our costs increased. In particular, some of our operating expenses, such as depreciation of right-of-use assets (which are linked to real estate lease payments) and personnel charges in specific countries, are linked to indices, including the Consumer Price Index, which may increase due to inflation. Furthermore, any extended period of inflation may lead to a stagflation or recession, which could in turn lead to the postponement of construction, infrastructure, civil engineering and other industrial activities, thereby lowering the demand for our services. See "—A regional or global health pandemic, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, may adversely affect our business and _exacerbate other risks to which our business is exposed."_ We operate across four geographic regions: the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe, and Other Countries. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we generated 24.0%, 35.7%, 37.1% and 3.1% of our total revenue in the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe and Other Countries regions, respectively. Within these regions, we are particularly exposed to the economic conditions in the Netherlands, Sweden and Germany. Our end markets may be impacted, either temporarily or over the long-term, by changes in: - government infrastructure spending; - spending levels by either public or private customers; - the credit markets and other economic conditions affecting our customers' ability to undertake new projects or hold events, or otherwise impacting customers' demand for our products and services; - the cost of construction and other materials; or - weather conditions affecting a particular region. Changes in these or other factors caused by deterioration in the construction, infrastructure, civil engineering and other industrial sectors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows in the future. If in any of our markets the economic conditions deteriorate or a return to economic growth is further delayed, our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected. -----

Subsubsection Title: The equipment rental industry is highly competitive, which puts downward pressure on prices.
Subsubsection Text: The equipment rental industry is highly competitive. Many of the markets in which we operate are served by numerous competitors, ranging from national, multi-regional and international equipment rental companies to small, independent businesses with a limited number of locations. In addition, we may encounter increased competition from existing competitors or new market entrants in the future. We face competition principally from pan-European and national rental companies, as well as from regional and local entities. Some of our competitors may have greater financial, marketing and other resources than we do. Our competitors may be more specialized or may have greater name recognition in some markets. We also face competition from smaller competitors operating at regional or local levels, many of which benefit from a strong market presence and local relationships. Over time, our competitors, whether pan-European, national, regional or local, could consolidate their businesses, and the diversified service offerings or increased synergies of these consolidated businesses could increase competition in the markets in which we operate. Competition is based on an array of different factors, some of which are interrelated, including: speed of integrating new or emerging technologies; technical specifications and condition of equipment; engineering solutions and technical know-how; range and timeliness of the products and services offered; availability of equipment; client relationships; ability to quickly adapt to client requirements; a track record of delivery; the willingness to accept higher contractual risks in tender contracts; price; compliance with health and safety and environmental standards; brand name and reputation; resources and budget available for marketing and sales of products and services; and relevant certifications. If we are unable to maintain our competitiveness in relation to one or more of these factors, we may not be able to grow our market share and may potentially lose existing client relationships, which would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In addition, the equipment rental market is increasingly becoming digitized and there is increased focus on the sustainability of equipment, factors which are beginning to be used as differentiators within the market and are central to our business strategy. There can be no assurance that we will be able to capitalize on such trends or achieve the expected benefits of this strategy, or that we will be able to successfully implement and maintain the necessary technologies, processes, and capabilities. Our digitalization strategy involves significant investments in our websites, enterprise resource planning ("ERP") tools, asset monitoring and maintenance systems, online platforms and data systems, many of which are provided by third-party service providers and partners. There can be no assurance that this strategy will be successful, will generate the anticipated benefits and will not increase our exposure to other risks related to increasing reliance on information technology systems and third-party service providers. See "—Risks related to our Business—Disruptions in _our information technology systems could limit our capacity to effectively monitor and control our operations" and "— Risks related to our Business—Our business and reputation may be adversely affected by the actions of third parties."_ Furthermore, we have invested, and expect to continue to invest, in growing our fleet of electrical, hybrid or batterypowered equipment. These investments can be costly and may become obsolete or ineffective due to changing customer preferences, market conditions, technological developments or other factors. Our customers might choose to use the services of our competitors rather than ours. Although our top 10 customers at Group level only represented approximately 7.1% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023, our results would be negatively affected if we were to lose one or more of our key customers to our competitors or if such customers were to decrease their business with us for any reason. These or other changes to the competitive landscape of our industry could result in a loss of market share, decreased revenue and a decline in profitability. From time to time, we or our competitors may attempt to compete effectively by lowering rental rates or prices. To the extent we lower rental rates or increase our fleet in order to retain or increase market share, our operating margins could be adversely affected. In addition, some of our operating expenses, such as depreciation of right-of-use assets (which are linked to real estate lease payments) and personnel charges in specific countries, are linked to indices, including consumer price indices, which may increase due to inflation. As such, price pressure can be particularly acute in an inflationary macroeconomic environment where we endeavor to offset increased operating costs, including the cost of purchasing equipment, by increasing the rental rates and prices that we charge our customers, and we may not always be able to sufficiently raise rates or prices to offset the impact of inflation on our costs. In addition, we may not be able to match a competitor's price reductions or fleet investment, which could cause our customers to reduce their level of business with us. Termination of contractual arrangements by our customers may result in decreased market share and revenue, either of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Future technological developments may render our current rental fleet technologically obsolete before the end of the initially estimated economic life.
Subsubsection Text: While technological development in the types of tools and equipment that we have traditionally focused our business on has been relatively slow as compared with other sectors that are characterized by more rapid technological change, our rental fleet is increasingly technologically advanced and dependent on complex systems and hardware ----- (including batteries) for their continued operation. Rapid technological evolution and disruptive technologies, failure to upgrade equipment with new technology in time and related changes in laws and regulations (for example, through governments requiring the use of lower emissions technology or by customers actively selecting more sustainable options), may render components of our rental fleet technologically obsolete or redundant prior to the end of their planned useful rental life. Although we seek to sell such redundant or obsolete products on the secondary market, a secondary market for such products may not exist or may be insufficient for our resale needs, which would adversely affect the prices at which we are able to sell and could require us to recognize impairments. Technical obsolescence and redundancy may materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: A regional or global health pandemic, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, may adversely affect our business and exacerbate other risks to which our business is exposed.
Subsubsection Text: Public health crises, epidemics or pandemics could materially and adversely affect our business. For example, governments around the world, including in most countries where we operate our activities, imposed restrictive measures to battle the spread of the respiratory disease COVID-19, including travel restrictions, curfews, lockdowns, quarantines and shutdowns of businesses and workplaces. During the year ended December 31, 2020, our business operations were adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Results differed by country and by end market depending on the severity of the government restrictions imposed and the severity of the pandemic. For example, the suspension of large gatherings and events caused demand for our products and services from the events end market to sharply contract. Overall, we estimate that, on a like-for-like basis reflecting the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, we experienced a mid-single digit revenue decline in the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. The decrease in our level of activity, in line with the decrease in market activity, was the sharpest in Italy, Austria, Belgium and the United Kingdom, where strict lockdown measures were imposed. There can be no assurance that a similar public health crisis will not occur again in the future on a global or regional basis and have a materially adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Our international operations expose us to risks inherent to international business, any of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: We have operations in 18 countries across Europe and upon the completion of the Acquisition of the Target Group, we will have operations in additional countries in Europe, including Denmark, France, Spain, Slovenia and Croatia, as well as outside of Europe, including India, Kazakhstan, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar. As a result, we are subject to numerous, rapidly evolving and complex laws and regulations which govern, among other things, labor matters, immigration, health and safety, financial reporting standards, corporate governance, tax, trade regulations, export controls, and competitive practices in each jurisdiction where we conduct our business. In addition, changes in regulations could impact the ability of rental operators to utilize their equipment in certain types of projects, affecting the competitive landscape in those projects, as well as in other areas in which the non-conforming equipment may be redeployed. Furthermore, we need to comply with various local standards and practices of different regulatory, tax, judicial and administrative bodies specific to each jurisdiction in which we operate. These risks may be heightened for countries in which we have limited operational history, including through the Acquisition of the Target Group. See "––Risks Related _to the Acquisition."_ Further, we are also reliant on local managers to oversee the day-to-day functioning of our branches and to ensure their compliance with local law, and we may be subject to risks related to such compliance, including issues that may arise as a result of insufficient oversight. In such cases, we could be fined or otherwise sanctioned by regulators, which could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. There are multiple risks associated with the international nature of our operations, including inconsistent regulations across jurisdictions, unanticipated changes in the regulatory environment, political instability (such as the threat of war, terrorist attacks or civil unrest) and import and export restrictions. Furthermore, these risks may be greater in certain areas where we operate. Any of these events may affect our employees, reputation, business or financial results as well as our ability to achieve our strategy, including the following specific business risks: - adverse economic developments in economies around the world; - social and political instability in a number of countries around the world (such as the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the conflict between Israel and Hamas); - potential terrorist attacks; - epidemics and pandemics, which may adversely affect our workforce, suppliers and customers; ----- - adverse changes in governmental policies, especially those affecting trade and investment and any regulations impacting the equipment rental business or commercial operations generally; - differing local product preferences and requirements; - pressures on management time and attention due to the complexities of overseeing multinational operations; - challenges in maintaining, staffing, managing multinational operations; - differing tax and regulatory regimes; - differing labor laws and collective bargaining regimes; - enforcement of remedies in various jurisdictions; - the foreign currency translation and transaction risks of operating in euro; - the risk that the business partners upon whom we depend will not perform as expected; - obstacles to the repatriation of earnings and cash; - reduced protection for intellectual property in some countries; - compliance with applicable antitrust and other regulatory and regulations relating to potential future acquisitions; - price controls; - ownership regulations; and - inflation, recession, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange and interest rates, burdensome fiscal policies and transfer restrictions. For example, on February 24, 2022, Russian military forces commenced a war against Ukraine, and conflict and disruption in the region is likely to continue. Although the length, impact and outcome of the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine are highly unpredictable, this conflict has led and could continue to lead to significant market and other disruptions, including significant volatility in commodity prices and the supply of energy resources, instability in financial markets, supply chain interruptions, political and social instability, as well as an increase in cyber-attacks. We have historically had indirect operations in Russia through Fortrent LLC ("Fortrent"), a 50%-owned joint venture with Ramirent Oyj, and which generated a gain of €2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, which was accounted for in our consolidated financial statements under the equity method. Considering the level of uncertainty due to the geopolitical situation resulting from the war in Ukraine and the high volatility of the Russian ruble, we fully impaired our investment in Fortrent in the year ended December 31, 2022, which included the write-down of the full amount of the carrying value of our investment in Fortrent amounting to €10.9 million, the depreciation of certain receivables amounting to €0.9 million and the reversal of the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €2.6 million for the period. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we reversed the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €8.5 million for the year. In November 2023, we disposed of our interest in Fortrent. See also "—Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory _Environment—Our business is subject to various legal and regulatory compliance risks, including those involving antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations and sanctions."_ We are actively monitoring the situation in Ukraine and Russia and assessing its impact on our business. The extent and duration of the military action, sanctions and resulting market disruptions could be significant and could potentially have a substantial impact on the global economy and our business for an unknown period of time. Although we do not have any current activities in Russia or Ukraine, we have activities in Scandinavia, Poland and the Baltic States, and if the conflict intensifies or expands beyond Ukraine, it could have an adverse impact on our business. For example, we may be forced to reorganize, reduce or terminate business operations in geographical areas where our employees, partners or subcontractors would otherwise be subject to unacceptable economic or personal risks, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. -----

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to execute our growth strategy.
Subsubsection Text: We have historically expanded our business through a combination of strategic acquisitions and organic growth. Our growth strategy depends in part on our ability to identify attractive acquisition candidates and successfully integrate them into our business. Acquisitions are subject to several risks and there can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive acquisition candidates in the future or complete the acquisition of any identified candidates at commercially acceptable prices or terms. In particular, our industry is experiencing rapid consolidation which could impact our ability to achieve our strategy. See also "—The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through _acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business." Our growth strategy also depends in part on our ability to_ successfully identify and open new depots, both in countries where we already have an established presence as well as other countries to which we may decide to expand in the future. There can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive new depot locations and successfully open and operate them. Opening new depots requires significant investments and management attention and may involve risks associated with entering new markets, including markets where we face significant competition. We may not have sufficient management, financial and other resources to successfully identify and operate such new depots.
