Any significant diversion of management's attention, unexpected cost associated with or any major difficulties encountered in acquiring new businesses or operating new depots could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows, and make it more difficult for us to achieve our strategy. Furthermore, general economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets could affect the timing and extent to which we can make strategic acquisitions and open new depots, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Furthermore, the success of our strategy, in particular with respect to organic growth, depends on our ability to accurately forecast trends. Our decisions about investments in new equipment, for example, are based in significant part on our views of future demand, and any failure to accurately predict demand could negatively affect our growth prospects. If anticipated growth does not occur, we may not earn the level of returns that we hope to achieve on investments made during the bottom of the cycle. Alternatively, if growth is greater than expected, we may not have a fleet of appropriate size and mix. More generally, uncertainty regarding future product demand in the markets in which we operate, or markets in which we seek to enter, could cause us to maintain excess equipment inventory and increase our capital expenditures beyond what is efficient. Alternatively, this forecasting difficulty could cause a shortage of equipment for rental that could result in an inability to satisfy demand for our products and a loss of market share which could in turn materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have achieved growth in part through acquisitions and our strategy assumes that some future growth will occur inorganically, through further acquisitions of businesses that we believe complement or enhance our existing products, services, markets, capabilities or technologies, including through the Acquisition of the Target Group. See "—Risks Related to the Acquisition." For example, in February 2020, we acquired Cramo Plc ("Cramo"), a provider of equipment rental and modular space solutions and greatly expanded our operations in the Nordics. Although the integration of the Cramo business into our Central Europe region is largely complete, we are continuing to undertake significant integration projects with respect to management structures and back-office functions, through our various "Oneprojects", including One-Finance, One-Fleet, One-HR and One-IT. A failure to successfully execute any of these integration projects on time, on budget and as envisaged could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. There can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive acquisition candidates in the future or complete the acquisition of any identified candidates at favorable prices or on advantageous terms. We expect to face competition for acquisition candidates, which may limit the number of acquisition opportunities we have and lead to higher acquisition costs. We may not have the financial resources necessary to consummate any acquisitions or the ability to obtain the necessary funds on satisfactory terms. Furthermore, general economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets could affect the timing and extent to which we successfully acquire new businesses. In general, the risks associated with acquisitions, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows, include the following: - we may lose sales and incur substantial costs, delays or other operational or financial problems in integrating acquired businesses and integration may be more costly and take longer than expected; - we may not achieve financial and operational synergies on a timely basis or without significant costs, if at all; - acquisitions may divert management's attention from the operation of the existing business; ----- - the assumptions underlying the business plans supporting the valuations of the acquisitions and expected synergies may prove inaccurate, in particular with respect to the future performance of the acquired businesses; - we may be forced to divest or reduce the scope of certain businesses to obtain the necessary regulatory authorizations, in particular with respect to anti-trust authorizations; - we may need to write down goodwill and certain other intangible assets from our balance sheet if our initial estimates of the value of an acquired business are higher than actual results; - we may be further exposed to risks of fluctuations in currency exchange rates; - we may not be able to retain key personnel of an acquired company, which could lead to loss of institutional knowledge and customer relationships; - we may not be able to retain existing customers of the acquired business; - we may experience corporate or market cannibalization; - we may face increased competition; - we may operate an acquired company as a joint venture with partners with whom we lack a longstanding relationship; and - we may encounter unanticipated events, circumstances or liabilities related to the acquired businesses, their integration and the growth of our business, particularly in geographic areas in which we have not previously operated. In addition to the risks described above, the integration of acquired businesses may be more difficult and take more time due to logistical, regulatory, linguistic, cultural and other factors such as our relative lack of familiarity with a given market and its economic, political and social dynamics. If we are not successful in implementing our acquisition strategy or integrating such acquisitions, or if some or all of our existing or future acquisitions prove ultimately to be unsuccessful, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: We depend on equipment manufacturers to obtain adequate rental equipment for our fleet on a timely basis.
Subsubsection Text: We purchase most of our rental equipment from well-known original equipment manufacturers. We rely on our relationships with original equipment manufacturers to centralize our procurement and benefit from economies of scale. Failure to maintain these relationships, or successfully optimize our economies of scale in the future, could lead to higher unit costs for our procurement and present availability issues due to shortages of material or components such as microchips. As we do not manufacture any of the products that we rent to our customers, we rely on third-party suppliers for the provision of the equipment, tools, spare parts and consumables that are essential to our business. However, our suppliers may not be able to fulfill the terms of their agreements with us on a timely basis or at all for logistical or strategic reasons, including issues affecting the global supply chain generally as a result of economic disruption. Further, suppliers may be unwilling to extend contracts that provide favorable terms to us, or they may seek to renegotiate existing contracts with us. As a result, we could face increased costs for our equipment or longer delivery times. Delays in the delivery of new equipment may impair our ability to respond to increases in demand, put us at a disadvantage to our competitors and may cause us to miss opportunities in our markets. For instance, equipment manufacturers have recently faced and continue to face supply chain difficulties, in particular with respect to the raw materials needed to manufacture chips and batteries, and as a result, we have recently experienced, and continue to experience, delays in deliveries of purchased equipment. In addition, delays in delivery can adversely affect our equipment maintenance and relocation costs, as there may no longer be local demand for the purchased equipment by the time it arrives at the point of delivery. We may experience further delays or an inability to source new equipment on a timely basis or at all. We may not be able to find alternative sources of supply for the equipment we purchase in each of our core product categories, and the termination or delay of equipment orders by a major supplier could adversely affect our business. If we are required to procure more costly equipment, our business could be adversely affected if we are not able to pass the cost increases of such equipment through to our customers. Furthermore, our top 10 suppliers at Group level represented approximately 20.3% of our total expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our procurement processes could be negatively affected if our business relationships with any of our top 10 suppliers are disrupted, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. ----- Any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The cost of equipment purchases for our rental fleet, in addition to other operating costs, may increase.
Subsubsection Text: The cost of new equipment that we purchase for our rental fleet may increase as a result of a number of factors, including increased raw material costs (such as costs of steel), scarcity of component parts necessary to manufacture our rental equipment (such as microchips and batteries), increased labor costs, inflation generally or geopolitical developments and other world events (such as the conflict between Russia and Ukraine or the conflict between Israel and Hamas and the wider instability in the Middle East). For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine destabilized the financial and commodity markets and resulted in an uncertain macroeconomic situation in Europe, causing inflation throughout the economy, rises in interest rates and volatile energy prices and such factors have had, and could have in the future, an adverse effect on the cost of new equipment we purchase for our rental fleet. Additionally, the recent military conflict between Israel and Hamas and instability in the Middle East, including the Red Sea, has led to delays and increased freight rates due to the rerouting of ships around the African continent. There can be no assurance that our shipping costs will not increase or our deliveries will not be delayed as a result. In addition, the cost of steel, which is a primary material used in most of our equipment and products, rose sharply in 2021 as countries around the world began to recover from the economic downturn caused by COVID-19 and has continued to rise following the commencement of hostilities between Russia and Ukraine due to a combination of sanctions against Russian producers and disruptions of production in Ukraine. While additional capacity currently exists that can replace the foregoing volumes, increases in the spot prices of steel in Europe may nonetheless persist. Further increases in prices of raw materials could cause the price of new equipment to rise, which could materially affect our business to the extent that we are not able to pass such cost increases through to our customers. We are also subject to risks related to the increases in energy or transportation costs. Energy prices are in turn subject to significant volatility caused by, among other things, inflation, market fluctuations, supply and demand, currency fluctuations, production and transportation disruptions, tariffs, resource availability, geopolitical developments and other world events, as well as climate change related conditions and other factors beyond our control. High energy and transportation costs could increase the price of new equipment purchases, which could adversely affect our business. Additionally, higher energy and transportation costs could significantly increase our operating costs. In 2022, partially as a result of the increase in fuel prices stemming from the conflict in Ukraine, we saw a significant increase in our logistics costs compared to prior years. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in minimizing our logistics costs through our hub-and-spoke logistics model or in passing along such costs to our customers. Any future increases in our logistics costs could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. Changes in customer demand due to changed technology, safety or environmental concerns, regulations, or other factors could cause certain of our existing equipment to become obsolete and require us to purchase new equipment, which would increase our costs. Further, electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment each have a purchasing cost which is significantly higher than similar equipment using older and less environmentally friendly engines. Purchasing electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment also incurs costs associated with training our employees and customers on the use, maintenance, safety requirements, and repair of the new technology. Due to the significantly higher purchasing costs of electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment our capital expenditure is expected to increase in the future. There can be no assurances that potential maintenance costs savings will offset the expected increase in capital expenditure. These factors in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The effective management, maintenance and repair of our rental fleet is vital to our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our rental equipment has a long economic life, and managing this equipment is a critical element to our rental business. Rental equipment asset management requires that we build up and maintain an inventory of durable, high-quality products that anticipate the needs of our customers and changes in technology, legislation, regulations, building codes and local permitting in the various markets in which we operate. In addition, we must successfully maintain and repair this equipment cost-effectively to maximize the economic life of the products and, to a lesser extent, the proceeds that may be received from the sale of these products. As the needs of our customers change, we may need to incur costs to relocate or retrofit our rental assets to better meet shifts in demand, beyond relocations that occur in the ordinary course of business to maximize fleet uptime and address customer demand. In addition, if the location of our assets is not efficiently coordinated with regional demand, we may incur costs from relocating the fleet (which includes costs associated with local regulatory compliance, as well as transportation and storage) or we may be unable to take advantage of business opportunities despite excess inventory in other regions. If we are not able to successfully manage our rental assets, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected. In addition, where we have contracts that employ the use of our rental equipment for long durations, we may be exposed to the risk that our costs increase materially over the term of the project, whether due to inflation, rising interest ----- rates or adverse movements in currency exchange rates, and we are unable to pass on those cost increases to such customers where fixed pricing has been agreed. If the project is significant (or if there are one or more issues that impact multiple projects) or experiences cost overruns, delays or issues with the quality or availability of supplies, any of these may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. As the equipment in our rental fleet ages, the cost of maintaining such equipment, if not replaced within a certain period of time, generally increases, and we may be unable to pass along such costs to customers. Determining the optimal average age for disposal of our rental fleet is subjective and requires considerable estimates by management. Additionally, maintenance of newer, electric and hybrid equipment may be costlier than the maintenance cost of older gas- and dieselpowered equipment, which could adversely affect our business if we are unable to pass those costs through to our customers. Our future operating results could be adversely affected because our maintenance and repair costs may be higher than estimated, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on our executives, managers and employees.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends, to a large degree, upon the continued effort and abilities of our existing management team, including our CEO and principal ultimate shareholder, Mr. Pierre Boels Jr. Our senior management team has significant experience in the industries and markets in which we operate. If we lose the services of any key member of our senior management team and are unable to find a suitable replacement in a timely manner, it may be a challenge for us to effectively manage our business and execute our strategy. Our success also depends on the experience and skills of our country and operational managers, district and area managers and depot managers, who have extensive knowledge of our business and industry experience. Competition for managers within our industry is generally significant, and, if any of our senior or regional managers joins a competitor or forms a competing company, we may lose customers, know-how and other personnel. In addition, we depend upon the quality of our staff personnel, including sales and customer service personnel who routinely interact with and fulfill the needs of our customers. There can be no assurance that we will be able to continue to attract, hire, train and retain qualified personnel, especially in the tight labor markets we currently face in most of the countries in which we operate or that we will not face increases in personnel expenses in line with, or above, inflation. A significant increase in personnel turnover or costs could negatively affect our results of operations and financial performance. Any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Damage to our reputation and our brand could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have developed a reputation and brand images associated with a high-quality fleet of rental equipment, customer service, reliability and social and environmental responsibility. Our brand names, trademarks and logos, as well as their respective reputation are valuable and powerful sales and marketing tools. Litigation, employee misconduct or the misconduct of anyone associated with the Boels brand (or any of our other brands), operational failures, accidents, the outcome of regulatory investigations, press speculation and negative publicity, disclosure of customer information, inadequate products and services, among others, could all affect our brand or reputation. Although our customers are generally responsible for the way in which they handle our rental equipment and despite our efforts to promote training and safety, accidents involving our equipment can and do occur, which can have an impact on the perceived image of our brands. Furthermore, the Boels brand is perceived to be strongly connected to our CEO, Pierre Boels Jr. and his family. Should Pierre Boels Jr. and his family cease to be connected to the Boels brand, for example, through exiting the business, our customer goodwill related to the Boels brand may decline. We are also exposed to the risk that individuals associated with the Boels brand (or any of our other brands) take actions that may affect our brand or reputation. The occurrence of any of the above risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Disruptions in our information technology systems could limit our capacity to effectively monitor and control our operations.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on information technology systems to track and bill our services, manage our fleet, meet our customers' needs and gather information upon which our management makes decisions regarding our business. Our information technology systems also facilitate our ability to adjust to changing market conditions. The administration of our business is increasingly reliant on the use of IT systems and artificial intelligence to digitalize processes and systems. The risk of a security breach or disruption, particularly through a cyber-attack or cyber intrusion, has risen as the number, intensity and sophistication of attempted attacks and intrusions around the world have increased. Additionally, due to the significant efforts to digitalize our business, an increasingly larger amount of data is stored in IT systems and vulnerable to data security breaches. Our information technology systems may not be fully protected against such third-party intrusions or ----- against viruses, ransom ware, or similar threats. Disruptions resulting from these threats, system crashes or other causes could have a material adverse effect on our business. In particular, we use several ERP systems across our network and any disruption to our ERP systems, or the failure of any of these systems to operate as expected could, depending on the magnitude of the problem, adversely affect our operating results. We back-up most of our data daily, train our employees in this regard, perform penetration testing and have a disaster recovery plan in place for most of our systems, including our ERP system. However, our disaster recovery plan does not cover all of our systems. Our back-up systems may fail, and any recovery of our data may be incomplete or subject to delay. In addition, because our systems may contain information about individuals and businesses, our failure to appropriately safeguard the security of the data we hold, whether as a result of our own error or the malfeasance or errors of others, could harm our reputation or give rise to legal liabilities. In most of the regions in which we operate, the processing of personal data is subject to governmental regulation and legislation. Any failure to comply with such regulations or legislation could lead to governmental sanctions, including fines or the initiation of criminal or civil proceedings. In the European Union, we must comply with strict data protection and privacy laws that restrict our ability to collect and use personal information relating to customers and potential customers, including the marketing use of that information. In particular, Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of April 27, 2016 (known as the "General Data Protection

Subsection Title: Regulation" or "GDPR"), which became applicable on May 25, 2018, increased both the number of and the restrictive
Subsubsection Title: Our business and reputation may be adversely affected by the actions of third parties.
Subsubsection Text: In our business, we rely on third-party partners for the provision of certain services, such as collections, IT systems and transport services. If a partner is unable to deliver its services or a supplier is unable to deliver equipment according to the pre-agreed terms or in a timely manner, our reputation may suffer, and we may be required to purchase such goods or services from another source at a higher price. We may not be able to recover all of these costs in all circumstances, which may reduce the profit expected to be realized under such agreements or result in a loss. Moreover, if we purchase services from a third party that is not one of our ordinary providers, there is a risk that we may fail to deliver such services at the quality standards that our customers have been accustomated to, which could be detrimental to our reputation and our relationships with our customers. While we carefully monitor internal and external developments for areas of potential reputational risk, and have established governance structures to assist in evaluating such risks in our business practices and decisions, we may be affected by the inappropriate, fraudulent, negligent, unauthorized or criminal activities of third parties, including employees, suppliers, customers and subcontractors, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We may be exposed to fraud or other misconduct committed by our employees, representatives, agents, customers or other third parties that could affect our reputation and subject us to litigation, financial losses and regulatory action. Such misconduct could include hiding unauthorized or unlawful activities resulting in unknown and unmanaged risks of losses, theft of equipment, improperly using or disclosing confidential information, misappropriating funds, engaging in misrepresentation or fraudulent, deceptive or otherwise improper activities or otherwise failing to comply with applicable laws or our internal policies and procedures. Actions taken by third-party partners acting as our agents may also subject us to vicarious liability suits. Additionally, our digitalization strategy requires us to increasingly rely on third-party providers to maintain our IT systems and to perform certain core business processes for our websites, ERP tools, asset monitoring and maintenance systems, online platforms and data systems. Outsourcing these processes exposes us to various risks, such as loss of control, data breaches, service disruptions, quality issues, contractual disputes and increased costs. We may not be able to monitor, manage, or remedy the performance or compliance of our IT service providers effectively or in a timely manner. We may also face difficulties in finding alternative or backup IT service providers in the event of termination, dissatisfaction, or insolvency of our current IT service providers. Failure to maintain our IT systems could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

Subsection Title: Regulation" or "GDPR"), which became applicable on May 25, 2018, increased both the number of and the restrictive
Subsubsection Title: Seasonality and severe weather conditions may cause fluctuations and disruptions in our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue and operating results have historically varied from period to period. In particular, many of the markets in which our customers operate are characterized by seasonal cycles causing our operations to experience a degree of seasonality in the first quarter of each year, driven principally by climatic conditions in our different regions of operations. Demand in the civil engineering, construction, infrastructure and other industrial markets tends to decrease in winter and during extended periods of inclement weather while increasing in the summer and during extended periods of mild weather. ----- Additionally, severe weather events, such as storms, floods and blizzards, can suppress activity in the civil engineering, industrial markets, construction and infrastructure markets, which can adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Regulation" or "GDPR"), which became applicable on May 25, 2018, increased both the number of and the restrictive
Subsubsection Title: We may be subject to liabilities that are not covered by our insurance policies.
Subsubsection Text: We carry insurance of various types, including but not limited to, property damage insurance, general liability coverage and directors' liability insurance. We may not always be able to accurately foresee all activities and situations in order to ensure that they are fully covered by the terms of our insurance policies and, as a result, our insurance may not cover such risks adequately or at all. While we seek to maintain appropriate levels of insurance, not all claims are insurable, and we may experience incidents of a nature that are not covered by insurance. Any significant uninsured liability may require us to pay substantial amounts, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Further, we may be exposed to multiple claims that do not exceed our deductibles, and, as a result, we could incur significant out-of-pocket costs that could adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations. In addition, the cost of our insurance policies may increase upon renewal of those policies as a result of general rate increases for the type of insurance we carry as well as our historical experience and experience in our industry. Our current insurance policies may not continue to be available in the future on economically reasonable terms, or at all. If we are required to pay significantly higher premiums for insurance or are not able to maintain insurance coverage at affordable rates, we could experience higher costs that could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Regulation" or "GDPR"), which became applicable on May 25, 2018, increased both the number of and the restrictive
Subsubsection Title: Our rental fleet is subject to residual value risk upon disposition.
Subsubsection Text: Our approach to fleet management is to replace equipment only at the end of its useful rental life, at which time it is sold, used for parts or sold for scrap. A piece of equipment is usually amortized at least to the level of its residual value by the time it is removed from the fleet. Nonetheless, the market value of any given piece of rental equipment could be less than its depreciated value or residual value at the time it is sold. The market value of used rental equipment depends on several factors, including: - general economic conditions; - worldwide and domestic demands for used equipment; - the supply of used equipment on the market; - the market price for new equipment of the same kind; - wear and tear on the equipment relative to its age; and - technological developments. Any significant decline in the selling prices for used equipment could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

Subsection Title: Regulation" or "GDPR"), which became applicable on May 25, 2018, increased both the number of and the restrictive
Subsubsection Text: nature of the obligations binding on us for the collection and processing of personal data. Additionally, we are subject to the supervision of relevant data protection authorities under the GDPR and, with respect to our operations in the United Kingdom, the United Kingdom General Data Protection Regulation and Data Protection Act 2018 (the "UK GDPR"), and could be fined under each of those regimes independently in respect of the same breach. Although we collect and store a limited amount of personal data, and have proper registrations in place, failure to comply with the provisions of GDPR or UK GDPR could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Unfavorable conditions in the capital and credit markets and political uncertainty may adversely affect business conditions and our access to credit needed to maintain and grow our business.
Subsubsection Text: Disruptions in the global capital and credit markets as a result of an economic downturn, economic uncertainty, regulatory changes, financial institution failures, armed conflict, pandemics, trade wars or other factors could adversely affect our ability to access liquidity to invest in our equipment fleet. In addition, bank failures, liquidity concerns and other adverse developments affecting financial institutions, or rumors about such events, may impact the stability of global financial markets. In the event of weakening macroeconomic conditions, our customers may face challenges to obtain financing for their projects from lenders or in the capital and credit markets, which may cause some of our customers to be unable to meet their payment obligations to us, increasing losses on bad debt. Delinquencies and credit losses generally can be expected to increase during economic slowdowns or recessions. See "—We are exposed to counterparty risks and _may incur losses because of such exposure." Moreover, our suppliers may also be adversely impacted by unfavorable_ capital and credit markets, causing disruption to or delay of product deliveries. Political uncertainty may also negatively impact the capital and credit markets, including through changes in foreign policy or regulatory requirements, trade restrictions or sanctions, higher tariffs and changes to existing, or the imposition of additional, regulations relating to the ----- import or export of products. In addition, if the financial institutions that have extended credit commitments to us, or from which we may seek credit commitments in the future, were to be adversely affected by conditions in the capital and credit markets, they might be unable or unwilling to fund borrowings under such credit commitments, which could have an adverse impact on our financial condition and our ability to borrow funds, if needed, for capital expenditures, working capital, acquisitions, and other corporate purposes. Global markets are experiencing volatility and disruption as a result of various macroeconomic factors, including global inflationary pressures and monetary policy tightening, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine and the current political instability in the Middle East, and trade tensions between the United States and China. Capital markets have been and may continue to be impacted by inflation, which is currently the case in many of the jurisdictions in which we operate, and there are concerns that current inflationary pressures could result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, decreases in global stock exchange indices, increased foreign exchange volatility and decreased GDP in the markets in which we operate. In addition, there are concerns that these events could push the Eurozone, the United Kingdom and/or the United States into an economic recession, any of which, were they to occur, would further destabilize the global financial markets. Any of the events described above could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Fluctuations in interest rates could increase our finance costs.
Subsubsection Text: Material increases in global inflation since early 2022, reaching double-digit levels not seen since the 1980s, and expectations that annual inflation may remain high for a long period of time (driven in part by the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the resulting impact on energy markets), have led central banks of the major world economies, including the U.S. Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, to significantly increase market interest rates in a short timeframe. Our finance costs are sensitive to interest rates, exchange rates and other monetary policies of governments and central banks in the jurisdictions in which we operate. We and certain of our subsidiaries borrow funds at both fixed and floating interest rates, which exposes us to the risk of rising interest rates, and on an as adjusted basis after giving effect to the Transactions, a significant amount of our indebtedness will bear interest at a floating rate. Although we seek to hedge against our interest-bearing liabilities through interest rate swaps, these instruments may not be effective or available in all circumstances. A sustained increase in inflation may result in higher interest rates on our borrowings (including finance leases) that are subject to a floating rate of interest, increasing our financial expenses and cost of borrowing. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2022 and the year ended December 31, 2023, we experienced an increase in financial expenses due to the rise in EURIBOR, which resulted in higher interest payments on our unhedged floating rate borrowings. In addition, we may not be able to refinance such debt in the future at interest rates that are as favorable as the ones currently applicable to our borrowings. See "—Risks _Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure—Some of our indebtedness, including the Existing Senior Facilities, bears interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow."_

Subsubsection Title: Our business could be materially adversely impacted if we are unable to obtain additional capital as required.
Subsubsection Text: We require capital for, among other things, purchasing rental equipment, opening new branches, expanding our business, completing acquisitions and refinancing existing debt. Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and our ability to generate cash. Our primary sources of cash are cash flows from operating activities and borrowings under our debt facilities, including our Existing Revolving Credit Facility and our Trade Receivables Purchase Program. This cash may be insufficient, and we may require additional financing to obtain capital for, among other purposes, operating expenses, capital expenditures, working capital requirements, acquisitions and debt service payments. Additionally, there is the risk that our capital expenditures will increase due to ineffective planning of investments or asset sales. See "—Risks related to _our Business—We may not be able to execute our growth strategy" and "—Risks related to our Business—The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business."_ There can be no assurance that any additional financing that we require will be available or, if available, will be available on terms that are satisfactory to us. In addition, in the future, we may need to rely on different sources of financing for our capital expenditures, the level of which significantly affects the age and size of our equipment fleet, and if we are required to reduce these expenditures for any reason, the reduced availability of equipment or the age of our rental fleet may cause us competitive harm and increase our maintenance costs. Any additional indebtedness that we incur will make us more vulnerable to economic downturns and limit our ability to withstand competitive pressures. If we are unable to obtain sufficient financing, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected. -----

Subsubsection Title: Fluctuations in currency exchange rates could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: Although we prepare our consolidated financial statements in euro, we derive revenue and incur costs in several different currencies, including the Swedish krona, the Norwegian krone, the Danish krone, the British pound, the Polish zloty, Swiss franc and the Czech koruna. Accordingly, movements in exchange rates between any of these currencies and euro could have an adverse effect on our results of operations to the extent we have a mismatch between our earnings in any foreign currency and our costs that are denominated in that currency. We also incur currency risk on the net investment in our subsidiaries in Sweden, Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and the United Kingdom. The results of operations and financial position of these subsidiaries are reported in the relevant functional currency of that subsidiary. These subsidiaries' assets and liabilities are converted to euro based on the exchange rate on the balance sheet date, and income statement items are converted to euro based on the average exchange rate during the relevant financial period. Significant increases in the value of the euro relative to foreign currencies could have a material adverse effect on our financial position and results of operations. Although we routinely engage in derivative transactions to hedge against any such fluctuations, there can be no assurance that we will be adequately protected against such risks. For example, our revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023 was negatively affected by the weakening of the Swedish krona and Norwegian krone against the euro. If we are exposed to significant adverse movements in foreign currency rates in the future, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to counterparty risks and may incur losses because of such exposure.
Subsubsection Text: Although our top 10 customers at Group level only represented approximately 7.1% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023, our business would be adversely affected if one or more of our key customers were to have liquidity problems and be unable to fulfill the terms of their rental agreements with us. Delinquencies and credit losses generally can be expected to increase during economic slowdowns or recessions. In case of such default in payment obligations, we may be unable to collect some or all of receivables due to us, in which case some or all outstanding amounts would need to be written off and we would need to seek alternative sources of funding for our working capital requirements. If we were to experience any disputes or a significant reduction in or loss of business with one or more customers, or if one or more customers were to experience difficulty in paying us on a timely basis, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected. Furthermore, should a supplier or service provider counterparty become insolvent or otherwise unable to meet its obligations, we may need to find a replacement to carry out such supply obligations or we may need to fulfill certain service obligations ourselves, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Additionally, we are exposed to counterparty risk from our financial investments, derivative financial instruments and deposits with financial institutions. If a counterparty fails to honor a payment obligation, such a loss will negatively impact our results of obligations and cash flows. Although we have adopted policies to manage this credit risk exposure, those policies may not prove effective against the risk of default by, or the insolvency of, one or more counterparties.

Subsubsection Title: We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum includes certain statements and figures relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures. These measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and are not measurements under IFRS standards or other generally accepted accounting principles. The Non-IFRS Measures are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or profit from ordinary operations or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other metrics calculated using Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA include estimated results of acquired businesses assuming such acquisitions were made at the beginning of the period presented. We calculated such figures using information and records available from the acquired businesses, which in certain instances was based on unaudited financial information, or were prepared under different accounting principles than Boels' financial statements, management schedules and therefore required significant assumptions and estimates, may not be up to date or may not be prepared on the same basis on which we prepare our accounts. These figures have not been reviewed nor audited by our independent auditors. While these figures are based upon the latest available financial information from the acquired business, actual figures may differ. Such figures represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and certain acquired businesses. Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information. Moreover, we can offer no assurances that the Acquisition will close or that we will recognize our estimated cost savings, synergies or efficiency gains. These adjustments are for illustrative purposes only. While we believe these estimates and assumptions to be reasonable, some or all of this information may prove to be inaccurate or incomplete. As a result, you should not unduly rely on such information in making an investment in the Notes. -----

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to stringent environmental and safety requirements, which can be costly to comply with and may subject us to liability.
Subsubsection Text: We store equipment and machinery as well as use and temporarily store fuels and certain chemicals at a variety of properties in jurisdictions where we have operations, any of which may subject us to stringent environmental requirements. We also lease or own properties on which industrial activities may have been conducted in the past and there may be contamination for which we could become liable for clean-up. As such, we may use hazardous materials to clean and maintain equipment, dispose of solid and hazardous waste and wastewater from equipment washing and store and dispense petroleum products from underground and aboveground storage tanks located at certain of our locations. In connection with these activities, we could contaminate soil, air, water and buildings or cause spills, emissions, leakages or other accidents. We are subject to a variety of environmental regulatory regimes that impose obligations and liability for the clean-up of properties affected by hazardous substance spills or releases. Such liabilities may be imposed on the parties generating or disposing of such substances or the operator of the affected property, often without regard to whether the owner or operator knew of, or was responsible for, the relevant incident. Accordingly, we may become liable, either contractually or by operation of law, for remediation costs even if a contaminated property is not presently owned or operated by us or if the contamination was caused by third parties. In addition, we may be liable for the loss of property value caused by such an incident and prior site assessments or investigations may not have identified all potential instances of contamination or the full extent thereof. Future events, including changes in existing laws or policies or their enforcement, or the discovery of currently unknown or undetected incidents, may give rise to additional remediation liabilities, which may be material. Further, we could also become subject to proceedings where a third party sues us due to a breach of environmental legislation and be ordered to pay damages or be subject to other sanctions. We have made and will continue to make capital and other expenditures in order to comply with these environmental and safety compliance and/or remediation laws and regulations. The requirements of these laws and regulations are complex, change frequently, and could become more stringent in the future. We may not be in complete compliance with all such requirements at all times, and we may be subject to potentially significant civil or criminal fines or penalties if we fail to comply. If any of the risks described above materialize, they may materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks related to environmental, social and governance matters, including the failure to meet certain of our targets.
Subsubsection Text: We must increasingly meet environmental, social and governance ("ESG") standards and expectations regarding environmental concerns (such as climate change and sustainability), social concerns (such as diversity, inclusion and human rights) and corporate governance concerns (such as taking employee relations into account when making business and investment decisions). Complying with certain ESG standards and expectations, in particular environmental standards, may pose challenges to our business and could lead to additional costs. We have set a number of targets with respect to ESG matters. These include ambitious sustainability and environmental targets relating to our emissions and the sustainability of our fleet, among others. We have also set a number of diversity and employee satisfaction targets with respect to our business. See "Business—Environmental, Social and _Governance." In addition, we have entered into a €100.0 million term loan to support our further investments in 'green'_ electric equipment in line with the European Investment Bank's commitment to climate action and environmental sustainability. See "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—EIB Loan". Any failure to achieve such targets could damage our reputation, impair our ability to attract and retain key personnel and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In particular, our emissions targets and targets relating to the development of our green fleet involve significant costs and are based on numerous assumptions, including, among others, the development or commercial viability of new technologies and sustainable equipment. Moreover, there is uncertainty with respect to the future supply and pricing of sustainable equipment, which could impact the level of capital expenditure required to meet our targets. If any of these assumptions do not materialize, we may be unable to achieve our targets within the set timeframe or without incurring prohibitive costs, either of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to various risks related to legal proceedings or claims.
Subsubsection Text: We are a party to lawsuits in the normal course of our business. Litigation in general can be expensive, lengthy and disruptive to normal business operations. Moreover, the results of complex legal proceedings are difficult to predict. Responding to lawsuits brought against us, or legal actions that we may initiate, can often be expensive and time-consuming and can divert management's attention from the operation of the business. Unfavorable outcomes from claims or lawsuits could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We could also suffer ----- reputational harm, incur substantial monetary liability and be required to change our business practices or implement new systems or procedures which may be costly. Our business exposes us to claims for personal injury, death or property damage resulting from the use of the equipment we rent, for injuries caused in motor vehicle accidents in which our delivery and service personnel are involved and for other employee-related matters. Additionally, we could be subject to potential litigation associated with compliance with various laws and governmental regulations, such as those relating to employment, health, safety, security and other regulations under which we operate. Such litigation could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Our risk management, internal controls and compliance processes may fail to detect, prevent and address the risks we face and, as a result, we may be subject to regulatory penalties and reputational damage.
Subsubsection Text: We operate a decentralized business through hundreds of depots across Europe. Our internal control and compliance processes may not prevent all future breaches of law, accounting standards or our internal codes of conduct or to otherwise detect, prevent and address the various risks we face. We may experience instances of fraudulent behavior and dishonesty by our employees, contractors or other agents. Any failure to comply with applicable laws, regulations and other standards could lead to fines, legal proceedings, loss of operating licenses and reputational harm, which could in turn materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations or cash flows. This risk has increased as a result of our acquisitions and organic growth. In recent years, we have expanded the size and scope of our operations, including most significantly with the acquisition of Cramo in 2020 and we may continue to pursue such growth in the future, including with the Acquisition of the Target Group. As we expand the size and scope of our business, there is an increased risk that our internal controls may not mature at the same pace. Further, we may be unsuccessful in deploying internal control systems across all of our operating subsidiaries, and the internal control systems we put in place may be inadequate or ineffective in certain circumstances, particularly if we are confronted with risks that we have not fully or adequately identified or anticipated. Any such failures of our internal control systems could adversely impact our ability to monitor local operations and to deploy strategy across our business, could result in damage to our reputation or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Our business is subject to various legal and regulatory compliance risks, including those involving antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations and sanctions.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to various legal and regulatory requirements and risks in the countries in which we are commercially active or have local operations, involving compliance with antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery and anti-corruption laws, including the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the U.K. Bribery Act, and other regulations and economic sanctions programs, including those administered by the United Nations, the European Union, the United Kingdom and the United States. In addition, sanctions imposed by international organizations or individual nations, such as the sanctions imposed as a result of the military conflict in Ukraine, restrict or prohibit transactions with certain countries, and with certain companies and individuals identified on lists maintained by the United Nations, the U.S. federal government, the European Union, various EU member states, the United Kingdom and other local governments. While we have completed our plan to dispose of our interest in Fortrent, we remain subject, either directly or indirectly, to the additional or heightened risks associated with Russia's military conflict in Ukraine, including risks related to sanctions, export or capital controls and currency exchange limitations, including risks associated with our compliance with evolving international sanctions and potential reputational harm as a result. We may be unaware of, or unable to timely anticipate and prepare for, developments in such laws, regulations and sanctions, and any of our employees, agents, third-party providers or any other representatives involved in our business may take actions in violation of such laws and regulations, any of which may subject us to legal or regulatory action by governments or regulators. Despite the fact that we operate a compliance program, our existing policies, procedures, training, whistleblower hotline, IT tools, internal controls and risk management in relation to antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anticorruption laws and regulations and sanctions, may not be sufficient in order to prevent or detect inadequate practices, fraud and violations of law by our employees, agents, third-party providers or any other representatives. For example, in the case that any employees, agents, third-party providers or any other representatives with whom we cooperate receive or grant inappropriate benefits or use corrupt, fraudulent or other unfair business practices, we could be confronted with legal sanctions, penalties, loss of business as well as harm to our reputation. Due to the increasing complexity, size and geographical spread of our operations and the extent of our reliance on employees, agents, third-party providers or any other representatives, it may become more difficult to effectively monitor and control all of our activities, particularly in markets which are known to be more prone to bribery, corruption and other compliance risks. As a result, our policies, procedures, internal controls and risk management may not be adequate. ----- Failure to comply with antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations, sanctions laws and regulations could expose us and our officers, directors and employees to civil and criminal prosecution and penalties, enforcement actions, the imposition of fines or export or economic sanctions, loss of business or reputational damage, any of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to laws and regulations governing labor, compliance with which entails cost and risk, and labor disputes could disrupt our operations or lead to higher labor costs.
Subsubsection Text: Labor laws applicable to our business in the countries where we operate are extensive and compliance therewith entails significant cost and management attention, particularly so in Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, and Poland. In the countries in which we operate, labor laws generally provide for strong protection of employees' interests, which may be at odds with the interests of our business. In addition, many of our employees are members of unions or, based on applicable regulations, represented by works councils or other bodies. In many cases, we must inform, consult with and request the consent or opinion of union representatives or work councils in connection with managing, developing or restructuring certain aspects of our business. These labor laws and consultative procedures could limit our flexibility with respect to employment policy or economic reorganization and could limit our ability to respond to market changes efficiently. Even where consultative procedures are not mandatory, important strategic business decisions could be negatively received by some employees and employees' representative bodies, which could lead to labor actions that could disrupt our business. We are subject to the risk of labor disputes, which may disrupt our operations. Labor laws applicable to our business in certain countries, are relatively rigorous. In numerous cases, labor laws provide for the strong protection of employees' interests. In addition, some of our employees are members of unions or, based on applicable regulations, represented by work councils or other bodies. Additionally, many of our suppliers and customers have unionized work forces. Strikes, work-stoppages or work-slowdowns experienced by these suppliers or customers could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. See "Business—Employees."

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Changes in applicable law and regulations, or our material failure to comply with any of them, can increase our costs, expose us to liability and have other negative impacts on our business.
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to a wide variety of EU, national and local regulations. See "—Risks related to our Business— _Our international operations expose us to risks inherent to international business, any of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows." These laws and requirements address_ multiple aspects of our operations including, among other things, workplace health and safety, product safety, consumer rights and labor relations, and such laws and regulations differ from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In addition, changes in regulations could impact the ability of rental operators to utilize their equipment in certain types of projects, affecting the competitive landscape in those projects, as well as in other areas in which the nonconforming equipment may be redeployed. Changes in regulatory requirements, or any material failure to comply with them, can increase our costs, affect our reputation, limit our business, require significant management attention and materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to tax laws and regulations in each of the countries where we operate, which may be subject to change from time to time. Our effective tax rate in any given financial year reflects a variety of factors that may not be present in succeeding financial years and may be affected by the interpretation of the tax laws of the jurisdictions in which we operate or changes to such laws. Changes in tax laws and related interpretations and increased enforcement actions and penalties may alter the environment in which we do business. In addition, certain tax positions that we take are based on industry practice and external tax advice and/or are based on assumptions that involve a significant degree of judgment. If challenges to our tax positions (through audits or otherwise) were to be successful, we may be required to pay additional taxes, penalty charges and interest and may incur costs in defending litigation or reaching a settlement with the relevant tax authority. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We often rely on generally available interpretations of tax laws and regulations in the jurisdictions in which we operate. These positions may relate to tax compliance (especially in the current international tax context tending towards enhanced mandatory disclosure obligations), classification of income, treaty relief and withholding tax, franchise, gross receipts, payroll, property and income tax issues, including tax base. We cannot be certain that the relevant tax authorities agree with our interpretation of these laws. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our products or services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations and have a negative effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. -----

Subsection Title: Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: The national implementation of Council Directive (EU) 2022/2523 of 14 December 2022 on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational enterprise groups and large-scale domestic groups in the European Union may result in a higher tax burden for the Issuer's Group which could have a negative effect on the Issuer's Group's solvency and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: The Global Anti-Base Erosion Model Rules ("Pillar Two"), an initiative by the OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework, introduces a minimum level of taxation for multinationals with annual consolidated revenue of €750 million or more in at least two out of the four fiscal years immediately preceding the tested fiscal year. The aim of Pillar Two is to ensure that large multinational enterprise groups are subject to a minimum effective tax rate of 15% in each jurisdiction where they operate. The Council of the European Union (the EU) formally adopted Council Directive (EU) 2022/2523 (the "Pillar

Subsection Title: Two Directive"). The Pillar Two Directive was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 22 December
Subsubsection Text: 2022. EU member states need to implement the Pillar Two Directive in their national laws by December 31, 2023. The Netherlands implemented the Pillar Two Directive in the Dutch Minimum Tax Act 2024 (Wet minimumbelasting 2024), which entered into force on 31 December 2023. The Dutch Minimum Tax Act 2024 applies the IIR and QDMTT (as further discussed below) for accounting periods starting on or after 31 December 2023 and the UTPR (as further discussed below) for accounting periods starting on or after 31 December 2024. The primary mechanism for implementation of Pillar Two will be an income inclusion rule (the "IIR") pursuant to which a top-up tax is payable by a parent entity of a group if and to the extent that one or more constituent members of the group have been taxed below an effective rate of 15%. In the situation that no IIR applies at the ultimate parent entity level, a lower-level (intermediary) entity may be required to apply the IIR. A secondary fall back is provided by an undertaxed payment rule (the "UTPR") in case the IIR has not been applied. The UTPR can be applied by (i) limiting or denying a deduction or (ii) making an adjustment in the form of an additional tax. The Netherlands opted for option (ii) i.e. to make an adjustment in the form of an additional tax. In addition, and in line with the Pillar Two Directive, the Dutch Minimum Tax Act 2024 also includes a qualified domestic minimum top-up tax (the "QDMTT"). A jurisdiction that incorporates the QDMTT becomes the first in line to levy any top-up tax from entities located in its jurisdiction. It must compute profits and calculate any top-up tax due in the same way as the Pillar Two rules. Without a QDMTT, another jurisdiction as determined by the Pillar Two rules would be entitled to levy the top-up tax. The implementation of the Pillar Two Directive could result in a higher tax burden for the Issuer's Group which could have a negative effect on the Issuer's Group solvency and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: We do not currently control the Target Group and will not control the Target Group until the Completion Date.
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we do not, directly or indirectly, own any of the assets or shares comprising the Target Group. As a result, our ability to influence the Target Group's management is limited. In particular: - The Target Group's management is independent and may not operate the business of the Target Group until the Completion Date in the same way that we would. - Much of the information contained in this offering memorandum relating to the Target Group has been derived from public sources and, in the case of certain additional information relating to the Target Group, has been provided to us by the Seller and the Target Group, and we have relied on such information that is publicly available or was supplied to us in our preparation of this Offering Memorandum. - The Acquisition has required, and will likely continue to require, substantial time and focus from the Target Group's management, which could adversely affect their ability to operate the Target Group's business. - In addition, the Target Group's management will be required to manage the business of the Target Group under its own responsibility and in a manner that is in the best interest of the Target Group. - Prior to the Completion Date, the Target Group will not be subject to the covenants described in the section titled "Description of the Notes." As such, we cannot assure you that, prior to the Completion Date, the Target Group will not engage in activities that would otherwise have been prohibited by the Indenture had those covenants been applicable to such entities as of the Issue Date and any such non ----- compliance will not constitute a Default or Event of Default under the Indenture prior to the Completion Date. There can be no assurance that the Acquisition will be consummated as expected or at all.

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to enforce claims relating to a breach of the representations and warranties that the seller has provided under the Acquisition Agreement.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, the seller has given certain customary representations and warranties in the Acquisition Agreement related to their shares, the Target Group and the Target Group's business. There can be no assurance that we will be able to enforce such claims against the seller relating to breaches of such representations and warranties. The seller's liability with respect to breaches of its representations and warranties under the Acquisition Agreement is subject to significant exceptions and limitations. However, there can be no assurance that attempts to recover from the seller on breaches of representations and warranties will be successful and if amounts are recovered, they may be inadequate to cover any losses or damages resulting from the seller's breach. Moreover, even if we ultimately succeed in recovering any amounts from the seller, we may temporarily be required to bear these losses ourself.

Subsubsection Title: Certain of the Target Group's contracts with customers and suppliers contain change of control and anti-assignment provisions, which may allow its counterparties to terminate the contract under certain circumstances, such as the Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: Certain of the Target Group's contracts with customers and suppliers contain "change of control" and "antiassignment" provisions that require the Target Group to notify the counterparty of a potential change of control and, where necessary, to obtain their consent (through novation or otherwise) or contain language that could be interpreted as allowing, subject to certain conditions, the counterparty to terminate the contract. There can be no assurance that counterparties will give their consent nor that they will not seek to exercise termination rights in the future. If a substantial number of these contracts were terminated as a result of the Acquisition, the Target Group may be forced to enter into new contracts. Some of these new counterparties may have stronger bargaining positions than when the Target Group's existing contracts were originally negotiated. As a result, the Target Group may not be able to secure replacement contracts on commercially favorable terms or at all. Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, significant costs in connection with the Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, we have incurred and expect to continue to incur significant costs and expenses, including financial advisory, legal, tax, accounting, consulting and other advisory fees and expenses. In addition, we may incur significant one-time charges as a result of costs associated with the Acquisition. Furthermore, we may be required to increase our capital expenditure going forward as a result of the Acquisition. We are not currently able to quantify the exact amount of these charges or the period in which they will be incurred. While we have assumed that a certain level of expenses will be incurred in connection with the Acquisition, there are many factors that could affect the total amount or timing of the implementation expenses. There may also be additional unanticipated significant costs in connection with the Acquisition that we do not anticipate and may not be able to recoup. These costs and expenses could reduce the benefits and income we expect to achieve from the Acquisition.

Subsubsection Title: Our opportunity to conduct due diligence with respect to the Target Group was limited, and its due diligence may not have revealed all facts that may be relevant in connection with the Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: Before making investments, we conduct due diligence that we deem reasonable and appropriate based on the facts and circumstances applicable to each investment. The objective of the due diligence process is to identify attractive investment opportunities based on the facts and circumstances of an investment, to identify possible risks associated with that investment. When conducting due diligence, we typically evaluate a number of important business, financial, tax, accounting, environmental and legal issues in determining whether or not to proceed with an investment. Outside consultants, legal advisors, accountants and investment banks are involved in the due diligence process in varying degrees depending on the type of investment. Nevertheless, when conducting due diligence and making an assessment regarding an investment, we rely on resources available to us, including information provided by the target of the investment and, in some circumstances, third-party investigations. Instances of bribery, fraud, accounting irregularities, contingent liabilities and other improper, illegal or corrupt practices can be difficult to detect, and fraud and other deceptive practices can be widespread in certain jurisdictions. There may be liabilities that we failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing due diligence investigations into the Target Group in connection with the Acquisition. Following the Acquisition, we may learn of additional information about the Target Group that adversely affect its business, such as unknown or contingent liabilities ----- and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws. Any such liabilities, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. We cannot be certain that our due diligence investigation has revealed or highlighted all relevant facts (including fraud, bribery and other illegal activities and contingent liabilities) that may be necessary or helpful in evaluating the merits of investing in the Target Group. We also cannot be certain that our due diligence investigations will result in the investment in the Target Group being successful or that the actual financial performance of such investment will not fall short of the financial projections we used when evaluating that investment.

Subsubsection Title: We may face unexpected difficulties and costs in integrating the Target Group and may not be able to realize the anticipated synergies, operational efficiencies and cost savings from the Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: We may face unexpected difficulties and costs in integrating the Target Group into our business. The integration presents various challenges which may be difficult and costly to overcome and could prevent us from realizing the expected benefits of the Acquisition. The Target has experienced operational challenges in recent years, we may face further difficulties and costs associated with integrating the Target's business and bringing its operations in line with our own. We may also decide to dispose certain parts of the Target Group if we determine that such parts are no longer economically practical or desirable. The expected benefits of the Acquisition, and in particular, the anticipated synergies and growth opportunities, may not be realized in full (or at all) or may take longer to realize than planned. Further, the integration of the Target Group may require management capacity which is not available for the further development of our business. In addition, we may lose employees who are instrumental for the integration and further development of the business as well as customers, suppliers and agents. Finally, the integration of the Target Group may cost materially more than we expect. Any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: If the Acquisition does not complete, the proceeds of the Notes may be used for alternative purposes.
Subsubsection Text: We expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with cash on balance sheet, to: (i) repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B on the Issue Date, (ii) finance the Acquisition on the Acquisition Closing Date, and (ii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The Acquisition is not contingent on the Offering and the proceeds of the Offering will not be held in an escrow account prior to the completion of the Acquisition. If the Acquisition does not complete, the Notes will not be subject to a special mandatory redemption and the proceeds of the Offering will not be returned to Holders of the Notes ahead of redemption or maturity. Although we intend to apply a portion of the proceeds of the Notes as described under "Use of Proceeds" to finance the Acquisition on the Acquisition Closing Date, the closing of the Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including, in particular, the receipt of merger control and other regulatory clearances in multiple jurisdictions and there can be no assurance that such conditions will be met. If the Acquisition does not complete, that portion of the proceeds of the Offering earmarked for the Acquisition will instead be used by the Issuer for general corporate purposes, including debt refinancing, capital expenditures and other strategic bolt-on acquisitions. In such circumstances, the Issuer will not be under any obligation to return the proceeds of the Notes to Holders and the Issuer would apply the proceeds as set out above.
