Subsubsection Title: Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be denominated and payable in euros. If investors measure their investment returns by reference to a currency other than euro, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to investors when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which the investors measure the return on their investments.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: You may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer and the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries are organized outside the United States, and our business is conducted primarily outside the United States. All of the directors, managers and/or executive officers of the Issuer and the Guarantors are non-residents of the United States. In addition, as all of the assets of the Issuer, the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries and those of their directors and executive officers are located outside the United States, you may be unable to enforce judgments obtained in U.S. courts against them. Moreover, actions of the Issuer and the Guarantors may not be subject to the provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States. The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards, rendered in civil and commercial matters with the Netherlands, Belgium, Finland, Germany, Norway or Sweden. There is, therefore, doubt as to the enforceability in the Netherlands, Belgium, Finland, Germany, Norway and Sweden of U.S. securities laws in an action to enforce a U.S. judgment in such jurisdictions. In addition, the enforcement in the Netherlands, Belgium, Finland, Germany, Norway or Sweden of any judgment obtained in a U.S. court, whether or not predicated solely upon U.S. federal securities laws, will be subject to certain conditions. There is also doubt that a court in the Netherlands, Belgium, Finland, Germany, Norway or Sweden would have the requisite power or authority to grant remedies sought in an original action brought in such jurisdictions on the basis of U.S. securities laws violations. For further information see "Service of Process and Enforcement of Judgments."

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time. Changes in our credit rating could adversely affect our ability to obtain future financing and the value of the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed herein and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. Credit rating agencies continually review the ratings they have assigned to us and our debt instruments and no assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. Additionally, an increase in our gross indebtedness in connection with the Transactions could be viewed negatively by ratings agencies. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The interests of our ultimate principal shareholders may be inconsistent with the interests of holders of the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The interests of our ultimate principal shareholders, in certain circumstances, may conflict with your interests as holders of the Notes. Our ultimate principal shareholders have, directly or indirectly, the power, among other things, to affect our legal and capital structure and our day to day operations, as well as the ability to elect and change our management and to approve any other changes to our operations. For example, our ultimate principal shareholders could vote to cause us to incur additional indebtedness, to sell certain material assets or make dividend distributions, in each case, so long as the Indenture, the Existing Indenture, the EIB Facility, the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement, and the Intercreditor Agreement so permit. The interests of our principal shareholders could conflict with interests of holders of the Notes, particularly if we encounter financial difficulties or are unable to pay our debts when due. Our ultimate principal shareholders could also have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings, dividend distributions or other transactions that, in their judgment, could enhance their equity investments although such transactions might involve risks to the holders of the Notes. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: Unless and until Notes in definitive registered form, or definitive registered notes, are issued in exchange for book-entry interests (which may occur only in very limited circumstances), owners of book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of the Notes. The common depository (or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the global notes representing the Notes. Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the relevant global notes representing the Notes will be made to the paying agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, these payments will be credited to participants' accounts that hold book-entry interests in the global notes representing the Notes and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee, the Registrar, the Transfer Agent or any Paying Agent will not have any responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a book-entry interest in the Notes, you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and if you are not a participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which you own your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the Indenture. Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have any direct rights to act upon any solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be permitted to act only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if applicable, from a participant. There can be no assurance that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any matters or on a timely basis. Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until the relevant definitive registered Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. We cannot assure you that the procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The transfer of the Notes will be restricted, which may adversely affect their liquidity and the price at which they may be sold.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Guarantees have not been registered under, and we are not obliged to register the Notes or the Guarantees under, the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from, or a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and any other applicable securities laws of a state of the United States or other jurisdiction. See "Notice to Investors." We have not agreed to or otherwise undertaken to register any of the Notes or the Guarantees, and do not have any intention to do so. It is the obligation of the holders of the Notes to ensure that their purchase and any subsequent transfer of the Notes, as applicable, within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws. Any of these restrictions and requirements will limit the ability of investors to resell the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Trading in the clearing systems is subject to minimum denomination requirements.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be issued only in minimum denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. It is possible that the clearing systems may process trades which could result in amounts being held in denominations smaller than the minimum denominations. If definitive Notes are required to be issued in relation to such Notes in accordance with the provisions of the relevant global notes, a holder who does not have the minimum denomination or an integral multiple of €1,000 in excess thereof in its account with the relevant clearing system at the relevant time may not receive all of its entitlement in the form of definitive notes unless and until such time as its holding satisfies the minimum denomination requirement.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The market value of the Notes may be adversely affected if additional notes are considered to have original issue discount and are not distinguishable from the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer may issue additional notes ("Additional Notes") as described under "Description of the Notes." These Additional Notes, even if they are treated for non-tax purposes as part of the same series as the original Notes in some cases, may be treated as a separate series for US federal income tax purposes. In such a case, the Additional Notes may be considered to have original issue discount (or a greater amount of original issue discount) for US federal income tax purposes which may adversely affect the market value of the original Notes of such series. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Indenture will not be qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the "TIA") and will not incorporate or include and will not be subject to any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the trustee or conflicting interests of the trustee. See "Description of the Notes." -----

_An investment in the Notes involves risks. Before investing in the Notes, you should consider carefully the following risk factors and all information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Additional risks and uncertainties of which we are not aware or that we believe are immaterial may also adversely affect our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations or prospects. If any of these events occur, our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations or prospects could be materially and adversely affected, the Issuer may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Notes when due and you could lose all or part of your investment. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. See "Forward-Looking Statements" Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Notes offered hereby[(1)] ....................... 500.0 Acquisition consideration[(2)]...................... 414.5 Cash on balance sheet ........................ 23.0 Repayment in part of Existing Term Loan 100.0 B[(3)] ............................................................ Estimated fees and expenses[(4)] ................. 8.5 Total Sources ....................................** 523.0 **Total Uses ................................................** 523.0 (1) Represents the expected gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes, assuming the Notes are issued at par. (2) Represents the estimated consideration to consummate the Acquisition, which includes the base purchase price payable under the Acquisition Agreement of €164.8 million and repayment of certain indebtedness of the Target Group of €234.9 million, subject to adjustments as set out in the Acquisition Agreement, including for certain notified cash leakage items. (3) The Existing Term Loan B has an aggregate principal amount outstanding of €1,250 million as of December 31, 2023, a portion of which will be repaid and cancelled with the proceeds of the Offering in connection with the Transactions (subject to closing of the Offering), excluding any accrued and unpaid interest. (4) Represents underwriting fees and commissions, other estimated transaction costs and professional fees and expenses to be paid in connection with the Transactions. -----

We estimate that the aggregate gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes will be €500.0 million (assuming the Notes are issued at par). We expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with cash on balance sheet, to: (i) repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B, (ii) finance the Acquisition on the Acquisition Closing Date, and (ii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The Acquisition is not contingent on the Offering and the proceeds of the Offering will not be held in an escrow account prior to the completion of the Acquisition. If the Acquisition does not complete, the Notes will not be subject to a special mandatory redemption and the proceeds of the Offering will not be returned to Holders of the Notes ahead of redemption or maturity. If the Acquisition does not complete, that portion of the proceeds of the Offering earmarked for the Acquisition will instead be used by the Issuer for general corporate purposes, including debt refinancing, capital expenditures and other strategic bolt-on acquisitions. See "Risk Factors– If the Acquisition is not completed, the proceeds _of the Notes may be used for alternative purposes."_ The following table illustrates the estimated sources and uses of funds in connection with the Offering. Actual amounts may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including differences from our estimates of outstanding amounts of existing indebtedness to be repaid on the Issue Date, differences from the date of consummation of the Acquisition, as well as the difference between estimated and actual fees, expenses and commissions. For descriptions of our current and anticipated indebtedness following the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, see "Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements" and "Capitalization."_

Subsection Title: As of December 31, 2023 Transaction** **As Adjusted for the Actual** **Adjustments** **Transactions
Subsubsection Text: _in millions of euros_

(1) On an actual basis, represents cash and cash equivalents as of December 31, 2023. The as adjusted amount represents cash and cash equivalents as of December 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions as set forth under "Use of Proceeds." The as adjusted amount is presented as of December 31, 2023 and does not reflect the impact of any subsequent trading, working capital movements, capital expenditures or cash management. As of April 12, 2024, we had approximately €5.7 million of cash and cash equivalents on balance sheet. (2) Represents the aggregate principal amount of the Notes offered hereby. (3) Represents the aggregate principal amount of outstanding Existing Notes. (4) As of December 31, 2023, the EIB Facility was undrawn. The Issuer may draw amounts under the EIB Facility in the second quarter of 2024 to finance its investment in "green" electric equipment in accordance with its terms. (5) The actual amount represents the principal amount outstanding under the Existing Term Loan B, which will be partially repaid and cancelled in connection with the Transactions (subject to closing of the Offering). (6) As of December 31, 2023, the Existing Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn. The actual amounts outstanding on the Issue Date may vary as a result of fluctuations in working capital requirements. In addition, the Group has access to an overdraft facility of approximately €20.0 million. As of December 31, 2023, the overdraft facility was undrawn. As a result of subsequent trading, working capital movements, capital expenditures and cash management, we had approximately €16.7 million in drawings under our Existing Revolving Credit Facility and €0.8 million in drawings under our overdraft facility outstanding as of April 12, 2024. The as adjusted amount reflects management estimates of lease liabilities recognized in accordance with IFRS 16 "Leases" as adjusted for the Acquisition. (8) Represents the aggregate principal amount outstanding under (a) loans provided by the Parent described in "Shareholders and Related Party _Transactions" of €3.5 million, (b) local financing arrangements existing at the time of the acquisition and deferred consideration in connection_ with acquisitions completed in the year ended December 31, 2023 of €1.0 million and (c) the Trade Receivables Purchase Program of €54.8 million. See Note 16 of the FY 2023 Financial Statements for further detail on our financial liabilities. (9) Represents the aggregate principal amount of our total senior secured debt, other loans and lease liabilities recognized in accordance with IFRS 16 "Leases," but excluding overdraft facilities and other working capital arrangements. (10) On an actual basis, represents total equity on our consolidated balance sheet. The following table sets forth our cash and cash equivalents and capitalization as of December 31, 2023, on an actual basis and on an as adjusted basis to give effect to the Transactions. This table should be read in conjunction with "Use of Proceeds," "Management's Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations," "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements" and the Financial_ Statements appearing elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Except as set forth in the table below and notes thereto, there have been no other material changes to our capitalization since December 31, 2023. See also "Summary—The _Transactions" and "Use of Proceeds."_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading rental equipment specialist in Europe. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2023, with strong market positions across our main markets, including the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden and the second largest market share in each of Germany and Finland, in each case in terms of revenue in 2023. Our family-owned business started out of four garage boxes in the 1970s, and, under five decades later, has expanded into an industry leader with an extensive network of 764 depots in 18 European countries and a fleet of approximately 865,000 rental units as at December 31, 2023. In the year ended December 31, 2023 we generated €1,552.7 million in revenue and €554.5 million in Adjusted EBITDA. We serve customers in a variety of end-markets from civil engineering, industrial, construction and infrastructure to events and warehousing. Our core product offering includes general and specialist rental equipment alongside complementary products and services, enabling us to be a one-stop-shop for our customer base of both corporate clients (business-to-business) and individuals including craftsmen and retail clients (business-to-consumer). Our generalist division is mainly focused on the less cyclical 'fit-out, maintain and operate' market segments which use lighter equipment, while our specialist division is tailored to reach niche markets, such as site preparation, sanitation and access control. With approximately 865,000 rental items and significant bulk rental items in our rental fleet, with a purchase value of €3.0 billion as of December 31, 2023, we offer our customers access to one of the largest, widest, highest quality, and latest ranges of rental equipment and tools in Europe, for use in the fields of civil engineering (such as excavators, landscaping tools and dumpers), transport and handling (such as forklifts, cranes and trailers), climate control (such as heating and cooling systems, mobile boilers and air purifiers), and construction (such as construction site and installation products), among others. In addition to our vast range of tools and equipment available in our general depots, we provide a wide range of specialist products to niche markets primarily outside the construction industry, which we believe differentiates us from our competition and contributes to our strong brand recognition and greater diversification in terms of end-markets and product offering. Our specialist products range from HVAC systems and hoisting and lifting machines to mobile LED screens, temporary housing solutions, portable kitchens and heavy duty pumps. In parallel, we offer "do-ityourself" ("DIY") shop-in-shops across Europe, in partnership with DIY retailers where retail clients get access to primarily smaller equipment rental, which we believe further renders our business less cyclical than the traditional equipment rental business. Our corresponding service lines are geared towards further simplifying our customers' complex projects and include equipment service and maintenance, fuel management, training courses, project management and emergency assistance. In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain information for the following four geographic regions: - **_The Netherlands, which generated €373.0 million in revenue (representing 24.0% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; - **_Central Europe, consisting of Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which generated €554.8 million in revenue (representing 35.7% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; - **_Northern Europe, consisting of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which generated €576.5 million in revenue (representing 37.1% of our revenue, with Finland, Norway and Sweden generating 33% of our total revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; and - **_Other Countries, consisting of Italy and the United Kingdom, which generated € 48.4 million in revenue (representing 3.1% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, in the year ended December 31, 2023, we introduced segmental reporting in line with IFRS 8 "Operating Segments" for the first time. For additional information on our operating segments, see "Presentation of _Financial Information—Operating Segments."_ ----- We operate under two main brands: Boels Rental and Cramo. Boels Rental, the original brand of the Boels Group, is active in 12 countries in Central and Western Europe and we believe holds the strongest brand recognition across our portfolio. Cramo is active in the Nordic and the Baltic states, having been an independent leading rental company in Europe since 1953 before we acquired it in 2020. We operate a hub-and-spoke depot network, consisting of 684 general rental product depots and 80 specialist rental product depots as of December 31, 2023. We believe the decentralized structure of our network enables us to provide our products and services to our customers more conveniently and efficiently, while also supplying us with a diversified and local customer reach. In countries where we have an extensive depot network, such as the Netherlands and Germany, each depot is connected to a central hub location. In countries with larger markets, we have several hubs. Our depots generally stock smaller and more commonly used equipment, while the larger and less commonly used equipment is stored at our hubs, from where they can be easily shipped directly to a customer or local depot as needed. We believe this structure allows us to make more efficient use of our fleet and minimize transport movements. Through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions, we have expanded significantly over the past decade, both in terms of geographical reach and product offering. Since Pierre Boels Jr. became the CEO of Boels in 1996, we have executed a growth strategy based on product portfolio diversification and greenfield openings (including through international expansion), as well as through strategic bolt-on acquisitions executed to enter specific geographic areas (such as Germany, the UK and the Nordics) or specialist markets (such as industrial rental and traffic service). In 2020, we acquired Cramo, which positioned us as one of the largest equipment rental companies in Europe and complemented our geographic presence with an expansion into the Nordics and a further extension of our Central European offering. In addition, our 2022 acquisition of Eekels Pompen allowed us to expand our specialist product line by adding a high-quality offering of pump rentals to our customers with niche needs. The sharing economy is at the very heart of our business, and we believe that long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, driven by increased consumer preferences for rental instead of ownership. From our perspective, renting provides our customers with optimal availability, accessibility, and capital deployment, enabling them to reduce the amount of capital required for their operations, and, in turn, increase their capacity to deploy it for other investments. As such, our rental concept aims to help customers and their end-consumers meet their targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality and sustainability. We also believe that rental, compared to ownership, can contribute positively to the environment. Therefore, alongside the benefits that we strive to offer our customers, we also invest in products and solutions that align with our commitment to advancing sustainability in our and our customers' industries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our products is dependent on the industries in which our customers operate, the general economy and other factors. Many of the markets in which our customers operate are cyclical, with activity levels that tend to increase during periods of economic growth and decline during economic downturns. Demand for our products is correlated to conditions in these industries and in the general economy, including credit markets. Conditions in the markets in which our customers operate have an impact on both the utilization rate of our equipment and on prices. As demand increases, so do utilization rates, and we can then, subject to existing agreements with customers, choose to allocate equipment to customers who are willing to pay higher prices. When demand decreases, so do utilization rates, and we may reduce prices to preserve utilization levels. Demand can be affected by general economic trends and cycles that can have an impact (positive or negative) over a longer period and by short-term factors, such as seasonality, that affect the utilization rates and prices for a brief period. See "—Seasonality" below. In the past, we have managed the impact of medium and long-term trends by optimizing our rental fleet utilization rate, developing specialist activities focused on non-construction-related niche markets (such as the DIY market and the market for pumping equipment), diversifying our customer base by investing in a broad product range aimed at non-construction-related customers and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction such as the fit-out, maintain and operation phases. We seek to further manage such trends through adjustment of our investments in new equipment, increases or decreases in sales of our equipment and the management of our depot network. ----- During the year ended December 31, 2020, our business operations were affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Results differed by country depending on the severity of the government restrictions imposed and the severity of the pandemic. The decrease in our level of activity, in line with the decrease in market activity, was most notable in Italy, Austria, Belgium and the United Kingdom, where strict lockdown measures were imposed. In particular, as the entire events industry came to a halt, demand from the events end market sharply contracted. Conversely, the COVID-19 pandemic had a positive impact on certain aspects of our business, such as unit rentals and our DIY business. We deployed a number of measures to mitigate the effects of the pandemic on the Group, including lowering the planned levels of capital expenditure and introducing a significant cost savings program. See also "—Operating Expenses" below. After a decrease in demand in 2020 related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the equipment rental market rebounded in line with the construction market, which benefitted from household savings, low interest rates and a relaunch of governmental construction projects. As a result of the measures we implemented in response to the pandemic and the recovery in demand that followed, we were able to generate positive Reported EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2020, and we increased our sales across all of our geographic regions in the year ended December 31, 2021, most notably in Northern Europe, driven by general economic growth and several large projects. Since February 2022, the Russian invasion of Ukraine has destabilized the financial and commodity markets and resulted in an uncertain macroeconomic situation in Europe, causing inflation throughout the economy, to which central banks have responded with rises in interest rates, and volatile energy prices. Although we have continued to experience overall growth in revenue and Reported EBITDA, these macroeconomic factors could have an adverse effect on the demand for rental services and, paired with other economic developments, impact our operating expenses and the cost of new equipment we purchase for our rental fleet. In addition, we have historically had a shareholding in Fortrent, a 50% owned joint venture with Ramirent Oyj with operations in Russia, which was accounted for in our consolidated financial statements under the equity method. Considering the level of uncertainty due to the geopolitical situation resulting from the war in Ukraine and the high volatility of the Russian ruble, we fully impaired our investment in Fortrent in the year ended December 31, 2022, which included the write-down of the full amount of the carrying value of our investment in Fortrent amounting to €10.9 million, the depreciation of certain receivables amounting to €0.9 million and the reversal of the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €2.6 million for the period. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we reversed the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €8.5 million for the year. In November 2023, we disposed of our interest in Fortrent. Despite the uncertain macroeconomic environment in the year ended December 31, 2023, we increased our revenue and Reported EBITDA by 5.6% and 4.2%, respectively, compared to the year ended December 31, 2022, demonstrating the resilience of our business model. In this year, each of our geographic regions experienced strong performance, with revenue generated by the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe and Other Countries (primarily Italy and the United Kingdom) regions increasing by 9.6%, 7.9%, 1.3% and 5.1%, respectively, compared to the prior year. In addition, while the inflationary environment resulted in an increase in our operating expenses during the year, particularly repair and maintenance expenses, transportation expenses and housing expenses, we were able to preserve our margins through our ability to increase prices and generate operational efficiencies. In 2024, we intend to continue our efficiency measures to limit the impact of the potential slowdown in certain markets in which we operate and to preserve our margins.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are primarily affected by factors that impact the equipment rental industry generally, particularly cyclicality and economic conditions affecting the civil engineering, industry, construction and infrastructure sectors, and our management of capital expenditures in response to changes in the cycle. Our results of operations are also affected by the expansion of our rental network through acquisitions and the opening and closing of depots. Our results of operations can also be impacted by seasonality and currency fluctuations in our principal markets. These factors are described in greater detail below. For trends affecting our business and the markets in which we operate, see also "Risk _Factors," "Industry Overview" and "Business."_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Maskinutleie"), a Norwegian rental company. Established in 2008 as part of Backe, BAS Maskinutleie
Subsubsection Title: Capital Expenditures, Fleet Age and Equipment Disposals
Subsubsection Text: The management of our level of capital expenditure by increasing or decreasing the amount of investment in our fleet is an important factor in our results of operations and cash flow. Decisions about investment in new equipment are based on the condition and remaining useful life of our existing equipment as well as on our views of future demand, ----- legislative developments and the industry transition towards higher sustainability standards. During growth cycles, we may decide to invest in our fleet by replacing aging equipment or equipment at the end of its useful economic life and by expanding the total size of the fleet, which in turn also reduces the average age of the fleet. In downturns we have the ability to limit capital expenditures to the replacement equipment at the end of its useful economic life and let the average age of the fleet slowly increase in order to conserve cash. In the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, our Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) amounted to €489.0 million, €533.4 million and €356.0 million, respectively. In addition, we benefit from a well-invested fleet of rental equipment with an average fleet age significantly below the average useful life, which enables us to control our maintenance capital expenditure levels. As a proxy, we target annual maintenance capital expenditure of approximately 10% of our total fleet purchase value, less income generated from the sale of used equipment. Our Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) during the period under review related primarily to growth in activity, greenfield depot openings and the development of a diversified, sustainable fleet in order to position us to capitalize on growth opportunities. In the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, investments in our fleet increased the number of serialized rental items by approximately 6% and 5%, respectively, reflecting a broadening of our existing assortment and our continued investment in the Eco-label fleet. These investments resulted in a decrease in the weighted average fleet age from 55 months in 2021, to 54 months in 2022 and 52 months as of December 31, 2023. We determine the allocation of investments in our rental fleet by the type of equipment and the requirements of our business units. We divide our equipment into several subgroups, which enables us to analyze the best strategic deployment, combined with the best possible use for customers, the lowest downtime and the most efficient economies of scale. As of December 31, 2023, our rental units were comprised of approximately 39% tools, 27% energy and climate, 13% material handling, 12% site huts and site preparation, 5% earthmoving and 4% access equipment. We continue to invest in our fleet to remain on top of market developments and play a leading role in the energy transition within the equipment rental sector, with a substantial amount of our planned capital expenditure to be invested in our Eco-label and zero-emission fleet. Of our total energy powered fleet, approximately 81.6% is electric as of December 31, 2023 and we aim to increase this percentage to 85% by 2025. Our aim is to be the frontrunner in investing in innovative solutions to increase the sustainability of our fleet. In addition, we generate revenue from the sale of assets in our fleet. In a typical year, we target selling assets in our fleet with a resale value of between €50 million and €60 million and realizing a profit margin compared to book value of between 40% and 50% depending on market conditions. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we generated 3.7% of our revenue from the sale of assets in our fleet. We sell assets in our fleet when we believe that these assets have reached the end of their useful life because they have become obsolete or when the cost of maintaining them in proper condition for customer use is too high. We may also sell assets in our fleet before the end of their useful life if we believe a decline in demand in a given market is likely to last for a significant period of time or if otherwise economical to do so. For instance, in 2022, the market for used equipment showed a high level of volatility and, as a result, we decided to resell certain categories of equipment and purchase new and more sustainable substitute equipment. The following table sets forth certain information on our fleet for the years indicated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Maskinutleie"), a Norwegian rental company. Established in 2008 as part of Backe, BAS Maskinutleie
Subsubsection Text: serves the construction market from eight geographically spread locations. - On May 15, 2023, our subsidiary, Cramo AB, completed the acquisition of 100% of the shares of KraftX AB ("KraftX"). KraftX is a leading provider in Sweden for power generators and emergency power supply. The company offers customers full-service power provision, from designing of the required power solution, rental and installation, through to support during the rental period. From its nine outlets across Sweden, KraftX serves customers in the construction, infrastructure and energy industries. - On January 4, 2024 our subsidiary, Cramo AB, completed the acquisition of 100% of the shares of MG Rental AB ("MG Rental"). MG Rental is a Swedish company in the field of equipment rental and related product sales. Founded in 2007, it is based in the Stockholm area and operates out of six locations in the region. Acquisitions impact our financial position and results of operations in a variety of ways. We incur costs related to the acquisition of the business, including the purchase price of the acquired business and the costs of integrating the acquired business, including any costs related to the generation of synergies. We take a conservative valuation approach and typically aim to pay EBITDA multiples of less than 4.5x for bolt-on acquisitions. Acquisitions may result in the addition of new depots and the closure of existing ones as we seek to optimize our fleet management and streamline our operations, which can impact on our sales from one period to the next. In addition, acquisitions can impact the comparability of our results between periods as our results for the period during which an acquisition takes place include the results of the acquired business only from the date of completion of the acquisition and the full impact of the acquired business is only reflected in subsequent periods. In addition to expanding through acquisitions, we have also grown organically during the period under review by opening greenfield depots, which in turn, contribute to our sales. Along with acquired depots, greenfield depot openings enable us to continue to strategically expand our depot network to ensure geographic coverage for our customer base and serve additional customer demand. In the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, we added 16 greenfield depots (net increase of 1 depot) and 19 greenfield depots (net increase of 1 depot), respectively, which contributed to our sales growth over those periods, particularly in our general rental business. Between January 1, 2021 and December 31, 2023, after the integration of Cramo Central Europe, we estimate that more than 85% of our revenue growth has been organic.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Operating Expenses
Subsubsection Text: Our business, like that of all equipment rental groups, is capital-intensive with a predominantly fixed cost structure that principally relates to the depreciation of our equipment fleet, operating expenses (such as personnel charges) that are relatively fixed for short or long periods of time, and to a lesser extent, real estate lease expenses. Some of our operating expenses, such as depreciation of right-of-use assets (which are linked to real estate lease payments) and personnel charges in certain countries, may be linked to indices, including consumer price indices, which may increase due to inflation. The management of our costs is an important factor in our results of operations and cash flows. With our centralized fleet ownership model, we seek to deploy our fleet efficiently across our network to respond to actual or ----- anticipated increases and decreases in demand rather than renting additional equipment from third parties to then rent it out to our customers or duplicating investments in the same piece of equipment in different geographies, which could eventually lead to over-capacity. We also monitor our costs and margins on a regular basis. For example, when faced with more challenging market conditions in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, we implemented a significant cost savings program, which included cutting certain fixed costs, such as staff costs through utilizing temporary contracts to increase the flexibility of our workforce during the period, as well as rationalizing our investment program on our fleet to focus on added value. In addition, we use temporary staffing from local employment agencies and contractor agencies where additional resources are needed for specific projects or to fill a vacant position in the short term, which enables us to maintain flexibility in our staff costs. For example, from March 2020, following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, we reduced our usage of temporary staff to manage our costs. Following the recovery in market activity in 2021, we increased our usage of temporary staff, which, together with higher hourly rates reflecting labor market shortages and the inflationary environment, resulted in an increase in our temporary staffing costs. This increase is reflected in our employee benefits expense in our statement of profit or loss.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Seasonality
Subsubsection Text: Our operations experience a degree of seasonality in the first quarter of each year, driven principally by climatic conditions in our different regions of operations. For example, in certain regions in which we operate, demand in the construction and civil engineering markets tends to decrease in winter and during extended periods of inclement weather while increasing in the summer and during extended periods of mild weather. However, the seasonality impact on our results of operations is relatively small given regional variations in the response to working practices in connection with weather, as some regions experience little to no change in operational activity despite weather variations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Currency Fluctuations
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our revenue (68% for the year ended December 31, 2023), expenses and obligations are denominated in euro. However, our results of operations are affected by changes in foreign exchange rates, as we generate revenue and incur expenses in a variety of currencies other than our reporting currency, the euro, primarily the Swedish krona, the Norwegian krone, the Danish krone, the British pound, the Polish zloty, Swiss franc and the Czech koruna. We also have net investments in foreign subsidiaries that are exposed to currency translation risk. We use forward exchange contracts to hedge some of our currency risks, mainly related to our cash flows in Sweden, Norway, the United Kingdom, Poland and the Czech Republic. However, we cannot eliminate all of our currency risks, and any significant or prolonged adverse movements in exchange rates could have a negative impact on our profitability, cash flows and financial position. As of December 31, 2023 and, 2022, we had outstanding forward exchange contracts with a nominal value of €270 million and €250.3 million, respectively, and a market value of negative €8.2 million and positive €2.4 million, respectively. The effectiveness of our hedging strategy depends on various factors, such as the accuracy of our forecasts, the availability and cost of hedging instruments, and the volatility of the currency markets. We monitor our currency exposure and hedge ratios on a regular basis and adjust our hedging activities as appropriate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Interest Rate Fluctuations
Subsubsection Text: Our financial expenses are affected by the movement of interest rates, particularly EURIBOR, which is the reference rate for most of our floating rate borrowings. Our policy is to hedge a portion of our interest rate risk by entering into interest rate swaps, which effectively convert some of our floating rate liabilities into fixed rate liabilities. However, we are not fully hedged and we remain exposed to changes in interest rates on our unhedged borrowings and on the fair value of our interest rate swaps. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 90% of the outstanding principal amount of our Existing Term Loan B was hedged through February 2028 with €1,000 million in notional amount of interest rate swaps. Pursuant to such interest rate swaps, the fixed interest rate at which EURIBOR has been swapped is 0.44% until February 2026, 2.84% between February 2026 and February 2027, and 2.68% between February 2027 and February 2028. See also "—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks—Market Risks—Interest rate _risk."_ In the year ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, we experienced an increase in financial expenses due to the rise in EURIBOR. This resulted in higher interest payments on our unhedged floating rate borrowings. We monitor the interest rate environment and the effectiveness of our hedging strategy on a regular basis and may adjust our hedging position as appropriate to achieve our desired risk profile. We also consider the availability and cost of alternative sources of financing and the maturity profile of our debt portfolio to optimize our capital structure and liquidity position.

Subsection Title: Explanation of Key Line Items from the Statement of Profit or Loss
Subsubsection Text: The following is a summary description of certain line items from our statement of profit or loss presented in IFRS. For more information see "—Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates" and the notes to our consolidated audited financial statements. ----- Revenue_ is comprised of revenue from equipment rental, which reflects the fees paid by customers to rent equipment, and revenue from sales of goods and other services, which reflects the sale of rental equipment at the end of its useful economic life and the sale of certain items associated with the use of rental equipment and fees paid by customers for additional services relating to equipment rental. In the year ended December 31, 2023, revenue from equipment rental represented 69.2% of our total revenue and revenue from sales of goods and other services represented 30.8% of our total revenue. _Materials and services principally includes cost of rental and rental-sharing, cost of goods sold, repair and_ maintenance cost, logistics cost, property cost, office cost, marketing and sales cost and other external costs _Employee benefits expense relates primarily to the salaries, social security charges, pension charges and other_ personnel costs for our employees. _Depreciation and amortization expense principally includes depreciation of property, plant and equipment (fleet_ and non-fleet). Depreciation and amortization also includes depreciation of intangible assets (trademarks and customer relationships). Under IFRS 16, as a lessee, we account for right-of-use assets associated with leases and recognize amortization in respect thereof on a straight-line basis over the lease term. _Net impairment losses on financial assets includes losses on bad debts, net of change in provisions on current_ assets. _Other operating expenses represents the impairment of investments in joint ventures, which in the year ended_ December 31, 2022 reflected our impairment of our investment in Fortrent and in the year ended December 31, 2023 a partial reversal of this impairment. _Financial income primarily includes interest income on cash balances. Financial expense comprises interest charges on bank loans and hedging expenses. It also includes changes in the_ fair value of derivatives instruments and the interest cost related to the lease liability generated by the application of the IFRS 16 standard. _Income tax expense consists of current and deferred taxes calculated in accordance with the relevant tax laws in_ force in the jurisdictions in which we operate. As of December 31, 2023, the statutory corporate tax rate in the Netherlands was 25.8%. We are also subject to tax rates in the other countries in which we operate. _Share of profit of joint venture represents results from our investments in associates and joint ventures, which are_ accounted for under the equity method, except when the investment is classified as held for sale, in which case it is accounted for in accordance with IFRS 5.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Our revenue increased by 5.6% to €1,552.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €1,469.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to strong performance across all of our key geographic markets, as discussed further below. Additionally, we experienced organic growth as a result of the expansion of our depot network by 16 new locations, bringing the total to 764 as of December 31, 2023. Growth from acquisitions in the period included the acquisitions of BAS Maskinutleie, KraftX and Illumin8 Lights as well as the acquisition of the assets of Hyresbutiken and Safelift, which, together, added 20 depots to our network. Out of the total revenue increase of 5.6% during the year, we estimate that approximately 3.6% of the total was derived from organic growth. Revenue generated by the Netherlands region increased by 9.6% to €373.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, from €340.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to significant growth in both our specialist and general rental product portfolios and the increasing demand in the industrial end market. Revenue generated by the Central Europe region increased by 7.9% to €554.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, from €514.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to strong performance in the general rental product portfolio in Germany and the Czech Republic, with modest growth in Belgium, Austria and Luxembourg. Revenue generated by the Northern Europe region slightly increased by 1.3% to €576.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, from €569.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to the acquisitions of BAS Maskinutleie in Norway and Hyresbutiken and KraftX in Sweden as well as organic growth in the Baltic countries within the region, partially offset by the unfavorable impact of the exchange rate of each of the Swedish krona and the Norwegian krone against the euro. Revenue generated by the Other Countries region increased by 5.1% to €48.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, from €46.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to the acquisition of Illumin8 Lights in the United Kingdom, partially offset by the unfavorable impact of the exchange rate of the British pound against the euro. ----- _Operating Expenses_ Materials and Services Materials and services expenses increased by 2.9% to €550.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €535.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the increase in logistics costs, mainly attributable to the sales growth during the year, as well as higher prices for fuel, parts and services, and increased office expenses such as expenses relating to IT and digitalization. The increase of expenses was partly offset by a release of an accrual of €7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. Employee Benefits Expense Employee benefits expense increased by 11.3% to €456.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €410.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the average number of employees to 7,071 full time equivalents for the year ended December 31, 2023, from 6,515 full time equivalents for the year ended December 31, 2022, as well as growth in wages and salaries which were increased as a result of the inflationary environment over the year. In addition, we incurred higher expenses for temporary staff in the year ended December 31, 2023 due to an increase in the number of temporary staff and higher hourly rates for such temporary staff. Depreciation and Amortization Expense Depreciation and amortization expense increased by 11.0% to €362.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €326.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to the significant increase of capital expenditures during the year ended December 31, 2022 and the year ended December 31, 2023, reflecting investments in our rental fleet and acquisitions. See "—Capital Expenditures" below. Net Impairment Losses on Financial Assets Net impairment losses on financial assets increased by 8.1% to €4.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €3.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to slightly deteriorated aging of outstanding receivables and changes in the expected credit losses, which increased loss allowances of trade and other receivables. Other Operating Income/(Expenses) In the year ended December 31, 2023, other operating income/(expense) amounted to an income of €8.5 million, compared to an expense of €11.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, reflecting the write-down of our investment in Fortrent in the year ended December 31, 2022 and subsequent partial reversal in the year ended December 31, 2023. See "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Economic Conditions" for additional information. _Financial Income and Expense_ Our net financial expense increased significantly from a net expense of €71.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to a net expense of €104.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, primarily due to an increase in interest expense in the year ended December 31, 2023 as a result of an increase in EURIBOR, which impacted the rate at which interest accrued on our unhedged floating-rate indebtedness, and an increase in our gross indebtedness over the year. We benefitted from the effectiveness of our interest rate hedging policy, which partially mitigated the impact of the increase in EURIBOR over the year. _Income Tax Expense_ Our income tax expense increased to €18.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €14.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, despite the lower earnings before tax in 2023. This is primarily due to the recognition of deferred tax assets for carry forward losses from previous years in Germany and Finland in the year ended December 31, 2022. _Profit for the year_ As a result of the factors discussed above, we recorded a profit of €69.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, a decrease of 31.3%, compared to a profit of €100.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to year ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Our revenue increased by 11.6% to €1,469.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €1,317.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to strong performance across all of our key markets and an increase in prices, as discussed further below. The vast majority of our revenue growth in 2022 was organic as a result of the expansion of our depot network by 19 new locations, bringing the total to 743 as of December 31, 2022. Growth from acquisitions in the period was limited to the acquisition of Eekels Pompen in the year ended December 31, 2022, which also added three depots to our network. Revenue generated by the Netherlands region increased by 17.8% to €340.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, from €288.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to growth in sales from our general rental activities, strong growth in sales from specialist rental activities (including from the acquisition of Eekels Pompen), as well as an increase in sales to the industrial end market. Revenue generated by the Central Europe region increased by 9.9% to €514.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, from €467.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to sales growth across all countries within the region, with notable growth in Eastern European markets, while Belgium and Luxembourg showed stable performance under tougher economic circumstances during the year. Revenue generated by the Northern Europe region increased by 9.8% to €569.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, from €518.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to strong performance and growth in sales across all countries in the region, supported by investment in our fleet in both years. Sweden and Finland, our two largest markets within the region, experienced notable growth, with Sweden particularly supported by large industrial projects. Despite the uncertainty and geopolitical developments in the region, the Baltic countries showed the strongest growth in the Northern Europe region. In addition, Norway experienced significant growth in sales compared to the prior year, despite a stronger competitive environment. Revenue generated by the Other Countries region increased by 8.7% to €46.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, from €42.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This was driven by strong economic conditions in the construction industry in the United Kingdom and Italy, respectively, in 2022, following the market recovery in 2021 after the COVID-19 pandemic. _Operating Expenses_ Materials and Services Materials and services expenses increased by 12.1%, in line with the increase in sales during the year, to €535.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €477.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the increase in logistics costs, mainly attributed to the sales growth during the year, as well as higher prices for fuel, parts and services and certain rental related services. Employee Benefits Expense Employee benefits expense increased by 12.3%, in line with the increase in sales during the year, to €410.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €365.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the average number of employees to 6,515 full time equivalents for the year ended December 31, 2022, from 6,329 full time equivalents for the year ended December 31, 2021, to support the growth of our business and annual salary increases driven by inflation during the year. Depreciation and Amortization Expense Depreciation and amortization expense increased by 7.7% to €326.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €303.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to the significant increase of capital expenditures in tangible and intangible assets in the year ended December 31, 2022, which resulted in increased depreciation of property, plant and equipment. See "—Capital Expenditures" below. Net Impairment Losses on Financial Assets Net impairment losses on financial assets increased by 15.6% to €3.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €3.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to growth in activities and sales, resulting in an increase in expected credit losses. ----- Other Operating Expenses We recognized other operating expenses of €11.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to nil in the year ended December 31, 2021, reflecting the write-down of our investment in Fortrent. See "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Economic Conditions" for additional information. _Financial Income and Expense_ Our net financial expense increased from a net expense of €70.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to a net expense of €71.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to an increase in interest expense in 2022 as a result of an increase in EURIBOR, which impacted the rate at which interest accrued on our floating-rate indebtedness, and an increase in our gross indebtedness compared to 2021. This increase was partially offset by the repricing of our Existing Term Loan B in June 2021, which resulted in lower interest rate margins in the second half of 2021. We also benefitted from the effectiveness of our interest rate hedging policy, which partially mitigated the impact of the increase in EURIBOR over the period. _Income Tax Expense_ Our income tax expense decreased by 32.4% to €14.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €21.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to the recognition of deferred tax assets previously not recognized for carry forward losses from previous years in Germany and Finland in the year ended December 31, 2022, partially offset by an increase in current tax expenses for the year ended December 31, 2022. _Share of Profit of Joint Venture_ Our share of profit of joint venture was nil in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €1.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, reflecting our decision to classify our investment in the Fortrent joint venture as assets held for sale for the year ended December 31, 2022. See "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Economic _Conditions" for additional information. Profit for the year_ As a result of the factors discussed above, we recorded a profit of €100.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, an increase of 25.3% compared to a profit of €80.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with the information set out in "Presentation of Financial and Other Information" and the Financial Statements included elsewhere herein. This discussion includes forward-looking statements that, although based on assumptions we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied herein. See "Forward-Looking Statements" and "Risk Factors" for a discussion of the risks, uncertainties and assumptions associated with these statements._

Our primary sources of cash are cash flows from operating activities and borrowings under our debt facilities, including the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and our Trade Receivables Purchase Program, and we may from time to time issue debt securities. Our principal uses of cash have been, and we expect will continue to be, operating expenses, capital expenditures, working capital requirements, acquisitions and debt service payments. As of December 31, 2023, our cash and cash equivalents amounted to €41.7 million. We currently have, and following the completion of the Transactions, will continue to have, substantial indebtedness. See "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements." As adjusted for the Transactions, as of December 31, 2023, we would have had outstanding €1,938.1 million of total net debt. See "Capitalization." Our indebtedness levels may have important negative consequences for noteholders. See "Risk Factors." There are also limitations on our ability to obtain additional debt financing. See "Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness." Further, any additional indebtedness that we do incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available to make payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby. Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including our obligations under the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and our ability to generate cash, which, to a certain extent, is subject to general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, as well as other factors discussed in "Risk Factors," many of which are beyond our control. ----- We believe that, based on our current level of operations, our cash on hand, cash flows from operating activities and the availability of borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and the Trade Receivables Purchase Program will be sufficient to fund our operating expenses, capital expenditures and debt service payments for at least the next twelve months.

The following is a discussion of our cash flows from operating activities, cash flows (used in)/from investing activities and cash flows (used in)/from financing activities for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023. The following table presents a summary of our cash flows for the years indicated.

Subsubsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: _Net cash from operating activities_ Net cash from operating activities decreased by 34.4% to €375.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €572.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to a significant increase in changes in working capital, from an impact of positive €84.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to an impact of negative €120.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This increase was primarily due to a large delivery of new fleet in the fourth quarter of 2022, for which payment was made in the year ended December 31, 2023. _Net cash used in investing activities_ Net cash used in investing activities slightly decreased by 3.0% to €535.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to €551.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to a decrease in investments in our rental fleet and other assets which was partially offset by an increase in acquisitions. Gross Capital Expenditure decreased to €543.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from €551.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, of which cash used for acquisitions amounted to €54.6 million and €17.8 million, respectively. _Net cash (used in)/from financing activities_ Net cash (used in)/from financing activities amounted to an inflow of €183.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to an outflow of €65.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to the issue of €400 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Notes, in combination with the use of the Trade Receivables Purchase Program, established in June 2023, in an amount of €54.8 million. This was partially offset by a repayment of €200 million of the Term Loan B and a €13.0 million distribution of dividends to the Parent in March 2023, of which €6.8 million was paid in cash and the remainder was settled with outstanding receivables from related parties.

Subsubsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to year ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: _Net cash from operating activities_ Net cash from operating activities increased by 24.6% to €572.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €459.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to growth in activity and revenue and a resulting increase in profit from ordinary operations. Changes in working capital increased from an impact of positive €26.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to an impact of positive €84.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to the high level of capital expenditure incurred in the fourth quarter of 2022, which was only paid in 2023. ----- _Net cash used in investing activities_ Net cash used in investing activities increased by 56.0% to €551.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €353.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to an increase in investments in our rental fleet and other assets, in line with a strong market demand and as a consequence of delays resulting from certain supply chain constraints in 2021 and the acquisition of a number of smaller specialist rental companies, such as Eekels Pompen. Gross Capital Expenditure increased to €551.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, from €356.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, of which cash used for acquisitions amounted to €17.8 million and nil, respectively. _Net cash used in financing activities_ Net cash used in financing activities decreased by 66.3% to €65.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €194.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to the repricing of our syndicated debt facilities in 2021, which included a full repayment of a €238 million Term Loan A and an increase in the notional amount of the Existing Term Loan B by €115 million.

Our capital expenditures consist principally of investments in fixed assets (in particular, our equipment fleet). We determine and allocate our budget for capital expenditures on an annual basis and update it on a regular basis throughout the year based on market developments. Decisions about investment in new equipment are based on the condition and remaining useful life of our existing equipment as well as on our views of future demand, legislative developments and the industry transition towards higher sustainability standards. During growth cycles, we may decide to invest in our fleet by replacing aging equipment or equipment at the end of its useful economic life and by expanding the total size of the fleet, while in downturns, we have the ability to limit capital expenditures to the replacement of equipment at the end of its useful economic life in order to conserve cash. See also "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures, _Fleet Age and Equipment Disposals."_ We define Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) as purchases of property, plant and equipment plus purchases of intangible assets shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows and Gross Capital Expenditure as Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) plus acquisitions shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows. However, other companies may present Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and Gross Capital Expenditure differently than we do. We present Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and Gross Capital Expenditure as additional information because we believe it is helpful to investors in highlighting trends in our business. Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and Gross Capital Expenditure are not measures of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. See "Presentation of Financial _Information—Non-IFRS Measures" for additional information._ The table below sets forth certain information on our capital expenditure for the years indicated.

Our Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to €543.6 million, of which €489.0 million was from Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and €54.6 million related to acquisitions. Gross Capital Expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2023 primarily reflected investments in our rental fleet, investments in software and the acquisitions of BAS Maskinutleie, KraftX and Illumin8 Lights as well as the acquisition of the assets of Hyresbutiken and Safelift in the year ended December 31, 2023. See "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations— _Capital Expenditures, Fleet Age and Equipment Disposals" for additional information._ Our Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2022 amounted to €551.2 million, of which €533.4 million was from Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and €17.8 million related to acquisitions. Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2022 primarily reflected increased investments in our rental fleet and other assets and the acquisition of Eekels Pompen. ----- Our Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2021 amounted to €356.0 million, all of which was from Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions). Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2021 primarily reflected investments in rental fleet and other assets. Given the macroeconomic headwinds in certain of our key markets, particularly Sweden and Finland, and the relatively high level of capital expenditures in the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, we aim to reduce our level of capital expenditure (excluding acquisitions) in the year ended December 31, 2024, targeting less than 25% of revenue in the medium term. See "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures, Fleet Age and _Equipment Disposals."_

For detail on our definition of Reported Free Cash Flow and Free Cash Flow, see "Summary Consolidated _Financial and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As Adjusted Financial Information" and_ "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures."

We define net debt as gross debt (representing long- and short-term loans with financial institutions and bonds (both excluding amortized costs), lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts) and the nominal amount of other loans) less cash and cash equivalents. Net debt presented as additional information because we believe that netting cash against debt may be helpful to investors in understanding our financial liability exposure. However, other companies may present net debt differently than we do. Net debt is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. See "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures" and "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS _Measures—Net Debt" for additional information._ The following table presents a reconciliation of net debt to amounts included in the consolidated balance sheet as of the dates indicated.
