(2) As of December 31, 2023, bank loans (excluding amortized costs) comprised €1,250.0 million under the Existing Term Loan B and nil drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. A portion of the proceeds of the Offering will be used to repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B. See "Use of Proceeds." (3) As of December 31, 2023, other loans comprised (a) loans provided by the Parent of €3.5 million (b) deferred consideration in connection with acquisitions completed in the year ended December 31, 2023 of €1.0 million and (c) the Trade Receivables Purchase Program of €54.8 million. (4) Represents the carrying amount of lease liabilities presented on our consolidated statement of financial position. Our lease portfolio consists of real-estate leases, vehicle leases and the rental of equipment. (5) Net debt/Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as net debt divided by Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant year, unless otherwise indicated. For the definition and reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA, see "—EBITDA" above. Net debt increased by €266.5 million to €1,938.1 million as of December 31, 2023, from €1,671.6 million as of December 31, 2022, primarily due to investments in our rental fleet and other assets as well as acquisitions during the year, with Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2023 amounting to €543.6 million compared to €551.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, partially offset by the growth in Adjusted EBITDA in the year. Based on Adjusted EBITDA for year ended December 31, 2023 of €554.5 million, the ratio of net debt to Adjusted EBITDA was 3.5x as of December 31, 2023. ----- Net debt increased by €47.6 million to €1,671.6 million as of December 31, 2022, from €1,624.0 million as of December 31, 2021, primarily due to increased investments in our rental fleet and other assets, with Gross Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2022 amounting to €551.2 million compared to €356.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, partially offset by the growth in Adjusted EBITDA in the year. Based on Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2022 of €523.8 million, the ratio of net debt to Adjusted EBITDA was 3.2x as of December 31, 2022.

As of December 31, 2023, we are a party to various customary off-balance sheet arrangements, including guarantees given to financial institutions and certain commitments relating to capital expenditures, which primary relate to rental fleet orders outstanding as of December 31, 2023. The bank guarantees primarily relate to contracts for the lease of real estate. See note 33 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements.

The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of revenues, expenses, assets and liabilities, and the accompanying disclosures, at the end of the reporting period. These estimates and judgements are subject to change based on experience and new information. The financial statement areas that required significant estimates, judgments and assumptions in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements are summarized in notes 2.4 and 3 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements, notes 2.4 and 3 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements and notes 1.7, 2 and 3 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements .

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Title: Market Risks
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to market risk mainly as a result of financial instruments denominated in a foreign currency (foreign currency risk) and our exposure to interest bearing liabilities such as loans (interest rate risk). ----- _Foreign currency risk_ Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates relates primarily to our operating activities (when revenue or expenses and their resulting receivable/payable positions are denominated in a foreign currency). The majority of our revenue (68% for the year ended December 31, 2023), expenses and obligations are denominated in euro. However, we are exposed to currency risk mainly from our cash flows generated in Sweden, Norway, the United Kingdom, Poland and the Czech Republic. We also incur currency risk on the net investment in our operations in Sweden, Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and the United Kingdom. Our management has determined, based on a risk assessment, to hedge some of these currency risks by using certain forward-exchange contracts. This policy is intended to protect our financial position. For additional information on foreign currency risk and our foreign exchange contracts, see note 32 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements. _Interest rate risk_ We are exposed to interest rate risk because entities in the Group borrow funds at both fixed and floating interest rates. Our policy is to have a fixed/floating interest rate profile on the interest-bearing liabilities which is fitting with the nature of our assets. Hedging activities are evaluated regularly to align with our hedging policy. As most of the interestbearing liabilities have a floating interest rate, we have contracted certain interest rate swaps so that we receive floating interest and pay fixed interest. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 80% of the outstanding principal amount of our Existing Term Loan B was hedged through February 2028 with €1,000 million in nominal amount of interest rate swaps outstanding. For additional information on interest rate risk and our interest rate swaps, see note 32 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Title: Credit Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that we face when a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations. Credit risk mainly arises on cash and cash equivalents and receivable balances from trade and other receivables and other longer-term receivables. As of December 31, 2023, amounts exposed to credit risk include trade receivables amounting to €254.0 million, other receivables amounting to €50.6 million and cash and cash equivalents amounting to €41.7 million. As of December 31, 2022, amounts exposed to credit risk include non-current loans receivable amounting to €2.5 million, trade receivables amounting to €210.4 million, other receivables amounting to €31.1 million and cash and cash equivalents amounting to €17.2 million. Substantially all of our cash at banks is held with high credit quality financial institutions with credit ratings of A(S&P) or higher. As of December 31, 2023, no significant increase in credit risk has occurred with respect to the above noted noncurrent loans receivable. The expected credit losses for these balances were computed based on a 12-month expected credit loss and was estimated to be remote. For additional information on credit risk, see note 32 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements and note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Title: Liquidity Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we encounter difficulty in meeting our financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. Our approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that we will meet our liabilities when they are due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to our reputation. We manage our liquidity risk by maintaining sufficient cash and available credit facilities through the continuous monitoring of future and actual cash flows and by matching the maturity profiles of our financial assets and liabilities. For additional information, see note 32 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements. -----

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various market and financial risks, including foreign currency risk, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. These risks and the manner in which we seek to mitigate them are summarized below and described in more detail in note 32 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements.

For detail on our definition of Reported EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA, see "Summary Consolidated Financial _and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As Adjusted Financial Information" and "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures."_

The equipment rental industry plays a key role in the value chain of significant and economically important endmarkets, including maintenance, infrastructure, construction, energy and energy transition as well as consumer-facing sectors. Equipment rental companies provide customers with a range of products from larger equipment such as aerial work platforms, excavators, earthmoving equipment and forklift trucks, to smaller equipment such as power saws, power generators, scaffolding, ladders, and small pumps. Rental companies are also active in rental markets for containers, sanitation, portable kitchens and trailers. In addition to providing equipment, many rental companies provide holistic support for their customers through a range of services such as maintenance, in-service inspection, repair, transportation, storage, compliance with health and safety regulations, insurance and training on the proper use of the equipment. The provision of holistic support along with equipment rental is becoming increasingly important for rental companies as large end-customers incrementally outsource those previously in-house services. Primary customers typically include engineering, procurement, and construction ("EPC") contractors, industrial companies, government entities, infrastructure facilitators, utilities, maintenance operators, construction companies as well as homeowners, craftsmen and small and medium-sized enterprises. A large portion of the equipment rental customer base comes from the industrial and the commercial construction sectors. Commercial construction rentals are geared towards contractors conducting new-build and repair and renovation work who rent a wide range of equipment from power tools to backhoes. Industrial rentals are geared towards businesses conducting routine plant maintenance as well as for projects that require specialized tools such as welding equipment, power washing equipment, forklifts and other material handling equipment. Additionally, craftsmen as well as events and media companies have increasingly relied on rental solutions for operational equipment such as power generators, portable toilets and specialized craft equipment. In parallel, specialized rental equipment are supplied for specific projects, such as transfer pump, site hut, security gate, site safe and industrial lighting. Increasingly, rental equipment is also requested in connection with the response to emergency situations and incidents, such as natural disasters and refugee crises. We operate depots in 23 countries with our key geographic markets being Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Finland, Norway and Belgium. The dynamics of the customer and geographic end markets we serve vary significantly, as described below under "—Our Key Geographic Markets."

Subsection Title: Customer Value Proposition and Equipment Rental Business Model
Subsubsection Text: The long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, supported by fundamental tailwinds as customers are increasingly renting (i.e., outsourcing) rather than owning operational equipment. The shift to outsourcing is also driven by structural macroeconomic and regulatory factors that increase the attractiveness of renting equipment. The advantages of equipment rental over ownership for companies includes: - **Cost and business flexibility: Equipment rental increases business flexibility by allowing companies to transform fixed costs into variable costs incurred on an as needed basis. In contrast, equipment ownership entails a higher proportion of fixed costs and includes a number of ongoing costs in addition to the cost of initial purchase, such as insurance, maintenance, in service inspection, repair, transportation and storage and depreciation costs, which tend to increase over the life of the equipment. Equipment rental also reduces the amount of capital required in comparison to purchasing equipment, reducing a customer's exposure to credit market conditions and preserving capital for other investments, all of which enables customers to focus on the core parts of their business. - **Equipment access and availability: Equipment rental gives customers access to a comprehensive range of equipment, including the latest generation of technology, allowing them to select the most appropriate piece of equipment for the task at hand, which can improve safety, efficiency and quality. Equipment rental also allows customers to benefit from a number of ancillary services provided by rental companies, including training, safety testing, regulatory compliance, logistical support and consultation on equipment selection. In addition, when renting from rental companies with a large network of branches, customers are able to optimize their logistics flows to and from their worksites. ----- - **Climate change awareness: Rental of equipment is part of the larger developing circular economy, where equipment is rented by many customers over its life cycle allowing for better utilization rates while the rental company maintains control over the equipment's good functioning order through a program of maintenance and regular inspections. Equipment rental allows customers to be a part of this circular economy and reduce their carbon emissions by reducing the overall size of their equipment fleet, limiting their carbon footprint to the use of such equipment only and utilizing newer and more sustainable equipment compared with company-owned equipment. - **Health and safety: Equipment rental generally enhances the operational safety of customers by providing modern, well-serviced equipment. In addition, equipment rental allows customers to more easily benefit from the mechanization and automation of many of their operations, including hazardous tasks, by providing access to and training on specialized equipment, such as power access tools. In the European rental market, the key performance criteria mentioned by rental equipment customers consist of the availability of equipment, equipment quality, location, flexibility, and safety, which can be more important than price in certain markets. Small and medium enterprises ("SME") tend to place orders via sales representatives or through direct engagement with a depot representative, while medium to large companies are increasingly ordering through online platforms. On average, most rental equipment clients use two or more equipment rental companies primarily as a result of assortment, availability and price differences for each product segment. The economic value-add of a rental equipment provider is derived from the benefit from a lower break-even period and enhanced returns compared to regular equipment purchasers as a result of more efficient fleet utilization, benefit from centralized procurement contracts resulting in lower purchase prices, centralized and lower annual repair and maintenance costs, benefit from higher resale value after the useful life and equipment financing benefits due to economies of scale.

Subsubsection Title: Growth of equipment rental market
Subsubsection Text: GDP growth and construction market activity levels Growth in the equipment rental industry tends to be closely correlated to growth in the construction market, as the equipment rental industry generally forecasts growth levels in the construction market and responds to changing demand related thereto. The construction market is composed of three primary subsectors: (i) new residential and non-residential building, (ii) renovation and maintenance, and (iii) infrastructure (which includes transportation infrastructure and telecommunications, as well as energy and water works). While the construction industry as a whole tends to be cyclical, within the overall construction market, individual end markets have differentiated growth patterns and dynamics. For ----- example, the renovation and maintenance end market tends to be less cyclical, as customers tend to reduce or delay new projects in favor of renovation and maintenance work during periods of economic downturns. In addition, construction activity can vary significantly between different regional and local markets, which provides further balance and diversification to demand for rental equipment. According to the 2023 ERA Market Report, the Eurozone construction downturn extends as housing woes deepen, with the aggregate reduction in the Eurozone mainly attributable to a marked deterioration in activity in Germany and to a lesser degree France. At the sector level, the contraction in Eurozone construction activity was led by residential construction. The reduced demand for construction materials and other inputs reduced the pressure on supply chains and also eased inflationary pressures in the sector. However, tighter financial conditions would spell more trouble for the residential construction segment, with the July 2023 forecast expecting a decline of 3.7% in 2023, followed by a further fall of 1.4% in 2024. The European rental market is expected to slow down from a strong growth of 7.5% in 2022 to 2.7% in 2023. However, high machinery purchase prices and uncertainty about the economic environment is shifting demand from ownership to rental, which drives the outperformance of the rental market over the construction sector. Nevertheless, investments in infrastructure projects supported by the EU's Recovery and Resilience Fund should support the rental market going forward. Thus, a rebound in 2025 is expected with rental growing by 4.6%. In the longer term, growth of the rental market is further supported by the diversification of the industry from construction. Furthermore, investments in green projects will also benefit the sector growth. We have a proven track record of minimizing the impact of economic trends on our business by diversifying our specialist activities across non-construction related niche markets and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction market, such as the fit out, maintain, and operation phases. We also operate in multiple end markets in various countries, which enhances our resilience and reduces our exposure to market volatility, macroeconomic developments and specific events. Approximately 54.8% of our sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 come from non-construction customers, indicating relatively modest exposure to the construction sector's cyclical volatility. Furthermore, our exposure to the construction end-market includes a large part of less cyclical businesses such as fit out, maintain and operation, which account for more than half of the construction-related sales. Urbanization Urbanization is a key driver of demand for rental services, as the population shift towards cities increases the need for infrastructure development and maintenance. This leads to higher expenditures on large infrastructure projects, which typically require a wide range of equipment and tools that are more cost-effective and convenient to rent than to buy.

Subsubsection Title: Increasing market penetration
Subsubsection Text: The European rental market has experienced a steady increase in its rental penetration rate over the past years, reflecting the growing preference of customers to rent rather than buy equipment and tools. The rental penetration rate varies across countries, with Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Belgium, Ireland, France, Denmark and the UK being relatively the most mature markets, and Eastern European countries having lower rental penetration rates, which offer significant growth potential. Increased benefits of rental versus ownership One of the key drivers for the increase in rental penetration rates is the enhanced value proposition of renting compared to owning equipment. Renting equipment offers access to modern equipment, flexibility, and cost-efficiency, as it reduces capital expenditure requirements, fixed costs of ownership, and residual value risk, while allowing customers to adapt to changing demand and project requirements. Moreover, large rental companies can leverage their scale and expertise in purchasing, maintenance, and repair of equipment, offering a competitive advantage over smaller companies that lack the financial resources for large fleet investments. Renting equipment also becomes more attractive for customers in an uncertain or declining economic environment, as customers in general prefer to opt for flexibility and avoid the burden of ownership and opt for more flexible and variable solutions. Decarbonization and ESG initiatives Another key driver for the increase in rental penetration rates is the growing pressure to decarbonize and adopt ESG initiatives across various industries. Renting equipment is inherently part of the circular economy, as it maximizes the utilization and lifespan of equipment, while ensuring its proper functioning and safety through regular maintenance and inspections. Renting also reduces the operational complexity and waste associated with owning equipment, as it requires fewer procurement, logistics, and disposal activities, while optimizing the carbon footprint. For instance, the building and construction industry, which is a significant contributor to global carbon emissions, can benefit from renting more energyefficient and ESG-friendly equipment from rental companies. As market participants require more energy efficient and ----- sustainable equipment, they are expected to rely more heavily on rental companies to provide the latest generation of equipment. Growing demand for digital solutions and add-on services Rental penetration rates are expected to be driven by the rising demand for digital solutions and add-on services that complement and enhance the rental offer and customer experience. Digitalization and technological advances enable rental companies to provide more value-added services, such as fleet management, route optimization, environmental reporting, online ordering and billing, which increase efficiency, transparency, and convenience for customers. Customers also expect more instant and easy access to information and offerings, price comparison, and online reviews, which rental companies can leverage to differentiate themselves and build loyalty. We have invested heavily in our digital capabilities and platforms to offer a seamless and customer-centric service across our markets and segments. Increasing preference for end-to-end proposition Growth in rental penetration rates is also expected to be driven by changing customer preferences for end-to-end propositions that provide turnkey solutions for their broader needs and project success, rather than just equipment or services for specific tasks. Customers seek more comprehensive and integrated solutions that cover the entire value chain and offer a degree of flexibility and customization. Rental companies can respond to this demand by offering and providing packaged solutions that include a full range of equipment and services, such as planning, installation, operation, and maintenance that are tailored to the specific requirements and objectives of each customer and project. For example, we have provided full turnkey solutions for an automotive gigafactory in Berlin-Brandenburg by supplying a full range of equipment and services.

The following chart sets forth certain information with respect to the estimated market size of each of our markets in 2023 based on the ERA 2023 Market Report. Source: ERA 2023 Market Report Note: UK (EUR/GBP 0.86979), Sweden (EUR/SEK 11.4788), Poland (EUR/PLN 4.5420), Norway (EUR/NOK 11.4248), Denmark (EUR/DKK 7.4509), Switzerland (EUR/CHF 0.9718), Czech Republic (EUR/CZK 24.004) Market sizes in local currency converted based on average exchange rate over 2023. Exchange rate sources: ECB According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the equipment rental market size for the 16 European countries covered by such report (representing Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Finland, France, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK and Portugal, together "ERA Europe Countries") was estimated at €29.7 billion in 2023. The market is mainly centered in Western and Central Europe with smaller market sizes for Northern, Southern and Eastern Europe. The UK, Germany and France are the largest European markets for rental ----- equipment with their combined share estimated at approximately 60% of the total market size. According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the market is highly fragmented with approximately 58% of European rental market revenue generated by small companies, approximately 23% generated by middle-size companies and nearly 20% generated by large companies (defined as companies with more than 250 employees). According to the ERA 2022 Market Report and the ERA 2023 Market Report, the European rental market (excluding Portugal) has seen strong growth between 2010 and estimates 2023 with a CAGR of 4.7%, which exceeds the average GDP growth of the 27 European countries over the same period. The European rental market grew by an estimated 7.5% in 2022 and 2.7% in 2023 and is forecast to grow by 2.7% in 2024 based on the ERA 2023 Market Report. The ERA 2023 Market Report forecasts an increase in rental industry sales for each of the ERA Europe Countries between 2023 and 2025, with significant growth forecasted for Boels' main markets in the Netherlands (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 4.7%), Germany (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 2.8%), Belgium (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 4.7%), Sweden (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of more than 3.9%) and Finland (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 4.7%). The following chart sets forth the forecasted growth rate for each of our key markets based on the ERA 2023 Market Report and our organic revenue growth in each market for 2022 and 2023. Source: ERA 2023 Market Report, except for information regarding Boels' growth in each country. Notes: (1) In local currency. The key growth drivers of the European rental market is a conjunction of both growth of the equipment rental market and increasing market penetration, as described further below.

The European equipment rental industry is highly fragmented, with a large number of small players serving local or regional markets, and a smaller number of medium-sized to large players serving regional, national and international customer bases. As a result, the industry has experienced a high degree of consolidation in recent years. For example, we have completed 28 acquisitions since 2012, including the transformational acquisition of Cramo in 2020. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2023, as illustrated by the chart below. We compete primarily with large national and international equipment providers that offer broad, generalized product ranges to customers. These include Loxam/Ramirent and Kiloutou, both of which have a strong presence in France. In contrast to our largest competitors which have a higher focus on heavy equipment required in the new building phases, our business model focuses more on lighter equipment used in the subsequent fit out, maintain and operate phase (post-heavy equipment phase), resulting in less cyclical end-markets with higher degree of flexibility in equipment allocation and utilization. Post-heavy construction phases tend to be more diverse in terms of workload and therefore provide a greater opportunity to differentiate the product and service offering, including potential for ongoing service elements. We believe we have strong market positions across our main markets. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we have the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden in terms of revenue in 2023, with an estimated market share of between 25% and 30% in the Netherlands, an estimated market share of approximately 10% in Belgium, and an estimated market share of approximately between 15% and 20% in Sweden. We believe we have the second largest market share in Germany and Finland in terms of revenue in 2023, with an estimated market share of between 5% and 10% in Germany and approximately 15% in Finland. In addition, we believe we have the third largest market share in Norway with an estimated market share of between 10% and 15%. The equipment rental market is characterized by competition among operators who seek to differentiate themselves on various factors including, the availability and quality of their equipment, the price and terms of their rental contracts, the strength and quality of their sales relationships, the speed and reliability of their delivery and service, and their adherence to health and safety standards. Despite the fragmentation of the equipment rental industry in Europe, the leading players benefit from certain advantages over smaller players or new entrants. These advantages stem from the large capital investments required to acquire and maintain a diverse and modern fleet of equipment as well as to establish and operate a network of depots close to the areas of high demand. Moreover, the largest equipment rental companies have built long-term and loyal relationships with key suppliers and customers, which enable them to secure preferential terms and access to equipment and projects. Additionally, they benefit from economies of scale, which allow them to optimize their costs and margins, and from strong brand positioning, which enhances their reputation and customer loyalty.
_Germany_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Germany for the periods indicated.

Germany ............................................................ 4.5% 3.6% 3.9% 1.2% 4.4% Source: ERA 2023 Market Report According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the German rental market is expected to reach a total size of approximately €5.6 billion in 2023, an increase of approximately 3.9% compared to 2022, and is forecast to grow by approximately 1.2% in 2024 and 4.4% in 2025. The growth in rental market turnover in 2023 is mainly attributable to price increases, with a slowdown in activity driven mainly by high inflation and weakening of economic conditions in Germany, contributing to lower demand in the construction segment. Demand in the construction sector accounts for approximately 65% of the total market sales. Within the infrastructure segment, European Union funding is expected to be spread out over several years and modestly support the near-term outlook of the segment, with maintenance of road networks, streets and bridges and construction of logistic centers expected to contribute to rental growth. The German rental industry, Europe's second largest market after the UK, is characterized by a fragmented and diversified competitive landscape consisting of a number of international and regional players with a strong local customer base. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we are the second largest player in the market, with a market share ----- estimated between 5% and 10%, based on 2023 revenue, with the largest player, Zeppelin, mainly focused on earthmoving equipment. Other large players include, HKL and Mateco. Recently, foreign players including Kiloutou and Riwal entered the German market through acquisitions but are still relatively small. German customer demand tends to be sophisticated in terms of higher focus on innovation, service offering and quality, illustrated by an increasing demand for on-site services such as temporary traffic management, on-site power and water, safety management, and site access control. We believe we are well-positioned to benefit from these factors with our strong services, network density and fleet offering, which include a wide range of equipment, from small tools to large machines, as well as specialized solutions for specific sectors and projects. The growth potential in Germany is significant and is expected to be primarily driven by two factors: increasing penetration of rental equipment and fundamental growth in infrastructure and energy sector in the mid-to-long term. In particular, the infrastructure and energy sector is expected to benefit from strong demand for infrastructure projects, especially within highways and bridges, which require substantial maintenance and modernization. According to ERA 2023 Market Report, maintenance of road networks, streets and bridges and construction of logistic centers are expected to contribute to rental growth in 2024. In addition, the energy sector is expected to provide further growth, particularly as coal energy production is set to end by 2037, which necessitates structural changes to Germany's current energy infrastructure, a trend which is also expected for other major European countries. The German government has recently announced €58 billion commitments to green infrastructure projects of which €18.9 billion are expected to subsidize building renovations and new buildings in 2024. Additional key trends in the German rental market that are expected to shape the industry dynamics and performance in the coming years include (i) further consolidation of the fragmented market, as larger players seek to gain scale and market share through acquisitions and partnerships, (ii) a focus on decarbonization of construction sites, leading to increased demand for newer and more efficient equipment, (iii) substantial government expenditures on large infrastructure projects, aimed at addressing a backlog of civil engineering projects (roads, bridges, rail) as well as investments in 5G infrastructure and energy transition as a result of policies to increase renewable energy sources, and (iv) increasing demand for one-stop-shop offering, over pure specialist rental companies, as customers seek to simplify their procurement processes and benefit from a broader range of equipment and services from a single provider. _The Netherlands_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for the Netherlands for the periods indicated. The Netherlands ................................................ 3.2% 7.2% 3.3% 3.9% 5.4% Source: ERA 2023 Market Report The Dutch equipment rental market is a sizable and growing sector, with an estimated value of approximately €1.3 billion in turnover in 2023 according to the ERA 2023 Market Report. The market is forecast to grow at a rate of approximately 3.3% in 2023 and accelerate to approximately 3.9% in 2024 and 5.4% in 2025 based on the ERA 2023 Market Report. The growth prospects are supported by the ongoing and planned investment in various segments of infrastructure, environment, and new technologies, with a focus on enhancing energy efficiency and security in the country. Nevertheless, construction represents the main risk to rental market growth in the Netherlands, mainly driven by the recent new carbon emissions legislation which includes new taxes on real estate companies and revocation of nitrogen emission exemption for the construction sector, which will mainly affect projects in housing and infrastructure. The Dutch rental industry is characterized by a relatively high degree of consolidation, with a dominant player and a few large competitors, followed by a number of smaller and more specialized or local providers. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we are the market leader in the Dutch rental industry in terms of revenue in 2023, with an estimated market share of between 25% and 30%. Although not directly comparable, other large players in the market include Collé, Loxam, Mateco and Peinemann. Smaller rental companies, with less than 50 employees, account for approximately 41% of the total market sales, reflecting the fragmentation of the market. Key trends in the Dutch rental market include: (i) increased market penetration, due to affordability constraints of buying new machines, (ii) consolidation, with smaller challengers being acquired by established players, (iii) increasing demand for DIY and rental of small equipment, driven by a growing number of independent craftsmen who prefer to rent rather than buy equipment for their projects, (iv) growing demand for digitalization of products and services offering, with currently low penetration of digital solutions as well as packaged services, which allows companies to reach more customers (v) increasing focus on emission and more hybrid solutions for rental equipment, due to stricter government regulations and environmental standards that require more energy-efficient and less polluting equipment, and (vi) increase ----- of maintenance and repair of infrastructure, with the recent Dutch government's announcement to address a number of repair issues in the existing roads and bridges. _Sweden_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Sweden for the periods indicated. Sweden ................................................................. 2.5% 7.2% 1.0% 3.0% 4.8% Source: ERA 2023 Market Report According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the Swedish rental market has an estimated value of SEK19.8 billion in turnover in 2023 and is forecast to grow by approximately 1.0% in 2023, accelerating to approximately 3.0% in 2024 and 4.8% in 2025. Demand in the construction sector accounted for approximately 70% of the total market sales in 2023, according to the ERA 2023 Market Report. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we have the second largest market position in the Swedish rental industry in terms of revenue in 2023, with a market share estimated between 15% and 20%. Other major competitors include Ramirent/Loxam and Renta. Compared to other European countries, the Swedish rental market is mature and has a high rental penetration rate, meaning that a large proportion of construction equipment is rented rather than owned. High inflation in Sweden is negatively affecting household spending power, thereby causing lower demand for new buildings, which in turn dampens the rental market growth outlook in Sweden. Moreover, rental activity is also negatively affected by tight financing conditions and high construction costs. In the medium to long term, the market is expected to benefit from the structural trends of public investment in greener iron, steel and battery production, as well as the shift to renewable power generation from wind and solar sources. Moreover, the events business is driving further rental market growth through growing demand for safety fences and equipment. Additionally, the market also observes a strong demand for ESG-compliant machinery, mostly supported by public purchasers. Sweden has one of the highest rental GDP and construction sector penetration in Europe, as well as high standards for safety, quality, and environmental performance. Customers are increasingly demanding end-to-end rental solutions that cover not only the equipment, but also the ancillary services such as on-site traffic management, waste management, and safety solutions. Moreover, there is a strong demand for modern and safer machines that have a lower environmental footprint, as the market is moving towards decarbonization and sustainability. _Finland_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Finland for the periods indicated. Finland .................................................................. 2.0% 9.2% 3.2% 3.7% 5.8% Source: ERA 2023 Market Report According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the Finnish equipment rental market has an estimated value of approximately €0.7 billion in turnover in 2023 and, is forecast to grow by approximately 3.2% in 2023 and growth is expected to accelerate to 3.7% in 2024 and 5.8% in 2025. Demand in the construction sector accounted for approximately 70% of the total market sales in 2023, according to the ERA 2023 Market Report. In the medium to long term, the market is expected to benefit from positive structural trends such as investments in energy infrastructure, including nuclear power, offsetting the effect of high inflation, labour shortage and increased material and energy prices on the construction sector. Moreover, the rental penetration rate and the outsourcing trend from ownership to rental are expected to increase further in the coming years. The competitive landscape of the Finnish rental market has historically been dominated by two local major players, Loxam/Ramirent and Boels/Cramo. However, the market has recently witnessed the emergence of Renta as a new ----- player, driving up investments and increasing competition through consolidation with small players. The market is also characterized by a large number of smaller companies (with 1-49 employees), which generated approximately 62.5% of the total industry revenue, and large firms (with over 250 employees), which generated approximately 37.5% of total industry revenue according to the ERA 2023 Market Report. The investment level in new machinery in the market is high, as companies seek to renew their fleet and add more sustainable fleet options, as demand for equipment such as access platforms, earth moving equipment and generators is strong. Moreover, the demand for greener equipment is supported by government environmentally friendly policies. Key trends that shape the Finnish rental market include: (i) a growing demand for add-on or packaged services, (ii) an increasing focus on digitalization with connected fleet and digital services, (iii) a rising focus on decarbonization and greener solutions following Finnish regulations aimed at reducing the emissions of the sector, and (iv) a geographical polarization, with construction and equipment rental market concentrated in the main urban areas. _Norway_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Norway for the periods indicated. Norway .............................................................. 2.0% 15.6% 4.0% 3.6% 7.1% Source: ERA 2023 Market Report According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the Norwegian rental market is expected to reach a total size of approximately NOK 10,1 billion in 2023, an increase of approximately 4.0% compared to 2022, and is forecast to grow by approximately 3.6% in 2024 and 7.1% in 2025. Growth of the rental market in 2023 was supported by rental prices increase but partially offset by a decline in utilization rate. Demand in the construction sector accounts for approximately 60% of the total market sales, with increasing contribution from industrial segments. An increase in infrastructure public investments, including oil & gas and renewable energy projects, as along with the demand for renovation projects and increasing market penetration, are expected to offset a decline in new building construction. Furthermore, the demand for ESG compliant machines is expected to continue rising. The major competitors in the Norwegian rental market include Ramirent/Loxam and Renta. The market is characterized by a large number of smaller companies (with 1-49 employees), which generated approximately 77% of the total industry revenue, and medium sized firms (with 50-250 employees), which generated approximately 18% of total industry revenue, according to the ERA 2023 Market Report. Moreover, companies are looking to expand their offerings and reinforce their market presence, leading to consolidation in the Norwegian market. _Belgium_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Belgium for the periods indicated. Belgium ................................................................ 3.5% 8.1% 3.3% 4.5% 4.8% Source: ERA 2023 Market Report According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the Belgian equipment rental market has an estimated value of approximately €0.8 billion in turnover in 2023 and, is forecast to grow by approximately 3.3% in 2023 and is forecast to accelerate to 4.5% in 2024 and 4.8% in 2025. Infrastructure business has driven growth of the rental market in Belgium, supported by a great number of government projects, which has increased in the run-up to upcoming 2024 elections. The Belgian rental industry is characterized by a high level of fragmentation, whereby only a few rental companies have national coverage, caused by the regional split between Flanders and Wallonia and the related language differences. Generally, Flanders tends to have more specialized rental companies that are oriented towards the non-construction sector, while Wallonia tends to have more generalist rental companies that are focused on the construction sector. This is a distinctive feature of the Belgian market compared with other European markets (except for Switzerland) and has not ----- significantly changed in the recent years. Given that most rental players are local rather than national, the language barrier increases the obstacles for new domestic or foreign players, as they need to adapt to the different customer needs in each region. We are one of the few players with nation-wide coverage in Belgium and, taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we have the largest market position in the Belgian rental industry in terms of revenue in 2023, with an estimated market share of approximately 10%. Other large players in the market include Loxam and TVH. Small rental companies (less than 50 employees) contributed approximately 77.5% to the total market sales in Belgium in 2023, according to the ERA 2023 Market Report. According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, although investment levels were flat in 2022 compared to 2021, investments are expected to grow in 2023 as Belgian rental companies are renewing their fleet and adding new machinery as market demand is trending higher for smaller machines, access equipment and telehandlers. However, due to higher purchase prices, similar amounts of money invested in new machinery would not yield as much machinery as it would have one or two years ago. Furthermore, the transition to hybrid machinery or battery powered equipment has resulted in increased demand, but this is still slow and not expected to materialize meaningfully in the short-term without governmental support or the introduction of new regulations. Additionally, outside the construction and industrial sectors, there has been a substantial increase in rental demand in the Belgian events sector, particularly during the summer season. -----

See "Presentation of Industry and Market Data" for additional information. Market data are inherently forward-looking and subject to uncertainty and do not necessarily reflect actual market conditions. See "Forward-Looking Statements."_

We are a leading rental equipment specialist in Europe. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2023, with strong market positions across our main markets, including the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden and the second largest market share in each of Germany and Finland, in each case in terms of revenue in 2023. Our family-owned business started out of four garage boxes in the 1970s, and, under five decades later, has expanded into an industry leader with an extensive network of 764 depots in 18 European countries and a fleet of approximately 865,000 rental units as at December 31, 2023. In the year ended December 31, 2023 we generated €1,552.7 million in revenue and €554.5 million in Adjusted EBITDA. We serve customers in a variety of end-markets from civil engineering, industrial, construction and infrastructure to events and warehousing. Our core product offering includes general and specialist rental equipment alongside complementary products and services, enabling us to be a one-stop-shop for our customer base of both corporate clients (business-to-business) and individuals including craftsmen and retail clients (business-to-consumer). Our generalist division is mainly focused on the less cyclical 'fit-out, maintain and operate' market segments which use lighter equipment, while our specialist division is tailored to reach niche markets, such as site preparation, sanitation and access control. With approximately 865,000 rental items and significant bulk rental items in our rental fleet, with a purchase value of €3.0 billion as of December 31, 2023, we offer our customers access to one of the largest, widest, highest quality, and latest ranges of rental equipment and tools in Europe, for use in the fields of civil engineering (such as excavators, landscaping tools and dumpers), transport and handling (such as forklifts, cranes and trailers), climate control (such as heating and cooling systems, mobile boilers and air purifiers), and construction (such as construction site and installation products), among others. In addition to our vast range of tools and equipment available in our general depots, we provide a wide range of specialist products to niche markets primarily outside the construction industry, which we believe differentiates us from our competition and contributes to our strong brand recognition and greater diversification in terms of end-markets and product offering. Our specialist products range from HVAC systems and hoisting and lifting machines to mobile LED screens, temporary housing solutions, portable kitchens and heavy duty pumps. In parallel, we offer "do-ityourself" ("DIY") shop-in-shops across Europe, in partnership with DIY retailers where retail clients get access to primarily smaller equipment rental, which we believe further renders our business less cyclical than the traditional equipment rental business. Our corresponding service lines are geared towards further simplifying our customers' complex projects and include equipment service and maintenance, fuel management, training courses, project management and emergency assistance. In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain information for the following four geographic regions: - **_The Netherlands, which generated €373.0 million in revenue (representing 24.0% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; - **_Central Europe, consisting of Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which generated €554.8 million in revenue (representing 35.7% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; - **_Northern Europe, consisting of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which generated €576.5 million in revenue (representing 37.1% of our revenue, with Finland, Norway and Sweden generating 33% of our total revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023; and - **_Other Countries, consisting of Italy and the United Kingdom, which generated € 48.4 million in revenue (representing 3.1% of our revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, in the year ended December 31, 2023, we introduced segmental reporting in line with IFRS 8 "Operating Segments" for the first time. For additional information on our operating segments, see "Presentation of _Financial Information—Operating Segments."_ ----- We operate under two main brands: Boels Rental and Cramo. Boels Rental, the original brand of the Boels Group, is active in 12 countries in Central and Western Europe and we believe holds the strongest brand recognition across our portfolio. Cramo is active in the Nordic and the Baltic states, having been an independent leading rental company in Europe since 1953 before we acquired it in 2020. We operate a hub-and-spoke depot network, consisting of 684 general rental product depots and 80 specialist rental product depots as of December 31, 2023. We believe the decentralized structure of our network enables us to provide our products and services to our customers more conveniently and efficiently, while also supplying us with a diversified and local customer reach. In countries where we have an extensive depot network, such as the Netherlands and Germany, each depot is connected to a central hub location. In countries with larger markets, we have several hubs. Our depots generally stock smaller and more commonly used equipment, while the larger and less commonly used equipment is stored at our hubs, from where they can be easily shipped directly to a customer or local depot as needed. We believe this structure allows us to make more efficient use of our fleet and minimize transport movements. Through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions, we have expanded significantly over the past decade, both in terms of geographical reach and product offering. Since Pierre Boels Jr. became the CEO of Boels in 1996, we have executed a growth strategy based on product portfolio diversification and greenfield openings (including through international expansion), as well as through strategic bolt-on acquisitions executed to enter specific geographic areas (such as Germany, the UK and the Nordics) or specialist markets (such as industrial rental and traffic service). In 2020, we acquired Cramo, which positioned us as one of the largest equipment rental companies in Europe and complemented our geographic presence with an expansion into the Nordics and a further extension of our Central European offering. In addition, our 2022 acquisition of Eekels Pompen allowed us to expand our specialist product line by adding a high-quality offering of pump rentals to our customers with niche needs. The sharing economy is at the very heart of our business, and we believe that long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, driven by increased consumer preferences for rental instead of ownership. From our perspective, renting provides our customers with optimal availability, accessibility, and capital deployment, enabling them to reduce the amount of capital required for their operations, and, in turn, increase their capacity to deploy it for other investments. As such, our rental concept aims to help customers and their end-consumers meet their targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality and sustainability. We also believe that rental, compared to ownership, can contribute positively to the environment. Therefore, alongside the benefits that we strive to offer our customers, we also invest in products and solutions that align with our commitment to advancing sustainability in our and our customers' industries.

Subsubsection Title: Leading market positions in a large and growing European market supported by favorable underlying growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We have grown significantly since our founding in 1977 as a local rental company. Since then, we have grown into a multinational company through a combination of organic growth and transformative and bolt-on acquisitions. With the Cramo acquisition in 2020 and with the pending acquisition of the Target signed in March 2024, which allowed us to further expand our operations in the Nordics, Baltics and other European countries in which we were not previously present while strengthening our network in Western and Central Europe, we have created a true pan-European rental equipment player with increased scale and resilience. We believe that our current footprint provides us with beneficial scale in strong and growing geographic and customer end-markets. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental business in Europe by rental revenue in 2023. As of December 31, 2023, we operated a comprehensive depot network of 764 depots, comprising 684 general rental depots and 80 specialist rental depots, and on a combined basis with the Target, we had 829 depots, comprising 684 general rental depots and 145 specialist rental depots. We believe that our scale is particularly important as a provider of rental equipment, because it helps us optimize fleet utilization rates through our ability to easily relocate units to areas with higher demand for specific types of equipment and provides us with additional bargaining power in negotiations with OEMs and equipment suppliers and maintenance partners. We believe that our scale and our market leadership also help to increase our brand recognition and affords us with greater opportunities to attract and retain talented and experienced personnel. Taking into account the Acquisition, in the Netherlands, which is historically our cornerstone market, we believe that we hold a strong leader position with between 25% and 30% of market share based on revenue in 2023, which we believe is significantly ahead of our competitors. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe we are also the leader in Belgium with approximately 10% of market share and the second-largest player in Germany with between 5% and 10% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2023. With the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, we expanded our presence into five more European markets (Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia and Lithuania) and significantly strengthened our ----- position in six European countries where Boels and Cramo had a joint presence. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe that we are the leader in Sweden, with between 15% and 20% of market share, and the second largest player in Finland, approximately 15% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2023. Taking into account the Acquisition, we believe that we are also the third-largest player in Norway with an estimated market share of between 10 and 15%, based on revenue in 2023. With the Acquisition of the Target, we are combining experience and resources in European regions where our presence overlaps, such as Germany, Sweden, Norway, Netherland or Poland while opening the doors to new markets such as Spain and France as well as international markets such as India or Qatar. We believe that the markets we address are strong and poised for further growth. According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the total market size of the top 16 European rental equipment markets covered in the report (representing Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Finland, France, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK and Portugal, together, the "ERA Europe Countries") is estimated to have increased by 2.7% from €28.9 billion in 2022 to €29.7 billion in 2023 and is forecasted to grow by 2.7% in 2024 and 4.6% in 2025. According to the ERA 2023 Market Report, the European market continues to be favorable, driven by an increased rental penetration and a structural shift in customers' preferences towards renting rather than owning equipment. This shift is supported by the attractiveness and flexibility offered by renting, as it optimizes the split between operating costs and capital expenditures by reducing the fixed portion of maintenance and fleet replacement costs and allows customers to avoid investing in expensive equipment that may not be used frequently. Moreover, the transition to achieving net zero CO2 emissions amplifies this effect, as electric equipment is generally more expensive. This structural shift is expected to support continued demand for rental equipment companies' products and services over the medium and long term. We believe that we are well-positioned to benefit from growth and positive trends in the equipment rental industry. The European rental equipment industry is still highly fragmented, consisting of a large number of small companies serving local or regional markets, with a limited number of medium to larger companies serving regional, national and international customers. We believe we are one of only a few companies with a strong pan-European platform, with strong relationships with the key equipment OEMs. We compete with a large number of smaller competitors locally and a few larger international competitors. We believe that we are well-positioned for growth by leveraging our scale and footprint, while relying on our proven approach of customizing our strategy for each local market, while centralizing our key operations.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model supported by robust diversification across geographies, end markets, products and customers, supported by a notable depot network
Subsubsection Text: We strive to minimize the impact of economic cycles through continually maximizing our rental fleet utilization rate, developing specialist activities focused on non-construction related niche markets, diversifying our customer base by investing in a broad product range aimed at non-construction related customers and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction projects. We have a diversified footprint and address several different customer end-markets, helping to mitigate our exposure to macroeconomic uncertainty. In particular, with the acquisition of Cramo, we significantly increased our geographical diversification, bringing our revenue generated in the Netherlands to 24% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to nearly half of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018. Moreover, no single country represented more than 25% of our revenue generation for the year ended December 31, 2023. We believe that our diversified geographical footprint will be reinforced with the Acquisition of the Target, which will not only strengthen our presence in the European markets in which we already operate in but will also expose us to new markets. We believe that this enhanced geographic diversification gives us greater resilience during periods of slow economic growth, as different countries operate within different economic cycles. Based on our revenue and EBITDA growth, we believe we outperformed our largest European competitors during the COVID-19 pandemic, proving the resilience of our business model. ----- The table below provides a breakdown of our revenue by geographic segment for the year ended December 31, 2023. (7) Northern Europe: Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. (8) Central Europe: Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia. (9) Other: Italy and the UK. We address multiple customer end markets, which also contributes to our resilience in reducing the impact of volatility of external factors such as market conditions and macroeconomic developments. We have positioned ourselves as a leading generalist equipment rental company that is also active in the attractive specialist sub-segment and in DIY, with specialist rental and DIY representing 28.6% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2023, approximately 54.8% of our sales were derived from non-construction end-markets, indicating a relatively modest exposure to the cyclical construction market. Furthermore, our exposure to the construction end market includes a large part of less cyclical phases of construction activities, such as the fit out, maintenance and operational phases. The chart below provides a breakdown of our revenue by end markets for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over time, we have continued to develop our expertise in specialist rental equipment, focusing on nonconstruction related end-markets, such as site preparation, modular space, measurement, testing and safety, sanitation, portable kitchen, hoisting and lifting, access control, and industrial rental and pumps. We believe our specialized knowledge is key to our ability to service different niche markets, providing further resilience and less exposure to the more cyclical construction market. By leveraging our generalist rental equipment business, we also aim to provide the best and most comprehensive rental solutions for our customers with the objective of cross-selling our specialist equipment to fuel future growth. Ultimately, our specialist business represents a key peer differentiator with customers, which we believe provides for higher returns. In parallel, we also operate in the niche market of DIY rental, with more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops as at December 31, 2023, where customers at DIY retail stores have access to primarily smaller equipment rental such as tools. This type of business is less cyclical than traditional equipment rental market and the costs to operate this business are typically lower than other equipment rental businesses due to the strong operational leverage of the existing rental depot network. In the DIY market, we are able to offer convenience as a differentiating factor to our customers, generating higher customer foot traffic in the stores, at a time when e-commerce is putting a strain on retailers and brick-and-mortar stores. We strive to offer a wide range of equipment and tools across all the phases of construction projects, including the build (both heavy construction and fit out), operate and maintain phases. Our business model also hinges on providing a diversified range of products to our customers. Approximately 16% of our rental revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023 was generated from smaller equipment rentals, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators and sanding equipment. These rentals position us within the less-cyclical 'fit out', 'maintain' and 'operate' phases of the asset cycle, as demand for such rentals is typically more resilient and makes us less dependent on lengthy construction ----- projects. For example, smaller equipment rentals tend to be more sought after for renovation and maintenance use, which are inherently less exposed to cyclical demand than other end uses. As of December 31, 2023, with a fleet of approximately 865,000 equipment units, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment, in addition to valueadded services such as logistics, we aim to provide full turnkey solutions to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner. Furthermore, with a comprehensive network of 764 depots (strategically located within a 50-kilometer reach of our key customers and project sites across Europe) and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of December 31, 2023, we are capable of mobilizing our rental fleet even in remote places for any customer or user at the right time, through multiple delivery methods: pick up and return or delivery to desired locations. By constantly adapting our network to changes and fluctuations in the market, we have the strategic ability to open or close access points near our customers. Based on market trends or developments in specific regions in Europe, we can adapt swiftly and embrace changes in our industry. Our hub-and-spoke networking model provides a diversified customer reach and develops efficiency and flexibility in our operations, ensuring that we are close to our customers and their projects, whether for pick-up and return or project delivery. This proximity to our customers results in shorter transport times, lower costs and lower CO2 emissions. Supported by our broad product offering and dense network, we also benefit from a large and diversified customer base, serving numerous customers of different sizes and from different sectors through our various channels (both generalist and specialist rental products) ranging from DIY customers, cash customers and craftsmen to large industrial, services and construction companies, potentially operating in different economic cycles. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our top 10 customers accounted for 7.1% of our revenue and our top three customers accounted for 3.7% of our revenue. No single customer accounted for more than 2% of our revenue in the same period. We benefit from strong customer loyalty, evidenced by the fact that our 10 largest customers by revenue have, on average, an approximately 20-year relationship with us. The chart below provides a breakdown of our customers for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Well-invested fleet focused on smaller equipment with strong unit economics and robust fleet management and digital capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We differentiate our offering from most of our peers by focusing on smaller rental items, such as tools and access equipment, in addition to construction equipment and containers. The chart below shows the breakdown of our rental revenue from our fleet by product category for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Reflects rental revenue of unique fleet only, excluding bulk and re-rent items. Over the last five years, we have invested more than €1.5 billion to renew our rental fleet, with €397.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. We have a young, well-invested rental fleet with a historical purchase value of €3.0 ----- billion as of December 31, 2023. These investments have reduced the weighted average age of our fleet to 52 months as of December 31, 2023, allowing us to offer our customers the latest advanced equipment and sufficient headroom to reduce or delay our capital expenditures during economic downturns. The chart below shows our rental equipment fleet's average useful life and its age (in months), by product category, as of December 31, 2023. Our tools product category, which amounted to 16% of our rental sales for the year ended December 31, 2023, has the lowest spread between average useful life and average fleet age in our fleet, with an average of approximately 4 years of use remaining before ultimately needing to be replaced. The weighted average fleet age of the Target is close to 94 months which is higher than the current average age for the Boels fleet, reflecting the different market dynamics in the regions where the Target operates. Particularly outside Europe, the Target provides equipment rental services in markets where the average age of rental equipment varies, allowing the Target to extend the economic life of its fleet toward close to 180 months. The Target's fleet management strategy involves deploying the equipment in three successive stages: "first life" in Central Europe, "second life" in the Middle East and "third life" in Kazakhstan and India. We will leverage on our existing young fleet and well-established fleet management to support the integration of the Target and an efficient transition towards Boels. Our smaller equipment, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators, sanding equipment, and other small tools, are characterized by superior unit economics compared to our other product categories, as they lead to higher money utilization rates (defined as our twelve-month fleet sales divided by the historical purchase price, based on the weighted average price by number of rental units). For the year ended December 31, 2023, our money utilization rate for the tools and light equipment product category was higher than our larger product categories, such as construction equipment, which we believe results in an increase in our return on fleet investments and an increase in our resilience through business cycles, given our high exposure to the tools and light equipment category. The chart below shows our money utilization rate for our different types of rental equipment for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Money utilization defined as our twelve-month fleet sales divided by the historical purchase price, based on the weighted average price by number of rental units Our focus on tools and access equipment makes us less dependent on lengthy construction projects and more exposed to the less cyclical renovation market, where we have a better pricing power among our smaller customers. On our major long-term projects, we often provide a full range of equipment from small hand-held tools to larger equipment, reflecting our ability to support our clients on their various steps and needs with adequate and available equipment. This ----- ability to provide full range of equipment in due time ultimately fosters relationships with our clients, creating recurring revenue streams and the potential for cross-selling between our generalist and specialist equipment. We have developed a robust asset management strategy for our extensive fleet. Our fleet management strategy covers the entire lifecycle of our equipment units, which includes purchasing, renting, and equipment servicing, as well as reselling the equipment at the end of its financial or economic lifetime. When making purchasing decisions, we seek to provide a true one-stop shop experience for our customers by ensuring a high degree of availability across our entire rental range and equipment that is adapted to their needs. By closely monitoring trends, events and market prices, we can quickly adjust and adapt our offer to customers' needs. For example, the share of Eco-labelled equipment in our fleet is relatively high and growing in line with higher market demand for electrical, hybrid or battery-powered equipment and the highest sustainability standards. Simultaneously, we seek time- and cost-efficiency to maximize our economies of scale and fleet occupancy performance. These initiatives improve our fleet availability and utilization rates while minimizing our maintenance capital expenditures. We have implemented an advanced and integrated infrastructure to drive decision making for our fleet, such as enterprise resource planning and specialized hardware and software. This asset management system allows us to track the complete life cycle of any rental asset in our fleet, providing us with visibility on our any given item (such as depot performance, inventory levels, fleet allocation and pricing) and the ability to adjust our fleet investment and pricing. This enables us able to serve our customers according to their needs, quickly and efficiently. In addition, this system makes it possible to limit downtime and improve utilization rates and pricing. Finally, as a piece of our equipment reaches the end of its lifecycle within the Company, we believe that we are able to optimize the timing of its resale and maximize its resale value through closely following secondary market prices and trends and taking third-party insights into account. Our fleet management strategy also relies on a central procurement strategy. This enables us to benefit from economies of scale and allows us to be close to our OEMs and their product development, positioning us at the forefront for the latest products in terms of efficiency, safety and sustainability. In addition, our relationships with OEMs not only allows us to negotiate better prices, but it also give us insights on the availability issues that may occur due to shortages of materials. In 2022, the equipment markets suffered from supply chain shortages. Due to our excellent relationships with our OEMs, we were able to successfully navigate these shortages, which we believe differentiates us from our competitors. We also foster our relationships with our OEMs by collaborating on technological developments and data analyses, and we aim to deepen our cooperation with them further. In addition, we have invested and continue to invest in the latest technology to help us efficiently process our fleet maintenance and repairs and minimize our related costs and administrative workload. These technological capabilities allow us to be in full control of depreciation and replacement strategies and therefore systematically improve our fleet usage, composition and performance. We monitor and reduce the impact machine repairs and maintenance have on lifetime costs and resale value. Finally, we seek to be a leader in innovation and digital transformation across the entire rental process, which we believe results in higher customer satisfaction and percentage of recurring business, better fleet damage control and substantial emissions savings. We were an early adopter of digital offerings in the European rental market, having anticipated this trend by preparing a detailed mapping of our customer experiences per segment, with the aim to simplify online rental in all our customer's life cycle stages and provide a one-stop-shop solution: from becoming a customer to online renting, logistics, usage, having all relevant information available and invoicing. In parallel, this digital transformation generates operational efficiencies by allowing us to optimize our processes such as transport and logistics.

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial and operational track record supported by counter-cyclical cash generation through capital expenditure flexibility and proven M&A integration capabilities
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance has been driven by a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions, which have expanded our geographical reach and product offering. Since our foundation more than 45 years ago, we have been focused on increasing scale and achieving sales growth. Our business model is based on actively distributing our fleet through our depot network, directly competing with local players and ultimately winning market share by providing newer equipment and better customer service. This model has delivered a proven track record of strong growth over the past decade. Between 2013 and 2023, our revenue grew at a CAGR of approximately 18.9%, significantly exceeding the growth of the economy, the construction market and the equipment rental market over the same period in Europe. While delivering robust sales growth, we have also managed to retain steady and high margins, with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 35.7% in the year ended December 31, 2023. By being highly focused on maintaining a high portion of variable costs, we have managed to retain our profitability during economic downturns. ----- The Acquisition fits well within our overall growth strategy built on both organic growth as well as selective bolton acquisitions. By realizing economies of scale, combining overhead costs, procurement advantages and cross-selling between Boels and the Target, the Acquisition is expected to generate meaningful synergies over the coming years. The following chart shows our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA growth from the year ended December 31, 2012 through the year ended December 31, 2023.
We believe our success is attributable to the following competitive strengths which will drive our future growth:

Subsection Title: Long-term financial track record (€ millions and %)
