Figures provided for 2020 reflect the unaudited management financial information presented using the principles applied by the Company to restate its Dutch GAAP financial statements in accordance with IFRS together with certain pro forma adjustments to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020. Figures provided for the Company for 2021, 2022 and 2023 reflect our results prepared in accordance with IFRS. It should be noted that the pro forma figures presented for 2020 represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and Cramo. Further, figures provided for Riwal and the combined figures, taking into account the Acquisition as if it had been completed January 1, 2023, are unaudited and represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and the Target. Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information and is presented for illustrative purposes only. The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma _Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (1) For comparability purposes, revenue growth between 2019 and 2020 is expressed as 2020 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020, compared to 2019 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2019, each prepared under Dutch GAAP. Revenue for 2019 has been prepared solely for illustrative purposes based on management estimates utilizing a simple aggregation of the revenue of Cramo and our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. (2) Represents the Group’s growth rate on a standalone basis (excluding the Target Group). We have the ability to actively manage our fleet investment based on existing market conditions and the stage of the industry cycle, which has contributed to our counter-cyclical cash generation. In an industry growth cycle, we invest in our rental fleet to enhance our product catalogue and expand into new products and markets. In a downturn, with our newly invested young fleet, we can rapidly reduce our capital expenditures and postpone our investments, streamline our depot network and the size of the fleet, and pay down debt with our strong cash flows resulting from lower capital expenditures. Our business has flexibility to make investment decisions on a regular, short-term basis, and has no long-term expansionary capital expenditures commitments. Therefore, we are generally able to quickly adjust our fleet investments to respond to the changing market environment. For example, recently, we were able to quickly adapt our investments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on maintaining our existing fleet through reduced capital expenditures. After the stabilization of market conditions in 2021, we resumed our investments by increasing our capital expenditures. The countercyclical nature of cash generation and our ability to adjust our capital expenditure while preserving our cash generation through the cycles supports our conservative leverage policy and enables us to deleverage during challenging economic periods, as we did during the global financial crisis between 2008 and 2009, the double dip recession, and more recently, during the COVID-19 pandemic. -----

Subsubsection Title: Strong senior and local management teams with extensive industry experience
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong management team with extensive experience in the equipment rental industry and a track record of operational excellence, led by one of the most recognized and distinguished people in the industry, Pierre Boels Jr., our Chief Executive Officer since 1996 and President of the ERA between 2016 and 2022. The members of our management are further supported by divisional and regional managers in an organizational structure that empowers entrepreneurship spirit and decision making. Jan Piet Valk, our Chief Financial Officer since 2020 and member of our Management Board, has acquired a proven international experience through his previous chief financial officer positions. He is responsible for the overall financial management, M&A strategy, health and safety policy, legal, treasury, sustainability and real estate matters and is involved in all key decisions in the company. Mr. Valk has recently been awarded "CFO of the Year" by Financieel Management, in recognition of his independent role in the leadership of our Group, his management skills and his board position. Mr. Valk is due to step down as Chief Financial Officer on June 1, 2024 to become chair of the Supervisory Board on September 1, 2024. Under Mr. Pierre Boels Jr.'s leadership, we managed to significantly increase our sales and EBITDA, both organically and through acquisitions, having successfully executed and integrated 28 acquisitions since 2012. Our CEO has assembled an experienced management team with significant industry expertise, including: - Reiant Mulder, Chief Operations Officer of Central Europe and member of our Strategic Board with more than 20 years of services experience. - Guy Cremer, Chief Procurement Officer, working with us since 1989 and leading in the Fleet Management department since 2000. Additionally, Mr. Cremer was recognized with the award for "Rental person of the year" by ERA in June 2023 for his influential role in the shift towards lower carbon emission equipment last year; and - Martin Holmgren: Chief Operations Officer of Nordics and a member of our Strategic Board. Mr. Holmgren is also Vice President of ERA and has worked for almost 30 years in the construction and rental industry. - René Olsthoorn, who will be appointed Chief Financial Officer for the Group on June 1, 2024 replacing Mr. Valk. Since May 2009, Mr. Olsthoorn has served as an executive officer of Timber and Building Supplies Holland N.V., first as Chief Financial Officer and, following his appointment in January 2019, as Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Olsthoorn began his career in 1990 as a project leader with Fokker Aircraft and has held management roles ranging from logistics to finance since then. Our highly qualified senior management team is in close contact with our local business directors, since investment decisions strongly benefit from local market knowledge. For example, the choice between opening a greenfield location when expanding into a new region or acquiring an established company in the region is based on local insights about rental company concentration provided by local business leaders: we consider acquisitions when rental concentration is high and greenfield expansion in locations where rental concentration is low. We have an external Advisory Board that meets five times a year and consists of a group of experienced entrepreneurs and leaders. This independent body advises the Management Board on policy matters and the general course of affairs of the Group. In addition, the Advisory Board and its individual members function as a critical sounding board for our Management Board. We are in the process of implementing a two-tier board system and aim to install a Supervisory Board in September 2024, which will replace the Advisory Board. The Supervisory Board will supervise the general course of affairs in the company and the businesses affiliated with the company. It will also supervise the functioning of the Management Board as such and the policy conducted and will provide the Management Board with advice. On March 19, 2024, it was announced that Jan Piet Valk will join the Supervisory Board of the Group as chairman as of September 1, 2024. For further discussion on our management team, see "Management." -----

Subsubsection Title: Ambitious CSR targets to lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry and mitigate environmental impact throughout the value chain
Subsubsection Text: We strive to lead our company with high business ethics and lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry. We have set ambitious CSR targets to position ourselves as a front runner in the development of a safe and environmentally friendly business and a key partner to our customers in meeting their increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. We believe that the core purpose of rental, compared to ownership, is the achievement of the efficient use of equipment and materials, therefore making a positive contribution to the circular economy. According to a research study led by ERA, efficient use of equipment results in a reduction of approximately 30% to 50% of CO2 emissions (depending on specific user practice) and that the rental business model stimulates such efficient use. Our rental concept allows our customers and their end-customers to meet their objectives and targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality, safety and to reduce their carbon footprint. CSR topics are at the heart of our business model. We also chose to apply the Global Reporting Initiative 2021 ("GRI 2021") Standards and Disclosures to report our sustainability-related data, to commit to the guidelines of UN Global Compact and to implement the Sustainable Development Goals relevant to our business. In addition, based on a formal materiality assessment, we have identified four focus areas covering all aspects of corporate and social responsibility, including Employee Care, Social Care, Customer Care and Environmental Care. We have also identified, key performance indicators in relation to each topic and set ambitious targets for 2025. We aim to be the leader in sustainable fleet investments, to enable our customers in executing their projects with the lowest level of emissions, while continuing to deliver profitable growth. Our Green Team, which includes members from our fleet, sales and marketing departments, has jointly set out a strategy to invest in anticipation of customer needs and develop ambitious and innovative solutions (including zero emission equipment) in their field. For our fleet, we invest in energy-efficient products to improve our energy performance. For example, our fleet includes electrical two-ton excavators, fully battery-operated six-meter telehandlers and over two-ton electric-wheeled loaders. We also have a wide availability of battery packs and have created solar panel roofs for site huts and new zero emission welfare units, which were both brought to market in 2022. Additionally, our fleet contains more than 10,000 Stage V engines meeting the EU standard for non-road machines with low emissions of particulate matter. On December 21, 2023, we entered into a €100 million loan agreement with the European Investment Bank to support our further investments in 'green' electric equipment. _See "Summary––Recent Developments––New EIB Facility."_ Our state-of-the-art fleet adheres to strict environmental and safety performance standards and helps increase our customers' productivity while reducing their emissions footprint. Of our total energy powered fleet units (equipment driven by a motor and with all types of power), approximately 82% is electrically-powered as of December 31, 2023 and we aim to increase this percentage to 85% by 2025. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 67% of our fleet value was comprised of electric, hybrid and gas equipment and not motorized equipment (meaning, equipment without an engine or motor). We have steadily reduced the portion of our diesel-powered equipment as a percentage of fleet value over time, reaching 23% as of December 31, 2023 (excluding Stage V diesel powered equipment). A breakdown of our fleet value by type of power as of December 31, 2023, is presented below.
