Acquisitions are also an integral part of our growth strategy that we pursue either for geographical expansion (filling in gaps in our existing footprint), increase market share, acquire specialist knowledge, improve our competitive position, or acquire certain assets. We have a clear, defined and well-established acquisitions strategy with a dedicated integration team in place. The success of our international expansion and our ability to effectively integrate acquired companies is demonstrated by our track record of 28 successful acquisitions since 2012. In particular, we demonstrated our disciplined M&A strategy and execution with our transformative acquisition of Cramo in 2020. During the 6 months of the initial integration period, our management executed a clear integration plan to minimize execution risk related to the acquisition, while maintaining a high quality service for our customers and efficiently responding to their needs. In countries where Boels and Cramo had geographic overlap, such as in Germany, Austria, Poland, Czech Republic and Slovakia, we focused our efforts on optimizing our depot network, rebranding and refurbishing Cramo's depots in Central Europe (including Germany), enhancing our cross-selling opportunities and optimizing our back-office functions. We also invested substantially in integrating the fleets in Western, Central and Eastern Europe, increasing the availability of fleet and our flexibility, allowing us to optimize our response to market demands. In 2021, 2022 and 2023, we invested in and deployed new equipment categories that meet specific local requirements as a result of our analyses of the local markets, in order to be less dependent on large projects, with the aim to reach small and medium enterprises and retail clients. As a result of such efforts, we were able to successfully integrate our Central European operations in only 10 months and achieved synergies in terms of centralization of our mutual best practices in our key operations: IT, finance, fleet management and human resources through the deployment of our One Boels strategy. As a result of these efforts, we believe we have realized significant synergies, which generate recurring savings in EBITDA and capital expenditures, primarily due to the optimization of our procurement functions, the consolidation of our IT systems and the reduction of our corporate expenses (including as a result of the closing of Cramo's headquarters in Finland). ----- We believe that our acquisition track record, including our ability to integrate companies, positions us for growth while strengthening our local presence. The success of our international expansion supports our financial and operational development and establishes us as a market consolidator in a fragmented equipment rental industry. For further details about certain of our recent acquisitions, "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings."_

Subsection Title: Our fleet value as of December 31, 2023 (in € billion)
Subsubsection Text: ----- Furthermore, during 2023, we have made significant progress in offering resource-efficient and sustainable alternatives to customers, supporting them to minimize climate impact: - We invested more than €50 million in 2023 in the electrification of our rental fleet. - We increased the share of units powered by electricity within our energy-powered fleet. - We increased the share of Eco-labelled fleet. - We invested over 2.5% of our total fleet value in high-tech, zero-emission machines, with a target to reach 4.7% by 2025. We also continuously work to mitigate our own climate impact by reducing energy consumption, increasing the use of renewable energy and increasing circularity of our products and operations. We reduce, reuse or recycle materials, reduce waste and handle hazardous waste properly. For facilities and installations, we invest in energy efficient products, services and design for energy performance improvement. For example, we have been increasing our energy efficiency while reducing our emissions through investments in sustainable technologies and services, LED lighting, solar panels, better insulation or development of energy management systems. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we reduced our energy use relative to sales by 8.6%, compared to 2022. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we reduced our gas usage by 25% compared to 2022, which resulted in a reduction of approximately 5,800 MWh and 720 tCO2 of our emissions. We are also improving logistics planning in order to limit emissions related to equipment deliveries, as well as increasing our purchase of more renewable energy. We also disclose the Group's greenhouse gas emissions for Scope 1 (direct emissions) and Scope 2 (indirect emissions) with clear reduction targets. In 2022, we announced a number of targets with respect to our carbon emissions for 2025, using 2021 as a baseline, including: - reduce our emissions (calculated in tCO2) relative to sales (Scope 1 and 2) by 20%; - reduce our energy use relative to sales (Scope 1 (direct energy use) and Scope 2 (purchased energy)) by 15%; and - increase our share of renewable electricity to above 92% (compared to 56% in 2022 and 49% in 2021). Simultaneously, we are assessing our scope 3 targets with the main initiatives expected to be set as soon as 2024. In 2023, we retained our EcoVadis Platinum status for Sweden and obtained EcoVadis Bronze status in the Netherlands. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental and social governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance." As a leading provider of sustainable AWP rental solutions in its markets, the Target fits well with our CSR strategy. It has a high proportion of electrically powered fleet in Europe, which we plan to increase further by 2030. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 60% of the Target's AWP fleet in Europe was electrically powered.

Subsubsection Title: Achieve a leading position in all our markets and become a leading partner for our customers
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue working to provide a high quality, one-stop-shop experience for both individual consumers and businesses, while ensuring that our entire rental range of products meets our customers' evolving demands, in order to achieve a leading market position in each of the markets we address. We believe that we are well-positioned to become the leading partner of our customers in all the geographies we serve. We believe that our customers already recognize us as a preferred one-stop-shop for their rental needs, primarily due to our diversification across products, end markets, general and specialist rental, and our strong European geographic coverage. Our acquisition of Cramo has demonstrated our ambition to keep strengthening and expanding our geographic coverage and diversifying our service offering. ----- We believe we can achieve a leading position in our markets through our strong, long-term partnerships with our customers. In order to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner, we aim to provide full turn-key solutions, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment (including site huts, site safes, traffic sets and sanitation), in addition to value-added services such as logistics. For example, in 2021, we delivered full service rental solutions for a wind farm project in Lithuania by providing site huts, construction equipment and special tools, in addition to access control, on-site maintenance, and helping with planning, transportation, delivery. Since 2022, we provide full turnkey solutions for an automotive Gigafactory located in Berlin-Brandenburg. We combine our proximity to customers and our understanding of their needs in order to continue providing our customers with valueadded services and products. Finally, we intend to continue pursuing our fleet investment strategy, which aims to maintain a complete range of sustainable and safe rental equipment.

Subsubsection Title: Grow through a combination of organic development and bolt-on acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: We have achieved an impressive track record of both sales and EBITDA growth through a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both our transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions. Through our acquisition strategy in particular, we have expanded to cover new geographic markets and have diversified our catalogue of products and services. We believe we have significant opportunities to continue growing organically due to our comprehensive network of 764 depots and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of December 31, 2023. We intend to increase the density of our network in less concentrated regions which we believe have a strong potential of profitable growth through our clear greenfield expansion strategy. We also intend to continue evaluating strategic acquisition targets to further strengthen and expand our operations and customer base, to selectively enter new markets over time, in particular in geographic areas with low rental company concentration to increase opportunities for upselling and cross-selling our products. In pursuing such acquisitions, we maintain the same disciplined, targeted, and opportunistic acquisition investment criteria that have historically enabled us to successfully identify acquisition targets and profitably acquire and integrate them. In March 2024, we announced the acquisition of the Target, a rental company with expertise in Aerial Work Platforms ("AWP"). This Acquisition will increase our network of depots to 829 depots as of December 31, 2023 (on a combined basis) while strengthening and diversifying our current geographic footprint. See "The Transactions" below. Successful integration of acquisitions is key to our strategy, and we believe we are well-positioned to integrate future acquisitions efficiently and profitably. We have dedicated integration teams supported by local teams with superior knowledge of their local markets to develop synergies in our fleet management, expedite the completion and integration of acquisitions and position us to achieve our long-term success.

Subsubsection Title: Drive digital innovation to increase productivity for our customers and improve our operational efficiency
Subsubsection Text: We have developed and intend to continue to develop digital services in order to improve our customers' experience and boost our operational performance. We believe that we are a leader in the development of new, innovative digital business models in our industry. We have developed and deployed new types of data- and connectivity-based solutions to connect our people, internal processes and fleet to our customers, such as our new smart application for mobile devices, "Equipment Pool", which improves customers' access to equipment and machines, while reducing transportation times to and from customers' construction sites. We believe that we can leverage our digital processes and use of data in a customer-focused manner in order to improve communication between our employees and our customers, better identify customers' needs and facilitate interactions and transactions with customers. Although we already have improved processes and digital tools in place to optimize our customers' experience, we intend to continue enhancing our rental websites, including those of Cramo, Boels Rental and IQ Pass, to add further equipment data and specifications and combine our general and specialist rental fleet in a single platform. We believe that such technological capabilities positions us to achieve the full potential of our one-stop-shop solutions. We also intend to continue leveraging digital tools to streamline and boost efficiency in our internal systems. For example, we have implemented a single group-wide financial system to monitor our cash flows and key performance indicators. We have also implemented our group-wide One Boels strategy in order to continue harmonizing systems and processes based on four pillars: (i) One IT approach, (ii) One financial organization, (iii) One fleet and procurement organization and (iv) One HR approach and organization. We have developed our One Boels strategy as a clear, distinct, and strong organization that focuses not only on our customers' needs, but also boosts our efficiency. We intend to continue enhancing our operational systems and processes to increase our operational and procurement efficiency, improve our ----- strategic relationships with OEMs, strengthen our fleet management and negotiating position for strategic procurement and maintenance of our fleet, and enhance our employee retention.

Subsubsection Title: Maintain top-tier performance as a leading rental company
Subsubsection Text: We aim to maintain our operational performance by systematically improving and optimizing fleet usage, composition and performance. Historically, we have had a more centralized business model where our rental fleet was managed centrally to optimize the allocation of equipment, while local managers organized by countries and depots offered knowledge of local markets. Cramo, on the other side, has historically had a more decentralized business group structure, where operating decisions were made at the country and business-unit level. With the integration of Cramo, we have developed a synergized approach, which aims to combine the best practices of both organizations by centralizing key operations such as procurement or fleet management, while we keep a flexible and locally oriented commercial approach for each market and geography. We believe that this approach, together with our close cooperation with, and monitoring of, our depots, business units and departments, positions us to achieve our strategy, whilst retaining our disciplined and flexible business and financial models.

Subsubsection Title: Reinforce our commitments to the environment, safety, quality and corporate responsibility
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to promoting and maintaining corporate sustainability and responsibility as a core component of our business. We intend to continue being a leading climate- and resource-efficient rental company, paving the way to enhance sustainability in the rental industry and to reduce our environmental footprint throughout our value chain. We believe that our value chain perspective on sustainability helps us identify how we can optimally manage our impact on the environment while efficiently operating our business. We also strive to meet our customers' increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. We are convinced that applying and maintaining an adequate corporate governance policy is a prerequisite to structure the organization efficiently and effectively and achieve our strategic goals. We also believe that our sustainability policy helps us to manage risks and to consider the interests of all our stakeholders, including our shareholders, our employees and our customers. We discuss our material sustainability topics, focus areas and strategic targets twice a year with our Strategic Board and our Operations Board, and periodically with the Sustainability Steering Committee that we have implemented to help us achieve our sustainability goals. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental, social and governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance."

Our business strategy focuses on profitable growth, further enhancing operational efficiency, strengthening our market position in all segments, expanding our service offerings, developing innovative digital solutions to improve customer efficiency and promoting corporate social responsibility.

Before Boels was incorporated in the Netherlands in 1977, our family started the business with four garage boxes, lending tools to friends and acquaintances. In 1980, we opened our first formal office in Sittard, and in the 1990s, we expanded to Belgium and Germany and began supplying mobile kitchens and in-shop rental points in DIY stores. As we continued on our trajectory of organic growth and expansion, Pierre Boels Jr. became CEO in 1996 and implemented our European growth strategy. In 2000, we commenced a full-service offering with OneCall, which provides customers with a single point of contact for their rental needs. We celebrated 25 years in business in 2002 with 650 employees and 65 depots in three countries. In 2004, we opened our 100th depot. During the early 2000s, we strategically expanded into countries and activities that were complementary to our original footprint and product and service base. In 2007, we commenced operations in Austria, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Poland, and at the end of 2011, we acquired Baurent Baumaschinen Miet-Service GmbH, a construction machinery and equipment rental company, expanding our presence in Germany. In 2015, we acquired leading specialist companies in climate and energy rental, shop-in-shop rental and earthmoving equipment. In 2017 we opened our 400[th] depot. In 2017 and 2018, we completed additional strategic acquisitions in the United Kingdom, while also adding to our industrial rental operation by acquiring Abird. The year 2020 marked an important point in our history, where our fleet exceeded the €2.0 billion purchase value mark for the first time reflecting both our organic growth and strategic acquisitions. We believe we became the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2022, all within 50 years of selling our first product, an 11-kilo breaker. That year, we acquired the listed Finnish rental company Cramo, integrating the five Central European countries where Cramo's presence overlapped with Boels and raising the overall number of countries in which we operated in to 18. In 2021, we launched our sustainability motto "Orange is the new green," highlighting our commitment to assisting our customers in building and working with lower emissions. In 2022, we acquired Eekels Pompen, a Dutch specialist pump company, expanding our product portfolio. That same year, we launched our One Boels program to integrate overhead activities, such as finance, HR, fleet management and IT throughout our entire network into the Boels organization. Our expansion through strategic acquisitions continued through December 31, 2023 with the acquisition of ----- Illumin8 in the UK and BAS Maskinutleie, Hyresbutiken AB and Kraftx AB in the Nordics and with the acquisition of MD Rental in Sweden in January 2024. For further details about our recent acquisitions, see "Management's Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings."_

Subsubsection Title: Equipment Rental
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading provider of rental equipment and services in Europe for various sectors, including civil engineering, industrial, construction, infrastructure, warehousing and events. We offer a wide range of products consisting of approximately 865,000 unique articles across 30 product groups, including tools, machinery, modular buildings, climate control, lifting and hoisting, surveying, safety, traffic services, earthworks, cleaning, flooring, and sanitation. Our rental product portfolio consists of two segments: general rental and specialist rental. As of December 31, 2023, we have 684 general rental depots and 80 specialist rental depots. In the year ended December 31, 2023, general rental generated 71.4% of our total rental revenue, and specialist rental (including DIY) generated 28.6% of our total rental revenue, comprised of 25.3% generated by specialist rental (excluding DIY) and 3.2% generated by DIY. For the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, generalist rental generated 73% and 74% of our total revenue, respectively. For the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, specialist rental (including DIY) generated 27% and 26% of our total revenue, respectively.

Subsubsection Title: General Rental
Subsubsection Text: As part of our general product line, we offer the following categories of equipment to rent to our diverse endmarket customers: - **Tools, including tools for landscaping, cleaning, drilling, breaking, sawing, sanding, grinding, mixing and blending and finishing. - **(Powered) Access Equipment, including scissor lifts (both battery and diesel-powered), passenger lifts, aerial work platforms, scaffolding, edge protection, and ladders and steps. - **Earthmoving, including excavators, plate compactors, rammers, dumpers and loaders, some of which form part of our Zero Emissions Evolution line of products. - **Materials Handling, including forklifts, telehandlers, hoists, winches, jacks, pallet trucks, trailers and conveyors, as well as accessories and rigging.

Subsubsection Title: Specialist Rental
Subsubsection Text: Through our specialist rental line, we provide support for a variety of customer segments that require specialist knowledge for applications and products. Our specialist product line consists of a wide range of tools and equipment to meet some of the more niche needs of our customers, and comprises: - **Site Accommodation and Sanitary Facilities, including interconnectable units, mobile units, storage containers, furnishings, sanitary facilities, and fittings and accessories. - **Building Site Preparation, including power and water supply, fencing, formwork, scaffolding, supports for floors and walls, construction hoists, etc. - **Security and Access Control, including complementary security services such as access control, crowd management and surveillance. ----- - **Power and HVAC, including generators, fuel tanks, cables, battery packs and heating through diesel, electric, gas, or carbon neutral sources, mobile boilers, air handlers, cooling systems, air humidification and purification and dust management. - **Industrial Rental, including industrial tools, welding machines, compressors and (Atex) tools - **Survey and Laser, including construction and sewer lasers, levelling instruments, GPS rovers, thermal imaging cameras, gas detectors and temperature meters. For these products, we offer the ability not only to rent but also to lease and buy measuring instruments, accessories and consumables. - **Pumps, including dirty water, plunger, dewatering, diaphragm and high-pressure pumps, hoses, pipes and valves. - **Portable Kitchens, including hot kitchens, cold kitchens, dishwasher kitchens, cooling and freezer units, food service counters, and other kitchen equipment. - **Traffic Control and Traffic Engineering, including trailer mounted variable message signs, barriers, turnstiles and mobile and fully rotational LED screens in a variety of sizes, which are operational within an hour. We have strategically grown our specialist rental offering having completed 13 acquisitions of specialist rental companies since 2015, which has contributed to a CAGR of approximately 30% in our revenue from specialist rental between 2015 and the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, we have increased our revenue from specialist rental organically through cross-selling between specialisms, resulting in a CAGR of approximately 10.5% in specialist organic revenue between 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Complementary Services and Product Ranges
Subsubsection Text: We complement our broad range of quality rental product offerings with service solutions and additional product ranges to support our customers through every step of their project implementation. Our services and additional products cover and/or include, where applicable: - **Onsite rental, where we provide a temporary rental point at our customers' sites and locations. - **Calamities, including assistance with emergencies or disasters such as power cuts, heat waves, floods or epidemics. Such help can include the opening of temporary depots and the rapid redeployment of large portions of our fleet, including fencing, emergency road signs and power generators. While individual products mirror those in our general and specialist rental segments, under this range they are organized and marketed for the needs resulting from specific emergencies, such as providing equipment and set up for COVID-19 vaccination sites during the pandemic. - **Long-term rental, including equipment and machine leases from one to five years, paired with maintenance and inspection. - **Project management and implementation, whereby our project managers assist customers in organizing the necessary equipment, personnel and other requirements for their complex projects, including an HSE plan. As part of this service, our customers can also benefit from our assistance with installation and maintenance, with specialists available 24/7. - **Site management, including facility services such as security, installation, cleaning and waste management. - **Service and maintenance, including equipment inspections, certifications and checks, and assistance with malfunctions. - **Fuel management, which leverages smart meter technology so that we can monitor our customers' fuel levels remotely. As part of this service, our suppliers periodically visit our customers to refuel their diesel-powered equipment. ----- - **OneCall, our customers' single point of contact for all their rental needs, including questions regarding our product offerings, reservations and even invoicing. - **Training courses, including equipment training courses, safety courses and more custom training courses such as toolbox presentations, tailored to our customers' particular needs. - **Product sales, including consumables and machine accessories. We also sell used machines and tools.

Our core product offering consists of general and specialist rental equipment in addition to complementary products and services, as well as the selling of used rental equipment as an integral part of our fleet management. Our used equipment sales help maintain optimal levels of fleet availability, age and variety. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our revenue was comprised of approximately 70% revenue from equipment rental and approximately 30% revenue from sales of products and other services.

We offer our products and services to a broad and diversified customer base of more than 670,000 customers who generated revenue as of December 31, 2023. Our customers range from large international companies to small- and medium-sized businesses, craftsmen and retail clients, who operate in many sectors, such as industrial, offshore, warehousing, infrastructure, chemical, events, construction, and infrastructure. Regardless of their size or industry, many of our customers have time-sensitive and complex projects, and we believe that our vast network of depots and wide range of general and specialist offerings allow us to meet our clients' needs. We also believe that increased use of data and digitization of processes can have a positive impact on our customer experience and are focusing on investing in solutions that improve customer centricity and processes. We continuously work to improve our rental website and portal (MyBoels) by updating equipment data and specifications, for example combining specialist items into a one-stop solution platform where our customers can access information on equipment availability, reservations, contracts, product details and invoicing across our general and specialist segments. We have implemented several data-driven dashboards to facilitate our monitoring of KPIs, progress and trends in order to better identify and anticipate issues. For certain major customers with high transaction volumes, we have built custom Enterprise Resource Planning ("ERP") and procurement system integrations, which allow them to connect to our IT system for access to our electronic catalogue, order-to-cash integration, and e-invoicing. Our sales team actively promotes this service as part of our rental offering to increase efficiency of renting across all of our depots for our large clients. With our largest key accounts and managed customers, we negotiate framework agreements establishing pricing policies for our equipment. These agreements typically have a duration of one to three years. Certain framework agreements contain discounts based upon volume commitments made by the customer. Smaller and more localized customers are typically subject to our standard terms and conditions. We have a diversified customer base, with our top 10 customers accounting for approximately 7.1% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023 and our top three customers accounting for 3.7% of our revenue. No single customer accounted for more than 2% of our revenue over the same time period. As a result of our diversification efforts over the past three years, we have decreased the percentage of our revenue derived from our top 10 largest clients. Furthermore, our customer base is loyal and has a high retention rate, with our top 10 customers having an average relationship with us of approximately 20 years. We believe that we have limited concentrations of credit risk in trade receivables as a result of the spread of our business across customers, markets and regions. Sales on account are only made to customers that meet the Group's credit rating requirements. Goods and services are sold subject to payment terms, the majority of which range between 15 to 60 days. A different payment period may apply to major customers, in which case additional security is demanded, including guarantees. Credit risks are routinely monitored by reviewing credit limits and payment terms per customer. Outstanding trade receivables are regularly monitored and legal action is taken against debtors with long outstanding balances. Overall, we believe that our exposure to long-outstanding balances exceeding the post-paid terms is not significant.

We maintain and invest in a strong sales and marketing organization, which we believe enables us to both maintain close and loyal relationships with our existing customers and expand our reach to attract and retain new customers. Our client management system operates on a tiered system based on size and geography. Within Boels, our local and small business customers are generally served by local depot managers and commercial rental employees who provide our customers with counter service and information on the rental process and equipment. Midsize customers are served by regional account managers and large key accounts are managed by key account managers who often operate internationally. Our sales and marketing departments, combined with innovative digital solutions, work to anticipate our clients' needs based on feedback from both customers, original equipment manufacturers ("OEMs") and suppliers, as well as industry research and trends. All of our customer interaction and feedback is stored in a centralized Salesforce platform, ----- using cloud services across sales, services and marketing. The Salesforce platform is used and updated on a daily basis by approximately 2,500 employees at Boels working in rental, sales and services. We believe that our use of digital solutions offers our customers convenient, fast and tailored products and services. Our self-service portals allow our customers to view their rented products, pricing, contract, invoicing and delivery information. Since the launch of the MyBoels portal, customers have been able to access more granular data on their rentals such as fuel and battery levels and service errors. For our major customers (including in the industries of infrastructure and construction), we have implemented building information modelling ("BIM") models, which are digital platforms that create and manage 3D models for building and infrastructure projects. BIM models are relevant at all phases of construction projects, from initial planning and design to construction and ongoing maintenance. The BIM models of our rental products are stored in our product information management systems, which are accessible through the MyBoels portal. In 2022, we invested in a project to optimize customer experience and engagement with our local listings, which aims to provide customers with immediate digital access to the nearest depot. As a result, each depot's opening hours, address and contact details are updated in real time across all our marketing channels and related online sources.

As of December 31, 2023, we had a rental fleet of approximately 865,000 pieces of serialized rental equipment units and significant bulk rental items, with a purchase value of €3.0 billion. We strive to offer a wide range of equipment and tools, representing 30 product groups across generalist and specialized equipment and tools. We strongly focus on lighter equipment, which positions us on the 'fit out', 'maintain' and 'operate' phases of the asset cycle. As of December 31, 2023, our fleet is comprised of approximately 39% tools, 27% energy and climate, 13% material handling, 12% site huts and site preparation, 5% earthmoving and 4% access equipment. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we generated €834.7 million in rental revenue from our fleet only (excluding revenue on bulk rental and re-rental items), of which tools and light equipment generated 49% (comprised of tools generating 16%, material handling generating 12% and energy and climate generating 21%), access equipment generated 24%, earthmoving generated 12% and site huts and site preparation 15%. With the goal of providing the European market with the best and latest equipment, we aim to invest strategically in high-quality equipment that adheres to strict environmental and safety performance standards. In the year ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, investments in our fleet increased the number of serialized rental items by approximately 6% and 5%, respectively, reflecting a broadening our existing assortment and our continued investment in the Eco-label fleet to meet higher market demands for electrical, hybrid and battery-powered equipment with high sustainability standards. We have continued to expand our fleet to include Eco-Label, Zero Emission, and Zero-Emission Evolution offerings. Machines and tools with the Eco-Label are less harmful to the environments in which they operate in terms of emissions, vibrations and noise. As a result, they are better for the health of the user and local residents. Zero Emission machines and tools that are manufactured to not emit carbon dioxide and Zero-Emission Evolution machines and tools are those which we believe are at the forefront of technical development and make a larger impact in reducing our customers environmental footprint. Examples of these include larger telehandlers, certain types of dumpers, and 4x4 heavy terrain scissor lifts. For a further discussion of our fleet management investment decisions, see "—Fleet Management." We have a well invested fleet as evidenced by the young weighted average age of our fleet which was 52 months as of December 31, 2023, compared to 54 months as of December 31, 2022, which we believe will allow more flexibility in our capital expenditures over the near to medium term.

Subsubsection Title: Digital innovation
Subsubsection Text: Our fleet management system tracks the complete life cycle of any rental asset at our disposal by serializing the vast majority of items within our fleet. Data from information technology systems provides us with a comprehensive overview of the health, profitability and productivity of our fleet. Utilizing this data allows us to provide recommendations to our customers concerning which machinery might meet their requirements best. Additionally, in each depot we keep a record of each missed rental caused by an item being unavailable either in a local depot or in our fleet more broadly. We believe this allows us to better anticipate local demand and further optimize our logistics system. We invest in innovative technology that enables us to not only track our rental items on a continuous basis but also to process fleet maintenance and repairs efficiently and with relatively low administrative costs. We believe this allows us to promptly register any equipment part for maintenance, thereby reducing duplicate purchases, as well as reducing the frequency of asset audits, and rapidly identify lost items. In 2022, we fully integrated digital document management in our fleet management system for all rental items, including with respect to all test certificates and CE declarations. Therefore, this system now allows us to track important documentation with respect to legal or regulatory compliance and further work to enhance our quality control and assurance, while reducing costs and equipment downtime through regular maintenance checks and repair.

Subsubsection Title: Procurement
Subsubsection Text: Our position as a leader in the European rental market has enabled us to create strategic relationships with our OEMs. Because we primarily employ a centralized procurement strategy, and due to our close relationships with our OEMs, we believe that we are able to influence product development at the stage of manufacturing, so that we can remain at the forefront of product innovation. For example, we have collaborated with our OEMs on various product improvements for our rental equipment, including the standardization of lighting units, type and positioning of support wheels and the placement of protective brackets, suspension points and lift points to aid in loading. This procurement strategy has also provided us with the ability to negotiate prices, better analyze constraints in supply and explore ground-breaking technological developments. While 2022 marked a challenging year in terms of supply chain constraints, our procurement strategy allowed us to mitigate their effects on our operations. See also "—Suppliers" below.

Subsubsection Title: Life cycle management
Subsubsection Text: Our fleet management strategy also offers services across the entire life cycle of our equipment units, including long-term rental, equipment servicing, and the resale of the equipment at the end of its financial or economic lifetime. The digitalization of our system has facilitated our fleet maintenance and repair strategy. For each numbered item in our fleet, we keep track of the total cost of ownership, which allows us to determine which brands or items are most efficient from a cost/quality perspective. Additionally, we believe this data enables us to determine the optimal time to sell to avoid ----- increased maintenance costs for ourselves while still offering the buyer a quality tool that can last. We may also decide to sell certain equipment sooner in cases where there is insufficient rental demand for such products. We sell our used equipment through various channels, of which direct sales from our warehouse and auction sales are the most important. We generally sell our used equipment outside of our principal markets, and occasionally we may need to sell equipment as scrap. The disposal of any piece of equipment from the fleet is a technical decision made by a technical manager based on analysis, recorded metrics, and historical lifetime expectations. We have established metrics and guidelines for each category of equipment that help determine the desired replacement cycle. Most metrics are based on repair costs relative to rental income, utilization rate and age.

Subsubsection Title: Strategic investments
Subsubsection Text: When in line with our growth strategy or otherwise key to overall performance, we invest in integrating and updating our fleet and we are able to react with agility to optimize our investments in response to changes in demand. For example, in 2020, shortly after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, we substantially reduced our capital expenditures and focused on achieving the synergies from the Cramo acquisition. Through consolidating depots in certain regions and increasing the density of our network in others, we were able to increase the utilization rates of our fleet. Following the Cramo acquisition, we also relocated equipment in order to generate better returns. In 2021 and 2022, we invested substantially in updating our fleet, which we believe not only increased our revenue and results, but also increased our flexibility and allowed us to react more quickly to increased market demand as end-market activity picked up. For a further discussion of our capital expenditures during the periods under review, see "Management's Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures, Fleet Age and Equipment Disposals."_

The asset management strategy for our extensive fleet that we have developed is based on a diversified deployment of equipment. We work to provide a one-stop-shop experience for our customers and aim to ensure that our rental range is available when needed, all while striving to minimize time and costs of delivery of equipment to customers and maximize economies of scale and fleet utilization performance. As part of our strategy, we divide our equipment into several subgroups which we believe enables us to analyze the most efficient and strategic routes for deployment, in addition to targeting the best possible use for our customers. Our fleet categories (Access, Earthmoving, Energy and Climate, Materials Handling, Site Huts and Site Prep, and Tools) are split into subcategories based on the characteristics of each item. By tracking maintenance costs and fuel consumption, among other metrics, we believe we are able to determine which piece of equipment is best suited for the job at the lowest cost and emissions. An increasing number of our fleet items are equipped with telematics, allowing us to track more data and provide our customers with up-to-date metrics on their usage on our recently launched MyBoels portal. Furthermore, we monitor fleet location, utilization and other metrics in one central ----- system. This allows us to have full visibility on individual depot performance, maintain appropriate inventory levels, and manage fleet allocation across our networks as well as plan and monitor capital expenditures. The following graphic illustrates asset management strategy.

We employ a centralized procurement model to leverage our scale. Alongside our OEMs, we plan and develop the equipment and machines we believe are needed in our markets and market segments in Europe, whether general or specialist. We believe our long-lasting relationships with large and recognized OEMs allow us to obtain useful information on new product innovations and assess market demand. Together with our OEMs, we analyze the time horizon for the next three years in terms of market demand whereby we address our requirements in terms of quality, safety and low maintenance costs. Our relationships with OEMs not only allows us to negotiate better prices, but it also give us insights on the availability issues that may occur due to shortages of materials. In 2022, the equipment markets suffered from supply chain shortages. Due to our excellent relationships with our OEMs, we were able to successfully navigate these shortages. See "—Competitive Strengths—Well-invested fleet focused on smaller equipment with strong unit economics and robust _fleet management and digital capabilities" for additional information. Additionally, the sheer volume of our fleet provides_ important data to the OEMs on their equipment, which we believe gives us additional leverage in managing our relationship with our OEM suppliers. We do not consider ourselves dependent on any single supplier, with most pieces of equipment available from multiple different suppliers with whom we have a relationship. As of December 31, 2023, our top 10 suppliers accounted for approximately 20.3% of our total purchases for that year, with no single supplier representing more than 6% of purchases for that year.

As of December 31, 2023, we had a network of 764 depots across the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe, and Other Countries. Out of the total number of depots, 684 are general rental depots and 80 are specialist depots. The table below shows certain information on our depot network by geographic region as of December 31, 2023:

Our hub-and-spoke, decentralized business model enables a diversified customer reach, allowing for increased efficiency and flexibility in operations and an expansive physical coverage. With this extensive network, we are able to be closer to our customers and their projects, whether for pick-up and return or project delivery. We believe that from an operational standpoint, this model reduces transport time and emissions, which from a service perspective results in shorter delivery and quicker response times for our customers. Our network of depots has grown significantly over the course of the past decade through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions. Our network management is dynamic and the decision to open a branch is driven by our analysis of the interaction of the proposed branch and our existing network, the conditions in the local market and the competition within that market. Whether we open a new branch or acquire an existing network depends on the level of saturation in that market and whether acquisitions can provide us a level of penetration that would take too long to develop organically. Branches may be merged or closed based on the market environment (if, for example, a large construction project concludes or an industrial site closes) or excess proximity to another branch following an acquisition. We may also relocate branches in light of the development of cities or the evolution of infrastructure, or to optimize our geographical coverage. We implement periodic network optimization plans to enhance the profitability of our depot network through better coordination of commercial activities and capital expenditures, pooling of resources, integrating overhead and backoffice activities between regions, improved exchanges of staff and equipment among branches and enhanced depot and hub positioning. Our depots are generally located around cities, particularly in the Nordics where economic activities are concentrated in urban areas. While our depots generally offer the same equipment, in certain industrial or more rural areas our depots may carry slightly different inventory to anticipate local demand. Our depots operate under the Boels and Cramo brands.

As of December 31, 2023, we had over 7,000 permanent employees. Our employees perform the following functions, among others: sales and marketing operations, maintenance and parts operations, rental operations, technical service and office and administrative support. Our employees are a core part of our business and we invest in their development and training, which are key priorities to ensure our customers consistently receive high-quality products and services. We place a strong emphasis on employee training, including safety and competence-based training, and strive to support our employees' career growth. We operate a defined contribution plan for our employees and pay contributions to pension funds and insurance companies on a contractual basis. Besides these contributions, we have no other obligations to pay further contributions by virtue of these pension plans. Of our foreign group companies, only Boels Rental Germany GmbH, Cramo AB and Cramo Services Sweden AB have their own pension plans as a result of a historic pension arrangement applicable to a specific group of former Cramo AG employees. These plans qualify as a defined benefit plan in accordance with IAS 19. Certain of our employees are represented by various works councils, unions and other employee representative bodies and are subject to collective bargaining or works council agreements. For certain courses of action, we require our works councils' and unions' consent, and for others, we are required to ensure our works councils and unions are informed of the processes or have an advisory role in undertaking such actions, as applicable. We believe we have a strong collaboration with our employees, works councils and unions based on clear processes and trust. -----

Over recent years, we have invested significantly in various IT systems to improve our internal operations, our sales and marketing processes, and our interactions with our customers. Operationally, we employ a centralized and robust information technology platform, which we refer to as One IT, whereby we strive to provide digitization, connectivity and innovation across our operations in a secure fashion. For marketing and sales, we have implemented and invested in improving various digital platforms to provide our customers with access to our products, such as self-service portals, ecommerce websites, and BIM models. We also employ the use of an optimized Salesforce CRM system to store customer information, interactions, and needs. In 2021, as part of our "One Boels" strategy, we focused on integrating Cramo's IT operations in Central and Northern Europe into the integrated hardware and software backbone of our IT systems, covering 5,000 workstations. In addition to undertaking this integration, and improving our customer experience on our Boels website, we implemented numerous digital programs in line with our IT strategy. These included our "Customer Excellence Programs" and mobile applications such as the Logistic application, Boels traffic service application, disaster management application, and waste data application. The customer applications and portals provide real-time information to the customers at each stage of the rental process from product search, reservation, ordering and logistics to invoicing. As part of this IT strategy, we also invested in developments to our company dashboards to improve our performance monitoring capacity with respect to operations, finance and HR and with respect to compliance measures, such as cash register and security systems. In addition, we implemented three additional data systems in 2021, including a Robotics Process Automation ("RPA") system (which automates certain manual processes), a Product Information Management ("PIM") system (which we use to help us process large amounts of complex product information and to distribute this data through their relevant channels, both internally and externally), and a Digital Asset Management ("DAM") system (which has the capacity to organize and manage digital content and assets for communication purposes, including brand logos, designs, images, video, presentations, and text files). In 2022, we introduced a new company-wide digital workspace (social intranet) for all countries, which is geared towards improving tailor-made internal communication and stimulating collaboration and interaction between all colleagues and across all departments. The intranet is a single platform for employees that contains information, news articles, HQ support, product information and best practices. In addition, we operate the One Boels IT team, which is located in Sittard and Stockholm. The main IT systems are SAP4H, IBS, inspHire, Salesforce CRM, SAP SuccessFactors and One Digital with SAP Commerce Cloud. The integration was built with MuleSoft technology and Microsoft Azure. The Backend ERP systems of Cramo and Boels (including SAP4H) are fully integrated with the Digital Frontend Portals and Salesforce using MuleSoft enterprise integration and Azure technology. Through this technology, our employees and customers are able to view the same realtime data as it relates to sales, support and field use.

We use several trademarks, mainly including the "Boels," "Cramo," "Niebo," "RENTPARTNER," "TRENDRENT," "IQ-Pass" and "Eekels Pompen" brands, all of which enjoy high brand recognition in their home markets. Our "Boels" trademark, and several of our other key trademarks are registered in the countries where we do business, including the UK, the Netherlands and other members of the European Union. Our trademarks, domain names, copyrights and all of our other intellectual property are important assets that afford protection to our business. Our success depends to a degree upon our ability to protect and preserve certain proprietary aspects of our technology and our brands. To ensure we meet that objective, we control access to our proprietary technology. Our employees and consultants enter into confidentiality and nondisclosure agreements with us. We protect our rights to proprietary technology and confidential information in our business arrangements with third parties through confidentiality and intellectual property and business agreements. We hold a number of third-party patent and intellectual property license agreements that afford us rights under third-party patents, technology and other intellectual property, including for the use of certain material software applications. We cannot ensure that future license agreements can or will be obtained or renewed on acceptable terms, or at all.

We are subject to comprehensive and frequently changing local, national and European Union-level laws and regulations, including those relating to emissions to the air, pollution of water and land, and the handling, storage, transportation, use and disposal of hazardous materials and wastes. Among other laws and regulations, we are subject to Regulation for Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH), the Energy Efficiency ----- Directive (EED), and the Plastic Regulation, Batteries Regulation, Packaging Directive, Regulation (EU) 2019/631, adopted in April 2019, which sets CO2 emission performance standards for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles. In 2021, the European Commission adopted the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive ("CSRD") in line with the commitment made under the European Green Deal. The CSRD, as further implemented by the EU Member States, amended the existing Non-Financial Reporting Directive (NFRD) and will substantially increase reporting requirements on the companies falling within its scope. With our application of the Global Reporting Initiative 2021 ("GRI 2021") Standards and Disclosures that we use to report our sustainability-related data in a transparent and credible way, we believe we are well prepared to meet CSRD's new reporting requirements. In addition to our regulatory obligations, we leverage our quality, safety, and environmental certifications, which we believe are an increasingly important factor in our customers' choice of rental partners. Our industrial, traffic services, survey and laser and IQ-Pass brands are certified according to ISO 9001 standards. For Cramo entities in Sweden, Finland, Norway, Estonia and Lithuania, we have been certified by ISO 9001, ISO 14001 and ISO 45001. All entities in the Netherlands and Germany have ISO 50001 certification. In addition, IQ-Pass is ISO 27001 certified. In the UK, we are audited by SafeHire and have met the bronze level requirements for Fors. Our Dutch (100%) and Belgian (60%) divisions are VCA certified for Safety, Health and Environment, and the Dutch divisions have the Safety Culture Ladder Step 2 certificate for safety awareness. _Corporate Social Responsibility_ We believe that sustainability primarily means striving for a safe and environmentally friendly fleet with a low climate impact. In addition, health, safety, well-being, diversity and social and ethical issues are among our top priorities. Our sustainability policy is comprised of three major ambitions: - we aim to become the most climate- and resource-efficient rental solutions company; - we aspire to lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry; and - we strive to lead our company with high business ethics. We believe that our value chain perspective on sustainability helps us identify how we can optimally manage our impact on the environment while optimizing our business. We also strive to meet our customers' increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. To help achieve our sustainability goals, we have implemented internal processes, including the establishment of a sustainability steering committee (the "Sustainability Steering Committee"). As part of these processes, we engage with and work towards material topics, focus areas, strategic targets and targets per focus area, all of which are approved and monitored by our Sustainability Steering Committee. Based on a formal GRI 2021 materiality assessment conducted in 2022, we have identified four focus areas: customer care, employee care, environmental care and social care, each of which we describe below. Our strategic targets for each of these focus areas for 2025, in each case using 2021 as a baseline, involve: - achieving 85% of units powered by electricity within our energy powered fleet; - developing a harmonized group-wide customer satisfaction methodology; - reaching a 10% reduction of lost time injury rate, representing the average number of injuries occurring over one million working hours, ("LTIR") per year; - attaining an employee satisfaction index of 84%; - reaching a wellbeing and diversity score of 80%; - achieving a 20% reduction in our Scope 1 and Scope 2 CO2 emissions (measured as tCO2/sales) (for the year ended December 31, 2023, this amounted to 26.3 tCO2/sales, a decrease of 3% compared to 2022); - achieving a 15% reduction in our Scope 1 and Scope 2 energy use (measured as MWh/sales) (for the year ended December 31, 2023, this amounted to €112 million per MWh, a decrease of 9% compared to 2022); ----- - increasing our share of renewable electricity use to above 92% (for the year ended December 31, 2023, this amounted to 58%); - having over 75% of our group entities receiving a silver or higher rating from EcoVadis (relative to revenue); and - reducing our exposure to legal proceedings pertaining to human rights, discrimination and sexual harassment, environment and anti-corruption. See "Risk Factors—Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment—We are subject to risks related to _environmental, social and governance matters, including the failure to meet certain of our targets." Customer Care_ We believe that priority should always be given to our customers' sustainable operations. We strive to provide a safe working environment at construction sites, digitalized solutions and high-quality rental equipment and services. We also aim to help our customers minimize their climate impact by increasing circularity and offering an increased range of resource-efficient and fossil fuel-free alternatives. Our focus in this respect therefore includes investing in modern, durable and innovative technologies, in line with our aim to limit hazardous substances in our products and operations. Because of our goals, we expect our suppliers and business partners to demonstrate similarly high ethical standards as ours. We offer our customers a line of Eco-Label products, which currently consists of ecological alternatives to commonly available fuel-powered machines. These sustainable options include either electric or battery driven products, or products that have the capacity to significantly reduce fuel consumption and emissions. We offer our Eco-Label products to assist customers in lowering their environmental footprint at construction sites and events. Eco-Label products also produce less noise and vibration and meet high standards for safety and user-friendliness. In addition to expanding our sustainable service offering, Boels Training and Cramo Schools offer safety trainings every year to our customers. Customers' safety is a top priority, and training programs help us prevent accidents at construction sites by increasing safety awareness and competence. _Employee Care_ We strive to offer safe and healthy workplaces for our employees. Our ultimate goal is to significantly reduce, and if possible, eliminate, the occurrence of accidents within our control across our operations. We are also committed to treating our employees in an open, honest and equal way and strive to provide a diverse and inclusive culture, where all employees of different ages, gender and backgrounds have the same opportunities for development. In 2023, we have created the diversity, equity and inclusion ("DEI") team to oversee our DEI initiatives, such as our leadership and talent programs. We believe our workforce should reflect the diversities of the communities in which we operate, and as such we strive to operate an unbiased recruiting process, remain committed to principles of fair pay and aim to consistently provide promotional opportunities. In addition, we value competence-based training and support career growth that encourages employees to achieve their full potential. We maintain confidential reporting channels for our employees throughout our organization and are in the process of harmonizing procedures following the Cramo acquisition, including through our group-wide business code of conduct which is now in place. In our Nordic regions where Cramo operates, we have a whistleblowing channel whereby any concern or issue regarding a potential compliance violation may be reported and investigated in a confidential manner. In Central Europe, we operate our "Trust Persons" program whereby employees can report misconduct and receive guidance, support and advice. A whistleblowing channel for Central Europe is expected launch in the near future. Finally, the safety of our employees is of critical importance to us, and we invest heavily in safety trainings and policies. Safety is a recurring topic in management sessions and is monitored through audits, inspections and reviews. For the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, we had a LTIR of 16.2 and 17.4 injuries per one million working hours, respectively. _Environmental Care_ We continuously work to advance our capacities to mitigate our climate impact. In this respect, we focus on finding ways to reduce our energy consumption, increase the use of renewable energy, and increase circularity of our products across our operations. We also strive to use efficient logistics and transportation, reduce, reuse or recycle materials, reduce waste, and handle hazardous waste properly. In terms of facilities, installations and vehicle fleet, we seek to invest in energy-efficient products, services, and design for energy performance improvement. ----- _Social Care_ We strive to respect human rights throughout our entire value chain, and we support the Ten Principles of the United Nations Global Compact, which we aim to incorporate throughout our business and processes. Furthermore, we believe that an active collaboration with our customers, suppliers and other stakeholders is key to the further development of sustainable rental solutions. We therefore endeavor, where possible, to take an active role in the communities in which we operate and encourage our employees to do the same, such as by donating to local charities.

We maintain the types of insurance and the insured sums customary in our industry and countries of operation. To ensure we retain the coverage appropriate for our international operations, we use the advice and services of a network of international and local insurance brokers in the countries in which we operate. Our group insurance portfolio consists of international insurance programs with major insurance providers, supplemented locally in certain countries where we operate. It is comprised, in particular, of our automotive fleet insurance, general liability insurance, property insurance, accident insurance and cybercrime insurance. This set of tailored insurance policies includes coverage for, among other things, occupational accidents and injuries, equipment, real estate and other property damage or loss, cyber risks, and employers, product, public as well as directors and officers' liability insurance. We consider our insurance coverage to be adequate both as to risks and sums insured for our business. Our insurance portfolio is constantly reviewed for adequacy and adjusted if necessary. We have not had any material claims that were not covered under our insurance policies.

We are party to certain pending legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business. We cannot estimate with certainty our ultimate legal and financial responsibility or obligations with respect to such pending matters. See "Risk _Factors—Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment—We are exposed to various risks related to legal proceedings or claims." Based on our examination of these matters and the provisions we have made, we believe that any_ ultimate liability we may have for such matters will not have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. -----

The Issuer is a private company with limited liability (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands, having its registered office at Dr. Nolenslaan 140, 6136 GV Sittard, the Netherlands and registered in the Business Register of the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce (handelsregister van de _Kamer van Koophandel) under number 60885602._

The Issuer's Management Board is responsible for formulating our strategy and policies and setting and achieving our objectives. The following table sets out the names, ages and positions of the members of the management board, each of whom are also the statutory directors of the Issuer:

Subsubsection Title: Pierre Boels Jr. was appointed as Chief Executive Officer July 1996 and, together with his wife, are the owners
Subsubsection Text: of the Group. He first became involved in the Group in 1980, taking on day-to-day management from 1996. Since joining in 1980, he developed a platform for growth by diversifying the company and focus investments on general rental and specialist rental divisions. Over the past 40 years, Pierre built a resilient and sustainable company that delivered significant, profitable growth while successfully navigating economic challenges. He has served as the Vice President of the board of the European Rental Association from 2013 to 2016 and as President from 2016 to 2022. He also served as a member of the supervisory board of Joh. Mourik & Co. Holding B.V. from 2012 to 2020.

Subsubsection Title: Lilian Boels-Van Kerkom joined the Group in July 1987 and was appointed as a statutory director of the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: in July 2018. She currently holds an advisory role regarding legal matters, sales and operations and contract management. Lilian joined the company at an early stage of its development and has played an instrumental role in its growth, developing the various divisions she had worked in. She started her career in the Group as a commercial team leader for machine and party rental before creating the account receivables and insurance department in 1992 and the legal department in 2001. Her wide experience and knowledge of our company is critical in guiding the development of front-line operations and constructing the framework for rental transactions. She also advises on a wide variety of topics given her deep institutional knowledge. She graduated from HEAO Sittard in 1987.

Subsubsection Title: Jan Piet Valk was appointed as Chief Financial Officer for the Group in April 2020 and was appointed as a
Subsubsection Text: statutory director of the Issuer in September 2020. During his 35 years working in finance, he has served in various finance and general management positions at several multi-national companies, including SHELL, with a focus on M&A and corporate finance. He has experience working across multiple jurisdictions for multinational companies as well as the Royal Netherlands Airforce. Prior to joining our Group, he worked at Teleplan International NV, starting as the CFO upon its acquisition by Gilde Buy Out Partners, and becoming first, President of the North American Region, based in Dallas, Texas, and then, acting CEO until the company's acquisition by Clover Wireless in 2019, when the company was divested under his leadership. He holds a master's degree in economics from Vrije University in Amsterdam. He is due to step down as Chief Financial Officer on June 1, 2024 to become chair of the Supervisory Board on September 1, 2024.

Subsubsection Title: René Olsthoorn will be appointed Chief Financial Officer for the Group on June 1, 2024. Since May 2009, he has
Subsubsection Text: served as an executive officer of Timber and Building Supplies Holland N.V., first as Chief Financial Officer and, following his appointment in January 2019, as Chief Executive Officer. He began his career in 1990 as a project leader with Fokker Aircraft and has held management roles ranging from logistics to finance since then. He holds a master's degree in industrial engineering and management science from Technische Universiteit Eindhoven and a CMA from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. We also maintain an external advisory board consisting of a group of experienced entrepreneurs and investors which advises the Management Board on policy matters and the general course of affairs of the Group. -----

Subsubsection Title: Reiant Mulder joined the Boels Rental Group in October 2018, and is the Chief Operating Officer Central Europe.
Subsubsection Text: Before joining the Boels Rental Group, he was the Chief Executive Officer of Randstad Netherlands and Chief Information Officer of Randstad Groep Nederland from September 2014 to September 2018. Prior to that, he was the Operational Director for Randstad Professionals, Randstad Recruitment Solutions, Randstad Search & Selection and managed the central delivery of key accounts for Randstad Nederland from September 2010 to September 2014. From July 2008 to November 2012, he was the Managing Director of i-Bridge B.V. (ICT Shared Service Center Randstad Groep Nederlands). He holds a master's in Business Administration from Erasmus University Rotterdam.

Subsubsection Title: Guy Cremer joined the Group in November 1989 and has been the Chief Procurement Officer since August 2022
Subsubsection Text: and is responsible for the development of our rental fleet and related services. Since starting at Boels, he has served in various operational and strategic management positions. Throughout his career at Boels, his responsibilities included setting up new business models such as the DIY- rental division and advising on all M&A transactions. From his professional experience, he has developed expertise regarding growth in various products and customer segments. Outside his work for the Group, he has held various roles at the ERA since 2006 and won the ERA's Rental Person of the Year award in 2023, acknowledging his experience, market knowledge and service to the rental industry. Throughout his career he has completed coursework in leadership skills, strategic negotiations, quality management and strategic management from ISBW (Instituut voor Sociale en Bedrijfswetenschappen) and NEVI (Nederlandse Vereniging voor _Inkoopmanagement)._

Subsubsection Title: Martin Holmgren joined the Boels Group in January 2020, around the time of the Cramo acquisition. He has been
Subsubsection Text: the Chief Operating Officer Nordics since August 2020 and oversees the day-to-day management in the Nordic and Baltic markets. Before joining the Boels Group, he worked at Cramo from 2003 and was the Executive Vice President of Cramo Group Fleet Management from 2009 to 2020 and the Executive Vice President of IT and Digital from 2018 to 2020. He holds a bachelor's degree in Business Administration and Marketing from Karlstad University. As of 2022, he is a member of the board of the ERA, representing rental companies and national associations from across Europe. We also maintain an operations board, consisting of the chief operating officer, managing directors of the business units or country operational entities and the staff managers of the Finance, HSE and HR departments, which oversees the day-to-day operations of the business.

The Issuer's Strategic Board is responsible for the day-to-day management of the business. The Strategic Board consists of the members of the Management Board together with other members of our senior management. The following table sets out the names, ages and positions of the current members of the Strategic Board:

Pursuant to the application of the Dutch structural regime (structuurregime) as referred to in Section 264 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code and subject to the Issuer having satisfied the requirements as referred to in Section 264 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code for three consecutive years, the Issuer is required to implement a two-tier board system in 2025. The Issuer aims to install a Supervisory Board in September 2024. The Supervisory Board will supervise the general course of affairs in the company and the businesses affiliated with the company. It will also supervise the functioning of the Management Board as such and the policy conducted, and will provide the Management Board with advice. On March 19, 2024, it was announced that Jan Piet Valk will join the Supervisory Board as chairman as of September 1, 2024. -----
For the year ended December 31, 2023, the aggregate compensation paid to our Statutory Board and our Management Board was €3.2 million (2022: €3.3 million). -----

Subsection Title: SHAREHOLDERS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, P.B.K. NV, a public limited company (naamloze _vennootschap/société anonyme)) organized and existing under the laws of Belgium having its statutory seat at Javanastraat_ 38, 3680 Maaseik, Belgium and registered with the Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (Kruispuntbank van _Ondernemingen/Banque-Carrefour des Entreprises) under number 0459.002.515 (Business Court of Antwerp, division_ Tongeren) (the "Parent"), owned 100% of our share capital. The Parent is wholly owned by our CEO, Mr. Pierre Boels Jr., and his wife, Lilian Boels-Van Kerkom.

Subsubsection Title: Shareholder Loans
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we had €9.8 million in outstanding balances with related parties arising from a sale and lease back transaction which was pending as of that date. After taking into account financial liabilities to related parties, the net amount receivable of total outstanding balances with related parties as of December 31, 2023 amounted to €3.1 million. Other than those balances set out above, all other outstanding balances with related parties shown in our Annual Financial Statements have been settled. For additional information, see note 30 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements.

Subsubsection Title: Management Agreement
Subsubsection Text: As of January 1, 2022, the Issuer entered into a management agreement with the Parent, pursuant to which the Parent provides certain strategic, organizational, research and administrative assistance, as well as analysis on business development opportunities, and financial and legal advice. With the same effective date, Boels Verhuur NV entered into a director's agreement with the Parent, pursuant to which the Parent executes the daily operational management and provides certain strategic organizational and administrative assistance. For the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, we were invoiced €123 thousand under these contracts, respectively.

Subsubsection Title: Real Estate
Subsubsection Text: We are party to several real estate lease agreements with related parties and may in the future engage in similar transactions. In the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, we incurred real estate lease expenses relating to these properties of €187 thousand, €357 thousand and €1,317 thousand, respectively.

Subsubsection Title: Dividends
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended December 31, 2023, we distributed €13 million in dividends to the Parent. See note 30 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements. See "Management" above for details of remuneration paid to the Management Board. -----

In the course of our ordinary business activities, we enter into related party transactions with our shareholders, key management personnel and associates. We believe that all transactions with such parties are negotiated and executed on an arms-length basis and that the terms of these transactions are comparable to those currently contracted with unrelated third-parties. See note 30 to the FY 2023 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Facilities Agreement") providing for a revolving credit facility in an aggregate amount of €214,300,000, which was
Subsubsection Title: Ancillary facilities
Subsubsection Text: Under the Revolving Credit Facility, a lender (or an affiliate of a lender) may make available an ancillary facility by way of an overdraft facility, a guarantee, bonding, documentary or stand-by letter of credit facility, a short term loan facility, a derivatives facility, a foreign exchange facility, or any other facility or accommodation which is agreed by the Company and the relevant ancillary lender, to a borrower in place of all or part of the respective lender's unutilized Revolving Credit Facility commitment.

Subsection Title: Facilities Agreement") providing for a revolving credit facility in an aggregate amount of €214,300,000, which was
Subsubsection Title: Interest and fees
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities bear interest at a rate of EURIBOR plus the applicable margin. The margin applicable to the Senior Facilities is adjusted from time to time, subject to certain conditions (including but not limited to, if an event of default under certain clauses has occurred and is continuing, the highest margin being payable) to a percentage rate per annum determined in accordance with a Senior Secured Net Leverage related margin grid, such Senior Secured Net Leverage as calculated and certified in each quarterly compliance certificate which is required to be delivered to the Agent. If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of any loan made under the Senior Facilities Agreement. Default interest is 1.00% per annum higher than the interest rate that would otherwise be applicable in respect of the unpaid amount. We are required to pay quarterly in arrears a commitment fee on the available but undrawn commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 35% of the then applicable margin for the period commencing on the Closing Date (February 6, 2020) and ending on the last day of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility (July 6, 2026) being the date falling one month prior to the termination date applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility (or, if earlier, the date on which the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full). We are not required to pay any commitment fees to a lender for so long as it is a defaulting lender. We are also required to pay certain fees to the facility agent and the security agent in connection with the Senior Facilities Agreement.
