Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of these consolidated financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires management to make judgements (other than those involving estimations) that have a significant impact on the amounts recognised and to make estimates and assumptions which affect the reported amounts in these consolidated financial statements. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could result in outcomes that require a material adjustment to the carrying amount of assets or liabilities affected in future periods. Estimates are based on historical experience, where applicable, and other assumptions which management believes are reasonable under the circumstances. The Group evaluates its estimates on an ongoing basis. These estimates are inherently subject to judgement and actual results could differ from those estimates. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognised in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future periods if the revision affects both current and future periods. _Judgements_ - _Note 18 Lease liabilities: lease term of leases – Whether the Group is reasonably certain to exercise extension options. The extension options held are exercisable only by the Group. The Group assesses at the lease commencement date whether it is reasonably certain to exercise the extension option. The Group reassesses whether it is reasonably certain to exercise the options if there is a significant event or significant changes in circumstances within its control. _Estimates and assumptions_ - _Note 18 Lease liabilities: Estimating the incremental borrowing rate – Key assumptions in determining the underlying external data to be used in calculating the rate per asset. Boels makes use of a so-called ‘discount rate table’ in which different discount rates are maintained for different types of assets, remaining lease term and different economic environments (e.g. based on country). - _Note 19 Deferred tax assets: Availability of future taxable profit against which deductible temporary differences and tax losses carried forward can be utilised. - _Note 8 Intangible assets and goodwill: Impairment tests for intangible assets with an indefinite useful life – key assumptions underlying recoverable amounts, including growth rates and calculation of the WACC. - _Note 13 Trade and other receivables: Provision for expected credit losses on trade receivables and contract assets – key assumptions in determining the weighted average loss rate. The loss rate is determined per country/group of countries and based on actual credit loss experience over the past 2 years. - _Note 6 Property, plant and equipment: key assumptions in determining the expected useful life and residual value of tangible fixed assets. The estimated useful lives, residual values and depreciation method are reviewed at the end of each reporting period, with the effect of any changes in estimates accounted for on a prospective basis. - _Note 32 Capital and financial risk management: Measurement of financial instruments at fair value – Key assumptions in determining the fair value. Derivative financial instruments are recognised at fair value using level 2 measurement. The valuation technique used is based on observable market data and is provided by the offering financing institutes. The preparation of these consolidated financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires management to make judgements (other than those involving estimations) that have a significant impact on the amounts recognised and to make estimates and assumptions which affect the reported amounts in these consolidated financial statements. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could result in outcomes that require a material adjustment to the carrying amount of assets or liabilities affected in future periods. Estimates are based on historical experience, where applicable, and other assumptions which management believes are reasonable under the circumstances. The Group evaluates its estimates on an ongoing basis. These estimates are inherently subject to judgement and actual results could differ from those estimates. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognised in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future periods if the revision affects both current and future periods. The areas involving significant estimates and judgements are: - Estimating the incremental borrowing rate and lease term of leases; - Deferred tax assets; - Impairment tests for intangible assets with an indefinite useful life; - Provision for expected credit losses on trade receivables and contract assets; - Expected useful life and residual value of tangible fixed assets; - Measurement of financial instruments at fair value; - Valuation of financial assets.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: For the purposes of comparison and understanding the progress of the business, the company presents comparative figures for the prior period alongside the current reporting period. Comparative figures have been reclassified, restated, or rearranged where necessary to conform to changes in presentation in the current year. Any significant adjustments or reclassifications, and the reasons for such changes, are disclosed in the relevant financial statement line item. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements incorporate the financial statements of the Company and entities controlled by the Company (its subsidiaries) made up to 31 December each year. Control is achieved when the Company: - Has the power over the investee. - Is exposed, or has rights, to variable returns from its involvement with the investee. - Has the ability to use its power to affects its returns. The Company reassesses whether or not it controls an investee if facts and circumstances indicate that there are changes to one or more of the three elements of control listed above. Consolidation of a subsidiary begins when the Company obtains control over the subsidiary and ceases when the Company loses control of the subsidiary. Specifically, the results of subsidiaries acquired or disposed of during the year are included in profit or loss from the date the Company gains control until the date when the Company ceases to control the subsidiary. Where necessary, adjustments are made to the financial statements of subsidiaries to bring the accounting policies used into line with the Group’s accounting policies. Profit or loss and each component of other comprehensive income are attributed to the owners of the Company and to the non-controlling interests. Total comprehensive income of the subsidiaries is attributed to the owners of the Company and to the non-controlling interests even if this results in the non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. Fortrent Oy, Vanta (Finland) (50% – shareholding) qualifies as a joint venture and the Group’s share in equity has been accounted for – refer to note 3.5 and 9 for further information.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In preparing the financial statements of the Group entities, transactions in currencies other than the entity’s functional currency (foreign currencies) are recognised at the rates of exchange prevailing on the dates of the transactions. At each reporting date, monetary assets and liabilities that are denominated in foreign currencies are retranslated at the rates prevailing at that date. Non-monetary items that are measured in terms of historical cost are not retranslated. Exchange differences are recognised in profit or loss in the period in which they arise, except for exchange differences on transactions entered into to hedge certain foreign currency risks (see below under financial instruments/hedge accounting). For the purpose of presenting consolidated financial statements, the assets and liabilities of the Group’s foreign operations are translated at exchange rates prevailing on the reporting date. Income and expense items are translated at the average exchange rates for the period, unless exchange rates fluctuate significantly during that period, in which case the exchange rates at the date of transactions are used. Exchange differences arising, if any, are recognised in other comprehensive income and accumulated in a foreign currency translation reserve.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Property, plant and equipment is initially measured at cost and subsequently stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses, except for land, which is stated at cost less any accumulated impairment losses. Depreciation is recognised so as to write off the cost less their residual values over their useful lives, using the straight-line method, on the following basis: - Land is not depreciated. - Buildings: 2% – 10% per annum. - Machinery and equipment: 5% – 33% per annum. - Right-of-use assets: 2% – 50% per annum. - Other assets: 2.5% – 50% per annum. The estimated useful lives, residual values and depreciation method are reviewed at the end of each reporting period, with the effect of any changes in estimates accounted for on a prospective basis. Right-of-use assets are depreciated over the shorter period of the lease term and the useful life of the underlying asset. The accounting policy for leases is included in note 3.11. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _Goodwill_ Goodwill is initially recognised and measured as set out in note 3.1. Goodwill is not amortised but is reviewed for impairment at least annually. Impairment testing for goodwill is further discussed in notes 3.6 and 8. The Group’s policy for goodwill arising on the acquisition of equity accounted investments is discussed in note 3.5. _Other intangible assets_ Intangible assets that are acquired separately are carried at cost less accumulated amortisation and accumulated impairment losses. Amortisation is recognised on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives. Intangible assets acquired in a business combination and recognised separately from goodwill are recognised initially at their fair value at the acquisition date (which is regarded as their cost). Subsequent to initial recognition, intangible assets acquired in a business combination are reported at cost less accumulated amortisation and accumulated impairment losses, on the same basis as intangible assets that are acquired separately. _Brand name_ The Brand name “Cramo” was acquired during the acquisition of the Cramo Group in 2020, before the transition to IFRS. The brand name has been measured during the purchase price allocation applying the relief-of-royalty method. _Customer Contracts_ In business combinations, part of the purchase price has been allocated to customer contracts. The initial measurement of these customer contracts was determined by applying the multi-period excess earnings method and the forecasted revenues and profits related to these contracts. _Software_ The software is acquired from external vendors. The estimated useful lives of the brand name, customer contracts and software are as follow: - Brand name: 10 years. - Customer contracts: 5 years. - Software: 5 years. Intangible assets are derecognised on disposal, or when no future economic benefits are expected from use or disposal. Gains or losses arising from derecognition of an intangible asset, measured as the difference between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset, are recognised in profit or loss when the asset is derecognised.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Equity accounted investments includes investments in associates as well as investments in joint ventures. The results and assets and liabilities of associates and joint ventures are incorporated in these financial statements using the equity method of accounting, except when the investment is classified as held for sale, in which case it is accounted for in accordance with IFRS 5. On acquisition of the investment in an associate or a joint venture, any excess of the cost of the investment over the Group’s share of the net fair value of the identifiable assets and liabilities of the investee is recognised as goodwill, which is included within the carrying amount of the investment. Any excess of the Group’s share of the net fair value of the identifiable assets and liabilities over the cost of the investment, after reassessment, is recognised immediately in profit or loss in the period in which the investment is acquired. When a Group entity transacts with an associate or a joint venture of the Group, profits and losses resulting from the transactions with the associate or joint venture are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of interests in the associate or joint venture that are not related to the Group.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _Goodwill_ For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill is allocated to each of the Group’s cash-generating units (or groups of cash-generating units) expected to benefit from the synergies of the combination. Cash-generating units to which goodwill has been allocated are tested for impairment annually, or more frequently when there is an indication that the unit may be impaired. If the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit is less than the carrying amount of the unit, the impairment loss is allocated first to reduce the carrying amount of any goodwill allocated to the unit and then to the other assets of the unit pro-rata on the basis of the carrying amount of each asset in the unit. An impairment loss recognised for goodwill is not reversed in a subsequent period. ----- _Impairment of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets_ At each reporting date, the Group reviews the carrying amounts of its property, plant and equipment and intangible assets to determine whether there is any indication that those assets have suffered an impairment loss. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated to determine the extent of the impairment loss (if any). Where the asset does not generate cash flows that are independent from other assets, the Group estimates the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs. When a reasonable and consistent basis of allocation can be identified, corporate assets are also allocated to individual cashgenerating units, or otherwise they are allocated to the smallest group of cash-generating units for which a reasonable and consistent allocation basis can be identified. Recoverable amount is the higher of fair value less costs of disposal and value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset for which the estimates of future cash flows have not been adjusted. If the recoverable amount of an asset (or cash-generating unit) is estimated to be less than its carrying amount, the carrying amount of the asset (or cash-generating unit) is reduced to its recoverable amount. An impairment loss is recognised immediately in profit or loss. Where an impairment loss subsequently reverses, the carrying amount of the asset (or cashgenerating unit) is increased to the revised estimate of its recoverable amount, but so that the increased carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined had no impairment loss been recognised for the asset (or cash-generating unit) in prior years. A reversal of an impairment loss is recognised immediately in profit or loss to the extent that it eliminates the impairment loss which has been recognised for the asset in prior years. _Equity accounted investments_ The net investment in an equity accounted investment is assessed for impairment if there is objective evidence of impairment as a result of one or more events that occurred after the initial recognition of the net investment (a ‘loss event’). An impairment loss is only incurred if that loss event (or events) has an impact on the estimated future cash flows from the net investment that can be reliably estimated. When objective evidence of impairment exists, the entire carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 as a single asset by comparing its recoverable amount (higher of value in use and fair value less costs of disposal) with its carrying amount. Any impairment loss recognised is not allocated to any asset, including goodwill that forms part of the carrying amount of the investment. Any reversal of that impairment loss is recognised in accordance with IAS 36 to the extent that the recoverable amount of the investment subsequently increases.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Inventory is stated at the lower of replacement value, i.e. purchase price and net realisable value. Cost is determined using the first in, first out (FIFO) method. Net realisable value is the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business less the estimated costs of completion and the estimated costs necessary to make the sale. Net realisable value is determined making allowance for obsolescence of inventories. Items of property, plant and equipment that were previously held for rental to others are transferred to inventories for disposal at their carrying value when they cease to be rented. When these assets are reclassified to inventory, they cease to be depreciated and are carried at the lower of cost (carrying amount at the time of transfer) and net realisable value.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Financial assets and financial liabilities are initially measured at fair value, except for trade receivables that do not have a significant financing component which are measured at transaction price. Transaction costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition or issue of financial assets and financial liabilities are added to or deducted from the fair value of the financial assets or financial liabilities, as appropriate, on initial recognition. _Subsequent measurement of financial assets_ The Group’s financial asset debt instruments consists mainly of trade receivables, other receivables, loans and cash and cash equivalents. _Trade receivables_ Trade receivables that do not have a significant financing component, are measured initially at the transaction price as determined in accordance with IFRS 15. Trade receivables are subsequently measured at amortised cost. ----- _Other receivables_ Other receivables relate to unbilled revenue accruals and contract assets. Other receivables are initially measured at the transaction price as determined in accordance with IFRS 15 and subsequently measured at amortised cost. _Loans_ Loans relate to loans to associates, participants and related parties. Loans are measured initially at fair value and are subsequently measured at amortised cost. _Cash and cash equivalents_ Cash and cash equivalents are measured initially at fair value and subsequently measured at amortised cost. _Impairment of financial assets_ The Group applies the simplified approach permitted by IFRS 9 and recognises lifetime expected credit losses (ECL) for trade and other receivables. The expected credit losses are estimated primarily by virtue of a provision matrix based on the Group’s historical credit loss experience, adjusted for general economic conditions and an assessment of both the current as well as the forecast direction of conditions at the reporting date. The Group also provides for a lifetime ECL on specific trade and other receivable balances based on individual assessment. For loans, the Group recognises a lifetime ECL when there has been a significant increase in credit risk since initial recognition. However, if the credit risk on the financial instrument has not increased significantly since initial recognition, the Group measures the loss allowance for that financial instrument at an amount equal to 12-month ECL. The Group recognises an impairment gain or loss in profit or loss for all financial assets with a corresponding adjustment to their carrying amount through a loss allowance account. Financial assets are written-off against the loss allowance account when there is information indicating that the debtor is in severe financial difficulty and there is no realistic prospect of recovery. Financial assets written off may still be subject to enforcement activities under the Group’s recovery procedures, taking into account legal advice where appropriate. Any recoveries made are recognised in profit or loss. While cash and cash equivalents are also subject to the impairment requirements of IFRS 9, the estimated ECL is insignificant. _Classification of financial liabilities_ All financial liabilities are measured subsequently at amortised cost using the effective interest method. The Group’s financial liabilities consists mainly of trade and other payables, bank- and other loans. _Trade and other payables_ Trade and other payables are initially measured at fair value and subsequently measured at amortised cost. _Borrowings_ Bank and other loans are initially measured at fair value and subsequently measured at amortised cost. _Derivative financial instruments_ The Group enters into a variety of derivative financial instruments to manage its exposure to interest rate and foreign exchange rate risks. Derivatives are recognised initially at fair value at the date a derivative contract is entered into and are subsequently remeasured to their fair value at each reporting date. Refer to note 3.9 for the accounting policy on hedge accounting. _Equity instruments_ An equity instrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all of its liabilities. Equity instruments issued by the Group are recognised at the proceeds received, net of direct issue costs. Equity instruments of the Group relates mainly to ordinary shares issued. _Share capital_ Share capital represents the nominal (par) value of issued shares. _Offsetting of financial instruments_ Financial assets and financial liabilities are offset and the net amount is reported in the consolidated statement of financial position if there is a currently enforceable legal right to offset the recognised amounts and there is an intention to settle on a net basis, to realise the assets and settle the liabilities simultaneously. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Group designates certain derivatives as hedging instruments in respect of foreign currency risk and interest rate risk in hedges of net investments in foreign operations, or cash flow hedges. At the inception of the hedge relationship, the Group documents the relationship between the hedging instrument and the hedged item, along with its risk management objectives and its strategy for undertaking various hedge transactions. Furthermore, at the inception of the hedge and on an ongoing basis, the Group documents whether the hedging instrument is effective in offsetting changes in cash flows of the hedged item attributable to the hedged risk, which is when the hedging relationships meet all of the following hedge effectiveness requirements: - There is an economic relationship between the hedged item and the hedging instrument. - The effect of credit risk does not dominate the value changes that result from that economic relationship. - The hedge ratio of the hedging relationship is the same as that resulting from the quantity of the hedged item that the Group actually hedges and the quantity of the hedging instrument that the Group actually uses to hedge that quantity of hedged item. If a hedging relationship ceases to meet the hedge effectiveness requirement relating to the hedge ratio but the risk management objective for that designated hedging relationship remains the same, the Group adjusts the hedge ratio of the hedging relationship (i.e. rebalances the hedge) so that it meets the qualifying criteria again. The group designates the full change in the fair value of a forward contract (i.e. including the forward elements) as the hedging instrument for all of its hedging relationships involving forward contracts. If the hedged item is time-period related, then the amount accumulated in the cost of hedging reserve is reclassified to profit or loss on a rational basis – the Group applies straight-line amortisation. Those reclassified amounts are recognised in profit or loss in the same line as the hedged item. Furthermore, if the Group expects that some or all of the loss accumulated in cost of hedging reserve will not be recovered in the future, that amount is immediately reclassified to profit or loss. Note 32 sets out details of the fair values of the derivative instruments used for hedging purposes. _Cash flow hedges_ The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivatives and other qualifying hedging instruments that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedges is recognised in other comprehensive income and accumulated under the heading of cash flow hedging reserve, limited to the cumulative change in fair value of the hedged item from inception of the hedge. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognised immediately in profit or loss and is included in the ‘Other gains and losses’ line item. Amounts previously recognised in other comprehensive income and accumulated in equity are reclassified to profit or loss in the periods when the hedged item affects profit or loss, in the same line as the recognised hedged item. Furthermore, if the Group expects that some or all of the loss accumulated in the cash flow hedging reserve will not be recovered in the future, that amount is immediately reclassified to profit or loss. The Group discontinues hedge accounting only when the hedging relationship (or a part thereof) ceases to meet the qualifying criteria (after rebalancing, if applicable). This includes instances when the hedging instrument expires or is sold, terminated or exercised. The discontinuation is accounted for prospectively. Any gain or loss recognised in other comprehensive income and accumulated in cash flow hedge reserve at that time remains in equity and is reclassified to profit or loss when the forecast transaction occurs. When a forecast transaction is no longer expected to occur, the gain or loss accumulated in the cash flow hedge reserve is reclassified immediately to profit or loss. _Hedges of net investments in foreign operations_ Hedges of net investments in foreign operations are accounted for similarly to cash flow hedges. Any gain or loss on the foreign currency forward contracts relating to the effective portion of the hedge is recognised in other comprehensive income and accumulated in the foreign currency translation reserve. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognised immediately in profit or loss.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents include cash-on-hand and bank balances. Bank overdrafts are included in current liabilities on the statement of financial position. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: 3.11 Leases: the Group as a lessee
Subsubsection Text: The lease portfolio of the Group consists of real-estate leases, vehicle leases and the rental of equipment. The Group assesses whether a contract is, or contains, a lease, at inception of the contract and recognises a right-of-use asset and a corresponding lease liability at the commencement date of the lease. The right-of-use assets are presented separately in note 7. The lease liability is presented as a separate line in the consolidated statement of financial position. As a practical expedient, by class of underlying asset, IFRS 16 permits a lessee not to separate non-lease components, and instead account for any lease and associated non-lease components as a single arrangement. The Group has elected the practical expedient to account for lease – and non-lease components (within a lease) as a single lease component for its vehicle leases. The Group has not elected the expedient for its real-estate and rental fleet leases and accounts for lease- and non-lease components separately. The Group has also elected not to recognise right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for leases of low-value assets and short-term leases (12 months or less). The lease payments associated with these leases are recognised as an expense within “Other operating expenses” on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 13 establishes a hierarchy that categorises into three levels the inputs used to measure fair value by giving the highest priority to quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets and liabilities (level 1 inputs) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (level 3 inputs). In some cases, the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset, or a liability might be categorised within different levels of the fair value hierarchy. In those cases, the fair value measurement is categorised in its entirety in the same level of the fair value hierarchy at the lowest level input that is significant to the entire measurement. Levels used in the hierarchy are as follows: Level 1: Fair values are based on quoted prices in active markets. Level 2: Fair values are determined on the basis of valuation techniques which use inputs that are based on observable market data. Level 3: Fair values that are determined on the basis of valuation techniques which use inputs that are not based on observable market data. _Financial instruments at fair value_ Derivative financial instruments are recognised at fair value using level 2 measurement. The valuation technique used is based on observable market data and is provided by the offering financing institutes. _Financial instruments at amortised cost_ The majority of the Group financial assets and liabilities are carried at amortised cost using the effective interest method. The fair values of these instruments are not materially different from their carrying values since the instruments are either short-term in nature or the interest rates are on market terms.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Group recognises revenue mainly from the rental of equipment. Other revenue is earned from the sale of consumables and smalls as well as additional services relating to equipment rental. _Equipment rental_ Components of rental contracts relating the use of an asset are accounted for as an operational lease, with revenue recognised on a straight-line basis over the duration of the lease. Lease duration generally varies from several days to a few months. Damage waiver’s taken up by customers do not transfer a separate service and are accounted for as part of, and over a consistent period with, the associated with the rental. _Sales of goods and other services_ Other contract components, or contracts which do not pertain to equipment rental, are recognised as revenue at the point in time at which control is transferred to the customer (for sales) or as the performance obligation is satisfied (for other services). Revenue is measured based on the total consideration to which the Group expects to be entitled from these contracts (excluding contract consideration allocated to equipment rental). The Group recognizes revenue from the sale of its fleet and other products at the point in time that the products have been collected by or delivered to the customer. The Group recognizes revenue from its labour services as these services are provided to the customer. The progress of these services provided are measured as the amount of hours of labour Boels provided to the customer. For this last service, as a practical expedient, the revenue is recognised at the moment the service is performed in line with IFRS 15.B16. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _Short-term and other long-term employee benefits_ Liabilities recognised in respect of short-term employee benefits are measured at the undiscounted amount of the benefits expected to be paid in exchange for the related service. A liability is recognised for benefits accruing to employees in respect of wages and salaries, annual leave and sick leave in the period the related service is rendered at the undiscounted amount of the benefits expected to be paid in exchange for that service. Liabilities recognised in respect of other long-term employee benefits are measured at the present value of the estimated future cash outflows expected to be made by the Group in respect of services provided by employees up to the reporting date. _Retirement benefits_ The Group operates a defined contribution plan for its employees. Boels Topholding B.V. pays contributions to pension funds and insurance companies on a contractual basis. Except for paying contributions, Boels Topholding B.V. has no other obligations to pay further contributions by virtue of these pension plans. No provision is made for probable future increase of premium. The employees bear the actuarial and investment risk. Payments to defined contribution retirement benefit plans are recognised as an expense when employees have rendered service entitling them to the contributions. Prepaid contributions are recognised as prepayments and accrued income to the extent that this will lead to a reduction in future payments or a cash refund. Of the foreign group companies of the Group, only Boels Rental Germany GmbH, Cramo AB and Cramo Services Sweden AB have its own pension plan as a result of a pension arrangement from the past that is applicable for a specific group of former Cramo AG employees. These plans qualify as a defined benefit plan in accordance with IAS 19. The Group has elected not to apply the IAS 19 disclosure principles applicable to defined benefit plans as the quantitative and qualitative effect is immaterial.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The income tax expense represents the sum of the tax currently payable and deferred tax. _Current tax_ The tax currently payable is based on taxable profit for the year. The Group’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. A provision is recognised for those matters for which the tax determination is uncertain, but it is considered probable that there will be a future outflow of funds to a tax authority. The provisions are measured at the best estimate of the amount expected to become payable. _Deferred tax_ Deferred tax is the tax expected to be payable or recoverable on differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit and is accounted for using the liability method. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognised for all taxable temporary differences and deferred tax assets are recognised to the extent that it is probable that taxable profits will be available against which deductible temporary differences can be utilised. The carrying amount of deferred tax assets is reviewed at each reporting date and reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that sufficient taxable profits will be available to allow all or part of the asset to be recovered. Deferred tax is calculated at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period when the liability is settled, or the asset is realised based on tax laws and rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner in which the Group expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and the Group intends to settle its current tax assets and liabilities on a net basis. _Current tax and deferred tax for the year_ Current and deferred tax are recognised in profit or loss, except when they relate to items that are recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity, in which case, the current and deferred tax are also recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity respectively. Where current tax or deferred tax arises from the initial accounting for a business combination, the tax effect is included in the accounting for the business combination. ----- _Related party transactions_ Key Management Personnel and their Close family members are related parties to Boels. Close family members are those family members who might be expected to influence, or be influenced by, that person in their dealings with the entity, this also includes adult children of the key management personnel (and their spouses). If a transaction with Key Management Personnel (or a close family member) is considered material, Boels will disclose the transaction.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: 4.** **Changes in material accounting policies 4.1** **Deferred tax related to assets and liabilities arising from a single transaction (Amendments to IAS 12)
Subsubsection Text: For some transactions, IFRS Standards require the simultaneous recognition of an asset and a liability. A consequence is that IAS 12 could also require the recognition of offsetting temporary differences. Before the amendments, it was not clear whether IAS 12 required recognition of deferred taxes for these temporary differences or whether the initial recognition exemption applied. That exemption prohibits an entity from recognising deferred tax assets and liabilities on initial recognition of an asset or liability in a transaction which is not a business combination and affects neither accounting nor taxable profit. The Board amends IAS 12 to provide a further exception from the initial recognition exemption. Under the amendments, an entity does not apply the initial recognition exemption for transactions that give rise to equal taxable and deductible temporary differences. The amendments were announced in 2021. The Group transitioned to IFRS last year and already was aware of the diversity in practice and the amendments forthcoming. Therefore on initial application, the Group already recognised deferred tax for transactions within the scope of the amendment, and therefore the amendments do not affect the Group.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: 4.2 International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules (Amendments to IAS 12)
Subsubsection Text: In December 2021, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) issued model rules for a new global minimum tax framework (Pillar Two), and various governments around the world have issued, or are in the process of issuing, legislation on this. The group has adopted International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules (Amendments to IAS 12) upon their release on 23 May 2023. The amendments provide a temporary mandatory exception from deferred tax accounting for the top-up tax, which is effective immediately, and require new disclosures about the Pillar Two Exposure. The Pillar Two rules apply to multinational enterprises that have consolidated revenues of € 750m in at least two of the last four years. Considering the Group’s revenues, Pillar Two rules apply to the Group. The mandatory exception applies retrospectively. However no new legislation to implement the top-up tax was enacted or substantively enacted at 31 December 2022 in any jurisdiction in which the group operates and no related deferred tax recognised at that date, the retrospective application has no impact on the Group’s consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: 4.3 Material accounting policy information (Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2)
Subsubsection Text: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) has issued ‘Disclosure of Accounting Policies (Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2)’ with amendments that are intended to help preparers in deciding which accounting policies to disclose in their financial statements. The amendments are effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2023. Disclosure of Accounting Policies (Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2) amends IAS 1 in the following ways: - an entity is now required to disclose its material accounting policy information instead of its significant accounting policies; - several paragraphs are added to explain how an entity can identify material accounting policy information and to give examples of when accounting policy information is likely to be material; - the amendments clarify that accounting policy information may be material because of its nature, even if the related amounts are immaterial; - the amendments clarify that accounting policy information is material if users of an entity’s financial statements would need it to understand other material information in the financial statements; - and the amendments clarify that if an entity discloses immaterial accounting policy information, such information shall not obscure material accounting policy information. In addition, IFRS Practice Statement 2 has been amended by adding guidance and examples to explain and demonstrate the application of the ‘four-step materiality process’ to accounting policy information in order to support the amendments to IAS 1. Boels has conducted a thorough review of the financial statements, resulting in the elimination of certain standardised texts. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 17 is effective from the beginning of 2023. The Group assessed whether the introduction of IFRS 17 has any implications for the group’s financial statements. It is worth mentioning that the group identified potential insurance contracts and specifically focussed on damage waivers. It is concluded that these do not qualify as insurance contracts or similar arrangements under IFRS 17. This amendment does not has an impact on the financial statements presented by the Group.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: 4.5 Definition of accounting estimates (amendments to IAS 8)
Subsubsection Text: The International Accounting Standards Board (the Board) has noted diversity in practice in making this distinction because the term accounting estimates was not defined and the previous definition of a change in accounting estimate was unclear. The Board has now issued amendments to IAS 8 Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors to clarify how companies should distinguish changes in accounting policies from changes in accounting estimates, with a primary focus on the definition of and clarifications on accounting estimates. This amendment does not has an impact on the financial statements presented by the Group.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The amended standards that are issued but not yet effective as at December 31, 2023, are listed below: Amendments to IFRS 16 Lease Liability in a Sale and Leaseback Amendments to IAS 1 Non-current Liabilities with Covenants Amendments to IAS 7 and IFRS 7 Supplier finance arrangements Amendments to IAS 21 Lack of Exchangeability The Group will adopt these amended standards when they become effective. The amended standards are not expected to have a material impact on the Group’s financial statements. -----

Subsubsection Text: Cost 413,122 33,999 11,610 46,156 504,887 Accumulated amortisation and impairment (39,186) (9,916) (6,773) (26,527) (82,402) Cost 413,122 33,999 11,610 46,156 504,887 Accumulated amortisation and impairment (39,186) (9,916) (6,773) (26,527) (82,402) ----- _Goodwill_ For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill acquired in a business combination is, from the acquisition date, allocated to each of the Group’s cash-generating units (CGUs), or groups of CGUs, that are expected to benefit from the combination, irrespective of whether other assets or liabilities of the acquisition are assigned to those units or groups of CGUs. Goodwill is tested for impairment, annually or more frequently if there are indications that goodwill might be impaired. In 2022, there were multiple groups of CGUs with allocated goodwill, the most significant being for the goodwill of the Cramo acquisition which has been allocated to Scandinavia, Finland and Baltics, and Central Europe. Goodwill is allocated to the respective CGU’s as indicated below: Finland and Central (x €1,000) Scandinavia Baltics Europe Total Carrying value as at December 31, 2022 158,169 81,764 134,003 373,936 Carrying value as at December 31, 2021 158,169 81,764 122,038 361,970 Carrying value as at January 1, 2021 158,169 81,764 122,038 361,970 The impairment test is based on cash flow projections for five years. CGU’s are tested for impairment by comparing the carrying amount of each group of CGU to its recoverable amount. Scandinavia The recoverable amount of the Scandinavia CGU, is determined based on a value in use calculation which uses cash flow projections based on financial forecasts approved by management covering a five-year period and a post-tax discount rate of 9.1% per annum (2021: 6.3% per annum) calculated by the weighted average cost of capital method as derived through the Capital Asset Pricing Model. The pre-tax discount rate equals 10.9% (2021: 7.4%). The key assumptions used by management in setting the financial forecasts for the initial five-year period were as follows: _Forecast sales growth rates_ Forecast sales growth rates are based on past experience adjusted for a continued strong growth rate as historically seen. Revenue is expected to grow at 2.2%. _Operating profits_ Operating profits are forecasted based on historical experience of operating margins adjusted for the impact of market expectations. _Cash conversion_ Cash conversion is the ratio of operating cash flows to operating profit. Management forecasts cash conversion rates based on historical experience. Finland and Baltics The recoverable amount of the Finland and Baltics CGU, is determined based on a value in use calculation which uses cash flow projections based on financial forecasts approved by management covering a five-year period and a post-tax discount rate of 9.8% per annum (2021: 6.7% per annum) calculated by the weighted average cost of capital method as derived through the Capital Asset Pricing Model. The pre-tax discount rate equals 11.8% (2021: 7.9%). The key assumptions used by management in setting the financial forecasts for the initial five-year period were as follows: _Forecast sales growth rates_ Forecast sales growth rates are based on past experience adjusted for a continued strong growth rate as historically seen. Revenue is expected to grow at 2.2%. _Operating profits_ Operating profits are forecasted based on historical experience of operating margins adjusted for the impact of market expectations. _Cash conversion_ Cash conversion is the ratio of operating cash flows to operating profit. Management forecasts cash conversion rates based on historical experience. Central Europe The recoverable amount of the Central Europe CGU, is determined based on a value in use calculation which uses cash flow projections based on financial forecasts approved by management covering a five-year period and a post-tax discount rate of 9.3% per annum (2021: 6.4% per annum) calculated by the weighted average cost of capital method as derived through the Capital Asset Pricing Model. The pre-tax discount rate equals 11.8% (2021: 7.8%). The key assumptions used by management in setting the financial forecasts for the initial five-year period were as follows: ----- Place of incorporation and principal place of business _Forecast sales growth rates_ Forecast sales growth rates are based on past experience adjusted for a continued strong growth rate as historically seen. Revenue is expected to grow at 2.2%. _Operating profits_ Operating profits are forecasted based on historical experience of operating margins adjusted for the impact of market expectations. _Cash conversion_ Cash conversion is the ratio of operating cash flows to operating profit. Management forecasts cash conversion rates based on historical experience. _Sensitivity analysis_ The Group has conducted an analysis of the sensitivity of the impairment test to changes in the key assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount for each of the group of CGUs to which goodwill is allocated. Management believes that any reasonably possible change in the key assumptions on which the recoverable amount of the CGUs are based would not cause the aggregate carrying amount to exceed the aggregate recoverable amount of the related CGUs. Based on the impairment analysis no impairment was recognized as at 31 December 2022, 31 December 2021 or 1 January 2021. _Impairment_ For the purpose of impairment testing, no impairment was identified as at 31 December 2022, 31 December 2021 or 1 January 2021 following the Group’s annual impairment test on Goodwill. Additionally, no indicators of impairment were identified for other intangible assets and detailed impairment testing was not required for these assets.

Sensitivity analysis The Group has conducted an analysis of the sensitivity of the impairment test to changes in the key assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount for each of the group of CGU’s to which goodwill is allocated. Management believes that any reasonably possible change in the key assumptions on which the recoverable amount of the CGU’s is based could cause the aggregate carrying amount to exceed the aggregate recoverable amount of the related CGU’s. _Scandinavia_ A 1% increase in the WACC for Scandinavia is considered reasonably possible based on recent experience and would lead to an impairment charge of EUR 17 million. A 0.5% decrease in the Forecast revenue growth rate, which is considered reasonably possible based on recent experience, would not lead to an impairment. _Finland and Baltics_ A 1% increase in the WACC for Finland and Baltics is considered reasonably possible based on recent experience and would not lead to an impairment. A 0.5% decrease in the Forecast revenue growth rate, which is considered reasonably possible based on recent experience, would not lead to an impairment. _Central Europe_ A 1% increase in the WACC for Central Europe is considered reasonably possible based on recent experience and would not lead to an impairment. A 0.5% decrease in the Forecast revenue growth rate, which is considered reasonably possible based on recent experience, would not lead to an impairment. Based on the impairment analysis no impairment was recognised as at 31 December 2023 (In 2022 no impairment was recognised). Impairment For the purpose of impairment testing, no impairment was identified as at 31 December 2023, following the Group’s annual impairment test on Goodwill. Additionally, no indicators of impairment 9 Investments in joint ventures Details of investments in joint ventures Name of joint venture Principal activity Proportion of ownership interest and voting rights held by the Group Fortrent Oy Equipment rental services Vantaa, Finland 50% (2022: 50%) The investment in Fortrent Oy is classified as an investment in a joint venture and is a private entity. As such, it is not listed on any public exchange and a quoted market price is not available for this investments. The company is owned and controlled jointly 50/50 by Cramo Oy and Ramirent Oyj. Fortrent Oy is a holding company that used to own Fortrent LLC, a construction machinery and equipment rental company operating in Russia. Fortrent Oy held a 100% share in the company Fortrent LLC in Russia, which was sold during 2023. Considering the level of uncertainty on its business operations in Russia and the high volatility of the Ruble, Boels had fully impaired its investment in Fortrent Oy in 2022. During 2023, € 7,351 thousand of the impairment is reversed as it became clear that Fortrent would be able to sell the subsidiary, which are the proceeds net received from the sale. Boels has no operational involvement in this joint venture, which functions as a stand-alone company in every respect. After the sale of Fortrent LLC, it was decided by Fortrent Oy to distribute all assets (cash) to its shareholders in December 2023 and liquidate the entity in 2024. Per year end only a small amount of cash remains in the joint venture, that will be used to liquidate the entity, which will take a few months. Therefore the fair value less cost to sell or distribute of the Joint Venture is nihil. No additional proceeds are expected from the joint venture. As a result of the sale of Fortrent Oy’s subsidiary, Boels has recycled the translation difference related to Fortrent through P&L. As part of the transition of Boels to IFRS per transition date (1 January 2021), the FX reserve was reset. Since then the FX reserves accumulated to a credit amount of € 1,160 thousand (Other Operating Expenses/Income). ----- _Reconciliation of carrying value at the beginning and end of the year Investment in joint ventures_ (x €1,000) 2023 2022 Carrying value at 1 January** - 10,396 Group's share of net profit in joint ventures - Movement due to FX - 547 Reclass to asset-held-for-sale - (10,943)

These facilities now consist of: - A bullet term loan B with a notional amount of € 1,250 million, maturing in 2027 (31-12-2022: € 1,450 million). - A Revolving Credit Facility of € 214.3 million (undrawn), maturing in 2026 (31-12-2022: € 179.3 million, undrawn). The maturity of the term loan B (nominal value) is as follows: No later than 1 year Later than 1 year and no later than 5 years 1,250,000 Later than 5 years In 2023 the average interest rate on the term loan B amounts to 6.2% (2022: 3.6%). The loan agreement contains certain restrictive financial covenants, typical to such agreements, primarily related to the leverage for the Group as a whole. The Company and certain of its main subsidiaries are jointly and severally liable for the syndicated facility agreement. During 2023 as well as on 31 December 2023 Boels has been in compliance with these financial covenants. The syndicated facility agreement is secured by: - A pledge over the shares of Boels Topholding B.V., Boels Holding B.V. and each material company that is an obligor in the facility agreement. - A pledge over shareholder loans and intercompany loans. - A pledge of certain bank accounts. _Securitisation of part of the accounts receivables_ During the reporting period, Boels Topholding B.V. attracted new financing by securitizing part of the Accounts receivables of the operating businesses Boels Verhuur B.V., Boels Rental Germany GmbH, and Boels Verhuur NV. Consequently, at December 31, 2023, € 86.3 million of Accounts Receivables are securitised. The remaining Accounts Receivable balance of € 167.7 million is not securitised. At December 31, 2023, the balance of the loan equals € 54.8 million, presented under Current Financial Liabilities. |(x €1,000)|Loans with financial institutions|Bonds|Derivatives|Other|Total| |---|---|---|---|---|---| |At 31 December 2022 Non-current Current Additions Amortised expenses Accrued interest Repayments Fair value adjustments|1,408,604 1,408,604 - 104,767 14,079 - (250,000) -|- - - 400,000 (6,597) - - -|1,093 1,093 - - - - - 22,390|7,460 7,411 49 1,683 - 19.697 - -|1,417,157 1,417,108 49 506,450 7,482 19,697 (250,000) 22,390| |At 31 December 2023 Non-current Current|1,277,450|393,403|23,483|28,840|1,723,176| ||1,222,953 54,497|393,403 -|15,303 8,180|7,311 21,529|1,638,970 84,206| |(x €1,000)|Loans with financial institutions|Bonds|Derivatives|Other|Total| |---|---|---|---|---|---| |At 31 December 2021 Non-current Current Additions Amortised expenses Accrued interest Repayments Fair value adjustments|1,398,512 1,398,466 46 - 10,137 - (45) -|- - - - - - - -|1,272 - 1,272 1,093 - - - (1,272)|7,753 7,699 53 - - (10) - (283)|1,407,537 1,406,166 1,371 1,093 10,137 (10) (45) (1,555)| ||1,408,604|-|1,093|7,460|1,417,157| ----- This transaction is facilitated by the newly created entity Boels Rental Finance B.V., to which the Group holds no voting rights. However, as the Group is exposed to the variability of returns from the performance of Boels Rental Finance B.V. and as Boels Rental Finance B.V.’s operations are dependent on the decisions made by the Group, Boels Rental Finance B.V. is consolidated and included in the Financial Statements of the Group. The accounts receivables are sold to Boels Rental Finance B.V., which is consolidated into the Financial Statements of the Group. As the Group effectively retains the economic ownership of the accounts receivables, the accounts receivables are included in Boels’ financial accounts. The agreement is subject to a floating interest rate with a fixed markup. _Bonds_ On September 21, 2023 the company has successfully issued its debut Bond for € 400 million maturing in 2029 with a fixed coupon of 6.25%. The maturity of the bond loans is as follows: No later than 1 year Later than 1 year and no later than 5 years Later than 5 years 400,000 In 2023 the average interest rate amounts to 6.25%. The Bond ranks pari passu with the term loan B and the Revolving Credit Facility. The indenture contains certain restrictive financial covenants, typical to such agreements, related to the incurrence of additional indebtedness for the Group as a whole. The Company and certain of its main subsidiaries are jointly and severally liable for the Bond. _Derivatives_ To manage interest rate risks at 31 December 2023, interest rate swaps have been concluded for an amount of € 1,000 million (2022: € 900 million), the duration is as follows: No later than 1 year Later than 1 year and no later than 5 years 1,000,000 Later than 5 years In 2023, additional interest rate swaps have been concluded for an amount of € 250 million (2022: € 550 million) with a duration of less than 1 year. _Other financial liabilities_ The other financial liabilities consist of: - Accrued interest on the loan from financial institutions for the amount of € 19,697 thousand. - Loans with a nominal amount of € 3,510 thousand. The interest amounts to 3.5% on annual basis. Repayment takes place at 31 December 2026. - Old age reserve to the CEO in amount of € 2,493 thousand has been presented as liability, which has a duration of more than 5 years. - Own benefit plan in amount of € 1,373 thousand which is the result of a pension arrangement from the past that is applicable for a specific group of former Cramo AG, Cramo AB and Cramo Services Sweden AB employees. - A current account of € 758 thousand. The interest on this loan is at arm’s lengths, refer to note 30. - Other financial liabilities in amount of € 1,009 thousand, which is related to unconditional deferred payments in relation the acquisition of KraftX AB and Illumin8 Lights Ltd.

Subsubsection Text: _Change in classification_ During 2023, the Group updated their Chart of Accounts. As a result it was noted that it is deemed more appropriate to separately report on Other Non-current Liabilities. In previous years the non-material amounts of Other Non-current Liabilities were presented as ‘Other Current Liabilities – Deferred Income’. Comparative amounts in the consolidated statement of financial position were reclassified for consistency. As a result, € 9 thousand was reclassified from ‘Other Current Liabilities – Deferred Income ’ to ‘Other Non-current Liabilities’. Considering this change is made to provide more relevant and more reliable information and has no material effect on the information in the balance sheet at the beginning of the preceding period, no opening balance sheet is required. 22 Operating segments The Group applies IFRS 8 Operating Segments for the first time as of the period ending December 31, 2023, since the Group has debt securities that are traded in a public market. In previous periods, the Group did not apply IFRS 8 Operating Segments, as it was not required to do so. Subsection Title: Income tax expense at effective tax rate** **18,940** **14,208
Subsubsection Text: Effective tax rate 23.8% 11.2% _Global Minimum top-up tax_ The group operates in several countries (a.o. the Netherlands) that have enacted new legislation to implement the global minimum top-up tax. It is noted that for the purposes of the top-up tax, if a single jurisdiction in which a group operates enacts or substantively enacts changes to its tax laws, then that entire group may be impacted regardless of whether a similar tax law has been enacted or substantively enacted in the jurisdiction of the ultimate parent. Therefore the whole group is subject to the requirements as stated in the narrow-scope amendments to IAS 12, ‘Income Taxes‘. The Group does not expect to be subject to the top-up tax in relation to its operations. Our impact assessment noted we need to closely monitor the effective tax rates in certain countries, amongst other Switzerland, Poland, the United Kingdom and Estonia due to tax regimes in those countries. Estonia is the only country with a potential impact. In Estonia companies pay corporation income tax only when profit is distributed as dividends. When the dividend decision is made before the financial statement will be signed, then the deferred tax position will be booked in the annual report. Assuming the entire profit is paid out as a dividend from 2024, the Effective Tax Rate (ETR) will be 20%. The real impact of Pillar Two is that we need to distribute profits to have an ETR of at least 15% and in that case are not subject to paying Global Minimum top-up taxes. Therefore the impact of Pillar 2 for the Group is deemed to be limited. However, the newly enacted tax legislation in the Netherlands is only applicable for accounting periods accounting periods beginning on or after 31 December 2023. However, as the Group is exposed to the variability of returns from the performance of Boels Rental Finance B.V. and as Boels Rental Finance B.V.’s operations are dependent on the decisions made by the Group, Boels Rental Finance B.V. is consolidated and included in the Financial Statements of the Group. Goal of the structured entity is securitizing part of the accounts receivables of the operating businesses Boels Verhuur B.V., Boels Rental Germany GmbH, and Boels Verhuur NV. The accounts receivables are sold to Boels Rental Finance B.V., which is consolidated into the Financial Statements of the Group. As the Group effectively retains the economic ownership of the accounts receivables, the accounts receivables are included in Boels’ financial accounts. 32 Capital and financial risk management _Capital management_ For the purpose of the Group’s capital management, capital includes share capital, and all other equity reserves as disclosed in the consolidated statement of changes in equity. The Group’s objectives in managing capital are to safeguard the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern in order to provide returns and benefits to stakeholders and to maintain an optimal capital structure to reduce the cost of capital. In order to maintain or adjust the capital structure, the group may return capital to shareholders, decrease or increase borrowings or issue new shares. The primary source of the Group’s liquidity is cash generated from operations. These funds are generally used to fund capital expenditures and pay interest and taxes. The Group is not subject to any externally imposed capital requirements. The Group’s aim is for a financing structure that ensures continuing operations and minimises cost of equity. For this, flexibility and access to the financial markets are important conditions. The Group monitors its financing structure using a gearing ratio, among other factors. The Group has a gearing ratio of per 376 per cent (see below) per 31 December 2023 determined as the proportion of Net debt to Equity. ----- The gearing ratio at the year-end is as follows: (x €1,000) 31-12-2023 31-12-2022 Debt 1,979,858 1,688,778 Cash and cash equivalents 41,709 17,192 Net debt 1,938,149 1,671,586 Equity 515,578 508,571 Net debt to equity ratio 376% 329% Debt is defined as long- and short-term borrowings and Lease Liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts). Equity includes all capital and reserves of the Group that are managed as capital. _Financial risk management_ The Group’s principal Financial Assets include Trade Receivables, Derivatives, Other Long-term Receivables and Cash and Cash equivalents that derive directly from its operations. The Group’s principal Financial Liabilities comprise borrowings, Trade and Other Payables as well as Lease Liabilities. The Group is exposed to market risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. The Group’s senior management oversees the management of these risks. The Group does not have a formal financial risk management policy program. Instead the susceptibility of the Group to financial risks is monitored as a part of its daily management of the business. _Market risk_ The group is exposed to market risk mainly as a result of financial instruments denominated in a foreign currency (i.e. foreign currency risk) and its exposure to interest bearing liabilities such as loans (i.e. interest rate risk). _Foreign currency risk_ Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. The Group’s exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates relates primarily to the Group’s operating activities (when revenue or expenses Boels Topholding B.V. is exposed to currency risk mainly from its cash flows generated in Sweden, Norway, the United Kingdom, Poland and Czech Republic. Boels Topholding B.V. also incurs currency risk on the net investment in foreign operations, mainly in Sweden, Poland, Czech Republic, Norway and the United Kingdom. Management has determined, based on a risk assessment, that some of these currency risks need to be hedged. This policy is intended to protect the statement of financial position. Forward exchange contracts are used for this purpose. At 31 December 2023 forward exchange contracts are outstanding with a nominal value of € 270.0 million (31 December 2022: € 250.3 million). The market value of these contracts amounts to € 8.2 million negative (2022: € 2.4 million positive). The Group applies hedge accounting with respect to the most material foreign exchange contracts. _Sensitivity analysis_ A reasonably possible strengthening (weakening) of the SEK, NOK or GBP against euro at 31 December would have affected the measurement of financial instruments denominated in a foreign currency and affected equity and profit or loss by the amounts shown below. This analysis assumes that all other variables, in particular interest rates, remain constant and ignores any impact of forecast sales and purchases.
