Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: SEK (10% movement) (8,190) 8,190 (6,294) 6,294 NOK (10% movement) (3,874) 3,874 (5,707) 5,707 GBP (10% movement) (646) 646 (1,128) 1,128 ----- Currency risk does not arise from financial instruments that are non-monetary items or from financial instruments denominated in the functional currency. The analysis above does not take into consideration investments in equity instruments as these are considered to be non-monetary items. As the group applies hedge accounting the result of the hedged items (FX Swaps) is shown in equity. The impact on equity would be largely offset by the investments in subsidiaries. _Interest rate risk_ The Group is exposed to interest rate risk because entities in the Group borrow funds at both fixed and floating interest rates. It is the policy of the Group to have a fixed/floating interest rate profile on the interest-bearing liabilities which is fitting with the nature of the Group’s assets. Hedging activities are evaluated regularly to align with the hedging policy. As most of the interestbearing liabilities have a floating interest rate, Boels Topholding B.V. has contracted interest rate swaps so that it receives floating interest and pays fixed interest. This policy is determined to obtain a desired risk profile in fixed and variable interest positions. To exchange floating interest for fixed interest, at 31 December 2023 interest rate swaps have been concluded for a nominal amount of € 1,000 million (31 December 2022: € 900 million), with a variable duration (refer to note 16). The market value of these interest rate swaps amounts to € 35,971 thousand (2022: € 84,083 thousand). The fair value of interest rate swaps at the reporting date is determined by discounting the future cash flows using the curves at the reporting date and the credit risk inherent in the contract. The average interest rate is based on the outstanding balances at the end of the financial year. As the critical terms (i.e. the notional amount, life and underlying) of the swap contracts and their corresponding hedged item are the same, the Group performs a qualitative assessment of effectiveness, and it is expected that the value of the swap contracts and the value of the corresponding hedged items will systematically change in opposite direction in response to movements in the underlying interest rates. The Group uses a hypothetical derivative method for the hedge effectiveness assessment and measurement of hedge ineffectiveness where the critical terms do not match. The main source of hedge ineffectiveness in these hedging relationships is the effect of the counterparty and Boels’ own credit risk on the fair value of the swap contracts, which is not reflected in the fair value of the hedged item attributable to changes in interest rates. The lack of a floor included in certain hedging instruments may cause additional ineffectiveness. No other The interest rate swaps settle on a quarterly basis. The floating rate on the interest rate swaps is 3-month Euribor. The Group will settle the difference between the fixed and floating interest rate on a net basis. All interest rate swap contracts exchanging floating rate interest amounts for fixed rate interest amounts are designated as cash flow hedges to reduce the Group’s cash flow exposure resulting from variable interest rates on borrowings. The interest rate swaps and the interest payments on the loan occur simultaneously, and the amount accumulated in equity is reclassified to profit or loss over the period that the floating rate interest payments on debt affect profit or loss. (effect x € 1,000) Profit or loss Equity 100 bps 100 bps 100 bps 100 bps Exposure increase decrease increase decrease Variable rate instruments (1,450,000) (15,000) 15,000 - Interest rate Swaps 900,000 9,000 (9,000) 31,000 (31,000) Cash flow sensitivity (net) (550,000) (6,000) 6,000 31,000 31,000 _Credit risk_ Credit risk is the risk that the Group faces when a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations. Credit risk mainly arises on cash and cash equivalents and receivable balances from trade and other receivables and other longer-term receivables. ----- A summary of amounts exposed to credit risk is presented below: (x €1,000) Notes 31-12-2023 31-12-2022 Non-current loans receivable 10 - 2,451 Trade receivables 13 253,983 210,396 Other receivables 13 50,595 31,097 Cash and cash equivalents 14 41,709 17,192 Substantially all cash at bank is held with high credit quality financial institutions with credit rating of A- (S&P) or higher. As at 31 December 2023 and 31 December 2022, no significant increase in credit risk has occurred with respect to the above noted non-current loans receivable. The expected credit losses for these balances were computed based on a 12-month expected credit loss and was estimated to be remote. Boels Topholding B.V. does not have any significant concentrations of credit risk in Trade Receivables as a result of the spread customers, markets and region. Sales on account are only made to customers that meet the Group’s credit rating requirements. Goods and services are sold subject to payment terms, the majority ranging between 15 to 60 days. A different payment period may apply to major supplies, in which case additional securities are demanded, including guarantees. Credit risks are constantly monitored by reviewing credit limits and payment terms per customer. Outstanding trade receivables are regularly monitored, and legal action is taken against debtors with long outstanding balances. The exposure to long-outstanding balances exceeding the post-paid terms are however not considered to be significant. The Group applies IFRS 9 and recognises lifetime expected credit losses (ECL) for Trade Receivables. The expected credit losses are estimated primarily by virtue of a provision matrix based on the Group’s historical credit loss experience, adjusted for general economic conditions and an assessment of both the current as well as the forecast direction of conditions at the reporting date. _Liquidity risk_ Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will encounter difficulty in meeting the obligations associated with its financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. The Group’s approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that it will meet its liabilities when they are due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to the Group’s reputation. The liquidity risk management implies maintaining sufficient cash and available credit facilities by continuously monitoring forecast and actual cash flows and by matching the maturity profiles of financial assets and liabilities. 33 Contingencies and commitments not included in the balance sheet _Commitments_ At 31 December 2023, the Group had commitments of € 145 million (31 December 2022: € 356 million) relating to capital expenditures. _Guarantees_ At 31 December 2023, bank guarantees issued by Boels Topholding B.V. and its subsidiaries amounted to € 3,597 thousand (31 December 2022: € 3,350 thousand). At December 31 2023 also company guarantees have been issued by Boels Topholding B.V. and its subsidiaries which amount to € 33,521 thousand (31 December 2022: € 21,500 thousand). 34 Acquisitions Acquisitions of new businesses during the reporting period were made to strengthen our market position and local presence in the region. These acquisitions affect the comparability of the consolidated financial statements. The consolidated financial statements, include the activity of: - Hyresbutiken, Sweden, acquired per 28 April 2023. We entered into an agreement to acquire assets of Hyresbutiken. Hyresbutiken is a rental company in Skellefteå with strong roots and a history of continuous and profitable growth. - BAS Maskinutleie, Norway, acquired per 21 April 2023. BAS Maskinutleie serves the construction market from eight geographically spread locations in Norway. BAS Maskinutleie is known for its wide range of equipment, extensive rental services and great expertise. - Safelift, Germany, acquired per 1 May 2023. We entered into an agreement to acquire assets of Safelift. Safelift has a deep experience in the hoisting and lifting industry. - KraftX, Sweden, acquired per 15 May 2023. KraftX is specialised in the rental of power generators and emergency power supply and services the Swedish market from nine outlets. - Illumin8, United Kingdom, acquired per 10 May 2023. Illumin8 provides lightning solutions throughout the UK and is especially strong in the events sector. ----- The goodwill arising from these acquisitions has been calculated as follows: (x €1,000) Total Consideration 58,506 Fair value of net identifiable assets (21,131) Newly identified intangible assets (14,161) Deferred tax liabilities as result of the PPA 2,297

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: As a result of these acquisitions, goodwill increased by € 25.5 million. There are no significant contingencies embedded in the considerations. There is no non-controlling interest in any of these acquisitions, the Group acquired 100% of the businesses. The group did not have any previous interest in these business. No other transactions took place between the group and any of the acquired business separately from the business combination. The acquisitions are accounted for based on the purchase accounting method. Per 31 December 2023 all acquisitions have been finalised, except for KraftX, which will be finalised in the beginning of 2024. The goodwill is not amortised but tested for impairment at the end of each reporting period. The goodwill is presented as intangible assets and goodwill, causing an increase of € 25.5 million. The newly identified intangible assets mainly consist of customer contracts. Goodwill includes synergies resulting from cost savings and increase in market share and non-contractual customer relationships that have not met the criteria for recognition as an intangible asset. The fair value of net identifiable assets mainly relates to fleet. The newly identified intangibles assets mainly relate to the valuation of customer contracts. 35 Subsequent events _MG Rental_ In 2024, Boels Group acquired 100% of the shares in MG Rental near Stockholm in Sweden, a local general rental company in an area where Boels Group had limited presence. MG Rental operates six depots and employs approximately 25 people. In 2022, MG Rental generated revenue of approximately 50 million SEK. The acquisition date is 4 January 2024. Due to confidentiality, we cannot provide any disclosure on the agreed upon purchase consideration. _Riwal_ On March 11, 2024, the Group announced that it has successfully come to an agreement on the acquisition of Riwal. The Group will acquire 100% of the shares of Riwal. The completion of the acquisition is subject to certain customary conditions to be fulfilled. The transaction must be notified to the competition authorities of the Netherlands, Germany, Norway, and Poland. Due to confidentiality, we cannot provide any disclosure on the agreed upon purchase consideration. Riwal currently operates 65 depots and employs approximately 1200 employees. Riwal generated revenue of approximately € 310 million. Riwal is currently active in 14 countries, holding a top 3 position in nine of them. This strategic alignment creates a solid foundation for further growth and exceptional customer service. In those countries where both Boels Rental and Riwal operate, the Group can strengthen their market share, especially in the field of aerial work platforms. Moreover, the acquisition will open new markets for the Group, enabling the Group to realise its growth ambitions there as well. This acquisition will allow the Group to increase the groups’ scale and facilitates the accelerated rollout of growth initiatives. The combined customer base and rental fleet represent an expanded platform for the rollout of Boels Rental’s strategic levers, including products and services, crossselling, and commercial best practices. The Group will specifically add even more aerial work platforms to our product line-up. But above all, the Group will be able to combine the collective expertise, know-how, and commitment of our employees to bring us even further. _EIB Loan_ In December 2023, the Group signed an agreement with the European Investment Bank (EIB) for a € 100 million loan. At 31 December 2023, the Group did not yet draw down (part of) this loan. Drawdown of this loan will take place in 2024, and will be used to further electrify the Groups’ fleet. _Change in the Board of Directors_ On 19 March 2024 it has been announced that Mr. Jan Piet Valk will step down as Chief Financial Officer and statutory director of the Group as per 1 June 2024. The successor of Mr. Jan Piet Valk will be Mr. René Olsthoorn, who will start at Boels on 1 April 2024 and will be officially appointed CFO as per 1 June 2024. |Goodwill|25,511| |---|---| ----- ## INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT To the shareholders of Boels Topholding B.V. Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Based on our professional judgement we determined the materiality for the financial statements as a whole at € 30 million. The materiality is based on a weighted average of 5,0% of EBITDA, 2,0% of revenue, and 2,0% of total assets, rounded down. We have also taken into account misstatements and/or possible misstatements that in our opinion are material for the users of the financial statements for qualitative reasons. We agreed with the Board of Directors that misstatements in excess of € 1.500.000, which are identified during the audit, would be reported to them, as well as smaller misstatements that in our view must be reported on qualitative grounds.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Boels Topholding B.V. is at the head of a group of entities. The financial information of this group is included in the consolidated financial statements of Boels Topholding B.V. Our group audit mainly focused on significant group entities including Boels Topholding B.V., Boels Verhuur B.V., Boels Rental Germany GmbH, Boels Verhuur N.V., Boels Maschinenverleih Österreich, Cramo AB, Cramo AS, and Cramo Finland Oy. ----- We have: - Performed audit procedures ourselves at group entities Boels Topholding B.V., Boels Verhuur B.V., Boels Rental Germany GmbH, Boels Verhuur N.V., and Boels Maschinenverleih Österreich. - Used the work of other auditors when auditing Cramo AB, Cramo AS, and Cramo Finland Oy. - Performed review procedures or specific audit procedures at other group entities. By performing the procedures mentioned above at group entities, together with additional procedures at group level, we have been able to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence about the group’s financial information to provide an opinion on the consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: We identified and assessed the risks of material misstatements of the financial statements due to fraud. During our audit we obtained an understanding of the entity and its environment and the components of the system of internal control, including the risk assessment process and management’s process for responding to the risks of fraud and monitoring the system of internal control and how the Board of Directors exercises oversight, as well as the outcomes. We note that management has not formalised its fraud risk assessment. We evaluated the design and relevant aspects of the system of internal control and in particular the fraud risk assessment, as well as among others the code of conduct, whistle blower procedures ‘Speak Up Policy’ and incident registration. We evaluated the design and the implementation and, where considered appropriate, tested the operating effectiveness, of internal controls designed to mitigate fraud risks. As part of our process of identifying fraud risks, we evaluated fraud risk factors with respect to financial reporting fraud, misappropriation of assets and bribery and corruption in co-operation with our forensic specialists. We evaluated whether these factors indicate that a risk of material misstatement due to fraud is present. We incorporated elements of unpredictability in our audit. We also considered the outcome of our other audit procedures and evaluated whether any findings were indicative of fraud or non-compliance. We identified the following fraud risks and performed the following specific procedures: We identified and assessed the risks of material misstatements of the financial statements due to fraud. During our audit we obtained an understanding of the entity and its environment and the components of the system of internal control, including the risk assessment process and management’s process for responding to the risks of fraud and monitoring the system of internal control and how the Board of Directors exercises oversight, as well as the outcomes. We note that management has not formalised its fraud risk assessment and fraud management strategy. We evaluated the design and relevant aspects of the system of internal control, including internal fraud & integrity protocols and incident registration. We evaluated the design and the implementation and, where considered appropriate, tested the operating effectiveness, of internal controls designed to mitigate fraud risks. As part of our process of identifying fraud risks, we evaluated fraud risk factors with respect to financial reporting fraud, misappropriation of assets, and bribery and corruption, where deemed necessary, in close co-operation with our forensic specialists. We evaluated whether these factors indicate that a risk of material misstatement due fraud is present. We identified the following fraud risks and performed the following specific procedures: _•_ _Risk of material misstatement due to fraud related to management override of controls:_ We presume a risk of material misstatement due to fraud as management is in a unique position to perpetrate fraud because of management’s assumed ability to manipulate ----- affecting the financial statements. We have pinpointed the possible incentives of management on meeting the loan covenants and the long term and yearly bonus plan for the strategic board members. In this respect EBITDA serves as the key performance indicator for the entity and management. _•_ _Risk of material misstatement due to fraud related to revenue recognition:_ We presume a risk of material misstatement due to fraud related to revenue recognition. This risk relates to the occurrence of revenues for non-transactional rental revenue transactions. To respond to these fraud risks we performed the following procedures: - We considered available information and made enquiries of relevant executives from the strategic board, directors, finance employees, risk manager and the general counsel. - We evaluated whether the selection and application of accounting policies by the group, particularly those related to subjective measurements and complex transactions, may be indicative of fraudulent financial reporting. - We evaluated all internally registered fraud instances in financial year 2022 and evaluated whether management’s follow up is appropriate. - We have performed data analytics, including detailed testing of journal entries in the financial administration (SAP/IBS) based on certain risk-based characteristics, as part of our audit approach to address fraud risks. - We performed supplementary substantive audit procedures, such as detailed testing of top-down journal entries. - We have reconciled the rental- and financial system on detailed level and performed extensive sampling testing on revenue postings not orginating from the rental system and on the accrual of customer bonusses. - We have included the fraud risks as specific focus area in the group instructions to the component audit teams and have conducted site visits on a number of business locations in Sweden, Norway and Finland. - We incorporated elements of unpredictability in our audit. We also considered the outcome of our other audit procedures and evaluated whether any findings were indicative of fraud or non-compliance. Our audit procedures for the year as specified in this paragraph did not lead to indications for fraud potentially resulting in material misstatements.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Risks related to management override of control Risks** **Responses
Subsubsection Text: Fraud risks related to management override and alteration of (financial) results to meet internal and external expectations. We have pinpointed the possible incentives of management on meeting the loan covenants and the long term and yearly bonus plan for the Strategic Board members. In this respect EBITDA serves as the key performance indicator for the entity and management. - We considered available information and made enquiries of relevant executives from the Strategic Board, directors, finance employees, risk manager and the general counsel. - We evaluated the design and implementation of internal controls that mitigate fraud risks with respect to manual journal entries. - We evaluated whether the selection and application of accounting policies by the group, particularly those related to subjective measurements and complex transactions, may be indicative of fraudulent financial reporting. We performed a retrospective review of management judgments and assumptions related to significant accounting estimates reflected in prior year financial statements. Impairment testing of intangible assets is a significant area to our audit as the determination whether these assets are not carried at more than their recoverable amounts is subject to management judgment. Reference is made to the section ‘Our key audit matters’. - We evaluated all internally registered fraud instances in financial year 2023 and evaluated whether management’s follow up is appropriate. - We have performed data analytics, including testing journal entries based on certain risk-based characteristics, as part of our audit approach to address the fraud risks identified. - We performed substantive audit procedures, such as detailed testing of top-side journal entries. - We have included the fraud risk and response as specific focus area in the group instructions to the component audit teams and have conducted site visits on a number of business locations in Sweden, Estonia, Lithuania and Finland. Based on the risk analyses conducted and considering the entity’s nature, no fraud risk has been identified regarding the completeness of revenue recognition. This is largely attributed to the company’s current phase, where the primary goal is to meet external expectations and further growth. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Risks related to revenue recognition Risks** **Responses
Subsubsection Text: Fraud risks related to the occurrence of revenues for non-transactional rental revenue transactions. For example, revenue transactions lacking actual substance or delivery. - We considered available information and conducted inquiries with operational staff stationed at the depots. - We evaluated the design and implementation of internal controls that mitigate fraud risks with respect to revenue recognition. - As part of our procedures we verified that recognized revenue exists on the basis of payments made by the customers, initial orders, contracts and delivery documentation. - We performed reconciliations between sales transactions recorded in the rental system and those in the financial system. - We tested credit notes and customer bonuses, ensuring accuracy and completeness. - We performed data analytics on revenue related journals to determine whether the journal entries follow the expected route. - We have included the fraud risks and response as specific focus area in the group instructions to the component audit teams and have conducted site visits on a number of business locations in Sweden, Estonia, Lithuania and Finland. - We inspected sales around year-end to assess whether revenue was recognized in the correct reporting period. - Furthermore, we also considered the outcome of our other audit procedures and evaluated whether any findings were indicative of fraud. Our audit procedures for the year as specified in this paragraph did not lead to indications for fraud potentially resulting in material misstatements

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Audit approach compliance with laws and regulations
Subsubsection Text: We assessed the laws and regulations relevant to the entity through discussion with Board of Directors, compliance officer and reading minutes. We involved our forensic specialists in this evaluation. Following our risk assessment procedures, we have recognized that the consequences of noncompliance may significantly differ. Therefore, we have included an examination of the following laws and regulations, which directly impact the financial statements, as an integral component of our audit procedures, to the extent that they are material for the financial statements: - Adherence to (corporate) tax law. - The requirements under the International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union (EU-IFRS) and Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. We obtained sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding provisions of those laws and regulations generally recognized to have a direct effect on the financial statements. Apart from these, the entity is subject to other laws and regulations where the consequences of non-compliance could have a material effect on amounts and/or disclosures in the financial statements, for instance, through imposing fines or litigation. Given the nature of the entity’s business, the complexity of the act on the Prevention of Money Laundering and Financing of Terrorism (‘Wwft’) and current EU sanctions with regards to Russia, there is a risk of non-compliance with the requirements of such laws and regulations. Our procedures are more limited with respect to these laws and regulations that do not have a direct effect on the determination of the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements. Compliance with these laws and regulations may be fundamental to the operating aspects of the business, to the entity’s ability to continue its business, or to avoid material penalties (e.g., compliance with the terms of operating licenses and permits or compliance with environmental regulations) and therefore non-compliance with such laws and regulations may have a material effect on the financial statements. Our responsibility is limited to undertaking specified audit procedures to help identify non-compliance with those laws and regulations that may have a material effect on the financial statements. Our procedures are limited to (i) inquiry of the Board of Directors and others within the entity as to whether the entity is in compliance with such laws and regulations and (ii) inspecting correspondence, if any, with the relevant licensing or regulatory authorities to help identify non-compliance with those laws and regulations that may have a material effect on the financial statements. Naturally, we remained alert to indications of (suspected) non-compliance throughout the audit. Finally, we obtained written representations that all known instances of (suspected) fraud or non-compliance with laws and regulations have been disclosed to us. We assessed the laws and regulations relevant to the Company through discussion with strategic Board members, reading minutes and reports of internal audit. As a result of our risk assessment procedures, and while realizing that the effects from noncompliance could considerably vary, we considered the following laws and regulations: adherence to (corporate) tax law and financial reporting regulations, the requirements under the International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union (EU-IFRS) and Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code with a direct effect on the financial statements as an integrated part of our audit procedures, to the extent material for the related financial statements. We obtained sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding provisions of those laws and regulations generally recognized to have a direct effect on the financial statements. Apart from these, the Boels Topholding B.V. is subject to other laws and regulations where the consequences of non-compliance could have a material effect on amounts and/or disclosures in the financial statements, for instance, through imposing fines or litigation. Given the nature of Boels Topholding B.V.’s business and the complexity of the act on the Prevention of Money Laundering and Financing of Terrorism (‘WWFT’), and current EU sanctions with regards to the joint venture in Russia, there could be a risk of non-compliance with the requirements of such laws and regulations. In addition, we considered major laws and regulations applicable to listed companies. Our procedures are more limited with respect to these laws and regulations that do not have a direct effect on the determination of the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements. Compliance with these laws and regulations may be fundamental to the operating aspects of the business, to Boels Topholding B.V.’s ability to continue its business, or to avoid material penalties (e.g., compliance with the terms of operating licenses and permits or compliance with environmental regulations) and therefore non-compliance with such laws and regulations may have a material effect on the financial statements. Our responsibility is limited to undertaking specified audit procedures to help identify non-compliance with those laws and regulations that may have a material effect on the financial statements. Our procedures are limited to (i) inquiry of management, the Supervisory Board, the Executive Board and others within Boels Topholding B.V.’s as to whether the Boels Topholding B.V. is in compliance with such laws and regulations and (ii) inspecting correspondence, if any, with the relevant licensing or regulatory authorities to help identify non-compliance with those laws and regulations that may have a material effect on the i ----- Naturally, we remained alert to indications of (suspected) non-compliance throughout the audit. Finally, we obtained written representations that all known instances of (suspected) fraud or non-compliance with laws and regulations have been disclosed to us.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Our responsibilities, as well as the responsibilities of management, are outlined under the prevailing standards in the “Description of responsibilities regarding the financial statements” section below. Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Key audit matters are those matters that, in our professional judgement, were of most significance in our audit of the financial statements. Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Description of our key audit matters Recognition and valuation of the rental fleet-related tangible fixed assets Description** **Audit approach Valuation of goodwill and impairment testing of goodwill Description** **Audit approach
Subsubsection Text: Boels has a history of engaging in multiple acquisitions, leading to a significant goodwill position of EUR 400 million on the balance sheet. The goodwill is predominantly attributable to the acquisition of the Cramo business in 2020. Additionally, we note increase in goodwill arising from annual acquisitions almost every year. In the year 2023, the increment was EUR 25.5 million, which pertains to the acquisitions of several entities. As the position of goodwill is evergrowing, the impairment analysis is of high importance to provide accurate reporting in the financial statements. Impairment has to be tested at least annualy under IFRS and the analysis is susceptible to management estimates and variables around: - The forecast of upcoming years - Revenue growth - Long term growth rate - Weighted average cost of capital Considering this, we have included goodwill valuation, and specifically impairment testing as a key audit matter. Based on our audit standards, and materiality level determined, we have audited the goodwill, impairment analysis, and acquisitions. We have gained insight into the process around goodwill recognition and the periodic impairment analysis, and have evaluated the design and implementation of associated control activities. Considering the identified risk, we have adopted a substantive audit approach. Our work performed mainly included the following procedures: - Testing of all new acquisitions in the year including the valuation of goodwill. - Assessing whether an impairment analysis is performed. - Determining that the level of cash-generating units is at the lowest possible level and assets are accurately allocated to these cash-generating units. - Evaluating the reasonableness of the budget used for the impairment analysis and performed backtesting on the budget of last year. An assessment of growth rates in upcoming years was also performed. - Engage valuation specialists to further test the used model, and the assumptions surrounding the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) and the long-term growth rate (LTGR). - Performing a sensitivity analysis to evaluate whether the impairment is highly susceptible to assumptions - Testing the disclosures in the financial statements on completeness and accuracy. In 2023, Boels acquired EUR 398 million worth of new fleet and disposed of EUR 21 million (bookvalue) fleet at the group level. The total value of the rental fleet- related tangible fixed assets per December 31, 2023 is EUR 1.483 million. The area of possible impairments and existence of the fleet-related tangible fixed assets is identified as a key audit matter in our audit. Based on our audit standards and materiality level determined, we have audited the fleet-related tangible fixed assets. We have gained insight into the fleet management process, and have evaluated the design and implementation of associated control activities. Considering the identified risk, we have adopted a substantive audit approach. Our work performed mainly included the following procedures: - We conducted a sample test related to the newly acquired and disposed fleet-related tangible fixed assets. - We confirmed the existence of the rental fleet by conducting physical and video counts, reviewing maintenance records, and verifying that customers have paid to rent equipment. - We assessed the correctness of the depreciation rates and residual values. - Finally, we analyzed the internal evaluation of money and time utilization of the rental fleet to identify potential triggers for impairment.

The financial statements include specific disclosures around goodwill and acquisitions, refer to: - Goodwill and impairment: paragraph 8. - Acquisitions in 2023: paragraph 34. - Subsequent events: paragraph 35. Based on the procedures performed as described above, and keeping our materiality levels in mind, we conclude that fleetrelated tangible fixed assets are recognized and valued in line with the applicable accounting principles. -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Financing of the group and recognition of these transactions Description** **Audit approach Financial statement disclosure** **Observation
Subsubsection Text: A significant part of the balance sheet of Boels is related to financial liabilities. Up to 2023, this mainly related to the Term Loan B and revolving credit facility. During 2023, Boels has diversified its finance structure with key transactions including the issuance of high-yield bonds for EUR 400 million and the securitisation of EUR 86 million in accounts receivables through a special purpose vehicle per 31 December 2023. The bond proceeds were partly used to reduce existing Term Loan B and revolving credit facility debts. Furthermore, Boels also has a specific strategy around limiting interest rate risks. To increase the consistency and predictability of interest payments, Boels has implemented interest rate swaps that cover the majority of the loans included. Considering the further growth of the financing structure of the group using external instruments, and increasing complexity of the used instruments, we have recognized these transactions as a key audit matter. Based on our audit standards and materiality level determined, we have audited the financial liabilities and derivatives. We have gained insight into the treasury process and have evaluated the design and implementation of associated control activities. Considering the identified risk, we have adopted a substantive audit approach. Our work performed mainly included the following procedures:

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: - We assessed the agreements related to the loans and bonds in general, and for embedded derivatives. - We evaluated all movements related to these loans and bonds. - We evaluated the correct amoritsation of capitalized loan costs. - We evaluated whether interest expenses are correctly reflected and accrued interest is in line with our expectation. - We assessed whether all covenants have been met per year-end. - We tested the disclosures in the financial statements on completeness and accuracy.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: - We assessed the agreements related to the transaction. - We consulted the consolidation of the special purpose entity and the recognition of the transaction in the financial statement with our technical accounting specialists. - We tested whether the loans are correctly presented in the financial statements. - We tested the disclosures in the financial statements on completeness and accuracy.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsubsection Text: - We determined whether hedge documentation is drawn up accordingly. - We assessed whether cashflow hedging requirements have been met. - We evaluated whether all derivatives are effective and if not, whether ineffectiveness has been correctly recognized. - We requested financial instrument valuation specialists to assess whether the market value of these instruments is determined correctly. - We tested the disclosures in the financial statements on completeness and accuracy. REPORT ON THE OTHER INFORMATION INCLUDED IN THE ANNUAL REPORT The annual report contains other information, in addition to the financial statements and our auditor’s report thereon. The other information consists of: - The Board of Directors’ Report. - Other Information as required by Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. Based on the following procedures performed, we conclude that the other information: - Is consistent with the financial statements and does not contain material misstatements. - Contains all the information regarding the management report and the other information as required by Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. We have read the other information. Based on our knowledge and understanding obtained through our audit of the financial statements or otherwise, we have considered whether the other information contains material misstatements. By performing these procedures, we comply with the requirements of Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code and the Dutch Standard 720. The scope of the procedures performed is substantially less than the scope of those performed in our audit of the financial statements. The Board of Directors is responsible for the preparation of the other information, including the Board of Directors’ Report in accordance with Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, and the other information as required by Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The financial statements include specific disclosures around the financing structure and finance risk management, refer to: - Financial liabilities: paragraph 16. - Capital and financial risk management: paragraph 32. Based on the procedures performed as described above and keeping our materiality levels in mind, we conclude that all financing transactions and balances have been accurately recognized in the financial statements. ----- DESCRIPTION OF RESPONSIBILITIES REGARDING THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Responsibilities of the Board of Directors for the financial statements
Subsubsection Text: The Board of Directors is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in accordance with EU-IFRS and Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. Furthermore, the Board of Directors is responsible for such internal control as the Board of Directors determines is necessary to enable the preparation of the financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. As part of the preparation of the financial statements, the Board of Directors is responsible for assessing the company’s ability to continue as a going concern. Based on the financial reporting frameworks mentioned, the Board of Directors should prepare the financial statements using the going concern basis of accounting unless the Board of Directors either intends to liquidate the company or to cease operations, or has no realistic alternative but to do so. The Board of Directors should disclose events and circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the company’s ability to continue as a going concern in the financial statements. The Board of Directors is responsible for overseeing the company’s financial reporting process.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS
Subsection Title: Our responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements
Subsubsection Text: Our objective is to plan and perform the audit assignment in a manner that allows us to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence for our opinion. Our audit has been performed with a high, but not absolute, level of assurance, which means we may not detect all material errors and fraud during our audit. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements. The materiality affects the nature, timing and extent of our audit procedures and the evaluation of the effect of identified misstatements on our opinion. We have exercised professional judgement and have maintained professional scepticism throughout the audit, in accordance with Dutch Standards on Auditing, ethical requirements and independence requirements. Our audit included among others: - Identifying and assessing the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, designing and performing audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtaining audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. - Obtaining an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the company’s internal control. - Evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the Board of Directors. - Concluding on the appropriateness of the Board of Directors’s use of the going concern basis of accounting, and based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the company’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our auditor’s report to the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify our opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause the company to cease to continue as a going concern. - Evaluating the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including the disclosures. - Evaluating whether the financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation. Because we are ultimately responsible for the opinion, we are also responsible for directing, supervising and performing the group audit. In this respect we have determined the nature and extent of the audit procedures to be carried out for group entities. Decisive were the size and/or the risk profile of the group entities or operations. On this basis, we selected group entities for which an audit or review had to be carried out on the complete set of financial information or specific items. We communicate with the Board of Directors regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant findings in internal control that we identified during our audit. ----- We provide the Board of Directors with a statement that we have complied with relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and to communicate with them all relationships and other matters that may reasonably be thought to bear on our independence, and where applicable, related safeguards. From the matters communicated with the Board of Directors, we determine the key audit matters: those matters that were of most significance in the audit of the financial statements. We describe these matters in our auditor’s report unless law or regulation precludes public disclosure about the matter or when, in extremely rare circumstances, not communicating the matter is in the public interest.
