CRAMO SK s.r.o., Bratislava (Slovakia) - CRAMO UAB, Vilnius (Lithuania) - Construction Vehicles Karvina s.r.o., Karvina (the Czech Republic) - Suomen Tähtivuokraus Oy, Vantaa (Finland) Fortrent Oy, Vanta (Finland) (50% - shareholding) qualifies as a joint venture. Control in the partnership firm is exercised jointly with the other partner. This joint venture has not been partially consolidated. Fortrent Oy holds a 100% share in the company Fortrent LLC in Russia. Boels Topholding B.V. has issued a declaration of joint and several liability in accordance with Article 403.1f, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code in respect of the consolidated associate Boels Verhuur B.V.

All legal entities that can be controlled, jointly controlled or significantly influenced are considered to be a related party. Also, entities which can control the Company are considered a related party. In addition, statutory directors and close relatives are regarded as related parties. Significant transactions with related parties are disclosed in the notes insofar as they are not transacted under normal market conditions. The nature, extent and other information is disclosed if this is required to provide a true and fair view.

Identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination are recognised in the consolidated financial statements from the acquisition date, being the moment that control can be exercised in the acquired company. The acquisition price consists of the cash consideration, or equivalent, agreed for acquiring the company plus any directly attributable expenses. If the acquisition price exceeds the net amount of the fair value of the identifiable assets and liabilities, the excess is capitalised as goodwill under intangible assets. Entities continue to be consolidated until they are sold. They are deconsolidated from the date that control ceases or if they are classified as disposal groups held for sale.

The cash flow statement has been prepared using the indirect method. The cash items disclosed in the cash flow statement are comprised of cash excluding bank overdrafts at credit institutions which have been presented as proceeds and repayments of loans under the cash flow generated from financing activities. Cash flows denominated in foreign currencies have been translated at average estimated exchange rates. Interest paid and received, dividends received and income taxes are included in cash from operating activities. Dividends and capital reductions paid are recognised as cash used in financing activities. -----

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with the relevant rules requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires management to exercise its judgement in the process of applying the Group’s accounting policies. If necessary for the purposes of providing the view required under Article 362(1), Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code, the nature of these estimates and judgments, including the related assumptions, is disclosed in the notes to the financial statement items in question.

Subsection Title: 2** **Accounting policies for the balance sheet 2.1** **General information
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the statutory provisions of Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code and the firm pronouncements in the Guidelines for Annual Reporting in the Netherlands as issued by the Dutch Accounting Standards Board. The accounting policies have been based on going concern assumptions. In general, assets and liabilities are stated at the amounts at which they were acquired or incurred, or current value. If not specifically stated otherwise, they are recognised at the amounts at which they were acquired or incurred. The balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement include references to the notes.

Boels is obviously very concerned about the situation in Russia and the impact this has on the entire world. Boels is not impacted by the Russia/Ukraine geopolitical situation, other than the impact it may have on the general economy in Europe. Boels has no presence in Russia or in Ukraine nor does it service any customers in those regions. Boels does not source from Russia or Ukraine. The Group owns 50% of Fortrent Oy, an equally held joint venture with Ramirent. Fortrent Oy operates in Russia. Boels has no operational involvement in this joint venture, which functions as a stand-alone company in every respect. Fortrent not being exclusively controlled by the Group, it is consolidated under the equity method in the Group consolidated financial statements. Fortrent is generating approx. € 25 million of revenues. In 2021, a net result of € 1.0 million from this joint venture is included in Boels’ net result. The Group will continue to assess the situation and the valuation of this joint venture.

The accounting policies have been consistently applied to all the years presented. The presentation of some prior year items in the balance sheet and income statements has been reclassified in comparison to last years’ annual accounts to comply with the accounting laws and regulations applicable to this financial statements (in particular Besluit modellen jaarrekening) and as a result of re-evaluation of the accounting policy regarding the classification of costs as other operating expenses. The following adjustments are made:
Amount 2020 in financial statement Item (x €1,000) 2020 2021 Difference Non-current receivables and prepayments 28,566 13,844 14,722 Deferred income taxes 99,305 84,583 14,722

_Functional currency_ Items included in the financial statements of group companies are measured using the currency of the primary economic environment in which the respective group company operates (the functional currency). The consolidated financial statements are presented in Euros, which is the functional and presentation currency of Boels Topholding B.V. _Transactions, receivables and debts_ Foreign currency transactions in the reporting period are translated into the functional currency using the exchange rates prevailing at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency at the rate of exchange prevailing at the balance sheet date. Foreign exchange gains and losses resulting from the settlement of such transactions and from the translation at year-end exchange rates are recognised in the income statement. _Group companies_ Assets and liabilities of consolidated subsidiaries with a functional currency different from the presentation currency are translated at the rate of exchange prevailing at the balance sheet date. Income and expense are translated at average exchange rates during the financial year. Any resulting exchange differences are processed directly to the legal reserve for translation differences within equity. The following exchange rates have been used to prepare the financial statements: (x €1,000) 31 December 2021 2021 EUR : CZK 1 : 24.86 1 : 26.24 EUR : PLN 1 : 4.60 1 : 4.56 EUR : HUF 1 : 369.19 1 : 363.89 EUR : CHF 1 : 1.03 1 : 1.08 EUR : DKK 1 : 7.44 1 : 7.44 EUR : NOK 1 : 9.99 1 : 10.47 EUR : SEK 1 : 10.25 1 : 10.03 EUR : GBP 1 : 0.84 1 : 0.90

Intangible assets are stated at historical cost less amortisation. Allowance is made for any impairment losses expected. A loss qualifies as an impairment loss if the carrying amount of the asset (or of the cash-generating unit to which it belongs) exceeds its recoverable amount. For details on how to determine whether an intangible asset has to be impaired, please refer to note 2.8 below. _Goodwill_ Goodwill on acquisitions is capitalised and amortised on a straight line basis over its estimated future useful life. Goodwill is amortised in 5 to 10 years and is dependent on the expected useful life. The useful life concerned is dependent on multiple factors such as plans for integration in the Boels organisation, the market position of the acquired company and the expected duration of the economic benefits. The CRAMO goodwill is amortized over 10 years given CRAMO’s market position, the expected economic benefits and CRAMO Group is acting as a relative standalone group within the Boels organization. The estimated future useful life of goodwill of small acquisitions is most often 5 years, as corresponding depots will be relatively quickly be fully integrated into the Boels operations. At acquired smaller companies, the staff turnover is often high. For this reason the initial estimated useful life of goodwill has an economic life of 10 years (and in most cases a maximum of 5 years). _Brand name_ The Brand name ‘CRAMO’ is acquired during the acquisition of CRAMO in 2020. The brand name has been measured during the purchase price allocation applying the relief- of-royalty method. The estimated useful life of the brand name ‘CRAMO’ is estimated on 10 years and accordingly amortised on a straight line basis. _Other intangible assets - Customer Contracts_ In business combinations part of the purchase price has been allocated to customer contracts. Initial measurement of these customer contracts applying the Multi-period Excess Earnings Method and the forecasted revenues and profits related to these contracts. The amortization period is 5 year. -----

Land and buildings are stated at historical cost plus expenditure that is directly attributable to the acquisition of the items, less straight line depreciation over their estimated future useful lives. Land is not depreciated. An allowance is made for any impairment losses expected on the balance sheet date. For details on how to determine whether property, plant or equipment is impaired, please refer to note 2.8 below. Other non-current assets are valued at historical cost, less straight line depreciation over their estimated useful lives and impairment losses. The manufacturing price is comprised of the cost of raw materials and consumables and also includes expenditure directly attributable to an asset’s manufacturing, including installation costs. No provision for major future repairs to buildings or machinery and equipment has been formed. Major repairs extending the estimated future useful lives are capitalized. in accordance with the component approach. Other repairs are recognized as expenses.

_Associates_ Group companies and other associates in which the Company exercises significant influence, generally accompanying a shareholding of 20% or more of the voting rights, are stated at net asset value. Net asset value is calculated using the accounting policies applied in these financial statements. Associates with an equity deficit are valued at nil. A provision is formed if and when Boels Topholding B.V. is fully or partially liable for the debts of the associate, or has the firm intention to allow the associate to pay its debts. Associates acquired are initially measured at the fair value of the identifiable assets and liabilities upon acquisition. Any subsequent valuation is based on the accounting policies that apply to these financial statements, taking into account the initial valuation. Associates in which no significant influence can be exercised are recognised at cost. _Loans to participants and other loans_ Upon initial recognition the loans to participants are valued at fair value and then valued at amortised cost, after deduction of any provisions. These provisions are determined by individual assessment of the receivables. _Deferred tax assets_ Deferred tax assets are stated under the financial assets if and to the extent it is probable that the tax claim can be realised in due course. These deferred tax assets are valued at nominal value and have a predominantly long-term character.

At each balance sheet date, the Company tests whether there are any indications of assets being subject to impairment. If any such indications exist, the recoverable amount of the asset is determined. If this proves to be impossible, the recoverable amount of the cash generating unit to which the asset belongs is identified. An asset is subject to impairment, if its carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less costs to sell and value in use. Fair value less costs to sell is determined based on the active market. An impairment loss is directly expensed in the income statement. If it is established that a previously recognised impairment loss no longer applies or has declined, the increased carrying amount of the assets in question is not set any higher than the carrying amount that would have been determined had no asset impairment been recognised. Goodwill impairments are not reversed. Management assesses at each balance sheet date whether there is objective evidence that a financial asset or a group of financial assets is impaired. If any such evidence exists, the impairment loss is determined and recognised in the income statement.

Raw materials and consumables are stated at the lower of replacement value, i.e. purchase price at the balance sheet date and net realisable value. Cost is determined using the first in, first out (FIFO) method. Net realisable value is the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business, less applicable variable selling expenses. Net realisable value is determined making allowance for obsolescence of inventories.
Trade receivables are recognised at cost, which is the fair value at moment of sale. When a trade receivable is uncollectible, it is written off against the allowance account for trade -----

Cash includes cash in hand, bank balances and deposits held at call with maturities of less than 12 months. Bank overdrafts are shown within loans in current liabilities on the balance sheet. Cash is stated at face value.
Minority interests in group equity are stated at the amount of the net interest in the net assets of group companies concerned.

_General information_ Provisions are recognised for legally enforceable or constructive obligations existing at the balance sheet date, the settlement of which is probable to require an outflow of resources whose extent can be reliably estimated. Provisions are measured based on the best estimate of the amounts required to settle the obligations at the balance sheet date. Unless indicated otherwise, provisions are stated at the nominal value of the expenditure expected to be required to settle the obligations. _Deferred income tax assets and liabilities_ Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognised to provide for temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities, and their carrying amounts in the financial statements (i.e. property, plant and equipment and fair value adjustments on acquisitions). Deferred income tax is determined using tax rates that have been enacted or substantially enacted by the balance sheet date and are expected to apply when the related deferred income tax asset is realised or the deferred income tax liability is settled. Deferred income taxes are recognised at face value. _Pension benefits management board_ At the 23rd of December 2019, the management board converted the self-administrated defined benefit pension plan to a fiscal old-age reserve (FOR). This means that as per the 23rd of December 2019, the defined benefit pension plan was stamped to its fiscal balance sheet value. The new fiscal old-age reserve, which compounds annually at the average U-return published by the Dutch Tax Authority, is presented in the balance sheet and corresponds with the present fiscal value. Since this date the reserve is presented as a long term liability. _Pension benefits employees_ For the employees, the group operates a defined contribution plan. For this plan, Boels Topholding B.V. pays contributions to pension funds and insurance companies on a contractual basis. Except for paying contributions, Boels Topholding B.V. has no other obligations to pay further contributions by virtue of these pension plans. No provision is made for probable future increase of premium. Contributions are recognised as expenses when incurred. The employees bear the actuarial and investment risk. Prepaid contributions are recognised as prepayments and accrued income to the extent that this will lead to a reduction in future payments or a cash refund. Of the foreign group companies of Boels Topholding B.V. only Boels Rental Germany GmbH has an own pension plan which is an the result of an pension arrangement from the past that is applicable for a specific group of former CRAMO AG employees. This plan classifies as a defined benefit plan. The obligation includes the present value of the expenditures that are probably required to settle. The present value factor is the market rate of interest of highquality corporate bonds. If the obligation is due within a year, the obligation is not discounted. Additions and withdrawals from the pension provision are taken into the profit and loss account. _Jubilee benefits_ The provision for jubilee benefits is measured at the present value of expected benefits payable during employment. The calculation of the provision, takes the expected future salary increases, the likelihood that employees stay at the company and actuarial discount rate of 1% into account. _Other provisions_ As the effect of the time value of money is not material, the other provisions are valued at face value.

Upon initial recognition, the loans and liabilities recorded are stated at fair value and then valued at amortised cost. _Finance lease_ A lease is classified as finance lease, if the risks and rewards incidental to ownership are borne wholly or almost wholly by the group as lessee. At the commencement date of the finance lease term, the lease object and the related liability are recognised at amounts equal to the fair value of the leased object or, if lower, at the present value of the minimum lease payments. The discount rate used in calculating the present value is the interest rate implicit in the lease. i ----- During the lease term interest charges are allocated so as to produce a constant periodic rate of interest for each period. Relevant assets are depreciated over the remaining useful life. Leases that do not classify as finance lease, classify as operating lease. For operating leases, lease payments are recognised as an expense on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

_Primary financial instruments_ The accounting policies for receivables and liabilities have been stated separately. _Financial derivatives_ Boels Topholding B.V. is making use of financial derivatives to cover the exposure to interest risks and foreign exchange risks. Financial derivatives are carried at cost or lower fair value. If the fair value at balance sheet date is negative, this is reflected as a liability in the balance sheet. Fair value is the amount for which an asset could be exchanged, or a liability settled, between knowledgeable, willing parties in an arm’s length transaction. Changes in the book value of these derivative instruments are recognised directly in the income statement. The group does not apply hedge accounting.

Subsection Title: 3** **Accounting policies for the income statement 3.1** **General information
Subsubsection Text: Profit or loss is determined as the difference between the realisable value of the goods delivered and services rendered, and the costs and other charges for the year. Revenues on transactions are recognised in the year in which they are realised. Profit or loss is determined, taking into account the recognition of unrealised changes in fair value of derivative financial instruments not designated as hedges.

_Sales of renting and services_ Revenue from sales of renting and services is recognised based on the renting and services delivered to the customer till the balance sheet date. The rental income is recognized on a straight-line basis during the rental period. _Sales of goods_ Revenue from sales of goods is recognised when all significant risks and rewards incidental to the ownership of the goods have been transferred to the buyer.
Exchange differences arising upon the settlement or conversion of monetary items are recognised in the income statement in the period that they arise, unless they are hedged.

Revenue comprises the fair value of the consideration received or receivable for the sale of goods and services in the ordinary course of the Company’s activities. Revenue is shown net of value-added tax, rebates and discounts and after eliminating sales within the group.
Cost of sold equipment/sales products represents the cost of inventories sold and the book value of machinery and equipment sold.

Subsection Title: 3.6 Cost of subcontracted work and other external charges
Subsubsection Text: Cost of subcontracted work and other external charges represents all costs incurred for the purpose of obtaining revenue (other than cost of sold equipment/sales products) and charged by third parties.

The other operating expenses represents all other expenses which are not attributable to costs of subcontracted work and other external charges, such as the change in provision for doubtful debts. -----

Intangible assets, including goodwill, are amortised and property, plant and equipment depreciated over their estimated useful lives as from the inception of their use. Land is not depreciated. Future depreciation and amortisation is adjusted if there is a change in estimated future useful life. Gains and losses on sales of land and buildings are presented as other income. The book value of machinery and equipment sold are recognised as a component of cost of sold equipment/ sales products.

_Short-term employee benefits_ Salaries, wages and social security contributions are recognised as expenses based on the terms of employment. _Pensions_ The Company operates a defined contribution plan for their employees. For its defined contribution plans, the company pays contributions to pension funds and insurance companies on a contractual basis. Except for paying contributions, Boels Topholding B.V. has no other obligations to pay further contributions by virtue of these pension plans. Contributions are recognised as expenses when incurred. Prepaid contributions are recognised as prepayments and accrued income to the extent that this will lead to a reduction in future payments or a cash refund.

_Interest paid and received_ Interest paid and received is recognised on a time-weighted basis. _Changes in financial instruments value below cost_ Changes in the value of the financial derivatives below cost are recognised directly through profit or loss.

Income tax is calculated on the profit or loss before tax in the income statement, taking into account any losses carried forward from previous financial years (where not included in deferred income tax assets), tax exempt items and plus non deductible expenses. Account is also taken of changes in deferred income tax assets and liabilities owing to changes in the applicable tax rates.

Subsection Title: 4** **Financial instruments and risk management 4.1 Price risk
Subsubsection Text: _Currency risk_ Boels Topholding B.V. is exposed to currency risk mainly from its cash flows generated in Sweden, Norway, the United Kingdom, Poland and the Czech Republic. Boels Topholding B.V. also incurs currency risk on the net investment in the operations in Sweden, Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and the United Kingdom. Management has determined, based on a risk assessment, that some of these currency risks need to be hedged. This policy is intended to protect the operational margin as well as the balance sheet position. Forward exchange contracts are used for this purpose. At December 31, 2021 forward exchange contracts are outstanding with a nominal value of € 118.5 million. The group does not apply hedge accounting. _Interest rate and cash flow risk_ The Company incurs interest rate risk on interest bearing non-current and current liabilities, including loans. It is the policy of the Company to have a fixed/floating interest rate profile on the interest bearing liabilities which is fitting with the nature of the Company’s assets. As most of the interest bearing liabilities have a floating interest rate, Boels Topholding B.V. has contracted interest rate swaps so that it receives floating interest and pays fixed interest. This policy is determined to obtain a desired risk profile in fixed and variable interest positions. At 31 December 2021 interest rate swaps have been concluded for a nominal amount of € 900m (31-12-2020: € 180m), with a duration of less than 5 years. The market value of these interest rate swaps amount to € 6,288k (31-12-2020: € 8,989k negative). ----- These interest rate swaps were entered into in February 2021 for a total amount of € 900m. These transactions are 1 year forward starting and have a term until February 2026. They have an average fixed rate of 0.174% and include a floor at 0%.

Boels Topholding B.V. does not have any significant concentrations of credit risk, this as a result of the spread customers, markets and region. Sales on account are only made to customers that meet the Company’s credit rating requirements. Goods and services are sold subject to payment terms, the majority ranging between 15 till 60 days. A different payment period may apply to major supplies, in which case additional securities are demanded, including guarantees. Credit risks are constantly monitored by reviewing credit limits and payment terms per customer. Financial receivables like cash in banks and derivative financial instruments are held with reputable banks with a solid credit rating.

On June 29, 2021 the company has successfully concluded a repricing of its existing 7 years syndicated debt facility agreement. After the repricing, this agreement consisted of the following facilities: - a € 1,450.0 million Term Loan B, maturing in 2027; - a € 179.3 million Revolving Credit Facility, maturing in 2026. The loan agreement contains certain restrictive financial covenants, typical to such agreements, primarily related to the leverage for the group as a whole. The group calculated various scenarios. Based on these scenarios management is comfortable with the compliance of the agreed covenants and with the liquidity for the group as a whole.

Other provisions include costs for insurance compensation, full repair, jubilee benefits and legal claims: - The provision for insurance is recognised to compensate damages to rented machinery and equipment of which the claim has been bought off by the customer by means of insurance. - The provision for full repair is recognised to compensate recurring maintenance at premises which have been sold and leased back. - The provision for jubilee benefits is formed for expected benefits payable to current employees. - The provision for legal relates to a claim of a third party for damages. -----

All loans are denominated in Euros. _Bank loans_ On June 29, 2021 the company has successfully repriced its seven years syndicated facility agreement. After the repricing, this financing arrangement consists of the following credit facilities: - A bullet term loan B with a notional amount of € 1,450 million, maturing in 2027. - A Revolving Credit Facility of € 179.3 million, maturing in 2026. The duration of the bank loans (nominal value term loan B) is as follows: No later than 1 year 0 Later than 1 year and no later than 5 years 0 Later than 5 years 1,450,000 At December 31, 2020, the outstanding amount on the TLA loan was € 244,556k. In 2021 the TLA has been repaid in full. In 2021 the average interest rate amounts to 3.83% (2020: 3.96%). The financing of Boels Group is subject to being in compliance with a leverage covenants typical for such agreements. The Company and certain of its main subsidiaries are jointly and severally liable for the syndicated facility agreement. On 31 December 2021 Boels has been in compliance with the bank covenants. The syndicated facility agreement is secured by: - A share pledge Boels Topholding B.V., Boels Holding B.V. and each material company part of the facility agreement. - Pledge agreement shareholder loans and intercompany loans. - Pledge of all material bank accounts. _Derivatives_ To cover interest risks at 31 December 2021 interest rate swaps have been concluded for an amount of € 900,000k, with a duration is less than 5 years. _Other loans_ The other loans consist of: - Loans with a nominal amount of € 3,510k and an average interest rate of 1.0%. Repayment takes place at 31-12-2023. - Old age reserve in amount of € 2,486k has been presented as liability, which has a duration of more than 5 years. The interest is equal to the U-yield. - Financial lease liabilities in the amount of € 7,772k: - € 3,481k as a result of a sale and financial lease back transaction in Belgium of 9 buildings during 2011. This liability will be settled by 216 monthly installments of € 60k and has an annual average interest rate of 9.6%. The total book value of these buildings is € 3,153k. - € 1,312k as a result of a sale and financial lease back transaction In Netherlands of 5 buildings on December 31, 2015. This liability will be settled by 60 quarterly installments of € 54k and has an annual average interest rate of 6.4%. The total book value of these buildings is € 923k. - € 2,979k as a result of a sale and financial lease back transaction in Belgium of 5 buildings in 2021, of which 1 property lease classified as financial lease back. This liability will be settled by 60 quarterly installments of € 64k and has an annual average interest rate of 2%. The total book value of this building is € 2,636k. ----- The financial lease liabilities at the end of the reporting period can be specified as follows: Lease (x €1,000) liabilities No later than 1 year 678 Later than 1 year and no later than 5 years 3,241 Later than 5 years 4,531

Subsection Title: 15** **Non-recognised assets and liabilities and contingent assets and liabilities
Subsubsection Text: _Contingent liabilities_ At year end, bank guarantees issued by Boels Topholding B.V. and its subsidiaries amounted to € 3,080k (31-12-2020: € 2,094k). At December 31, 2021 also company guarantees have been issued by Boels Topholding B.V. in amount to € 26,495k (31-12-2020: € 6,110k). _Commitments for capital expenditures_ Commitments for the purchase of equipment, cars/trucks and real estate in the sum of € 116,452k (31-12-2020: € 68,828k) have not been disclosed in the balance sheet. _Lease commitments_ The obligations from operational leases relates to the rental of our rental depots and vehicles. The obligations at the end of the reporting period can be specified as follows: _Non-recognised assets_ The group has a condition right to off-set € 41.6 million of tax losses, which have not been recognised.

_Eekels acquistion_ On January 21rd, 2022, an agreement was signed in which Boels-Gosink B.V. acquired all shares of the companies Eekels Pompen B.V. and Eekels Materieelbeheer B.V. (further Eekels Pompen). This acquisition fits in Boels’ strategy of growing in specialist niche rental activities. Eekels Pompen has offered professional pump hire solutions and temporary pump systems in the Netherlands and Belgium for more than 100 years. With a fleet of over 1,000 pumps and pipes and hoses, Eekels Pompen supports a.o. the public sector, industry, marine and offshore and civil engineering throughout the Netherlands and Belgium. In 2021 Eekels Pompen generated a revenue of € 12.3 million and an EBITDA of € 3.9 million with a headcount of approx. 50 people. Very recently Boels started with the integration of Eekels Pompen within the Boels organisation. Also the group is planning to take the first steps in relation to the purchase price allocation of the aforementioned acquisition. As such, it is currently practical not possible to disclose the details about the expected outcome of the purchase price allocation. In respect to this matter Boels Topholding B.V. uses the exemption as stipulated in the Dutch Accounting Standard 216.410. _Geopolitical situation Russia/Ukraine_ Reference is made to the disclosure in paragraph 2.2. -----

Subsection Title: REPORT ON THE AUDIT OF THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2021 INCLUDED IN THE ANNUAL REPORT Our opinion
Subsubsection Text: We have audited the accompanying financial statements 2021 of Boels Topholding B.V., based in Sittard. In our opinion the accompanying financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of Boels Topholding B.V. as at 31 December 2021, and of its result for 2021 in accordance with Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The financial statements comprise: 1. The consolidated and company balance sheet as at 31 December 2021. 2. The consolidated and company income statement for 2021. 3. The notes comprising a summary of the accounting policies and other explanatory information.

We conducted our audit in accordance with Dutch law, including the Dutch Standards on Auditing. Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the “Our responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements” section of our report. We are independent of Boels Topholding B.V. in accordance with the Wet toezicht accountantsorganisaties (Wta, Audit firms supervision act), the Verordening inzake de onafhankelijkheid van accountants bij assurance-opdrachten (ViO, Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants, a regulation with respect to independence) and other relevant independence regulations in the Netherlands. Furthermore, we have complied with the Verordening gedrags- en beroepsregels accountants (VGBA, Dutch Code of Ethics). We believe the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion.

Subsection Title: Information in support of our opinion
Subsubsection Text: We designed our audit procedures in the context of our audit of the financial statements as a whole and in forming our opinion thereon. The following information in support of our opinion was addressed in this context, and we do not provide a separate opinion or conclusion on these matters.

We identified and assessed the risks of material misstatements of the financial statements due to fraud. During our audit we obtained an understanding of the entity and its environment and the components of the system of internal control, including the risk assessment process and management’s process for responding to the risks of fraud and monitoring the system of internal control and how the Board of Directors exercises oversight, as well as the outcomes. We reported to the Board of Directors the company has not formalized its fraud risk assessment and fraud management strategy. We evaluated the design and relevant aspects of the system of internal control, including internal fraud & integrity protocols and incident registration. We evaluated the design and the implementation and, where considered appropriate, tested the operating effectiveness, of internal controls designed to mitigate fraud risks. As part of our process of identifying fraud risks, we evaluated fraud risk factors with respect to financial reporting fraud, misappropriation of assets and bribery and corruption in close co-operation with our forensic specialists. We evaluated whether these factors indicate that a risk of material misstatement due to fraud is present. We identified the following fraud risks and performed the following specific procedures: _•_ _Risk of material misstatement due to fraud related to management override of controls:_ We presume a risk of material misstatement due to fraud as management is in a unique position to perpetrate fraud because of management’s assumed ability to manipulate accounting records by overriding controls and include intentional bias in estimates affecting the financial statements. We have pinpointed the possible incentives of management on meeting the loan covenants and the long term and yearly bonus plan for the strategic board members. In this respect EBITDA serves as the key performance indicator for the entity and management. _•_ _Risk of material misstatement due to fraud related to revenue recognition:_ We presume a risk of material misstatement due to fraud related to revenue recognition. This risk relates to the occurrence and correct period cut-off of revenues for nonstandard rental revenue transactions. To respond to these fraud risks we performed the following procedures: - We considered available information and made enquiries of relevant executives from the strategic board, directors, finance employees, risk manager and the general counsel. - We tested the appropriateness and business rationale of journal entries recorded in the general ledger and other adjustments made in the preparation of the financial ----- - We evaluated whether the selection and application of accounting policies by the group, particularly those related to subjective measurements and complex transactions, may be indicative of fraudulent financial reporting. - We evaluated all internally registered fraud instances in financial year 2021 and evaluated of management’s follow up is appropriate. - For significant transactions such as refinancing and restructuring we evaluated whether the business rationale of the transactions suggests that they may have been entered into to engage in fraudulent financial reporting or to conceal misappropriation of assets. - We evaluated whether the judgments and decisions made by management in making the accounting estimates included in the financial statements indicate a possible bias that may reflect a risk of material misstatement due to fraud. Management insights, estimates and assumptions that have a major impact on the financial statements are disclosed in note 1.7 of the financial statements. We also performed a retrospective review of management judgments and assumptions related to material accounting estimates reflected in prior year financial statement, such as the depreciation rates, valuation and impairment triggers of intangible and tangible assets. - We have performed extensive sampling testing on revenue postings not orginating from the rental system and performed extensive procedures to determine appropriate period cut-off of the revenue in the financial statements. - We have included fraud as a specific focus area in the group instructions to the component audit teams and have conducted site visits on a number of business locations to Sweden and Finland. - We incorporated elements of unpredictability in our audit. We also considered the outcome of our other audit procedures and evaluated whether any findings were indicative of fraud or noncompliance. Our audit procedures for the year as specified in this paragraph did not lead to indications for fraud potentially resulting in material misstatements.

Subsection Title: Audit approach compliance with laws and regulations
Subsubsection Text: We differentiate our audit approach between two categories - Rules and regulations that directly impact the financial reporting - Rules and regulations that indirectly may have material impact on the financial statements In the first category, we considered adherence to (corporate)tax law and financial reporting regulations including the requirements under Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. These i In the second category, we considered other laws and regulations where the consequences of non-compliance could have a material effect on amounts and/or disclosures in the financial statements, for instance, through imposed fines or litigation. This category includes regulations related to the act on the Prevention of Money Laundering and Financing of Terrorism (‘WWFT’). Our procedures are more limited with respect to laws and regulations that do not have a direct effect on the determination of the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements. Compliance with these laws and regulations may however be fundamental to the operating aspects of the business, to Boels Topholding B.V.’s ability to continue its business, or to avoid material penalties and therefore non-compliance with such laws and regulations may have a material effect on the financial statements. Our responsibility for these matters that indirectly impact the financial statement is limited to: (i) inquiry of the Board of Directors, the risk manager, legal counsel and others within the Company as to whether the Company is in compliance with such laws and regulations, and (ii) inspecting correspondence, if any, with the relevant licensing or regulatory authorities to help identify non-compliance with those laws and regulations that may have a material effect on the financial statements. (iii) request and obtain written representations that all known instances of (suspected) fraud or non-compliance with laws and regulations have been disclosed to us. We remained alert to indications of non-compliance throughout the audit.

Our responsibilities, as well as the responsibilities of management, are outlined under the prevailing standards in the “Description of responsibilities regarding the financial statements” section below. Management has assessed the going concern assumption, as part of the preparation of the consolidated financial statements. Management believes that no events or conditions, including the COVID-19 pandemic, give rise to doubt about the ability of the group to continue in operation of at least twelve months after the date of the financial statements. We have obtained management’s assessment of the entity’s ability to continue as a going concern, and have assessed the going concern assumption applied. As part of our procedures, we evaluated whether sufficient appropriate audit evidence has been obtained regarding, and have concluded on, the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting in the preparation of the consolidated financial statements. Based on these procedures, we did not identify any reportable findings related to the entity’s ability to continue as a going concern. -----

Subsection Title: Emphasis on the impact of the Russia/Ukraine-Crisis
Subsubsection Text: The Russia/Ukraine-Crisis also impacts Boels Topholding B.V. Management disclosed the estimated impact on financial performance and health of Boels Topholding B.V. and her plans to deal with these events or circumstances in paragraph 2.2, page 22 of the financial statements. Our opinion is not modified in respect of this matter.
